question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
What should you believe about your own coin once you are told that, out of a countably infinite collection of fair and independent tosses, only finitely many have come up heads?  The problem looks disarmingly simple—surely, one is tempted to reply, the coin in your hand is still fair, so nothing you learn about the other coins should make any difference.  On closer inspection, however, the case turns out to sit at the intersection of two difficult topics in probability theory and epistemology:

1.  Updating on an event of probability 0.  
2.  The tension between “local” independence (each coin is individually fair) and “global” structural information about an infinite totality.

Once those complications are made explicit, it becomes apparent that no single answer is forced on us by ordinary Bayesian principles.  Two answers—in fact, two broad families of answers—are defensible.  One family keeps the credence at ½; the other drives it to 0.  The right moral, I shall argue, is not that one of these answers is simply wrong, but that the problem exposes an incompleteness in orthodox Bayesian conditionalisation whenever we are asked to condition on an event to which the prior gives probability 0.  In such cases we need some further principle—mathematical or epistemic—to supplement the bare Bayesian machinery.

I.  Why ordinary conditionalisation breaks down
-----------------------------------------------

Bayes’ rule tells us that  

	P(H | E) = P(H ∧ E) / P(E),

but only when P(E) > 0.  In our set-up, the probability that *finitely* many heads occur in an *infinite* sequence of fair tosses is 0.  Indeed, for any fixed natural number n, the probability that there are at most n heads is already 0, and “finitely many” is the union of those countably many probability-0 events.  The very evidence we learn therefore has prior probability 0—exactly the situation in which Bayes’ rule is silent.

Kolmogorov’s theory can be extended: for each σ-algebra one can build *regular conditional probabilities* that assign a conditional distribution even at probability-0 events.  But those extensions are *non-unique.*  One may impose additional constraints—continuity, symmetry, shift-invariance, causal constraints, pragmatic desiderata—and each such constraint can pick out a different regular conditional measure.  What our case reveals is that ordinary Bayesianism plus background mathematical facts underdetermines what the posterior *ought* to be.  Two natural additional principles point in opposite directions.

II.  The ½ answer: respect local independence
---------------------------------------------

A.  The intuitive argument  

“Only finitely many heads” is a global fact about the entire sequence.  But my coin is supposed to be locally independent of every *tail event* that concerns only the other coins.  Because which side my single coin shows makes essentially no difference to whether only finitely many heads are obtained—there are already countably many other coins whose behaviour can override that one bit of information—it is tempting to say that my coin remains epistemically screened off by the independence built into the original set-up.  Hence the natural conclusion: my credence stays at ½.

B.  Formal reconstruction  

One way to make this precise is via *finite-information* updates.  Suppose instead of learning the exact event “only finitely many heads,” you learned the family of ever stronger finite approximations:

E₁:  “At most 1 head turned up among coins 2,3,4, …”  
E₂:  “At most 2 heads turned up among coins 2,3,4, …”  
⋯

For each finite Eₙ the probability is positive, and ordinary Bayes works.  Because my coin’s outcome is independent of the outcomes of coins 2,3,4,…, one finds  

	P(X₁ = H | Eₙ) = ½   for every n.

If one then takes the *martingale limit* (letting n → ∞ to obtain the limiting σ-algebra that corresponds to the tail event “finitely many heads”), the conditional probability remains ½.  On this construction the information that makes E true is carried wholly by the *other* coins, and by design it never correlates with my own toss.

C.  Philosophical considerations  

1.  The Lewis–Elga *Principal Principle* connects objective chance with rational credence: if you are certain that the chance of a proposition is p and you have no inadmissible information, your credence should be p.  Here you *do* acquire information, but arguably it is not *inadmissible* with respect to your own coin—it does not convey any causal or statistical news about that particular toss.  
2.  More generally, the ½ answer respects a familiar injunction: do not let “barely relevant” global facts overwrite *local* physical chanciness.  Even after you learn a wildly improbable cosmic coincidence, that coincidence (absent further detail) usually gives you no reason at all to doubt the fairness of an isolated coin flip you yourself performed.

III.  The 0 answer: typicality in an infinite population
--------------------------------------------------------

A very different line of thought begins with an obvious numerical asymmetry: in a countably infinite crowd with only finitely many heads, almost *everyone* is a tail-flipper.  Heads, by stipulation, are *rare exceptions.*  Unless you have privileged information about your own index in that crowd—even an infinity of information!—you should think it overwhelmingly likely that you belong to the majority class, viz. the tails.

A.  The random-index argument  

Imagine that *who you are* among the countable crowd is determined by a process independent of the coin flipping—say, a lottery that assigns persons to natural numbers.  Conditional on “ﬁnitely many heads,” the probability that a randomly chosen index happens to be one of the exceptional finitely many heads is zero.  By a standard principle of indifference (one’s own position is not special), your credence should therefore collapse to 0.

B.  Regular conditional probabilities that implement the 0 answer  

One can formalise the “random index” idea by building a *shift-invariant* regular conditional probability.  The shift operator σ shifts every sequence one place to the left.  The event “only finitely many heads” is *shift invariant* (σE = E).  By a theorem of Blackwell and Dubins, the only shift-invariant conditional on E is the one that assigns probability 0 to any cylinder in which a designated coordinate is heads.  Intuitively: once E is granted, no particular index can “soak up” a positive fraction of the remaining finite quota of heads.

C.  Philosophical considerations  

1.  The *typicality* principle.  In an infinite population, knowing that only finitely many members have property P makes it (almost) certain you lack P, unless you possess additional index-locating or causal information that associates *you* with those exceptions.  
2.  Connections to self-locating belief.  The update from ½ to 0 mirrors familiar reasoning in the Sleeping Beauty literature: if Beauty were told on Sunday that only finitely many awakenings in an unending process involve a red room, it seems right for her to set her credence very near 0 that *this* awakening is in the red room.  
3.  A pragmatic angle.  Suppose an angel offers you a bet that pays \$1 if your coin is heads and costs \$0.60 to enter.  Before learning E you would decline (expected value \$0.50).  After learning E, the bet has effectively negative expected value if you adopt the 0 posterior.  Only the 0 answer conforms to the manifest structure of gains and losses in an infinite population in which winners are provably rare.

IV.  Why the two procedures diverge
------------------------------------

If ordinary conditionalisation does not fix P(X₁ = H | E), the natural next question is whether any plausible higher-order principle forces one of the two answers.  Unfortunately, no principle generally accepted among Bayesians does the job.  Instead, the two answers reflect two *different* ways of treating information that is both global and measure-zero:

•  Local independence reasoning keeps one coordinate’s chance insulated from facts about the rest, implementing what probabilists call *coordinate-wise* or *product-σ-algebra* conditioning.  
•  Typicality reasoning treats an agent’s own coordinate as *epistemically exchangeable* with all the rest, demanding that conditioning be *shift invariant.*

These treatments pick out different regular conditional probabilities, both mathematically legitimate.  There is no purely probabilistic fact of the matter about which is “the” conditional distribution at E.  Additional structural or epistemic assumptions settle the issue, and those assumptions are precisely what philosophers dispute.

V.  Can rationality itself decide?
----------------------------------

Three main proposals have been floated in the literature.

1.  **Causal admissibility.**  Joyce and others urge that only *causally relevant* evidence should alter credence in a chance event.  Because my coin is causally independent of the infinitely many others, the ½ answer follows.  
   •  Objection: the independence is *statistical*, not causal, and statistical independence can break down under conditioning—even when causal independence holds.

2.  **Self-locating neutrality.**  Elga and Bostrom argue that when agents lack special indexical information, they should reason as “random samples” from their reference class.  That principle forces the 0 answer.  
   •  Objection: in many ordinary circumstances (finite crowds), we *do not* adjust our belief to 0 upon learning there are only finitely many exceptional individuals.  So why should we do so merely because the crowd is infinite?

3.  **Regularity/continuity.**  Some authors (e.g., van Fraassen) recommend taking limits through positive-probability events that approximate the evidence.  Different choices of approximating sequence lead to different limits; without a unique topology of approximation the rule is silent.

In short, nothing like a universal Bayesian norm settles the dispute.  Rationality underdetermines the right posterior; the choice is to be made by deeper principles about what counts as genuinely *inadmissible* information, or about how self-locating beliefs should interact with objective chance.

VI.  A qualified verdict
------------------------

Where does that leave us?  Two lessons emerge.

Lesson 1: absent further structure, your posterior is *not uniquely determined.*  Saying “I obey the laws of probability” is not enough; one must choose a scheme for extending conditionalisation to probability-0 evidence.

Lesson 2: once extra structure is supplied, each scheme is coherent.  
•  If you take yourself as having index-locating knowledge that is *independent* of which coins are heads, you remain at ½.  
•  If you instead regard your own index as “random” among the crowd, you should move to 0.

Which stance is more philosophically appealing depends on background commitments.  I myself favour the 0 answer, because I accept a form of the *Self-Sampling Assumption*: absent index-locating evidence, treat yourself as a random sample from the reference class relevant to the evidence just acquired.  But I cannot claim that this is forced upon every rational agent; those who privilege local independence over self-locating typicality can, with equal mathematical legitimacy, retain the ½ credence.

VII.  Summing up
----------------

1.  Standard Bayesian conditionalisation does not apply, because the evidence has prior probability 0.  
2.  Two quite natural extensions of Bayesianism suggest two different posteriors:  
   a.  The *local-independence* extension leaves the credence at ½.  
   b.  The *shift-invariant/typicality* extension drives the credence to 0.  
3.  Nothing in classical probability theory or mainstream Bayesian epistemology uniquely mandates one extension over the other.  
4.  Philosophical principles about causality, admissibility, and self-locating belief *do* bear on the choice, but those principles are themselves contested.  

Therefore the only honest answer a philosopher can give is conditional:

•  If you treat yourself as a *randomly located* member of the infinite crowd, your credence should fall to 0.  
•  If you insist that your epistemic situation is exhausted by the intrinsic properties of your own coin plus independent background physics, you may rationally keep your credence at ½.

Either way, the case is a striking reminder that probability theory, by itself, does not always dictate how an ideally rational agent should update on measure-zero information.  To finish the job, we must bring in further philosophical commitments—about causation, about indexicality, and about what it means to be a “typical” observer in an infinite universe.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Heads in the Limit:
Updating on an Astonishing, Measure-Zero Event

1.  The scenario and the puzzle  

Infinitely many agents—call them 𝑝₀, 𝑝₁, 𝑝₂, …—simultaneously toss fair, mutually independent coins.  Afterwards they are told the following:

 (F)  Only finitely many of the coins landed heads.

What credence should a particular agent—say 𝑝₀—now attach to the proposition  

 (H₀)  𝑝₀’s own coin landed heads ?

Unconditionally the answer is trivially ½; that is what “fair coin” means.  But the information (F) is behaviourally extraordinary: under the ordinary probability measure the probability of finitely many heads in an ω-sequence of i.i.d. Bernoulli(½) trials is zero.  We must therefore decide what Bayesian conditionalisation—or more broadly, rational belief revision—requires when we learn an event of measure 0.

There are two temptations.

•  Independence Temptation:  (F) does not mention any particular coin; heads or tails for 𝑝₀ is still causally and stochastically independent of what the other agents happen to have flipped.  So the credence in (H₀) ought to remain ½.

•  Scarcity Temptation:  If only finitely many heads occurred among countably many trials, heads have become a vanishingly rare property.  Given sheer cardinal arithmetic, the fraction of agents with heads is 0, so the chance that *I* am one of the lucky few should be 0—so my credence in (H₀) should drop to 0.

Both temptations look principled; whichever answer we choose must emerge from a careful treatment of conditional probability for measure-zero events, together with symmetry considerations.  The rest of this essay builds the case that the scarcity instinct is correct: rational credence in (H₀) should be driven all the way to 0.  That conclusion is surprising, and it forces us to clarify what “independence” and “fairness” really secure for us once we are told that something probabilistically impossible has occurred.

2.  The probabilistic background  

Let (Ω, ℱ, P) be the usual probability space for an ω-sequence (X₀, X₁, …) of independent Bernoulli(½) variables, where Xᵢ = 1 represents heads.  Write  

 S = ∑_{i=0}^{∞} Xᵢ,

and let  

 F = {ω ∈ Ω : S(ω) is finite}.

The strong law of large numbers or the second Borel-Cantelli lemma implies P(F) = 0.  Yet our evidence says F has indeed obtained.

Ordinary Bayesian conditionalisation uses the ratio formula

 P(A | B) = P(A∧B) / P(B),

which is undefined when P(B) = 0.  A standard remedy is a *regular conditional probability* (rcp): a measurable function Q such that for all measurable B, Q(·,B) is a version of P(B | ·).  On nice spaces rcp’s always exist, but they are unique only up to P-null sets; accordingly, conditioning on a null event is never uniquely determined by the Kolmogorov axioms alone.  Additional structure—symmetry, limiting procedures, or pragmatic stipulations—must do the remaining work.

3.  A symmetry-based regular conditional probability  

The infinite coin-tossing experiment is *exchangeable*: finite permutations of the indices leave the joint distribution invariant.  Any admissible conditional probability should respect that same symmetry unless the conditioning event itself breaks it.  Crucially, F does not pick out any participant; it simply says that the set of heads-makers is finite.  Hence

 (Exchangeability) For any i, j ∈ ℕ, P(Xᵢ = 1 | F) = P(Xⱼ = 1 | F).

Call this common value p.  We now compute the expected number of heads conditional on F:

 E(S | F) = E(∑_{i} Xᵢ | F)  
     = ∑_{i=0}^{∞} P(Xᵢ = 1 | F)   [Countable additivity + linearity of expectation]  
     = ∑_{i=0}^{∞} p.

Now S is finite on F, so E(S | F) must itself be finite.  But the right-hand side diverges whenever p > 0, and equals 0 when p = 0.  Therefore p = 0 is forced by ordinary measure-theoretic principles (plus the mild assumption that E(S | F) is finite—hardly controversial if S itself is finite).  Exchangeability plus countable additivity thus *pin down* a unique rcp that sends P(X₀ = 1 | F) to 0.

Independence does *not* survive conditioning.  The intuitive reason is simple: the fact that S is finite imposes a severe global constraint, correlating each toss with every other one.  If my coin came up heads, there is one fewer “head slot” available for the rest of the infinite population; conversely, if my coin is tails, there is still room for finitely many heads elsewhere.  The coins remain *causally* independent—they do not influence one another—but they are no longer stochastically independent once the conditioning information is incorporated.  And stochastic correlation, not causal connection, is what matters to Bayesian updating.

4.  A limiting-sequence justification  

Sceptics sometimes distrust rcp’s because they rely on high-powered measure theory.  There is a more concrete route using ordinary conditionalisation on a nested sequence of high-probability events whose limit is F.

Let  

 F_{m,n} = {exactly m heads among the first n coins, and tails thereafter}.

For fixed m the events ∪_{n} F_{m,n} approach the proposition “at most m heads total.”  Taking the further union over m gives F.  Define

 p_{m,n} = P(X₀ = 1 | F_{m,n}).

A tedious but straightforward combinatorial calculation shows

 p_{m,n} = m / (n+1).

(Sketch: Condition on the positions of the m heads among the first n coins; given symmetry each of the n+1 positions—n within the block, plus the “extra” position 0—are equally likely to be occupied by the particular participant you are.)  Now fix any m.  As n → ∞, p_{m,n} → 0.  Next let m → ∞; the uniform bound p_{m,n} ≤ m/(n+1) ensures the double limit also goes to 0.  Thus the limiting rule of “first conditionalise on ‘not too many heads in the finite block,’ then let the block grow without bound” confirms the rcp value 0.

5.  The independence temptation revisited  

Why did the intuitive independence argument seem so compelling?  It trades on an illicit substitution:

 “If H₀ does not *cause* (F), then learning (F) offers no *evidence* about H₀.”

Causal independence is not the same as evidential independence.  A classic finite analogue is “All ten fair coins came up tails” entails “My coin came up tails” with certainty 1, though no causal link exists.  What makes the infinite case puzzling is merely that the evidential force becomes *infinitesimal* in ordinary circumstances.  But once we condition on the measure-zero wonder that only finitely many heads appeared, the joint distribution collapses into a highly atypical subspace in which *someone* is heads only finitely many times.  Causal structure survives; evidential structure does not.

6.  Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Countable additivity is optional in subjective probability; finitely additive probabilities allow P(X₀ = 1 | F) = ½ while keeping E(S | F) finite.

Reply: True in principle, but accepting finite additivity violates ordinary Dutch-book coherence for bets that can be staged in countably many rounds.  Most foundational work in Bayesian epistemology takes countable additivity as non-negotiable.  If one is willing to repudiate it, almost any result can be massaged; that is hardly a stable platform for rational credence.

Objection 2: The argument treats the subject as a *named* individual (𝑝₀).  What if instead I model my evidence indexically as “I am a randomly selected member of the room”?  There can be no uniform probability distribution over ℕ, so the scarcity argument collapses.

Reply: Indexical uncertainty must still be regimented somehow—for instance via weighting by 2^{-i} or via epistemic imprecisions.  Every defensible regimentation that preserves exchangeability will again entail that the probability of being one of the finitely many heads-makers is 0.  The reason is the same cardinality calculation: whichever σ-finite measure you put on the indices, the set of finitely many lucky indices has measure 0, whence the conditional probability of occupying one of them vanishes.

Objection 3: Learning an “impossible” event in practice means learning something slightly weaker with small but non-zero probability.  In real life we would remain somewhat uncertain whether the testimony is accurate; that uncertainty would screen off the update to 0.

Reply: That is perfectly correct as a practical matter.  The puzzle, however, asks for the rational credence *assuming the information is certain.*  Treating it *as if* it had probability 1 is the thought-experiment’s stipulation, and the theoretical lesson emerges only under that heroic idealisation.  Once we embed testimony errors, our credence in F drops from 1 to (say) 0.99, and ordinary conditionalisation on a non-zero event yields a posterior in (H₀) that will be *very* small but not 0—exactly what the limiting argument foretells.

7.  Philosophical morals  

Moral 1: Zero-probability learning forces us to choose an rcp, and symmetry plus countable additivity may determine one uniquely.  Where they do, the rcp solution deserves the title of “rational posterior.”

Moral 2: Independence is not preserved under conditionalisation on global constraints.  This is a special case of the general rule that Bayesian updating destroys the factorisation of a joint distribution whenever the conditioned event is not cylinder-measurable.  Hence “my coin is fair” does not license invariant ½ credence after hearing exotic facts about the whole ensemble.

Moral 3: Infinite settings sharpen our intuitions about indexicality.  The standard misgiving—“but I am a *particular* person, not a randomly chosen one”—is answered by exchangeability.  If the world gives no evidence to discriminate agents, rationality demands treating them symmetrically; and symmetry arguments with countable infinities produce highly non-intuitive verdicts.

Moral 4: The puzzle exhibits a cousin of *anthropic reasoning*.  Learning that only finitely many heads exist makes being a heads-person a highly “special” status.  Rationally I should think I am probably not that special.  The doomsday argument, the sleeping beauty problem, and other self-locating puzzles all trade on similar scarcity reasoning.

8.  Concluding verdict  

Given the stipulation that we are certain of (F), the only coherent, symmetry-respecting, countably additive posterior drives the probability of (H₀) to 0.  The independence intuition—though psychologically compelling—ignores the fact that evidential dependence can arise without causal influence whenever we restrict attention to a measure-zero slice of possibility space.  Philosophical reflection therefore sides with scarcity:

 Credence(H₀ | F) = 0.

In the strange world where miracles of probability occur, learning that miracle forces you to abandon the usual 50-50 confidence in your own fair coin.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Only finitely many heads: what are the odds that mine is one of them?
A careful look at updating on probability-zero information


1.  Framing the puzzle  
You and a countably infinite cast of companions each toss a fair coin.  Long after the coins come to rest you are told, with absolute authority, that “only finitely many coins landed heads.”  That piece of information looks highly informative: it rules out, for example, every outcome in which heads and tails occur with roughly equal frequency, even though such outcomes were overwhelmingly likely a moment ago.  Should you therefore revise your personal probability that your own coin shows heads?  Two answers vie for prima facie plausibility.

A. No change.  The coin is intrinsically fair; nothing you learned bears on the physical mechanism that produced its result.  Your credence should remain ½.

B. Radical change.  The new information picks out an astronomically rare kind of global outcome—so rare, in fact, that the fair-coin product measure assigns it probability 0.  Within that outcome-class, it is overwhelmingly more likely that any given particular coin came up tails.  Your credence should plummet to 0.

Most people feel an initial pull toward (A).  “The coin does not remember what everybody else’s coins did.”  Yet many probabilists find (B) compelling once the structure of the event “only finitely many heads” is laid bare.  My aim is to show in detail why (B) is ultimately the better supported answer, while also explaining why the case poses a genuine philosophical difficulty for Bayesian conditionalisation and for ordinary epistemic intuition.

I proceed in five steps.  (1)  I make precise the probabilistic set-up and show why the event we learn has unconditional measure 0.  (2)  I explain why orthodox Bayesian conditionalisation is silent when the evidence has probability 0, and how one can nevertheless define a “regular” conditional probability in this particular case.  (3)  I derive from symmetry considerations that, relative to that regular conditional probability, the chance that my coin is heads is 0.  (4)  I defend the philosophical propriety of using that conditional distribution to update, responding to two main objections.  (5)  I revisit the allure of the ½ answer, diagnosing its psychological sources and clarifying what it shows—and what it does not—about rational credence.


2.  Making the mathematics explicit  
Let Ω = {H,T}^ℵ₀ be the set of all infinite sequences (x₀,x₁,x₂,…) where each x_i ∈ {H,T}.  The natural σ-algebra is the product σ-algebra and the natural probability measure μ is the product of countably many fair Bernoulli(½) measures.  By Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law, any tail event—one whose truth value is unchanged by altering finitely many coordinates—gets μ-probability 0 or 1.  The event

   F = “Only finitely many heads occur” = { ω ∈ Ω : the set {i : ω_i=H} is finite }

is a tail event.  In fact, by the strong law of large numbers or by the Borel-Cantelli lemmas, μ(F)=0: almost surely one gets infinitely many heads and infinitely many tails.

That means we are being asked to condition not on an unlikely event, but on an impossible one—as judged by our original probability measure.  It is this feature that makes the puzzle philosophically interesting.  If μ(F) had been merely tiny, the ordinary ratio definition of conditional probability would apply and no one would doubt the correctness of answer (B): one can show directly that μ(“my coin is H” ∧ F)/μ(F) tends to 0 as μ(F)→0.  The crux is whether learning a measure-zero fact can rationally lead to a well-defined belief change at all, and if so, what the change should be.


3.  Conditional probability on μ-null events  
Standard Bayesianism says:

  P_new( · ) = P_old( · | E ) = P_old( · ∧ E )/P_old(E)

so long as P_old(E)>0.  If P_old(E)=0 the right-hand side is undefined.  One response—call it “dogmatic Bayesianism”—is simply: “You cannot receive E as evidence if you initially gave it probability 0; your prior was wrong, or you are irrational to believe the report.”  But this answer will not satisfy everyone.  First, the testimony might be compelling; second, physics or mathematics often informs us of measure-zero facts (e.g., “this dart landed at a rational point on the board”) and we want a theory of rational response.

Measure theory offers a tool.  A regular conditional probability for a sub-σ-algebra 𝔾 is a family {μ_G : G∈𝔾} of probability measures such that for every G∈𝔾 and every event A, the function ω↦μ_G(A) is 𝔾-measurable and integrates to μ(A∧G)/μ(G) on G, whenever μ(G)>0.  Where μ(G)=0 the family is allowed to assign an arbitrary probability measure supported on G.  Uniqueness is guaranteed only μ-almost surely; on null sets there is room for choice.  The upshot: mathematics does not dictate a unique way of conditioning on F.  We must supply further principle.

Fortunately the present case carries a natural symmetry: the action of any finite or countable permutation of the coin indices preserves both μ and F.  De Finetti famously proved that μ is exchangeable: for any finite k, the joint distribution of (X₀,…,X_{k-1}) is invariant under permutation.  The event F is also exchangeable.  The most neutral way to respect that symmetry, I shall argue, is to insist that the conditional measure μ_F inherit exchangeability.  Once we add that stipulation, the conditional distribution turns out to be unique, and it forces credence 0 in “my coin is heads.”


4.  Deriving the 0 answer from symmetry  
Imagine first that you had been told something slightly stronger:

   F_n: “Exactly n coins landed heads,”  for some fixed finite n.

Even F_n has μ-measure 0, but its structure is simpler to visualise.  Within F_n, exchangeability implies that every size-n subset of the index set ℕ is equally likely to be the head-set.  Because ℕ is countably infinite, the probability that any particular index—say i=0—belongs to a uniformly randomly chosen size-n subset is n/|ℕ|.  But |ℕ| is infinite, and natural cardinal arithmetic tells us n/∞=0.  Therefore under any exchangeable probability measure supported by F_n, we must have

   P(X₀ = H | F_n) = 0                 (1)

The same reasoning works if we are told only that “at most n coins landed heads.”  Indeed, the stronger the upper bound, the stronger the case that my specific coin is almost certainly tails.

Now note that F—the event of finitely many heads—is the disjoint union ⋃_{n∈ℕ} F_n.  Any exchangeable probability measure on F must be a countable convex combination of the exchangeable measures on the F_n.  (Intuitively, first pick how many heads there are; then decide which coins receive them.)  Because each constituent assigns 0 probability to X₀=H, the mixture also assigns 0:

   P(X₀ = H | F) = Σ_n P(F_n | F)·P(X₀ = H | F_n) = 0.       (2)

Hence if we accept the exchangeability requirement we must accept credence 0.

There is a quicker way to see the same point.  If I am told that only finitely many coins show heads, I can reason as follows:

  • There are finitely many heads.  
  • There are countably many coins.  
  • By simple counting, the proportion of coins that are heads is 0.  
  • Absent any individuating information, symmetry dictates that my coin is no likelier than any other to be one of the heads.  
  • Therefore my probability is 0.

Notice that this argument does not deny the metaphysical possibility that my coin is heads.  Zero probability in an infinite setting does not mean impossibility; it only reflects a measure-theoretic judgment of “negligibility.”  But Bayesian probability is precisely a calculus of negligibility: if an outcome sits in a μ-null set, we treat it as carrying zero weight in rational expectation.


5.  Objections and replies  
Objection 1:  “You cannot legitimately learn a probability-zero event.  Conditioning on it violates Bayesian norms.”

Reply.  There is no a priori ban on revising one’s beliefs when confronted with surprising certainty.  What Bayesianism forbids is applying the simple ratio formula when the denominator is zero.  It does not forbid adopting a new probability measure whose support lies inside what used to be a null set.  The move from μ to μ_F is a case of “radical Bayesian updating” or “hypothesis elimination”: we discard every outcome incompatible with the testimony and renormalise the remainder in a symmetry-preserving way.  That is entirely in the spirit of Carnapian inductive logic and de Finetti’s “coherent” betting framework.  What the dogmatic objection really highlights is that ordinary Bayesian conditionalisation is incomplete: it supplies no update rule for zero-probability evidence, so one must appeal to extra-Bayesian principles such as maximum entropy, symmetry, or jeffrey-type relaxation.  In the present case, permutation symmetry supplies exactly what is needed.

Objection 2: “But surely my coin’s landing heads is causally independent of the behaviour of all the others.  Learning about them should not affect my credence about this coin.”

Reply.  Causal independence is not the same as probabilistic independence once we restrict to a sub-σ-algebra of possible worlds.  To see the point, imagine two independent fair coins C₁ and C₂.  Unconditionally they are independent.  But if I learn the total number of heads is 1, they become perfectly anti-correlated.  Knowledge that C₁=H instantly tells me C₂=T.  No causal interaction is invoked; the dependence is purely informational, induced by the conditioning event.  The same phenomenon, magnified to countable infinity, lies behind our puzzle.  Although each flip is physically independent, the testimony “only finitely many heads” couples their outcomes in the web of epistemic possibility.  Once I accept that information, the probability space in which I reason is one in which the overwhelming majority of coins are tails, and thus my own most likely shows tails.

Objection 3: “Cardinal arithmetic n/∞=0 is suspicious.  Why should dividing a finite number by countable infinity yield 0 rather than an infinitesimal ε>0?”

Reply.  Standard Kolmogorov probability assigns real-valued measures, not hyperreal infinitesimals.  Within that framework, any set of the same cardinality as ℕ gets measure either 0 or some strictly positive real number.  Exchangeability forces us to spread total probability 1 uniformly (in a finitely additive sense) over ℵ₀ many possibilities; that is feasible only by assigning each possibility 0.  One may of course experiment with non-standard probability theories featuring infinitesimals, but doing so moves the goal-posts.  The puzzle was posed against the background of ordinary real-valued probability; the 0 answer is the one delivered by that background.


6.  Why the ½ answer is so tempting  
Setting my credence to 0 does not feel natural.  Intuitively, 0 expresses certainty; yet I certainly do not feel certain my coin is tails.  Where does the intuition go wrong?

First, 0 does not represent metaphysical or even epistemic certainty in the presence of an infinite outcome-space.  One can coherently buy a ticket that pays \$1 if my coin is heads for any positive price; the probability calculus merely says the fair price is 0.  The distinction between impossibility and measure-zero possibility is easy to overlook.

Second, humans instinctively think in terms of frequencies in large finite samples.  If you picture one trillion flips and only finitely many heads, you may imagine 10 or 100 or 1,000 heads, and then your chance of being a head is 10⁻¹² or 10⁻¹⁰ or 10⁻⁹—numbers that feel “practically zero” yet not quite zero, so you round back up to “roughly ½” because that is the default.  But letting the sample size grow without bound while the number of heads is kept fixed forces the relative frequency strictly to 0 in the limit.  Our finite-minded heuristics resist that limit.

Third, Bayesian conditionalisation on measure-zero events is not part of everyday reasoning.  In ordinary statistical life we nearly always deal with events of positive likelihood.  Hence we lack the experiential anchor that would make the 0 answer feel as obvious as it mathematically is.

Finally, some philosophers read the principal principle—“your credence should match the objective chance if known”—as supporting the ½ answer.  Yet that principle applies only when the objective chance is defined conditional on the total information you possess.  The very thing at issue is what the objective chance is given the information that only finitely many heads occur.  Once we incorporate that information, the chance changes.


7.  What if we adopt a different regularisation?  
Could one define a non-exchangeable conditional probability on F that keeps P(X₀=H)=½?  In principle yes: because F has μ-measure 0, Kolmogorov gives us carte blanche to paint any probability distribution we like on it so long as it stays inside F.  For example, put all the probability mass on the single outcome in which the first coin (mine) is heads and every other coin tails.  That bizarre measure would indeed satisfy P(X₀=H|F)=1.  But by the same token it violates every intuitive symmetry of the problem.  To accept such a measure is to treat the index 0 coin as special for no reason whatsoever.  Most philosophers and mathematicians regard that violation of symmetry as a decisive reductio.

The moral is that updating on probability-zero evidence is unavoidably underdetermined by pure measure theory.  One must inject further rational constraints—usually symmetry or a maximum-entropy rule—to fix a unique posterior.  Once those constraints are made explicit in the present case, the posterior credence in heads becomes 0.


8.  Conclusion  
Our initial, pre-evidence credence that the coin we happen to hold lands heads is ½, by fairness.  Upon learning the astounding fact that only finitely many of countably infinitely many coins land heads—a fact that had prior probability 0—we must abandon the original product measure and adopt a new probability measure concentrated on the newly revealed possibility-set.  Requiring the new measure to respect the obvious permutation symmetries of the situation forces it to distribute probability so thinly over the finitely many heads that every individual coin almost surely lies outside that elite group.  The unique, symmetry-respecting regular conditional gives:

   P_new(“my coin is heads”) = 0.

The lesson is twofold.  First, probability-zero evidence can rationally trigger drastic belief revisions, but only when accompanied by principled criteria—such as symmetry—for pinning down a revised distribution.  Second, causal independence does not shield events from becoming probabilistically dependent once we learn global constraints.  In the strange realm of the infinite, learning that a population contains merely finitely many exceptions makes being an exception a probability-0 status.  Your coin, like almost every coin in the room, is almost certainly tails.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Heads or Tails in a Sea of Coins:
A Philosophical Analysis of Updating on a Probability-Zero Event
≈ 2 000 words  

1. The Set-Up  

Imagine a denumerably infinite row of agents, each holding an identical, fair coin. All the coins are tossed once, independently and simultaneously, and no one looks at the outcome. Before anyone sees anything, every agent is completely certain of three facts:

• Each individual toss is fair, so P(Heads) = ½ for every coin considered in isolation.  
• The tosses are mutually independent.  
• From these two facts it follows that, with probability 1, infinitely many heads and infinitely many tails will be observed; the expected number of heads is infinite and the variance is infinite as well.

Now an announcement is made: something extraordinary occurred—only finitely many of the coins (say n < ∞ of them) landed Heads. You, like everyone else, accept that the announcement is accurate. What ought your credence now be that your own coin showed Heads?

Two natural but competing reactions suggest themselves.

Reaction A (Conservatism): “The announcement is about the joint pattern, not about my coin in particular. Absent any coin-specific evidence I should keep the prior ½.”

Reaction B (Holism): “If altogether only finitely many Heads were tossed among countably many fairness-guaranteed trials, the overall proportion of Heads is 0. That must drastically lower the chance that my particular coin is one of the rare Heads; the rational posterior is 0.”

Which reaction is correct? I will argue that the holist answer—credence 0—is rationally mandatory once the announcement is accepted, but also explain why the case is philosophically delicate: it involves updating on an event of probability 0, and Bayesian orthodoxy leaves such updates non-unique unless further constraints are imposed. Sorting the constraints reveals the deep tension between local independence and global information in infinite settings.  

2. Why “Only Finitely Many Heads” Has Prior Probability 0  

Let Hi be the indicator that coin i lands Heads, and let S = ΣHi be the (possibly infinite) total number of Heads. Because the Hi are i.i.d. Bernoulli(½),

P(S = k) = 0 for every finite k,  
P(S = ∞) = 1.

One way to see this is by Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law: the event “only finitely many Heads” is a tail event (it is unchanged by altering any finite subset of tosses) and has probability either 0 or 1. The expected number of Heads, E[S] = ∞, so probability 1 is impossible; therefore P(S < ∞) = 0.

Thus the announcement presents us with a probability-zero event. Standard conditional probability P(A | B) = P(A∧B)/P(B) is undefined when P(B)=0. So merely repeating “conditionalize!” is not enough; we must decide how to extend Bayesian updating to measure-zero cases.   

3. Regular Conditional Probabilities and Limiting Procedures  

The canonical fix is to replace crude ratios with a regular conditional probability (RCP): a σ-additive function P*(· | F) that is defined for almost every outcome in F, satisfies the Bayes law for all positive-probability subsets of F and recovers ordinary conditionalisation whenever that is defined. Existence is guaranteed on standard (Polish) probability spaces; uniqueness is not. Distinct RCPs correspond to distinct ways of approximating an event of probability 0 by events of positive probability.

So the real question is not “What is P(Hi | S < ∞)?” in abstraction—that is under-determined—but “Which RCP, if any, is epistemically privileged for a rational updater who receives exactly the information ‘S < ∞’?”  

4. The Natural Approximation: ‘At Most N Heads’  

A compelling approximation scheme is:

Fn := {S ≤ n}  (n ∈ ℕ).

Each Fn has positive probability and Fn ↓ F := {S < ∞}. Moreover they preserve the intuitive content of the announcement: that the number of Heads is bounded. Taking n → ∞ seems an obvious way to ‘learn’ that S is finite while staying inside ordinary conditionalisation at every finite stage.

What posterior does this limiting path deliver?

Compute for any fixed coin k:  

P( Hk ∧ Fn ) = (½) P( S≤n−1 ) because Hk uses up one of the ≤ n Heads.  
P( Fn )       = P( S≤n ).

Therefore  

P( Hk | Fn ) = P( Hk ∧ Fn ) / P( Fn )  
             = ½ · P( S≤n−1 ) / P( S≤n ).

But P( S≤n ) – P( S≤n−1 ) = P( S = n ) > 0, and P( S = n ) falls super-exponentially (a negative binomial series). Consequently  

P( Hk | Fn ) ≤ ½ · P( S≤n−1 ) / P( S≤n−1 + P(S=n) )  
            = ½ · 1 / (1 + P(S=n)/P(S≤n−1))  
            < ½.

The ratio goes to 0 as n grows: the probability mass in P(S≤n) is concentrated overwhelmingly at the largest admissible value n; but if Hk is Heads we must move to n−1 or less. One can make this precise via Stirling’s approximation, obtaining

lim_{n→∞} P( Hk | Fn ) = 0.

Hence the RCP generated by the canonical bounded-Heads sequence mandates posterior credence 0.  

5. Exchangeability and de Finetti’s Representation  

Another route uses symmetry. The initial (prior) joint distribution over ⟨Hi⟩ is exchangeable. Upon conditioning on “S<∞”, the updated distribution must still be exchangeable because that event is permutation-invariant. De Finetti’s theorem tells us that an exchangeable sequence of Bernoullis is a mixture of i.i.d. sequences with some mixing measure μ over p= P(Heads) values. Before the announcement, μ is the point mass at p=½. After learning S<∞, what mixture yields finite total Heads almost surely?

Only the degenerate component p=0 does. Any p>0 gives infinite Heads μ-a.s. Conversely p=0 yields S=0 finitely (indeed exactly zero) μ-a.s. Therefore the conditional mixture collapses to p=0, making every Hi almost surely Tails. Credence in ‘my coin is Heads’ must be 0.

This argument bypasses the technicalities of regular conditional probabilities altogether; it exploits the qualitative probabilistic fact that finiteHeads is incompatible with any strictly positive per-trial Head chance.  

6. Can a Posterior of ½ be Defended?  

Advocates of the conservative reaction appeal to two principles:

a. Locality: My coin toss is still a fair, independent micro-event; the announcement concerns only the global pattern.  
b. Principle of Indifference: Absent coin-specific evidence symmetry dictates ½.

Yet these principles cannot be jointly sustained with the announcement. Suppose your posterior for each Hi were still ½ and the Hi remained independent. Then the expected number of Heads, conditional on S<∞, would still be infinite (∞·½). But by hypothesis you are completely certain the number is finite—a contradiction. Independence, fairness, and finiteHeads cannot all hold simultaneously. The announcement forces you to abandon at least one. The natural one to give up is independence/fairness of each coin, because that is exactly what the new information undermines: it creates global negative correlation among the Hi.  

7. A Borel-like Paradox?  

In finite-dimensional conditioning on a zero-measure manifold (e.g. conditioning a spherical distribution on latitude 0°) yields different answers depending on the limiting approach used: the classic Borel paradox. Is our case similar? In fact no. Any reasonable filtration that respects permutation symmetry and is measurable with respect to the tail σ-algebra leads to the same RCP we already met. The event “S<∞” lives in the tail σ-field, which is trivial under the prior measure; the only consistent update that preserves exchangeability sends μ to δ0 and each Hi to probability 0. So the posterior is in practice unique once we add the mild, epistemically natural constraint of exchangeability.

One can, of course, cook up bizarre approximations (e.g. condition on ‘at most n Heads in the first n² coins’) that keep P(Hi)=½ in the limit. But those approximations encode extra illicit information about the indexing of coins, information not provided by the bare announcement. Because rational agents should disregard arbitrary indexings, such updates violate the symmetry (or ‘relevance’) principles that justified indifference in the first place.  

8. Intuitive Picture: Urns, Tickets, and Sparse Winners  

Think of the infinite population as an urn containing one ticket per person. Exactly n tickets are secretly coloured red (‘Head’); the rest stay white. You are handed a randomly selected ticket but cannot look at its colour yet. If you are only told that the urn is infinite while reds are finite, it is overwhelmingly plausible that the ticket you hold is white: the reds are “sparse.” Your chance of having drawn one of the finitely many reds out of a proper class of whites should be 0. The coin example is just a dynamically generated version of the sparse-reds urn, and the same intuition applies.

Some commentators object that 0 credence seems incompatible with the logical possibility that your coin is red—after all, you might be one of the lucky few. But probability 0 of A does not mean A is impossible; it only means that A is measure-theoretically negligible relative to the given information. Countably many specific sequences of Who-Got-Heads collectively cover the finiteHeads event, yet each such sequence itself has probability 0. This is common in continuous models (a dart landing at exactly 0.5 on [0,1]); the present case is a discrete-infinite analogue.  

9. Decision-Theoretic Support  

Suppose you are offered two gambles, priced at fair expectation:

G1: win $1 if your own coin is Heads. Expected value at ½: $0.50.  
G2: win $1 if at least one coin in the room is Heads. Expected value prior: $1 (because prior probability of “no Heads” is 0).

After the announcement “only finitely many Heads,” but before learning how many or who they are, compare the gambles. Under a ½ posterior for your coin, G1 would still be worth $0.50, whereas under the holist posterior, G1 is worth $0. Analogously, G2 is now worth $1 because you know finitely (hence at least one) Heads occurred. If you kept the ½ valuation you would still view G1 as half as attractive as G2, but if you coherently integrate the new information you must prefer G2 infinitely more: it is guaranteed to pay $1, G1 is practically certain to pay $0. So any agent that sticks to ½ would be exploitable by a Dutch book as follows: simultaneously buy from her G2 for $0.99 (she thinks its value $1) and sell her G1 for $0.49 (she thinks its value $0.50). Net gain $0.50 guaranteed to the bookie, loss to the agent, whenever S<∞. Coherence requires revising the ½.

10. Philosophical Up-Shot: Local vs Global Information in the Infinite  

The heart of the puzzle is that a single tail fact about an infinite family can override every local fact about each member. In finite contexts, independence plus identical marginals is compatible with any global constraint formulated solely in terms of the sum; the constraint merely introduces negative correlation. But in the infinite limit the negative correlation becomes maximal, forcing each marginal probability all the way down to 0.

This phenomenon mirrors other measure-zero updates that break factorisation—e.g. conditioning a two-dimensional Gaussian on X+Y=0 yields perfect anticorrelation even though X and Y were independent a moment before.

For philosophers, the case offers lessons on:

• The limits of the Principle of Indifference: one must heed all the evidence, even non-local evidence.  
• The non-Boolean structure of Bayesian conditionalisation when confronted with impossible-but-possible information.  
• The fragility of independence assumptions under global data, a moral relevant to the Sleeping Beauty debate, anthropic reasoning, and infinite ethics.

11. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1. The announcement could in principle be false—probability-zero events have probability 0, not impossibility—so conditionalising on it at all violates Bayesian dogma that one should never update on information you expected with probability 0.

Reply: Bayesianism forbids assigning probability 1 to contingent propositions; it does not forbid updating on events to which you gave probability 0. Think of winning the jackpot: before the draw P=10-8, yet if you see all the matching numbers you rationally update to certainty you won. Likewise here; receiving probability-zero evidence is entirely admissible though it forces you to deploy the RCP machinery.

Objection 2. If credence becomes 0, how could you ever rationally believe your coin is Heads even after you look? Seeing a Head is logically compatible with the announcement, yet on your model has posterior probability 0, contradicting your sight.

Reply: Once you look, you receive new evidence distinct from the announcement: “My coin is Heads.” Conditionalize again; that forces the posterior to jump from 0 to 1. Probability 0 to 1 updates are permitted because 0 is not impossibility; it is merely measure-zero given earlier data.

Objection 3. The conditional expectation argument presupposes exchangeability; suppose the agents are labelled by the natural numbers and the ‘finitely many Heads’ happen to occur among the first ten coins. Then if I know I am randomly selected from the end of the row, maybe ½ is right for me.

Reply: The original thought-experiment says only that “you” are one of the countably many people, with no extra location information. Any label-sensitive update uses information not in the common announcement. If additional self-locating facts are supplied, the correct posterior may indeed differ; but holding those fixed, symmetry trumps indexical fantasies.

12. Conclusion  

Conditioning on “only finitely many Heads” transforms the probabilistic landscape. Because a fair, independent Bernoulli(½) process nearly surely produces infinitely many Heads, learning that finitely many occurred is as epistemically catastrophic for the original model as learning that water is not H2O would be for chemistry. The only coherent regular conditional probability respecting the symmetry of the problem assigns probability 0 to any particular coin’s being Heads. Any attempt to hang on to the original ½ marginal contradicts the finite-Heads datum, violates exchangeability, and exposes the agent to Dutch books.

Therefore your rational credence that your coin landed Heads, upon accepting the miraculous announcement, should be 0, not ½. The case is a vivid reminder that in the infinite, global facts decisively shape local probabilities, and that conditioning on probability-zero events demands careful, measure-theoretically informed treatment lest intuition go astray.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Heads, Tails and the Indescribable Event  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  

1.  The puzzle  

Countably many people, labelled 0, 1, 2, … , each toss a fair and independent coin in the usual sense: before any information is revealed the unconditional probability of heads (H) for each coin is ½ and the joint distribution is the product measure (½, ½)^ℕ.  After the tosses an oracle announces the following astonishing fact:

 F: “Only finitely many of the coins landed heads.”

F has prior probability 0.  (Kolmogorov’s 0–1 law or the second Borel–Cantelli lemma implies that, with probability 1, infinitely many heads occur.)  You are person 0 and you have not looked at your own coin.  The question is:

 Given F, what ought your personal credence be that your own coin landed heads?  

A quick, intuitive reaction says “½—why should the global announcement matter to my local, independent toss?”  An equally quick, opposing intuition says “the set of heads is finite and there are infinitely many people, so the chance that the special finite set happens to contain me should be 0.”  Behind the clash of intuitions lies a serious technical issue: how, if at all, should a Bayesian conditionalise on an event that had probability 0 under the prior?  I shall argue that, once we impose the two natural constraints that (i) the update respect the symmetry of the situation and (ii) the update be given by a regular conditional probability (i.e. the probability-theoretic extension of Bayes’ rule to measure-zero events), the rational credence for heads is 0.  I then examine the objections that motivate retaining ½, and explain why they fail once the subtleties of conditioning on measure-zero events are made explicit.  In closing I draw some lessons for the epistemology of probability‐zero information.

The discussion is self-contained, but interested readers may consult Lévy (1937), Blackwell and Dubins (1962), Hájek (2003) and recent work on the “doomsday” and “random observer” paradoxes for further background.

2.  Why ordinary conditionalisation does not apply  

For events of positive probability Bayes’ rule is unproblematic:

 P(A | B) = P(A∧B)/P(B)     provided P(B)>0.

When P(B)=0 the ratio is undefined.  Philosophers sometimes speak loosely of “conditioning on probability-zero events”, but strictly speaking one must replace the ratio by a **regular conditional probability measure**.  Given a σ-algebra 𝔽 and an underlying probability space (Ω,𝒜,P), a regular conditional P(· | 𝔽)(ω) is a family of probability measures that (i) coincides with ordinary conditional probability when the conditioning event has positive probability, and (ii) is measurable in ω.  Regular conditionals always exist for standard Borel spaces, and they are unique up to P-null sets, but they are often **non-unique on a given probability-zero event**.  In other words, different regularisations of Bayes’ rule can assign different posteriors to the very same information F.  So before we ask whether the correct answer is 0 or ½, we must ask what constraints single out the “right” regular conditional.

3.  Two natural constraints  

C1. Symmetry (exchangeability).  The prior treats all coins alike.  Learning F does not single out any particular agent; it merely says that the set of heads is finite.  Any posterior that broke symmetry between persons 0,1,2,… would therefore import information that the oracle never gave us.  

C2. Tail-measurability.  The event F depends only on the “tail” of the sequence—informally, no finite block of coins suffices to determine whether F is true.  Hence, by Lévy’s zero-one law, F is independent of every finite initial segment of the sequence.  The usual way of capturing such independence inside regular conditional probabilities is to require that the posterior sit on the **tail σ-algebra**, exactly as in the Kolmogorov–Levy martingale convergence theorem.

Under these two constraints, the regular conditional probability is unique, and it yields credence 0 for your head.  Here is the argument in three mutually reinforcing ways.

4.  Three routes to the result “H with probability 0”  

4.1  The proportion argument  

Let I_i be the indicator of heads for person i.  Exchangeability implies

 E(I_0 | F) = E( (1/n)∑_{i=0}^{n-1} I_i | F )      for every n≥1,

because the conditional expectation of any particular I_i given F must equal the conditional expectation of their finite average.  But under F at most finitely many of the I_i equal 1, so

 lim_{n→∞} (1/n)∑_{i=0}^{n-1} I_i = 0    with F-probability 1.

Taking expectations and using dominated convergence gives

 E(I_0 | F) = 0.

So the posterior probability that your own coin is heads is 0.

4.2  The “random natural number” analogy  

Imagine numbering the (possibly) finitely many heads in increasing order and then choosing a random natural number, n, independent of the coin tosses.  The probability that n lies in a fixed finite set is 0.  Conditioning on F amounts to asserting that the set of heads, call it H*, is finite; the probability that a random index (person 0, in particular) lies in H* is therefore 0.  The analogy is exact once we formalise “random index” via the product measure and the canonical projection.

4.3  The de Finetti–Schervish computation  

De Finetti’s representation is not directly applicable because the common success probability is fixed at ½.  Nevertheless we can write the joint law as a mixture over the latent empirical frequency θ = limsup (1/n)∑_{i<n} I_i.  The prior puts all its mass on θ=½.  The event F is contained in {θ=0}.  When we condition on F we necessarily move all of our probability mass to θ=0.  Given θ=0 the conditional probability for any particular I_i is 0.  Thus P(I_0=1 | F)=0.

Notice that the three routes use nothing that distinguishes person 0 from the others; indeed any fixed finite coalition of people has probability 0 of comprising one of the finitely many heads.  The result is therefore a direct corollary of C1 and C2.

5.  The intuitive objection: “Independence should block learning”  

The strongest temptation to stick with ½ rests on the following line of thought:

 (a) My coin was tossed before I learned F.  
 (b) It was physically independent of the other coins.  
 (c) Learning F only concerns the outcomes of the other coins, so  
 (d) It should not affect the probability of my own outcome.  

Step (b) is correct; step (a) is irrelevant; step (c) is partially correct; but step (d) is a non-sequitur.  Independence can be destroyed by conditioning.  A textbook illustration is two independent fair coins A and B: unconditionally they are independent, but conditioned on the event “A≠B” they become negatively correlated.  Our case is merely the infinite analogue.  The initial product measure makes the coins independent; the zero-probability event F correlates them maximally (they must “conspire” so that only finitely many are heads).  So learning F does create extremely strong statistical dependence between your coin and the rest.  Under that dependence the probability that you were one of finitely many lucky heads falls to 0.

6.  The technical objection: “Regular conditionals are not unique, so ½ is permissible”  

True: if one removes either C1 or C2 one can cook up a bizarre regular conditional that assigns probability ½ (or ⅓, or √2/π, or anything in [0,1]) to I_0=1 given F.  For instance, fix an arbitrary well-ordering of sequences with finitely many heads, search for the first position in which two sequences differ, and let that position govern how probability is split.  Such disintegrations exist (this is a version of **Borel’s paradox**).  But they all violate symmetry.  They either privilege person 0 a priori or embed some external well-ordering into the updating rule.  Nothing in F, and nothing in the fair-coin hypothesis, justifies doing either.  If *rationality* is taken to mean *respecting the evidential symmetry of the problem*, then only the symmetric regular conditional is admissible, and that conditional gives credence 0.

7.  A concrete operational test  

Suppose a bookmaker offers you the following bet after the oracle’s announcement: pay $1 now, receive $k > 0 if your coin is heads.  At what odds k would you regard the gamble as fair?  If you stick with credence ½ you will accept whenever k≥2.  But consider the sequence of moments at which you and your co-participants inspect your coins in turn.  Each time a person discovers tails the posterior odds that the *remaining* unseen coins contain one of the finitely many heads worsens.  By optional stopping and symmetry one can construct a martingale that forces a sure loss on anyone who buys the bet at k=2 but sells it back whenever they learn that their own coin is tails.  No such Dutch book arises for the player who assigns credence 0 from the outset.  This provides pragmatic corroboration for the theoretical conclusion.

8.  Philosophical morals  

8.1  Learning probability-zero truths.  Bayesian conditionalisation can be extended to measure-zero events, but additional structural principles (here: symmetry and tail-measurability) are needed to make the update unique.  Without these principles “anything goes”; with them the update can be perfectly determinate even when the learned event was deemed practically impossible ex ante.

8.2  Independence is fragile under learning.  The case underlines a moral familiar from quantum entanglement: physical or causal independence at the prior does not entail epistemic independence after new information is received.  One can learn about one variable by learning a global constraint that ties many variables together.

8.3  Infinite idealisations matter.  In any *finite* group of coin-flippers the same announcement (“only finitely many heads”, now necessarily “at most N heads”) would marginally *raise* the probability that your own coin is heads, because the base-rate of heads has been lowered but not eliminated.  The limit as N→∞ reverses the effect entirely.  Philosophers who are uneasy about idealisations to ω-sequence lotteries must therefore decide whether the pathology is an artefact or a genuine feature of rational belief in infinite settings.

9.  Conclusion  

Under the usual Bayesian norms, augmented by the minimal symmetry and tail-measurability constraints that are already implicit in the problem statement, one must update to posterior credence

 P(“my coin is heads” | F) = 0.

The argument is not a refutation of independence, nor does it rest on mysterious “causal influence” from the other tosses; it simply recognises that learning the probability-zero fact F carves away all those independent product worlds in which infinitely many heads occur, leaving only the highly correlated worlds in which the empirical frequency of heads is 0.  In those worlds the chance that any particular person belongs to the privileged finite set of heads is 0.  The initially tempting answer ½ survives only if one is prepared to ignore the evidential symmetry of the situation or to tolerate non-regular disintegrations of the prior—moves that, on reflection, carry an unacceptable epistemic cost.

Those who find the conclusion uncomfortable should perhaps take comfort, or feel renewed unease, in its very source: the paradoxical behaviour of probability at the frontier where the “almost impossible” becomes actual.  Bayesianism can accommodate learning the impossible, but only by forcing us to revise even those credences—like ½ for a fair coin—that seemed immune to revision.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
What follows is a sustained attempt to think through the question from a recognisably Bayesian point of view, while taking seriously the measure–theoretic subtleties that arise whenever one conditions on an event of probability 0.  The conclusion I finally recommend is that, once you have learnt that only finitely many heads were obtained, your rational credence that your own coin landed heads should collapse to 0.  I first show informally why that answer seems unavoidable, then give a more rigorous derivation by way of an approximating‐sequence argument, and finally rebut the most natural reasons for insisting that the credence ought to stay at 1⁄2.

1.  Setting the stage  

Let ℕ = {1,2,3,…} index the people in the room.  For each i∈ℕ, let Hᵢ be the indicator random variable that equals 1 when the ith coin lands heads and 0 when it lands tails.  Our probability space (Ω,𝔽,𝑃) is the usual infinite product of copies of the fair‐coin space, with the product σ–algebra and independent ½–½ product measure.  The event we learn is  

F := {ω ∈ Ω : Σ_{i=1}^{∞} Hᵢ(ω) < ∞}.  

Because the expected number of heads in an infinite sequence of fair flips is infinite and, by the second Borel–Cantelli lemma, infinitely many heads occur with 𝑃‐probability 1, we have 𝑃(F)=0.  That already warns us that ordinary conditional probability 𝑃(•|F) is undefined; we shall need a more careful story about how to update on F.

2.  The intuitive argument for credence 0  

Suppose you have been told with certainty that only finitely many of the countably many coins landed heads.  If there are only finitely many heads among countably many coins, then “most” coins—indeed, all except a finite handful—must be tails.  Now focus on your own labelled coin, say coin #k.  Nothing you have learnt singles out coin #k for special treatment; the information concerns only the global pattern of heads and tails.  In any world in F there exists an N such that for all n>N, H_n=0.  For any fixed k, we can always choose N larger than k, so it is entirely possible that the finitely many heads are all located among coins with indices less than k and that H_k=0.  What is the probability that k itself makes it into the finite “head list”?  In a purely combinatorial sense it is 0 : when infinitely many positions compete for finitely many slots, every particular position is almost surely excluded.

A useful analogy: imagine writing the natural numbers on slips of paper, mixing them thoroughly in a box, and then blindly drawing finitely many slips.  Before you peek at the slips you have drawn, what probability should you assign to the claim “the slip numbered k is in my hand”?  It should be 0, because out of the infinitely many slips only finitely many were picked; the probability that any specified slip is among them vanishes.  The same “vanishing‐share” intuition applies to the head event H_k=1 conditional on F.

3.  Making the intuition precise  

Intuition, however, is not always trustworthy at probability 0, and we need a principled updating rule.  Among the many proposals available (Jeffrey’s method, Lewis’s conditional credence, van Fraassen’s ratio formula, etc.) the most conservative is to define the conditional probability by a limiting sequence of positive–probability events that shrink down to F.  The sequence that suggests itself here is

F_n := {ω : Σ_{i=1}^{∞} Hᵢ(ω) ≤ n}, n∈ℕ.

Each F_n has strictly positive probability (in fact exponentially small, but non-zero) and ⋂_{n=1}^{∞} F_n = F.  Write

p_{k,n} := 𝑃(H_k=1 | F_n).

If lim_{n→∞} p_{k,n} exists, we may adopt that limit as 𝑃(H_k=1 | F).

(Strictly speaking, we should first verify that the limit is independent of the particular approximating sequence; I return to that in section 6.  For the moment, let us compute.)

Because the product measure is exchangeable, every coin has the same conditional distribution.  Indeed, for fixed n and k,

𝑃(H_k=1 ∧ F_n) = (½)·𝑃(Σ_{i≠k} Hᵢ ≤ n−1)

and

𝑃(F_n) = (½)·𝑃(Σ_{i≠k} Hᵢ ≤ n−1) + (½)·𝑃(Σ_{i≠k} Hᵢ ≤ n).

Hence

p_{k,n} = 𝑃(H_k=1 | F_n) = (½)·𝑃(S≤n−1) / [(½)·𝑃(S≤n−1)+(½)·𝑃(S≤n)],

where S := Σ_{i≠k} Hᵢ.  Now S is an infinite count of independent Bernoulli(½) trials, so 𝑃(S≤m) tends monotonically down to 0 as m increases but is always positive and finite.  Because 𝑃(S≤n−1)≤𝑃(S≤n), the fraction is at most ½, but we can obtain a sharper estimate:

𝑃(S≤n−1) ≤ 2^{−n}·C(n), for some polynomial C(n).

As n grows large, 𝑃(S≤n−1) and 𝑃(S≤n) are both doubly‐exponentially tiny, but crucially their ratio 𝑃(S≤n−1)/𝑃(S≤n) goes to 0; in fact

lim_{n→∞} 𝑃(S≤n−1) / 𝑃(S≤n) = 0,

because adding the possibility “exactly n heads” contributes asymptotically far more weight than was already present.  Consequently,

lim_{n→∞} p_{k,n} = 0.

Therefore, using this perfectly natural approximating sequence of positive‐probability events, one arrives at

𝑃(H_k=1 | F) = 0.

4.  A symmetry‐based derivation  

Another, perhaps simpler, route appeals only to symmetry and linearity of expectation.  Assume for the moment that some regular conditional probability 𝑄(•|F) exists (in whatever sense) and that it is permutation‐invariant, i.e. it treats each labelled coin identically.  Let N(ω) = Σ_{i=1}^{∞} Hᵢ(ω) denote the total number of heads.  Because F says “N is finite,” N takes values in ℕ under 𝑄(•|F) and hence has finite expected value:

𝔼_𝑄[N | F] = Σ_{k=0}^{∞} k·𝑄(N=k | F) < ∞.

Now by linearity of expectation,

𝔼_𝑄[N | F] = Σ_{i=1}^{∞} 𝑄(H_i=1 | F).

If every term in that sum were ≥ ε for some ε>0, the expected value would diverge.  For the sum to converge, the individual terms must converge to 0; indeed, permutation invariance forces them all to be equal, so they must all equal 0.  Hence 𝑄(H_k=1 | F)=0 for every k.  In short, no permutation‐invariant regular conditional probability can preserve the ½ marginal once we have learnt F.

5.  Why “stick with ½” looks tempting—and why it fails  

The view that one should not adjust away from ½ usually rests on two thoughts.

a.  Independence. Before learning F, you regarded your coin as independent of the rest.  Learning F does not reveal the outcome of any specific other flip, so (the reasoning goes) you have learned nothing germane to your own coin; independence ought to screen off F.

b.  Zero‐probability events are epistemically negligible. Conditionalisation on measure‐0 events is arbitrary; therefore rationality imposes no definite update here, so sticking with the prior ½ is at least permissible.

Both arguments falter under closer inspection.

Ad (a). Your coin is independent of each other individual coin, but it is not independent of the tail event F, nor even of the family of events F_n.  Indeed we computed above that 𝑃(H_k=1 | F_n) < ½ for every n and that the conditional probability tends downward to 0.  The independence premises simply do not extend to the collective, highly non-local information supplied by F.

Ad (b). True, standard Kolmogorov conditional probabilities are undefined on measure-0 events, but in practice we repeatedly find ourselves updating on what the prior said had probability 0 (witness continuous‐valued observations in physics).  The usual resolution is to appeal to limits of conditional probabilities on positive‐measure sets that approximate the target event.  For your coin-tossing problem, every “reasonable” approximating sequence that respects the qualitative content of F—e.g. the sequence (F_n) used above, or any cofinal subsequence—yields the same limit 0.  In that important sense the update is unambiguous.  Conversely, one can manufacture exotic approximations that force the limit to take other values (indeed any value between 0 and 1), but those sequences encode extraneous information, such as a special role for low-indexed coins, that is not embodied in the original description of F.  If one demands symmetry—and almost every philosophical discussion of the case does—credence 0 is the unique answer.

6.  Existence and uniqueness of a regular conditional distribution  

Given a countably generated σ-algebra and a σ-finite measure, disintegrations (regular conditional probabilities) exist almost everywhere.  In our case the event F itself has probability 0, so one cannot appeal to an “everywhere” result; nevertheless one can build a σ-additive measure 𝑄 on (Ω,𝔽) that (i) is supported by F, (ii) is permutation-invariant, and (iii) agrees with the product measure on tail events mod F.  The Kolmogorov extension theorem ensures uniqueness of such a measure, and straightforward calculations then show 𝑄(H_k=1)=0.  Hence, once we insist on countable additivity and symmetry, the conditional distribution is fixed and the credence in H_k drops to 0.

7.  A cautionary note on finitely additive alternatives  

Some writers (notably, proponents of de Finetti style finitely additive probabilities) have observed that one can concoct a finitely additive conditional on F for which each marginal remains ½.  The trick is to sacrifice countable additivity: one assigns probability ½ to H_k=1 but assigns probability 0 to the disjoint union ⋃_{k=1}^{∞} {H_k=1}, thereby avoiding any contradiction with the knowledge that only finitely many heads occur.  Whatever the merits of finitely additive probabilities in general, that manoeuvre buys stability of the ½ credence at the price of violating an axiom (countable additivity) that underpins virtually all mainstream Bayesian reasoning.  Since the original problem is posed in the ordinary Kolmogorov framework, appeal to purely finitely additive revisions looks more like an evasion than a solution.

8.  Philosophical morals  

The coin‐room story is a vivid illustration of three broader lessons.

i.  Global information can swamp local independence.  Even when individual variables are mutually independent, learning a non-local fact about the ensemble can dramatically affect your beliefs about each part; the present example is a limiting case.

ii.  Events of prior probability 0 are not epistemically inert.  Rational agents must sometimes condition on such events, and when they do, the correct update is fixed once symmetry and continuity constraints are imposed.

iii.  Infinite idealisations matter.  No finite analogue of the story produces the same reversal: in a room with N people you could never learn that “only finitely many heads” occurred, because that statement furnishes no new information.  The limit N → ∞, however, changes the situation qualitatively.  Philosophers and scientists should be cautious when exporting finite‐case intuitions to countably infinite settings.

9.  Conclusion  

Given the standard Bayesian norm of conditionalisation, augmented by the familiar device of limit conditioning and by the natural symmetry requirement that labelled coins be treated alike, the only coherent credence to adopt upon learning that only finitely many heads occurred is 0 (strictly: as close to 0 as one cares to make it, the limit being 0).  Retaining the prior value ½ is untenable, for it makes the expected number of heads infinite and flys in the face of every reasonable regularisation of conditional probability on F.  At the same time the example usefully reminds us how delicate conditional reasoning becomes in measure-zero contexts, and how care with infinite idealisations can upset the deliverances of naïve intuition.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
What follows is a sustained attempt—roughly two thousand words—to work out, with some care, what rational credence you ought to assign to the proposition

H: my own coin landed Heads

once you learn

F: in the entire infinite collection only finitely many coins landed Heads.

At first pass the puzzle seems to pull us in opposite directions.  On the one hand it is hard to see how learning something about the other ∞ − 1 coins could, by itself, make any difference to the intrinsic chance of my own flip; after all, the coins are stipulated to be fair and probabilistically independent.  That suggests that the correct posterior credence should still be ½.
