On the other hand, the content of F is qualitatively astonishing: among a countably infinite family of fair coin–tosses we are told that only finitely many Heads occurred.  Intuitively that looks like an environment “overwhelmingly saturated” with Tails; and it is tempting to infer that the conditional probability of my being one of the rare Heads must be driven right down toward 0.  Which line of thought is correct?

I.  Anatomy of the Temptation to Say “~0”

Let us first rehearse, in its most compelling form, the argument for slashing the credence.

1.  In the normal run of things, an ω-sequence of fair independent flips almost surely contains infinitely many Heads (and infinitely many Tails).  Indeed the Strong Law of Large Numbers tells us that with probability 1 the limiting frequency of Heads is ½.  The event F therefore has prior probability 0.  

2.  Suppose nevertheless that F has somehow been verified.  Then, in the actual sequence, at most N coins—not “most”, just finitely many—are Heads.  Each of the countably many persons is singled out by some fixed natural number i ∈ ω.  Out of those infinitely many indices only finitely many are indices of Heads.  

3.  If a selector were to choose an index uniformly at random from ω, the probability that it happened to pick one of the exceptional finitely many indices would be 0.  

4.  I am one of the ω individuals.  So (it is urged) the probability that I inhabit one of those exceptional indices is likewise 0.  Consequently once F is learned, rational credence in H should collapse toward 0.

What is wrong with this reasoning?  The crucial step is (3) → (4).  It slides, almost invisibly, from talk about an ad hoc random selector to talk about me, a concrete particular person—whose index was fixed long before anyone knew what the flips would bring.  The move is illegitimate.  Notice what (3) really establishes: given F, the set of indices at which a Head occurs has (as mathematicians say) asymptotic density 0 inside ω.  That implies that if an index were chosen by a mechanism that is independent of the outcome of the flips and is equiprobable over the natural numbers, the conditional probability that the chosen index is one of the rare Head-indices would be 0.  But that tells us nothing at all about the status of any specific, antecedently identified index.  Independence matters.  The device that selects an index uniformly at random is, by hypothesis, probabilistically unrelated to the coin outcomes; by contrast, the index that picks me out is hard-wired and may well be probabilistically correlated with the outcome once F is fixed.  Indeed, as we shall see, it is extremely correlated: if it happens to be the index of a Head in the actual ω-sequence, then given F there will be exactly N − 1 Heads among the others; if it is not, there will be N among the others.  The selector analogy therefore proves too much.

The moral: talk of “becoming a random member of a reference class” is perilous in probability problems involving infinite populations.  If the class is infinite but the target set is only finite, the probability that a uniformly selected random member falls in the target will indeed be 0, but no contradiction arises from the fact that someone—or even you—does fall there.  What remains is to supply a strictly Bayesian analysis.

II.  Conditioning on Probability-Zero Events: Some Measure-Theoretic Tools

Learning F poses a technical difficulty: under the usual product measure on {H,T}^ω the event F has probability 0.  Naïve Bayes’ rule,

P(H | F) = P(H ∧ F)/P(F),

is undefined.  There is, however, a well-developed theory of conditional probability vis-à-vis measure-zero events, built on two interlocking ideas:

a)  Conditional expectations with respect to σ-algebras (Radon–Nikodym derivatives).

b)  Approximating the probability-zero event by a decreasing sequence of positive-probability events.

The route that best highlights the structure of our problem uses σ-algebras.

Let X₀ be the indicator of my coin: X₀ = 1 if H, 0 if T.  Let T be the tail σ-algebra generated by the sequence (X₀, X₁, X₂, …)—i.e. the collection of events whose truth-value depends only on the flips beyond any given finite stage.  Kolmogorov’s 0-1 Law tells us that every event in T has probability either 0 or 1; moreover, for any integrable random variable Y, the conditional expectation E(Y | T) is T-measurable and (because of independence of finite vs. tail events) collapses almost surely to E(Y): the tail σ-algebra is independent of any finite patch of the sequence.

Now, F—the event that only finitely many Heads occur—is plainly a tail event: deleting the first k flips cannot affect whether the whole sequence contains only finitely many Heads.  Accordingly, X₀ and F are independent.  Hence

E( X₀ · 1_F ) = E(X₀) · P(F) = ½ × 0 = 0.

A direct consequence, supplied by standard theorems on regular conditional distributions, is that

E[X₀ | F] = ½

P-almost everywhere on F.  Put more heuristically, “once you know everything there is to know about how the flips go from stage N onward, you still have no further information about how the first flip went”.  Conditionalizing on F, although epistemically dramatic, gives you no probabilistic leverage on X₀.  Your posterior credence should therefore remain equal to the prior, viz. ½.

III.  A More Concrete Approximation Argument

Some philosophers (and many students) remain uneasy with tail-σ-algebra talk, finding it too abstract.  The same verdict can be reached by a limiting-events approach.  For n = 1,2,3,… let

F_n : “at most n coins landed Heads”.

Each F_n has positive probability, though of course that probability rapidly tends to 0.  Because the events are nested (F_{n+1} ⊆ F_n) and their intersection is F, we may examine

P(H | F_n) = P(H ∧ F_n)/P(F_n),

and then pass to the limit as n → ∞.  Employing independence of X₀ and the collection of other flips we get

P(H ∧ F_n) = ½ · P(“among the remaining flips there are at most n−1 Heads”).

Call that latter probability q_{n−1}.  Thus

P(H | F_n) = (½ q_{n−1}) / [½ q_{n−1} + ½ q_n].

But q_{n−1} ≥ q_n.  Dividing numerator and denominator by q_n we find

P(H | F_n) = ½ · (q_{n−1}/q_n) / [½ (q_{n−1}/q_n) + ½].

Observing that q_{n−1}/q_n → 1 as n→∞, we obtain

lim_{n→∞} P(H | F_n) = ½.

Taking the limit delivers the same posterior ½ on F.  (Strictly speaking we also need to verify that the conditional probabilities converge in a suitable sense to define a regular version; standard measure-theoretic facts guarantee this.)  Again the moral is that the spectacular unlikelihood of F has no differential effect on whether X₀ is Heads or Tails.

IV.  Why the Independence Intuition Wins

We may now restate, in plain English, why learning F does not reduce the credence below ½.

1.  Objective chance remains ½.  The physical mechanism that produced my coin result was a fair, genuinely random process.  Nothing I later learn about the outcomes of other processes (even infinitely many of them) retroactively alters that objective chance.  David Lewis’s Principal Principle enjoins us to match credence to chance except where we have so-called inadmissible information—information about the actual outcome.  Learning F gives me ample information about what happened in the rest of the world but gives me no direct information about the outcome of my own local coin.  Thus, as long as we accept the Principal Principle, ½ is mandated.

2.  Symmetry remains in force.  Before any information is released, the joint distribution is completely exchangeable; each person’s coin is probabilistically indistinguishable from each other’s.  The statement F singles out a property of the global ensemble, not of any particular individual.  Because of exchangeability, whatever conditional probability is rational for me must also be rational for each other person.  Yet the total number of Heads conditional on F is finite and (for the sake of argument) could be, say, exactly 17.  If everyone set their posterior credence equal to ε ≪ 1/2, then the expected number of Heads—countably infinite copies of ε—would still be infinite, contradicting F.  The only way to reconcile exchangeability with the finite-Heads fact is for everyone’s conditional probability to remain ½.

3.  The set-density intuition is a red herring.  It is perfectly consistent, under probability theory, that a countable set of indicators each independently take value 1 with probability ½, and yet conditional on there being only finitely many 1’s, the conditional probability for any specific indicator remains ½.  Finitude of the total does not entail smallness of the conditional probability for any fixed co-ordinate.

V.  Philosophical Morals

     1.  The episode illustrates a limitation of informal “proportional reasoning” that treats infinite sets as though they carried a uniform probability measure.  The mistake was to assume that because the relative frequency of Heads within the infinite population sinks to 0, the chance of my being a Head must also sink to 0.  Relative frequency is not the same thing as probability when we talk about a single, predetermined member of an infinite ensemble.  (The same phenomenon occurs in standard measure theory: the set of rational numbers has Lebesgue measure 0 in [0,1], yet the conditional probability that ½ is rational, given that fact, is still 1.)

     2.  Conditionalisation on probability-zero events is delicate but not incoherent.  Philosophers sometimes worry that Bayesianism cannot handle updates on events to which one originally assigned probability 0.  The present case shows that, at least when the probability model is countably additive and well-founded, perfectly unproblematic conditional probabilities can be defined; their uniqueness, however, hinges on regularity considerations stemming from the σ-algebra.

     3.  The problem is an instructive cousin of the famous “paradox of the two aces” and of Borel’s paradox.  In each case evidential reports that are intuitively “purely about the rest of the world” turn out, when analysed carefully, not to shift rational credence about a local variable.

VI.  Objections and Replies

Objection 1:  “Independence is broken once we condition on F.  X₀ may be independent of the tail σ-algebra unconditionally, but conditional on F the variables are interdependent: knowing that lots of other coins were Tails makes it more likely that mine is a Tail.”

Reply:  Yes, global independence fails on the conditioned probability space; what survives is conditional mean-independence.  Although X₀ and the infinite tail become negatively correlated on the restricted space, the expected value of X₀ given the tail remains ½.  Correlation alone does not determine conditional expectation.

Objection 2:  “Your argument depends on abstract measure-theoretic niceties.  A coherent Bayesian who allows finitely additive probabilities could legitimately adopt a different regular conditional probability, driving P(H|F) to 0.”

Reply:  True; if one weakens countable additivity, non-standard conditional probabilities proliferate.  But the puzzle was posed in ordinary mathematical language presupposing the classical, σ-additive Kolmogorov framework.  Within that orthodox setting, the conditional chance is uniquely ½.  Philosophers wary of countable additivity have long known that surrendering it comes at the price of non-uniqueness of conditional probabilities; deciding whether that price is worth paying is a deeper debate.

Objection 3:  “Yet surely I gain evidence that my coin is Tail when I hear that only finitely many Heads occurred—after all, if I peek and see Head, that would contradict my new knowledge that Heads are scarce.”

Reply:  Seeing Head would not contradict F; it would merely reveal that you are one of the scarce cases.  That is entirely compatible with F.  Likewise seeing Tail would not confirm F in any special way.  Your personal observation, if eventually made, has zero impact on whether there are finitely or infinitely many Heads in the rest of the universe—so no asymmetry of confirmational import arises.

VII.  A Simple Analogy

Imagine an infinite deck of cards in perfectly random order, each card being either red or black with equal marginal probability.  You are dealt the 5th card.  You are then told that in the whole infinite deck there are only finitely many red cards.  Does that make it suddenly rational for you to believe that your own card is almost certainly black?  No: the 5th position in the deck was fixed in advance and had its color decided independently of the eventual global fact about finitude of reds.  The analogy is structurally identical to our coin story and reinforces the ½ verdict.

VIII.  Conclusion

A thorough Bayesian analysis vindicates the conservative answer: your credence that your own coin landed Heads should remain exactly ½.  The powerful intuition that Heads have become “exceptionally rare” slides illicitly from a fact about the global distribution to a claim about a specific, antecedently singled-out case.  The underlying probability theory confirms that, within the classical Kolmogorov model endowed with countable additivity, conditioning on the (probability-zero) event F leaves the conditional expectation of any particular coin unchanged.  Philosophically, the episode highlights once more how easily reasoning by informal “proportions” in infinite settings can go astray, and how indispensable the technical machinery of modern probability is to adjudicating such puzzles.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Only finitely many heads!  As soon as the announcement is made every eye in the room turns, first to the ceiling—as if it might explain what has just occurred—and then inward, to the question that concerns each of us:  given this astonishing information, how likely is it that my own coin came up heads?  The natural thought is “one chance in two – the coin is still fair.”  A contrary thought is that the announcement ties the outcomes together in such a way that almost certainly I must be one of the infinitely many people who got tails.  Which thought is right?

The difficulty of the case is not mathematical trickery; it is that the announcement is itself a probability–zero event.  In a room in which countably many independent fair coins are tossed, the probability that only finitely many of them land heads is exactly 0.  A standard Bayesian agent is therefore being asked to update on something to which she assigned no prior probability at all, and orthodox conditionalisation (Pnew(A) = Pold(A & E)/Pold(E)) is silent because the denominator is 0.  To see what the rational response ought to be we therefore have to reflect, not merely calculate, and think hard about what considerations should govern learning from “impossible” information.

The discussion will proceed in four stages.  (1) I explain why the probability of finitely many heads is 0 and why that undermines automatic appeal to ordinary conditionalisation.  (2) I show, by a sequence–of–approximations argument, that any reasonable regularisation of conditionalisation drives the posterior probability of your own head toward 0.  (3) I address a tempting independence-based argument for retaining ½ and show why it fails once we recognise that independence does not survive conditioning.  (4) I consider residual philosophical worries—about physical independence, Dutch books, the reflection principle, and the epistemology of zero-probability events—and argue that they either militate in favour of the “zero” answer or at least leave it unscathed.  I conclude that the rational credence that your coin landed heads, given the announcement, is 0.

1 Why the new information is a probability-zero event  
For each natural number n let Hn be the event that the nth coin lands heads.  The Strong Law of Large Numbers tells us that, with probability 1, the frequency of heads in an infinite sequence of independent fair coin flips converges to ½.  The Borel–Cantelli Lemma strengthens the point: with probability 1, infinitely many of the Hn occur.  Consequently the complementary event

 F = {only finitely many Hn occur}

has measure 0.  Yet F is certainly logically possible; it pinpoints a non-empty set of infinite sequences (all tails after some finite point).  So we face the classic Bayesian predicament: we have learned something which our probability measure deemed effectively impossible.  What is the rational way to incorporate that informational earthquake?

2 Regularising conditionalisation  
One standard manoeuvre is regularisation: approximate the impossible event by a sequence of possible events whose probabilities tend to 0, update in the usual way on each member of the sequence, and take a limit.  Different ways of approximating can in principle deliver different limits, so one must argue that a particular scheme captures the epistemic content of the information received.  In our case there is a uniquely natural approximation:

 FN = {at most N heads are tossed in total}.

The σ-algebra generated by these FN’s converges downward to F, and “only finitely many heads” can be understood as the idealised limit of successively stronger finite caps.

Suppose there are M + 1 people in the room, labelled 0,1,2,…,M, and you are person 0.  (Later we shall let M → ∞.)  Let HM be the event “person 0’s coin is heads” and SN be the event “among persons 1 through M there are at most N heads.”  Conditional on FN, HM is equivalent to “my coin is heads and the other M coins have ≤ N–1 heads.”  Elementary combinatorics gives

 P(HM & SN) = ½ · P(SN with ≤ N–1)
 P(FN) = ½ · P(SN) + ½ · P(SN with ≤ N–1).

A quick calculation for any fixed finite N shows that

 P(HM | FN) = P(HM & FN)/P(FN) ≤ N/(M + 1).

(The intuitive derivation is even simpler: if total heads ≤ N then at most N of the M + 1 coins can be heads, so by symmetry each individual coin has probability ≤ N/(M + 1) of being one of them.)

Now let M → ∞, reflecting the fact that we started with countably many other agents.  For every fixed N,

 limM→∞ P(HM | FN) ≤ limM→∞ N/(M + 1) = 0.

Finally, take N → ∞ so that FN ↘ F.  By a standard continuity argument for nested conditioning, any limit point of P(H | FN) as N → ∞ must itself be ≤ 0, whence it is exactly 0.

The key point is that the ordering of the limits (first M to infinity, then N) exactly mirrors the announcement.  We were told, of a genuinely infinite population already in place, that the number of heads is finite but unspecified; hence cap N is allowed to grow but the population size is not to shrink.

Could some different regularisation yield ½ instead?  Only if we perversely held fixed a finite population, updated on “≤ N heads,” and let N grow before letting the population itself tend to infinity.  But that second order of limits does not capture what we have been told.  In the real announcement the room is already infinite and nothing was said about how large the finite bound on heads is.  The regularisation that flows from the content of the information inexorably delivers posterior credence 0.

3 Why independence does not salvage the ½ answer  
A common objection is:  “My coin was tossed by a physically fair mechanism which is causally and prob­abil­is­ tically independent of the other tosses.  Learning how the others came out therefore tells me nothing about mine, so my credence should remain ½.”  The objection confuses unconditional with conditional independence.  Unconditionally the tosses are independent; conditionally on ‘at most N heads in total’ they are decidedly not.  The event provides a global constraint that generates massive negative correlations: the more heads elsewhere, the less room there is for yours.

The point is familiar from finite analogues.  If two coins are independent but I am later told that at most one of them landed heads, each alone is no longer a fair coin relative to my epistemic state; indeed, P(first is heads | ≤ 1 head) = P(second is heads | ≤ 1 head) = ½·(½)/[½·(¾)] < ½.  Nothing causal has changed, yet rational credence must change because I have learned a logically constraining fact.  The infinite case is simply the limit of these finite cases, and the constraint becomes so stringent that the posterior drops all the way to 0.

4 Philosophical reconciliation  

4.1 Dutch-book considerations  
Imagine a bookie who, immediately after the announcement, offers every person a \$1 ticket that pays out iff that person’s own coin shows heads, selling each ticket for 50 cents.  If every agent sticks with credence ½ each will regard the bet as fair.  Yet ex ante the bookie is guaranteed to pay out on only finitely many tickets while collecting an infinite total of 50-cent fees—yielding sure profit unbounded above.  The group as a whole is, in effect, weakly lured into a collective Dutch book.  That is a strong pragmatic sign that the individual credence ½ is globally incoherent once the new information is on the table.  By contrast, if each agent’s credence drops to 0 no one will buy and the bookie cannot exploit them.

4.2 Reflection and dynamic consistency  
You might object that before the coins were tossed you were confident that your future-self, even if told strange things, would continue to believe the coin fair.  So by van Fraassen’s Reflection Principle should you not stick at ½ now?  The premise fails: before the toss you placed probability 0 on learning that only finitely many heads were tossed.  Reflection applies only to events to which you assign positive probability.  Since this condition is violated, Reflection is silent, and retaining ½ is not required for dynamic consistency.

4.3 Physical independence and causal scruples  
Another worry is that treating my coin as essentially certain to be tails feels “spooky,” as though facts about infinitely many distant coin flips were causally influencing a local event.  The reply is that the influence is purely epistemic.  You have not changed your view about the causal structure of the world; you have merely come to learn that you are in a very special world, one whose global configuration virtually guarantees that any randomly selected coin is almost surely tails.  Learning global statistical constraints rationally changes local expectations without postulating new forces.  (Compare: learning that there are only a hundred albinos in the world makes it rationally nearly certain that a randomly chosen person is not an albino even though pigmentation genes remain causally independent across individuals.)

4.4 Learning from probability-zero events  
Can one ever rationally learn from something that had prior probability 0?  Orthodox Kolmogorov probability theory gives no general recipe but nothing prohibits extended Bayesian schemas.  Richard Jeffrey’s “radical probabilism” and Bas van Fraassen’s “conditionalisation on becoming certain” both allow credence revision toward 0 or 1 when faced with zero-measure evidence, provided the update is generated by an appropriate limiting procedure.  The appropriateness, in turn, is judged by whether the limiting conditional probabilities track the informational content of the evidence.  In our case they do; the 0-answer is therefore squarely in the spirit of sophisticated Bayesian epistemology.

5 Summing up  
We were told something that is both astonishing and, by our own lights, probabilistically impossible.  The information is epistemically potent because it tightly couples outcomes that were previously independent, producing overwhelming negative correlation.  A principled regularisation of Bayesian conditionalisation shows that, under that coupling, the chance that any particular coin—including yours—landed heads must sink to 0.  Independence arguments fail because they ignore the conditional structure; Dutch-book, reflection, and causal considerations either support or at least do not undermine the 0-verdict.

Accordingly, upon learning that only finitely many coins landed heads, rational credence that one’s own coin landed heads should fall from ½ to 0.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Learning that only finitely many heads were tossed in a countably‐infinite sequence of fair, independent coin flips is epistemically explosive.  The information you acquire is logically compatible with the original measure on outcomes, yet it sits in the very far recesses of that measure: it is an event to which the original probability is not merely tiny but exactly zero.  Because ordinary Bayesian conditionalisation is defined only for positive‐probability events, there is no automatic, uncontroversial recipe for updating on it.  That observation already suggests that reasonable people might differ about what one “ought” to believe after hearing the news.  Still, there is a natural, deeply rooted tradition— stretching from Borel through de Finetti to modern treatments of regular conditional probability—according to which your posterior credence that your own coin landed heads should plunge not to ½ but to 0.  In what follows I shall:

1.  Set out the intuitive tension between the “independence therefore ½” thought and the “finitely many heads therefore almost certainly tails” thought.  
2.  Show formally why, under any exchangeable and countably additive extension of the ordinary coin‐toss measure, the second thought wins: the conditional probability has to be 0.  
3.  Explain why the independence argument is fallacious once one takes conditionalisation seriously.  
4.  Discuss alternative updating schemes (Popper functions, Lewis’s imaging, etc.) and show why they either reproduce the 0 answer or make the posterior indeterminate.  
5.  Close with philosophical reflections on what the case teaches us about learning from zero‐probability information.

Because the question asks what “your credence should be,” I take our target to be a rational degree of belief rather than a purely mathematical conditional probability.  My claim is that, given the background of orthodox Kolmogorov probability and a broadly Bayesian attitude to updating, the rational credence is 0.

1.  A clash of intuitions  

   1.1  The independence intuition.  
   Each individual coin is fair and the flips are mutually independent.  Learning about other coins, one might think, does not affect the chances for yours.  Formally:

      P(H₀ = 1) = ½,    
      P(H₀ = 1 ∧ FinitelyManyHeads) = ?

   If H₀ is independent of the global event F (call it F), then

      P(H₀ = 1 ∧ F) = ½·P(F),

   whence Bayesian conditionalisation would yield ½ again.  So, by the simplest application of “independence is forever,” your credence stays at ½.

   1.2  The finitude intuition.  
   On the other hand, to say that only finitely many heads occurred among countably many flips is to say that almost every coin, indeed all but finitely many coins, came up tails.  If almost every coin is tails, why should you expect yours to be one of the privileged finitely many heads?  The natural reaction is that the chance must be 0, or at any rate exceedingly small.

We have a standoff, apparently produced by two equally compelling probabilistic principles.  To resolve it we must get more precise.

2.  The formal argument for a posterior of 0  

   2.1  Exchangeability.  
   The prior probability distribution is perfectly symmetric: relabelling the coins cannot affect probabilities.  In technical terms the sequence (H₀, H₁, H₂, …) is exchangeable.  Exchangeability survives conditionalisation provided the condition itself is permutation‐invariant.  Our condition F—“only finitely many heads in total”—is obviously permutation‐invariant.  Hence whatever posterior we adopt, it must still treat the coins symmetrically.  That is,

      For every n,   P(Hₙ = 1 | F) = p

   for some common value p between 0 and 1.

   2.2  Countable additivity.  
   Write N for the (possibly infinite) number of heads.  Because the indicators Hₙ are pairwise disjoint events of the form “coin n is the first head” etc., countable additivity implies

      E[N | F] = Σₙ P(Hₙ = 1 | F) = Σₙ p.

   Now F is the event that N is finite.  Consequently N is almost surely finite under the posterior, and hence its expected value E[N | F] must be finite as well.  The only way an infinite sum of identical non‐negative summands can be finite is if each summand is 0.  Therefore

      p = 0.

   So symmetry plus countable additivity force

      P(H₀ = 1 | F) = 0.

   There is no wiggle room; any exchangeable, countably additive posterior gives that answer.

   This argument is due in spirit to de Finetti (1931) and appears in modern textbooks under “the zero–one law for individual coordinates given tail events.”

3.  What went wrong with the independence intuition?  

   3.1  Independence is not preserved under conditioning.  
   Your coin is indeed independent, in the prior, of each finite subcollection of the others.  But it is not independent of a tail event—an event that depends on the infinite future of the sequence.  A quick check:

      Prior:   P(F) = 0 (as the strong law of large numbers entails infinitely many heads with probability 1).

      Counterfactual:   P(F | H₀ = 1) versus P(F | H₀ = 0).

   Intuitively, if you are told in advance that coin 0 landed heads, that makes it harder (never mind how much) for the totality of coins to end up with only finitely many heads; one head has already been “used up.”  So H₀ and F cannot be independent.  Because the event F itself had prior probability 0, the ordinary factorisation proofs of independence never even get off the ground.

   3.2  Conditional dependence is commonplace.  
   Elementary examples abound.  Two fair dice are independent.  Condition on their sum’s being 12, and they become perfectly correlated.  The present case is exactly the same pattern, except that “sum = 12” degrades to “finitely many heads,” an event of prior probability 0.  Once one appreciates that independence can evaporate under conditioning, the intuitive basis for staying at ½ collapses.

4.  Alternative updating methods  

   4.1  Popper‐Renyi conditional probability.  
   Several philosophers (notably Hajék and others) urge that rational credence be represented not by a single Kolmogorov function but by a Popper function or a Renyi conditional probability, which assigns primitives of the form P(A | B) for every B, including B of measure zero.  On the canonical construction for an exchangeable sequence of coin flips, the Popper conditional coincides with the argument in section 2, so again one gets 0.

   4.2  Lewis’s imaging.  
   Suppose, more unconventionally, that upon learning F you “shift” each possible world to the most similar F‐world (David Lewis’s imaging).  Because any heads‐world has to be moved to a tails‐world for all but finitely many coins, and because similarity is normally taken to preserve coin identities, the image of a world in which H₀ = 1 will usually be a world in which H₀ = 0.  Though models differ, the typical outcome once more credits 0 to H₀.

   4.3  Indeterminate credences.  
   Joyce, Levi, and others allow that, when conditioning on measure‐zero information, rationality may leave you with a set of permissible posteriors rather than a sharp one.  Even on that permissivist approach, however, ½ is hard to sustain.  Any posterior retaining the fair probability ½ for a single coin must, by symmetry, confer infinite expectation on N, in flat conflict with F.  Hence the set of permissible posteriors will contain only distributions driving P(H₀ = 1) all the way to 0.

5.  Philosophical morals  

   5.1  Learning the improbable.  
   The case dramatises how a rational agent can coherently “learn the impossible.”  Before you opened your ears the hypothesis “only finitely many heads” had credence 0.  Yet epistemic life goes on once you accept it.  What must give is the idea that conditionalisation rules alone settle every posterior; updates on zero events require a supplementary norm (e.g. “choose a regular conditional”, “extend by exchangeable Popper function”, etc.).  Given almost any such norm, however, the posterior for your own coin is 0, not ½.

   5.2  Dependence without causation.  
   Nothing causal connects your coin to the infinitely many others.  Nevertheless they become probabilistically dependent after the new evidence arrives.  Philosophers sometimes assimilate probabilistic dependence to causal influence, but the present example shows how misleading that assimilation can be.

   5.3  The power—and limits—of symmetry.  
   At an intuitive level, symmetry pulled both ways.  One symmetry consideration said “my coin is no different from any other; since at most finitely many are heads, almost surely mine is tails.”  Another said “my coin is no different now from before, so its probability remains ½.”  The formal analysis vindicates the first and exposes the second as resting on an illicit transfer of independence across the conditioning boundary.  In short, symmetry coupled with countable additivity is a potent argument, but one must deploy exactly the right symmetry: permutation of *labels* survives the update; independence generally does not.

   5.4  Countable versus finite additivity.  
   One way to rescue a ½ answer is to abandon countable additivity in favour of merely finite additivity.  De Finetti himself was open to that route.  If one drops σ‐additivity, the proof in section 2 fails.  Yet finite additivity courts paradoxes (Banach‐Tarski‐style) and has never won wide acceptance as a rational standard.  Moreover, there remain finitely additive representations that still give 0.  So the appeal to finite additivity saves ½ only at the cost of deep theoretical revision.

Conclusion  

A careful examination of the probabilistic structure shows that the remarkable announcement—that only finitely many of a countably infinite family of independent, fair coins came up heads—demands a radical update.  Once we condition on that zero‐probability tail event, exchangeability and countable additivity force the posterior probability that any particular coin was one of the few heads to drop to zero.  The superficial independence argument for retaining ½ falters because independence is not preserved under conditioning, least of all conditioning on an event of prior measure zero.  Alternative formalisms—Popper functions, Lewisian imaging, sets of credences—either reproduce the 0 verdict or withhold a determinate answer; none vindicate a steadfast ½ unless they depart in dramatic ways from the mainstream probabilistic norms.  Hence, on the most orthodox Bayesian analysis available, your rational credence that your own coin landed heads should not stay at ½; it should be 0.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
What should you believe about your own coin once you are told that, out of countably infinitely many fair and independent tosses, only finitely many came up heads?  Philosophers and probabilists are divided.  One reflex reaction is: “My coin is fair, it has a physical chance of ½, and nothing I have learned concerns its micro‐state, so my credence should stay ½.”  An opposite, equally reflexive reaction is: “Among an infinity of people, only finitely many were lucky enough to see heads; the chance that I—picked at random from the room—am one of this privileged finite group is effectively zero; so my credence in heads should plummet to 0.”  These two instincts pull in opposite directions, and the tension reveals deep issues about conditional probability, regularity, independence, and the relation between objective chance and epistemic probability.  I shall argue that the second instinct is correct: once you learn that only finitely many heads occurred, rational credence in the proposition “my coin landed heads” should be 0.  But I shall also explain why this answer is compatible with the coin’s objective ½ chance, why the symmetry of the situation does not force a ½ credence, and why the result does not impugn the usual maxim that “independent evidence never bears on independent events.”

1.  Setting the stage: the measure‐zero update  

Let Ω be the set of all infinite sequences of H (heads) and T (tails) indexed by the natural numbers 1,2,3,…, and let P be the usual product measure that makes the coordinates i.i.d. with P(H)=P(T)=½.  For person i the outcome of her coin is the i-th coordinate.  The event F we are told about is
 F = {ω ∈ Ω : only finitely many coordinates equal H}.
Because the probability that a fair coin lands heads is ½, the strong law of large numbers entails that with P‐probability 1 the limiting relative frequency of heads is ½, so almost surely infinitely many heads occur.  Hence P(F)=0.  We are therefore asked to condition on a measure‐zero event.  The usual Bayes formula
 P(A|F)=P(A∧F)/P(F)
is undefined.  One must therefore appeal to the more sophisticated concept of a regular conditional probability—a conditional distribution P(·|F) that assigns probabilities to events given F in a way that (roughly) respects countable additivity and agrees with Bayes on events of positive measure.  The bad news is that regular conditionals are not unique on null events.  The good news is that, in this particular problem, symmetry and the Kolmogorov extension theorem do single out a natural candidate, and it sets P(“my coin is heads” | F)=0.

2.  Why the “symmetry” argument for ½ fails  

A first thought is that since all coins are probabilistically identical, whatever credence I assign to my own coin should also be assigned to every other person’s coin.  So if I assign ½ to mine, I must assign ½ to each.  But then, summing expected numbers, I would expect infinitely many heads, contradicting the information that only finitely many heads occurred.  Something has to give.  The symmetry that matters after learning F is not “every coin is equally likely to be heads”; rather, it is “every coin is equally likely to be one of the (now known to be) finitely many heads.”  Because there are countably infinitely many coins but only finitely many heads, the probability that a given coin is among the heads must be 0.  The naïve symmetry argument overlooks the impact that F has on the joint distribution: the coins are no longer independent conditional on F, and their marginals are no longer ½.

3.  An approximation argument with finitely many coins  

Some philosophers distrust measure‐zero updates because uniqueness is not guaranteed.  One useful diagnostic is to approximate the infinite problem with a finite one on which ordinary conditioning works, then examine the limit.  Imagine first N people instead of countably many, and replace F by the event F_N that at most K_N heads occurred, where K_N = ⌊√N⌋.  For each fixed N, the event F_N has positive probability; hence conditional probabilities are unambiguous.  A brief calculation using hypergeometric distributions gives
 P(“my coin is heads” | F_N) = E[#heads]/N = K_N/N = √N/N = 1/√N,
for large N (ignoring negligible terms).  As N grows, this conditional probability shrinks to 0.  Because the events F_N converge “downward” to F and the conditional probabilities converge to 0, it is natural—indeed forced by any reasonable regularity‐preserving scheme—to set P(Head|F)=0 in the limit.

4.  Exchangeability and de Finetti’s theorem  

Another rigorous route uses exchangeability.  The family (X_1,X_2,…) of coin indicators (1 for head, 0 for tail) is exchangeable under the original measure.  According to de Finetti, there is a latent random parameter Θ, distributed Beta(1,1) (i.e. uniform on [0,1]), such that conditional on Θ the X_i are i.i.d. Bernoulli(Θ).  Under the original measure, Θ almost surely equals ½ (for the product measure), so the representation degenerates, but we can still use the idea heuristically: learning F tells us that the limiting frequency of heads is 0.  So, in every sequence compatible with F, the empirical average (1/n)Σ_{i≤n}X_i tends to 0.  By exchangeability, for any fixed i we have
 P(X_i = 1 | F) = lim_{n→∞} E[(1/n)Σ_{j≤n}X_j | F] = lim_{n→∞} 0 = 0.
Thus the conditional probability is 0.  Put another way, in any exchangeable model, if the total number of successes is finite almost surely, the probability that a randomly chosen index is a success is 0.

5.  Independence after conditioning  

A common objection is: “How can information about the other coins affect mine when all tosses were independent?”  The answer: independence is fragile; it does not in general survive conditioning.  Two events A and B that are independent under P can become dependent once we restrict attention to an event F that correlates them.  The classical Borel paradox makes the same point: latitude and longitude of a random point on a sphere are independent, but if you are told the point lies on (say) the north–south axis—a probability‐0 set—then latitude and longitude are perfectly correlated.  Likewise here: the event F essentially says, “The vast majority of coins landed tails,” which introduces a strong negative correlation among coin outcomes.  Given F, the fact that almost every other coin is tail is evidence that yours is too.

6.  Objective chance versus epistemic probability  

Isn’t the objective chance that the coin lands heads still ½?  Yes.  Nothing in the physics of the tosses has changed.  But epistemic probability tracks rational degrees of belief in light of one’s total evidence, not propensities per se.  Suppose you learn from a reliable oracle that a particular fair coin toss resulted in tails.  The objective chance of heads was ½, but your credence in heads should now be 0.  Evidence always trumps prior chances.  The present case is more subtle only because the evidence concerns the entire ensemble rather than the single toss, and because it has probability 0 given your prior.  But those facts do not insulate the toss from evidential impact.  The oracle’s message “finitely many heads” is logically compatible only with sequences in which your own toss is almost surely a tail.  Conditionals are sensitive to logical compatibility, not just to physical propensity.

7.  Arbitrary re‐labeling and the principle of indifference  

Another way to see why ½ is untenable invokes a variant of the “mantis shrimp” trick familiar from discussions of self‐locating probability.  After hearing F, imagine you are blindfolded and randomly re‐assigned a seat number by a drum lottery that permutes the countable list of people.  Because the underlying product measure is invariant under finite or even countable permutations, your credence distribution after re‐labeling must coincide with your earlier one.  But the expected number of heads in the first million seats, conditional on F, is some finite number M.  Invariance requires that each seat have the same conditional probability q of being heads; hence M = q·1,000,000.  Since M is finite but the number of seats tends to infinity, q must be 0.  This reasoning is a special case of a standard result in exchangeable probability called “Kingman’s paintbox.”

8.  Non‐uniqueness of regular conditionals and why uniqueness is restored here  

Kolmogorov’s axioms alone do not guarantee a unique conditional probability on null events.  In simple examples, one can write down different regular conditional distributions that disagree about P(A|F).  So a skeptic might claim that ½ is an equally legitimate conditional as 0.  However, additional natural constraints do pin things down.  One such constraint is “consistency under finite approximations”: any candidate conditional should be the limit of ordinary conditionals on a decreasing sequence of positive‐measure events that approximate F.  The K_N approximation in §3 yields the limit 0, not ½.  A second constraint is “permutation invariance”: there is no fact of the matter about which labels 1,2,3,… attach to which people, so any admissible conditional must commute with all finite permutations of indices.  It can be proved (and has been, e.g. by Berti, Pratelli & Rigo, 2007) that under such constraints the conditional is unique, and in the present case assigns probability 0 to any fixed coin being heads.

9.  Practical Bayesianism: how a finite Bayesian would reason  

Imagine a colossal but finite Bayesian who, before learning F, assigns the standard product‐measure prior to an explicit cutoff N = 10^{100}.  She learns that at most one million heads have occurred.  Ordinary Bayesian updating then gives her posterior credence in “my coin is heads” as ≤10^{6}/10^{100}=10^{-94}.  The posterior is therefore extremely low, not ½.  If she now declares herself willing to raise her cutoff—“I was never committed to N=10^{100}; I can allow any finite N”—then in the limit as N→∞ her posterior tends to 0.  That limiting posterior is precisely the regular conditional we have identified.

10.  Philosophical morals  

a.  Evidence about the global configuration of an infinite system can rationally alter beliefs about a local component, even when the physical chances remain fixed.  Objectivity of chance and independence are not sufficient for doxastic inertia.  
b.  Conditioning on measure‐zero events is coherent provided one supplements Kolmogorov with reasonable regularity constraints.  In the present case, those constraints lead unambiguously to the 0 answer.  
c.  The case illustrates the subtlety of the Principle of Indifference.  If you apply it naïvely—“I have no reason to favor heads over tails”—you get ½.  But once you incorporate all your information, you do have a reason: it is massively more plausible that you are one of the countably infinite tails than one of the rare heads.  
d.  The reasoning generalizes: whenever you are one member of an infinite exchangeable population and you learn that only finitely many members satisfy a certain property, your credence that you yourself satisfy it must be 0.

11.  Replies to three objections  

Objection 1: “The update makes me certain my coin is tails, yet I acknowledge a ½ chance in the physical sense.  Isn’t that inconsistent?”  
Reply: No.  The two statements concern different modalities.  You are certain, epistemically, that you are in the tails subset of the actual world, but you concede that in the space of nomologically possible worlds, roughly half the worlds have your coin head.  Certainty about actuality coexists with modal uncertainty.

Objection 2: “If my credence is 0, I would pay an arbitrarily large finite sum for a bet that pays only \$1 if my coin is tails.  But that seems absurd.”  
Reply: The bet hypothetical is misleading.  Two things you would almost surely do after learning F are (i) refuse any stake, however small, that pays \$1 on heads, and (ii) accept any stake, however large and finite, that pays \$1 on tails.  Given the information you possess, that is perfectly coherent: the event that costs you money has conditional probability 0.  The scenario is not incoherent; it is just extreme.

Objection 3: “But couldn’t a different regular conditional, maybe one that exploits non‐measurable pathologies, give ½?”  
Reply: Yes in principle, no in practice.  Without additional constraints Kolmogorov does not fix a unique conditional.  But Bayesianism typically presupposes some normative principles beyond mere sigma‐additivity: e.g. approximate consistency, permutation invariance, and countable supervenience on one’s credences about finite sub‐algebras.  Under any such principle the 0 answer emerges.  The ½ proposal survives only by rejecting those very principles and embracing non‐measurable constructions that have no empirical or decision‐theoretic justification.

12.  Summation  

The question poses an apparent paradox: how can new information about events elsewhere in an independent system affect your belief about the outcome of your own fair coin?  The resolution is that while independence holds unconditionally, it is destroyed by conditioning on the global, highly informative event F.  Any regular approach to conditional probability—whether via finite approximations, exchangeability, or invariance—makes your posterior credence in heads collapse from ½ to 0.  Far from violating probability theory, this collapse is demanded by it once one recognizes that (i) F is a probability‐0 event, (ii) conditional independence generally fails on such events, and (iii) symmetry requires that the few heads in F be spread so thinly across the countably infinite population that the chance of being one of them is null.  Thus rational belief differs from objective chance: the toss objectively remains a 50–50 gamble, but, given the astonishing oracle testimony that only finitely many heads occurred, you should be certain, for all practical purposes, that yours was not among them.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Only finitely many heads have occurred.

Those five words force us into a region of probability theory and formal epistemology where several apparently straightforward principles come apart.  At first sight there are two natural reactions.

A.  Independence:  “My coin is fair and independent of the others; nothing I have learned makes it more or less likely to be heads.  My credence should stay at ½.”

B.  Scarcity:  “I now know there are only finitely many heads spread over countably many coins.  That makes the proportion of heads zero.  The chance that my particular coin is one of the rare heads must therefore be 0.”

The puzzle, then, is to decide whether (A) or (B) is the correct response—or whether something has gone wrong in the way the question is framed.  I shall argue for (B): after learning that only finitely many heads were tossed, a rational agent should assign credence 0 to her own coin’s landing heads.  On the way to that conclusion I will

1.  make precise the mathematical framework;
2.  explain why naively appealing to independence is a fallacy once one conditions on an event of probability 0;
3.  construct a regular conditional probability that delivers credence 0 and show why no rival construction can deliver ½ without violating standard Bayesian norms; and
4.  reflect on the philosophical morals for learning from “measure-zero” information.

1.  The probabilistic set-up  

Let Ω be the product space {H, T}^{ℕ}.  Write X_n(ω) = 1 if the n-th coin in outcome ω is heads, 0 otherwise, and let P be the usual product measure generated by independent fair coins (so P(X_n = 1) = ½ and the X_n are mutually independent).  Put  

F  := {ω ∈ Ω : Σ_{n=1}^{∞} X_n(ω) is finite}.

Classic results—Kolmogorov’s 0–1 law or the second Borel-Cantelli lemma—tell us that P(F) = 0.  Indeed, with probability 1 there are infinitely many heads and infinitely many tails.

We have therefore been told that an event of probability 0 happened.  If one insists on a purely frequentist construal of “chance,” that very announcement looks incoherent; but Bayesian epistemology, decision theory, and modern statistics all allow conditioning on measure-zero events via regular conditional probabilities.  The question becomes what conditional probability P(X_0 = 1 | F) ought to be taken to mean and what value it should receive.

2.  Why “independence” stops just where the puzzle starts  

The first impulse is to invoke independence.  The trouble is that independence is formulated for unconditional probabilities.  The proposition “X_0 is independent of F” means  

P(X_0 = 1 ∧ F) = P(X_0 = 1)·P(F).

Both sides of that equation are 0, so independence obtains trivially.  But it does not follow that  

P(X_0 = 1 | F) = P(X_0 = 1).

Whenever P(F) > 0, independence guarantees that equality; when P(F)=0 the conditional probability is not defined by the usual ratio and further work is needed.  To see why the intuitive independence argument fails, consider a simpler finite illustration.

Finite analogy.  Two fair coins are tossed.  Let E be the event “the two coins differ.”  E has probability ½.  Condition on E.  Given E, the coins are perfectly anticorrelated, not independent: P(first is heads | E) = ½ but P(first is heads ∧ second is heads | E) = 0.  Merely learning that E holds destroys independence, even though each coin’s toss was physically independent.  In our infinite case, learning F will likewise create correlations; we cannot assume that X_0 retains its prior probability.

3.  Constructing a regular conditional distribution  

Bayesians need a principled way to update on F.  Kolmogorov’s theory supplies one: for every σ-algebra ℱ there exists (on nice spaces such as Ω) a regular conditional probability P(· | ℱ).  Taking ℱ = σ(F), we seek a probability measure Q_F such that for any event A in Ω,  

(i)   Q_F(A) is a measurable function of ω constant on F and on Fᶜ,  
(ii)  ∫_F Q_F(A) dP = P(A ∧ F).

Because P(F)=0, (ii) does not pin down a unique value of Q_F(A) on F; but additional symmetries of the underlying probability space often single out a “natural” conditional.  That is what happens here.

Shift invariance.  Let S be the left-shift operator on Ω: (Sω)_n = ω_{n+1}.  P is S-invariant.  Furthermore, F is shift invariant; if ω has only finitely many heads, so does Sω, and vice-versa.  A standard ergodic-theoretic argument shows that any regular conditional measure Q_F that preserves the shift symmetry among coordinates must assign probability 0 to X_0 = 1.  Sketch:

1.  For each n, let H_n be {ω : X_n(ω)=1}.  Because of shift symmetry, Q_F(H_n) must take the same value for every n.  Call that value r.

2.  The expected number of heads under Q_F is then Σ_{n=1}^{∞} r, which is 0 if r=0 and infinite otherwise.

3.  But by definition of Q_F, that expected number must be finite—F entails finitely many heads.  The only way to reconcile finitude with countable additivity is to have r=0.

Thus symmetry alone drives us to r = 0.  More concretely, one can approximate F by the increasing family of finite events F_k = {at most k heads}.  For each k, the ordinary conditional probability

P_k(X_0 = 1) := P(X_0 = 1 | F_k)

can be calculated explicitly:

Let S_{≠0} be the sum of heads among the other coins.  Then

P_k(X_0=1 ∧ F_k) = ½ · P(S_{≠0} ≤ k-1),  
P(F_k)           = ½ · P(S_{≠0} ≤ k) + ½ · P(S_{≠0} ≤ k-1).

Hence

P_k(X_0=1) = P(S_{≠0} ≤ k-1) / [P(S_{≠0} ≤ k) + P(S_{≠0} ≤ k-1)].

Now P(S_{≠0} ≤ m) → 0 as m→∞ (with an astronomically fast super-exponential rate).  The numerator and denominator both go to 0, but the numerator does so at least as fast as the denominator, driving the ratio to 0.  Taking the limit along this canonical approximating sequence gives Q_F(H_0)=0.

Any attempt to obtain ½ must therefore abandon either shift invariance or countable additivity.  The first step would be ad hoc—why privilege one person over another?  The second would be a radical departure from classical Bayesianism.  Absent such departures, credence 0 is forced.

4.  Objections answered  

a)  “But someone’s coin did come up heads”  

It is tempting to reason: F is compatible with, say, exactly 7 heads.  Conditional on exactly 7 heads, the expected number of heads is 7, so the average conditional probability across coins is 7/ω(∞) = 0.  No contradiction.  Indeed, under Q_F, the event “some coin is heads” has probability 1, while each individual coin’s probability of being heads is 0.  That is not paradoxical; it is simply an instance of countable additivity in an infinite space.

b)  “My coin was designated in advance—doesn’t that matter?”  

Yes, and it is the reason the answer is 0 rather than something like “undefined.”  If one were to pick a coin uniformly at random from among the infinitely many people, the very idea of “uniformly at random” breaks down; different regularizations would lead to different answers.  Because the problem fixes a particular person (you), we can use the symmetry argument above.   

c)  “Doesn’t conditionalization on probability-zero events undercut Bayesian methodology?”  

No.  A regular conditional probability is as canonical and well-behaved as the ordinary ratio definition when the conditioning event has positive measure.  The seeming pathology comes from our intuitions, honed on finite cases, not from the mathematics.  Moreover, in decision theory we often do need to update on what, ex ante, was thought virtually impossible (Black Swan events).  Doing so coherently requires the very machinery deployed here.

5.  Philosophical upshot  

(i)  Independence is fragile.  Physical independence of data-generating processes does not generally survive epistemic conditioning.

(ii)  Scarcity beats symmetry when there is an infinite population.  Even though every coin has the same prior properties, the global information that heads are scarce makes it rational to believe almost surely any given coin is tails.

(iii)  Measure-zero learning is coherent—so long as one follows the formal rules.  In finite probability theory, the formula P(A | B) = P(A ∧ B)/P(B) suffices.  In the infinite setting, one needs the full apparatus of regular conditional probabilities plus the symmetries of the problem to pin down the right posterior.

(iv)  Infinite additivity matters.  Someone might protest that it is strange for every individual probability to be 0 while the probability that “somebody got heads” is 1.  But that consequence flows straight from countable additivity, a foundational axiom of Kolmogorovian probability.  Abandoning that axiom creates far more problems than it solves.

(v)  Practical moral.  Suppose an experimenter announces an outcome that, according to your prior, had probability 0.  You can still update rationally; but you must beware of implicit independence assumptions.  A shift in the global pattern of data can drastically change the evidential relevance of local facts.

6.  Conclusion  

Under the standard Bayesian conception of rational belief, augmented by the theory of regular conditional probabilities and guided by the symmetries of the infinite product measure, the credence that your own coin landed heads, given that only finitely many coins did, should be 0, not ½.  The intuition that “nothing has changed about my coin” overlooks the fact that the very meaning of “independent” changes once one incorporates global information of measure-zero probability.  Far from revealing a flaw in Bayesian reasoning, the puzzle illustrates its subtlety and strength: when the impossible becomes actual, the rational agent can still learn, and the content of that learning can be mathematically—and philosophically—precise.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
Self‐locating belief, infinitary probability, and the problem of conditioning on measure–zero propositions all come together in the “countable miracle” you are asked to assess.  The situation appears simple—every coin is fair, mine included—but the information I later receive (“only finitely many heads were tossed”) is so extraordinary that it is assigned probability 0 by the very theory I am using to model the coins.  Classical conditionalisation therefore cannot be applied in the usual way, and we must decide how to update when the evidence has prior probability 0.  Philosophers disagree about how such updates should be handled, and (as I shall argue) two quite natural updating rules lead to two different answers.  In what follows I (i) formalise the problem, (ii) explain why the standard Kolmogorov framework goes silent, (iii) present and evaluate two rival updating principles—“symmetry-based” and “typical-member” updating—and (iv) offer a tentative verdict.  I end by drawing a moral about the limits of purely probabilistic reasoning in infinitary, self-locating cases.

1.  Formal set-up  

Let Ω be the set of sequences ω = (ω₁,ω₂,…) with ωᵢ ∈ {H,T}.  Equip Ω with the usual product σ-algebra and the fair product measure P under which the coordinates (X₁,X₂,…) are IID Bernoulli(½).  Let

E  = {ω ∈ Ω :  #{i : ωᵢ = H} < ∞ }.

E says “only finitely many heads occur.”  For each n ∈ ℕ define

E_n = {ω :    #{i ≤ n : ωᵢ = H}  ≤ n  and  ωᵢ = T  for all i > n }.

E_n is the event that after time n every toss is tails.  E is the union of countably many events of this type:

E = ⋃_{m=0}^∞  {ω : there exists N such that  #{i≤N : ωᵢ = H} = m  and ωᵢ = T for i>N} 
    = ⋃_{N=0}^∞  E_N.

Every E_N has probability 0 (because the chances that the sequence eventually “locks in” are zero), hence P(E)=0.

Our question: given the information E, what should

P*(H₁)  =  P(X₁ = H  |  E)

be?  (H₁ abbreviates {ω : ω₁=H}.)  The problem is that P(·|E) is undefined in orthodox probability theory.

2.  Why ordinary conditionalisation fails  

Bayes’ rule tells us
          P(A|E) = P(A∩E) / P(E),
provided P(E) ≠ 0.  Since P(E)=0, the ratio 0/0 is not defined.  Mathematicians handle such cases with “regular conditional probabilities” (RCPs).  An RCP is a σ-additive family of measures {P_E(·)}_E defined on a sub-σ-algebra such that, for measurable F,   P(F∩E) = ∫_E  P_E(F)  dP.  But RCPs are only unique up to P-null sets.  As soon as a conditioning event itself is P-null, nothing in Kolmogorov’s axioms pins down a single conditional distribution.  In our case there are in fact many RCPs compatible with the product measure; some make P_E(H₁)=½, some make it 0, and some make it any value between.  That is the mathematical reflection of a philosophical freedom: before we say what our new credence should be we must choose an updating principle that resolves the indeterminacy.

3.  Two prominent philosophical principles  

3.1  Symmetry‐based updating—stay at ½  

One influential idea, descended from de Finetti and van Fraassen, is that an agent who learns a tailor-made, measure-zero proposition should take a limit of “nearby” positive‐probability propositions.  The most straightforward family to use are the events

F_k  = {ω : #{i≤k : ωᵢ = H} < ∞ }.

Note that F_k has probability 1 (there are only finitely many tosses up to time k), so P(H₁|F_k)=½ by plain independence.  If one lets k→∞, the sequence F_k tends downwards to the tail σ-algebra event E.  By ∗continuity of conditional probabilities∗ one thereby obtains

lim_{k→∞} P(H₁ | F_k) = ½.

This conclusion is buttressed by the following symmetry‐argument: (i) each coin is exchangeable, (ii) the fact that “only finitely many heads occur” is permutation-invariant, and (iii) under an exchangeable prior, symmetry demands identical posteriors for each coordinate.  If every coin must have the same conditional distribution and the total number of heads is finite, that distribution cannot be 0 (all tails) or 1 (all heads); the only candidate is ½ itself.  In effect, the new information concerns the global pattern of the sequence and, by invariance, does not single out coin 1 in any special way.  Many philosophers take this to show that one’s credence should remain ½.

3.2  Typical-member updating—go to 0  

A different line of thought takes as basic the idea that “I am one member of a countably infinite population but did not receive any label entitling me to special treatment.”  Given E, there are only finitely many heads.  If I regard myself as a randomly selected (self‐locating) observer from the population, the chance that I am one of those finitely many special individuals appears to be 0.  A vivid way to see this is to let H be the set of people whose coin showed heads.  Under E, H is finite, the complement H^c is infinite, and the natural density of H within the people is 0.  So by the Principal Principle connecting objective chances with rational credence, the right posterior for my coin is 0 (or at least “arbitrarily close to 0”).

Formalising this intuition, one constructs a different approximating family of events.  Let

G_m = {ω : #{i : ωᵢ = H} ≤ m }.

For each m, both the numerator and denominator of P(H₁|G_m) are positive (though tiny).  Because of exchangeability,
         P(H₁ & G_m) = 2^{-1} P(G_{m-1}),
while
         P(G_m)      =       P(G_m).

Hence
         P(H₁ | G_m) =  (½) P(G_{m-1}) / P(G_m).

As m→∞ the ratio P(G_{m-1}) / P(G_m) tends to 0 (intuitively: requiring one fewer head is a negligible tightening of a probability‐0 constraint), so the conditional probability goes to 0.  One can also use martingale theory: the fraction of heads after n tosses is a martingale that almost surely converges to ½, but upon conditioning on the event that the limiting average is 0, the martingale collapses to 0 at every finite stage.  That gives a rigorous conditional probability making P_E(H₁)=0.  (Technically, one is choosing an RCP that transforms the sequence of IID Bernoulli(½) variables into IID Bernoulli(0) variables.)

Advocates of typical-member updating further note that some decision‐theoretic recommendations support the 0 verdict.  Suppose everyone who got heads will be executed unless at least one of them happens to draw a joker from an infinite deck.  Before learning E your chances of being executed are ½.  After learning “only finitely many heads”, the expected number of condemned persons is finite, but the number of safe persons is infinite; your personal chance of being in danger therefore vanishes to 0 (javian-characteristic “dilution”).  Action-guidance lines up with the 0 answer.

4.  Weighing the arguments  

4.1  Independence is a red herring.  The datum E is not independent of my coin; indeed H₁ ⊂ Ē  implies dependence.  So the mere fact that X₁’s outcome was settled by an independent physical process does not guarantee that its conditional distribution stays the same.  That point favours the typical-member camp, at least insofar as it undercuts the simplest objection to any change of credence.

4.2  Exchangeability does not decide the issue.  True, every coin is exchangeable, but an exchangeable prior may have multiple exchangeable RCPs on E.  The ½-updaters choose one, the 0-updaters another.  Symmetry itself therefore underdetermines the answer; one needs tie-breakers such as “preserve marginal probabilities when possible” (favouring ½) or “apply anthropic typicality” (favouring 0).

4.3  Handling of self-locating belief.  If one thinks the problem is essentially anthropic—“what are the odds that I am one of the remarkable few?”—the typical-member perspective seems tailor-made.  But if one insists that person 1 is objectively singled out (I know I am agent #1), self-location is no longer modal; then the symmetry that links me to the other agents is broken, and the force of the dilution argument weakens.  The two camps tacitly adopt different attitudes toward personal indexicals.

4.4  Decision theoretic tests.  Suppose you may sell a ticket paying £1 if your coin shows heads; what price is coherent given E?  Under the ½ rule you value the ticket at 50p.  But imagine the social pool of all such tickets were bought by an outside bookmaker.  Knowing E, the bookmaker can be sure that he will have to pay out only finitely many pounds while he collects infinitely many 50p premiums, guaranteeing infinite profit.  Agents following the ½ rule would be collectively exploitable.  Typical-member updating removes the Dutch book—each ticket is deemed worthless—so collective coherence considerations point toward 0.

4.5  Compatibility with alternative probability axioms.  Jeffrey conditionalisation, imaging, or Kullback-Leibler projection can each be extended to measure-zero updates.  Minimal‐information projection (a.k.a. “entropic updating”) would choose the posterior that minimises KL-divergence subject to E; that posterior forces every coin to be tails almost surely, thereby yielding credence 0.  By contrast “centered” Radon–Nikodym RCPs (as used in Bayes nets) give credence ½.  Which meta-principle is more fundamental is, of course, open to debate.

5.  A tentative verdict and a moral  

The case exhibits a genuine underdetermination: orthodox probability theory plus the bare descriptive set‐up do not single out a unique posterior.  You must import an extra updating norm.  If you treat yourself as a fixed, labelled subject you have weak reason to preserve the ½ prior; if you count yourself as a randomly sampled member of an actually infinite population—and if you accept minimal-information updating or anthropic typicality—your credence rationally plummets to 0.  Because the story as told in the problem statement is silent about whether I am “person #1” or merely “somebody in the room”, I judge the second interpretation the more natural and therefore conclude:

After hearing that only finitely many heads were tossed, one ought to adopt credence 0 that one’s own coin landed heads.

But I also recognise that the rival ½ verdict can be justified by a different, equally coherent modelling choice.  The lesson is that rationality constraints inside Kolmogorov probability do not always fix a unique answer in measure-zero, self-locating problems; philosophical work is required to choose an updating principle, and the choice can reflect deep commitments about identity, symmetry, and typicality.

question: Consider the following case: You are in a room with a countable infinity of people, and each of you flips a fair coin without looking at the result. You know that all the coin flips are fair and independent. You are then informed that something remarkable happened: only finitely many coins landed heads. What should your credence be that your coin landed heads? Should it remain at 1/2, or should it change? Provide arguments for your answer.
answer:
What follows is a sustained attempt to think through the epistemic situation in which you find yourself after learning that, among countably many independent fair‐coin trials, only finitely many came up heads.  Because the announced event has classical probability 0, it puts pressure on the usual Bayesian recipe for conditionalising on evidence.  Yet the case is not a mere curiosity: it sharpens familiar puzzles about updating on measure–zero propositions, about the interaction of symmetry with infinite collections, and about the conceptual content of probabilistic independence.  I shall proceed in five stages.  First, I give a precise mathematical characterisation of the evidence.  Second, I sketch three routes for extending Bayesian conditionalisation to measure–zero events, each of which suggests that the posterior probability of “my coin is heads’’ is 0.  Third, I address the intuitive worry that independence should ‘protect’ your original ½ credence.  Fourth, I consider objections drawn from self-locating uncertainty and from the Reflection principle.  Finally, I summarise why, despite those objections, the rational credence is (virtually) 0.

1.  Formal set-up  

Let ω = (ω₁, ω₂, …) be an element of the product space {H,T}^{ℕ}, endowed with the usual product σ-algebra and fair product measure P, so that the ωₙ’s are i.i.d. fair outcomes.  Let H₁ be the event {ω : ω₁ = H}, and let  
 F := {ω : only finitely many n satisfy ωₙ = H}.  
By the strong law of large numbers, P(F) = 0; indeed P-almost surely the relative frequency of heads converges to ½, so the number of heads diverges.  You are told that F has happened.  What, if anything, is P(H₁ | F)?

When the conditioning event has probability 0, the usual definition  
 P(A|B) = P(A∩B)/P(B)  
is undefined.  Bayesian orthodoxy therefore requires an extension—either by taking suitable limits, or by positing infinitesimal probabilities, or by invoking a regular conditional probability (RCP).  I examine each approach in turn.

2.  Three paths to a posterior of 0  

2.1  Limiting approximations  

Fix k ∈ ℕ and consider, for each finite N > k, the event  
 F_{k,N} := “among the first N coins, at most k are heads’’.  
For every finite N, P(F_{k,N}) > 0, so ordinary conditioning works.  Let H₁ be as before.  An elementary combinatorial calculation yields  

P_N(H₁ | F_{k,N})  
  = [Σ_{h=0}^{k-1} (N-1 choose h)] / [Σ_{h=0}^{k} (N  choose h)].  

Since (N-1 choose h) / (N  choose h) = (N-h)/N, the numerator is at most k/N times the denominator.  Hence  

0 ≤ P_N(H₁ | F_{k,N}) ≤ k/N.  

Let N → ∞ while k is held fixed; then k/N → 0.  Now let k range over ℕ and note that F = ⋃_{k} ⋂_{N≥k} F_{k,N}.  Taking a suitable double limit (or employing a standard Daniell–Kolmogorov RCP construction) gives  

P(H₁ | F) = lim_{k→∞} lim_{N→∞} P_N(H₁ | F_{k,N}) = 0.  

In short: for any finite upper bound k on the number of heads in a sufficiently large initial segment, your chance of being one of those heads is at most k/N; as the segment grows without bound, that chance tends to 0.

2.2  Regular conditional probability  

Measure theory assures us that for exchangeable product measures on countably infinite sequences there exists an RCP: a measurable function ω ↦ P(•|E)(ω) that behaves, for P-almost every ω, like an ordinary conditional distribution even when P(E)=0.  If we use de Finetti’s representation, the product measure can be viewed as a mixture of Bernoulli(θ) distributions with respect to the Beta(1,1) (i.e. uniform) prior on θ.  The event F corresponds to θ = 0: only if the limiting frequency of heads were 0 could there be at most finitely many heads.  Given F, the posterior on θ collapses to a point mass at 0, and conditional on θ=0 every ωₙ is almost surely T.  The RCP therefore assigns  

P(H₁ | F) = 0.  

2.3  Infinitesimal probabilities  

Some Bayesians prefer to model “probability-0 but possible’’ events by enriching the real unit interval with infinitesimals (e.g. via a hyperreal field).  One spreads the initial fair measure to give F a positive infinitesimal weight ε.  Because the construction is again symmetric, the mass of worlds in which both F and H₁ occur is of order ε·0: the joint event “F and H₁’’ inherits an even smaller infinitesimal weight, for the same combinatorial reasons as under 2.1.  Dividing infinitesimal by infinitesimal, one finds that the ratio is 0 in the standard part.  Thus even on a non-Archimedean implementation the posterior is infinitesimally close to 0.

All three frameworks—limiting, RCP, infinitesimal—converge on the verdict that, once you learn F, you should be virtually certain that your coin came up tails.

3.  Why independence does not freeze the prior at ½  

A natural objection is that your toss was statistically independent of all the others; therefore, knowledge about them should not influence the probability of your own result.  The objection trades on an ambiguity:  

Unconditional independence:  P(H₁ ∧ G) = P(H₁)·P(G) for every G generated by the other flips.  This indeed holds.  

Conditional independence:  For all G, P(H₁|G) = P(H₁).  This is false in general.  

If the objection were sound, no evidence about other flips—no matter how specific—could ever shift your credence about your own flip.  But consider the finite analogue: two coins are tossed independently and fairly; you learn that at most one landed heads.  Now the results are negatively correlated, and P(“my coin is heads’’ | “at most one head’’) = ½·0 + ½·1 / (¾) = ⅓ < ½.  Independence is not preserved under conditioning on relational information.  Likewise, in the infinite case, conditioning on F introduces massive negative correlation among the flips, driving the conditional chance of H₁ down to 0.

The moral is that independence is a statement about the joint prior, not a guarantee that all conditional distributions remain factorised after updating on evidence that links the variables.

4.  Two philosophical worries addressed  

4.1  Self-location and the ‘random observer’  

One might argue that although only finitely many heads occurred, you have no reason to think you are not one of them; after all, from the inside each person is subjectively indistinguishable.  Were we allowed to impose a uniform distribution over which agent you are, symmetry would push P(H₁|F) back to ½.  But there is no countably additive uniform distribution over ℕ.  Any probability measure absolutely continuous with respect to counting measure assigns 0 to every individual index.  Once we are told that only finitely many indices carry the property H, the measure of belonging to that finite subset is 0.  The same conclusion follows from anthropic ‘random-assignment’ considerations standardly used in infinite Sleeping Beauty variants.  Symmetry is respected; it simply fails to yield a non-zero probability of landing in a finite cell of an infinite partition.

4.2  Reflection and ‘unforeseen evidence’  

How can Bayesian epistemology require you to move to credence 0 in an event you originally thought had probability ½, when you also assigned probability 0 to ever receiving the evidence F?  Won’t the Reflection principle forbid this shift on pain of dynamic incoherence?

The short answer is that Reflection applies only to updates on events to which you assigned positive probability (de Separated by a row of blank lines to avoid misinterpretation   Finetti’s “probability 0 does not mean impossibility’’ slogan notwithstanding).  In standard Dutch-book arguments, learning a probability-0 event is modelled by an ideal limit of probability-ε events.  You were not, and could not rationally have been, certain about what credence you would adopt conditional on a datum you deemed impossible‐to‐happen; so Reflection is silent.

A longer answer draws on recent work by Rescorla, Steele, and others on dilations and nonmeasurable updates.  The prescription “posterior = appropriate regular conditional probability’’ maximises expected epistemic utility subject to the total evidence norm.  Failing to update to 0 would expose you to accuracy dominance: by your own lights, any other agent whose posteriors coincide with the RCP beats you in squared-error expectation.

5.  Summation
