The hierarchical model therefore seems tailor-made to explain why some adjusted preferences remain autonomous: people often make peace with genuine constraints. A paraplegic who learns to value wheelchair basketball over mountaineering is not thereby alienated from herself; she may second-order endorse her new sports preferences wholeheartedly.

But the model fares poorly in paradigmatic cases of oppressive adaptation. Consider the village girl who has been told since birth that educating women undermines family honour. She not only claims to lack interest in schooling, she sincerely repudiates such aspirations when she introspects. On Frankfurt’s test, her desire appears autonomous, since it is endorsed at the second order. Yet many of us balk: the stability of her endorsement results from a sustained deprivation of information, options, and counter-narratives. The problem seems not to be located within her current motivational hierarchy alone. What is missing is any check on whether higher-order endorsement itself has been distorted by social power.

Attempts to patch up the hierarchical account by adding a “wholeheartedness” or “authenticity” condition do not resolve the difficulty. The villager may indeed be perfectly wholehearted; the entire structure of her culture confirms that submissiveness is honourable. Frankfurt’s approach offers no criterion to distinguish wholeheartedness born of independent reflection from wholeheartedness produced by an oppressive upbringing. It risks an excessively internalist picture in which any desire that the agent comfortably owns here and now passes muster, no matter how malign the forces that shaped her comfort level.

Some subjectivists respond by embedding their model in a richer procedural framework. They propose, for instance, that autonomy requires exposure to critical reflection, imaginative rehearsal of alternatives, or dialogical challenge. If the villager had never seriously considered an alternative life, her second-order endorsement is “procedurally defective.” This move edges the subjectivist view toward a historically sensitive analysis, since the required critical capacities and information depend on the agent’s past. Still, once one appeals to such broader social conditions, the distinctive explanatory depth of the pure hierarchical model is lost; the heavy work is done by historical variables.

II. The Content-Based Account

A quite different strategy, associated with Martha Nussbaum, Amartya Sen, and capability theorists, holds that certain life activities and goods are objectively central to human flourishing. If a preference is forgoing, say, bodily health, practical reasoning, or affiliation, then the preference itself is suspect. The woman who “prefers” female genital cutting or illiteracy is less than fully autonomous because her preference endorses a genuine harm. Were she functioning properly, she would recognise this; her apparent endorsement is an indicator of adaptive degradation.

Content‐based approaches capture an important moral insight. Oppression can warp people’s desires so that they welcome their own subordination; identifying and criticising that content is sometimes indispensable. Moreover, these accounts explain why our negative judgment is strongest when the adapted preference concerns urgent capabilities (e.g., bodily integrity) rather than more trivial options (preferring coffee to tea because the shop is out of tea seems innocuous).

Yet content-based theories face two formidable objections.

1. Paternalism. Declaring that certain preferences are not truly the agent’s because they deviate from an external list can slide into paternalistic disrespect. Many feminists warn that outsiders may too quickly brand some minority practices “autonomy-reducing,” imposing their own cultural standards.

2. Conflation of Autonomy with Well-Being. Autonomy concerns self‐government, not whether the self happens to govern badly. A person can autonomously choose an objectively poor life, just as she can autonomously gamble away her fortune. Substance theorists risk collapsing the distinction between living well and living self-directedly.

To illustrate, imagine an ascetic monk who wholeheartedly, and after critical reflection, prefers a life of material deprivation. On a strict capability metric, his preference threatens basic human functioning. Yet it would be odd to deem him non-autonomous. He has not adjusted under oppressive constraint but out of religious commitment. The content of his preference alone cannot settle the autonomy question.

This gap is even clearer with “trivial” adaptive preferences. Suppose a commuter in a strike-bound city comes to enjoy bicycling; his desire has adapted to the unavailability of trains. The content (liking cycling) is benign, but the causal story is still adaptive. We normally see no autonomy deficit here. Therefore content-based accounts over-generate judgments of non-autonomy when they treat any preference involving reduced capabilities as suspect, and under-generate when the harmed capability is not on the list.

III. The Historical Account

Historical theories locate autonomy in the diachronic trajectory of preference formation. What matters is whether the agent had adequate opportunities, information, critical scrutiny, and social space to accept or reject a preference as it emerged. The dominant line, pioneered by Diana Meyers, Natalie Stoljar, Marina Oshana, and Paul Benson, insists that autonomy requires “new explanatory spaces” connecting agency to social power.

Adaptive preferences under oppression are exactly those shaped by histories of multifaceted constraint: material deprivation, cultural devaluation, false consciousness, habituation, or threats of sanction. These mechanisms neither force moment-to-moment behaviour nor completely silence reflection; rather, they channel the developmental environment so that certain options never present themselves as live possibilities, or present themselves only as shameful, dangerous, or unnatural. The resulting preference may be wholeheartedly embraced, and its content might not be obviously disvaluable (imagine preferring house-work to wage labour), but nonetheless it originates in a process systematically engineered to serve another group’s interests.

Historical accounts can accommodate three features that confound rival theories.

1. The Autonomy/Well-Being Distinction. Because they focus on genesis rather than content, historical models can say that the commuter’s newfound love of cycling is autonomous: it arose from a temporary, non-oppressive shortage of trains, a constraint not intended to keep him subservient. By contrast, the oppressed villager’s disdain for education emerged from a patriarchal structure aimed at entrenching gender power. Autonomy deficits track oppressive causal pathways, not mere disadvantage.

2. Variability Among Adaptive Preferences. Not every adaptation is suspect. If a paraplegic cultivates a taste for wheelchair basketball through supportive rehabilitation, the historical process is empowering, not oppressive. Historical accounts can differentiate benign from malignant adaptation by scrutinising the social forces at work.

3. Responsiveness to Counterfactuals. Suppose the villager had been presented with sustained, non‐coercive access to schooling role models. Would she likely revise her preference? If yes, this indicates that the actual preference is fragile with respect to unjust background conditions. Historical models incorporate this counterfactual sensitivity naturally: autonomy requires that the agent’s preference be robust across changes that remove oppressive obstacles.

Nevertheless, historical theories invite worries of their own.

A. The Etiological Challenge. Every preference has determinants—family influence, random encounters, biological impulses. If mere causal dependency undermines autonomy, none of our preferences would be autonomous. Historical theorists must distinguish normal socialisation from autonomy-defeating manipulation.

B. The Access Problem. To judge whether a preference arose through oppression, we need detailed empirical knowledge about the agent’s biographical context. Philosophers risk speculative armchair diagnoses.

C. The Causal/Normative Gap. Even if a preference was produced by injustice, why does that fact reduce present authority? After all, adults can reflect and endorse their formative influences. Historical accounts need a normative bridge explaining why certain causal histories remain tainting despite later endorsement.

Several theorists have proposed solutions. Oshana argues that autonomy is essentially relational: it obtains only when social conditions ensure “self-authorised” choice. Oppressive structures undermine that standing forever, unless dismantled and the agent gains an opportunity to reconsider. Benson appeals to “normative competence”: oppression can impair the development of interpretive skills necessary for critical identification with one’s commitments. These proposals aim to answer the Etiological Challenge by specifying which kinds of causal histories deprive agents of the dispositions, competencies, or social authority that autonomy presupposes.

Importantly, historical accounts can integrate procedural tests familiar from the subjectivist framework: an individual may recover autonomy over a once-adaptive preference by re-examining it under non-oppressive circumstances, exercising critical faculties unobstructed by fear or misinformation. The complaint is not that the preference’s origin irreversibly pollutes it, but that until adequate opportunities for re-evaluation arise, the preference lacks standing.

IV. Why Oppression Matters: A Functional Diagnosis

To see why adaptive preferences under oppression are autonomy-impaired, consider the functional role autonomy plays in normative theory. Autonomy allocates responsibility and respect: autonomous agents are trustworthy to set their own ends. The social point of blaming oppression is that it interferes with this self-legislation. Oppressive adaptation is autonomy-defeating insofar as it systematically shuts down the very capacities—imaginative, deliberative, affective—that make genuine self-direction possible.

Subjectivist endorsement cannot, on its own, guarantee that these capacities have not been truncated, because endorsement itself may be conditioned by truncated capacities. Content-based criteria lack the flexibility to track whether the capacities are functioning, since a preference for a capability loss can be fully autonomous in certain contexts (monastic vows). Historical scrutiny, by contrast, directly evaluates whether the agent had a fair developmental field on which to exercise and cultivate her capacities for critical reflection.

We can formulate a two-stage historical diagnosis:

Stage 1. Deprivation of Counterfactual Choice. The agent’s social world lacked minimally sufficient exposure to alternative forms of life, or punished exploration of those alternatives. This undermines the initial formation of evaluative attitudes.

Stage 2. Persistence Without Re-Evaluation. The agent continues to live under circumstances that block serious reconsideration. So long as this blockage persists, the preference remains autonomy-deficient, regardless of present endorsement.

These stages answer the Causal/Normative Gap objection: it is not causal origin per se that matters, but the ongoing absence of fair conditions of self-scrutiny. Once those conditions are met—say, after migration to a different culture or through feminist consciousness-raising—the agent can autonomously reaffirm, modify, or abandon the preference. Historical taint is not indelible; rather, autonomy is a standing that can be regained when the oppressive context is lifted.

V. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: Some adaptive preferences emerge under hard but non-oppressive constraints—e.g., miners who grow to like underground work because above-ground jobs disappeared. Historical accounts would have to label these preferences non-autonomous, which seems excessive.

Reply: The historical model can differentiate between “hardship adaptation” and “oppressive adaptation.” Oppression involves structural asymmetries of power where one group benefits from another’s curtailed options. Geological shifts that close factories impose hardship but do not express an unjust hierarchy. Thus the miners’ adapted preference can be fully autonomous.

Objection 2: Historical accounts render autonomy hostage to sociological facts agents themselves may not know. That seems unfair; autonomy should be ascribed based on what the person can reasonably access.

Reply: Autonomy concerns the normative legitimacy of self-governance, which partly depends on whether the social environment has sabotaged deliberative competencies. It is a relational status, not an introspective feeling. Therefore some facts the agent cannot know may be relevant—just as consent in medical ethics can be invalid if information is hidden, even if the patient feels fully informed.

Objection 3: Sometimes oppressed agents actively resist internalisation and still prefer certain traditional roles. If historical accounts condemn any preference traceable to oppressive structures, they disrespect these women’s agency.

Reply: The view proposed here targets preferences produced by deprivation of critical opportunity, not preferences that persist after authentic resistance. When a preference survives robust, uncoerced examination, its oppressive origin no longer undermines autonomy. The key is whether the agent had—and took—credible chances to scrutinise and explore alternatives.

VI. A Tentative Synthesis

While I have argued that historical explanations best capture the autonomy deficit, the discussion reveals useful insights from each framework.

From subjectivists we learn that autonomous preference ultimately requires some form of self-endorsement; external correction alone is insufficient. Historical accounts should include a procedural threshold: at some point the agent must, reflectively and with competence, ratify or revise her wants.

From content theorists we learn that certain substantive human interests (bodily integrity, practical reason) are especially vulnerable to adaptive deformation and merit vigilance. Historical models can use such interests as diagnostic prompts: when a preference undermines them, we have prima facie reason to suspect defective formation.

Thus a hybrid account emerges.

1. Autonomy‐relevant interests: Identify domains where impairment would gravely handicap future self-rule.

2. Historical scrutiny: Ask whether, in forming a preference within those domains, the agent had adequate informational, imaginative, and social resources.

3. Reflective endorsement: Require that, given access to such resources, the agent maintain or reaffirm the preference.

Only when all three conditions are met should we deem the preference fully autonomous.

VII. Conclusion

Adaptive preferences puzzle philosophers because they straddle the boundary between rational coping and distorted acquiescence. A person logically adjusts her wants to what is feasible; yet under oppression, that very logic can entrench injustice by creating the appearance of consent. Subjectivist accounts, focusing on present endorsement, overlook the formative deprivation; content-based accounts, focusing on objective goods, elide the agent’s own authority. Historical accounts, properly developed, show why the absence of formative freedom undermines current self-governance, while allowing that autonomy can be reclaimed through re-evaluation under emancipatory conditions.

In the end, the autonomy deficit arises not because the adaptive preference is unendorsed, nor because it is aimed at the wrong object, but because the social process that forged it disabled the agent from exercising the full repertoire of reflective, imaginative, and self‐corrective capacities that autonomy presupposes. Only a historically attuned analysis can keep faith with the lived complexities of oppression while safeguarding the ideal of persons as authors of their own lives.

question: What makes adaptive preferences—preferences shaped in response to constraints on one's feasible options—less than fully autonomous? Consider whether subjectivist accounts (such as Frankfurt's hierarchical model of desire endorsement), content-based accounts (which evaluate the moral quality of what is preferred), or historical accounts (which examine how the preference was formed) best explain the autonomy deficit that adaptive preferences seem to exhibit, particularly in cases of oppression.
answer:
1. Introduction: Adaptive Preference and the Puzzle of Impaired Autonomy  

A shop-girl in nineteenth-century Manchester “prefers” twelve-hour shifts over the prospect of idleness; a bride in contemporary rural Bangladesh “prefers” early marriage to prolonged schooling; a factory worker accepts the absence of safety regulations as a “necessary sacrifice.”  In each case the agent’s stated preference looks voluntary—no one points a gun to her head—yet philosophers, policy-makers, and the women themselves, once circumstances change, are uneasy.  The worry is not merely that the preference leads to bad outcomes; it is that the preference seems less than fully her own.  We confront the phenomenon that Amartya Sen, Jon Elster and others call adaptive preference: an agent alters her preference set so that what remains feasible, however impoverished, comes to feel “preferred.”  The normative question is why such preferences strike us as deficient in autonomy.  

Three broad diagnostic families compete for explanatory primacy:

     (1) Subjectivist/hierarchical accounts, epitomised by Harry Frankfurt, locate autonomy in the agent’s reflective endorsement of her first-order desires.  

     (2) Content-based or perfectionist accounts judge autonomy by the substantive moral quality of what is preferred.  

     (3) Historical or procedural accounts explain deficits by appeal to the oppressive or distorting processes through which the preference was formed.  

I argue that while each approach illuminates part of the puzzle, historical accounts—supplemented by a relational understanding of how social power infiltrates deliberation—offer the most adequate explanation of the autonomy deficit typical of adaptive preferences.  They avoid the circularity of content-based views and the “internality” blind spot of subjectivist models, yet give principled reasons for why and when external interference (education, option-expansion, sometimes even paternalistic constraint) can enhance rather than violate autonomy.

2. The Subjectivist Promise—and Its Limits  

On Frankfurt’s canonical picture, an agent acts autonomously when her first-order desire (D1) to φ is wholeheartedly endorsed by a higher-order desire (D2) that she want the first-order desire to move her to action.  If the bride sincerely wants to marry at fourteen and also wants that very desire to shape her life, she is, by Frankfurtian lights, acting freely.  Subjectivist models thus appear friendly to the idea that even strongly constrained or socially shaped preferences can be autonomous, provided the agent reflectively embraces them.

Yet adaptive preference cases place stress on two key premises of the subjectivist view:

     a) Reflective access and imagination:  Frankfurt assumes that the agent can envisage and assess alternative first-order desires.  But adaptive preferences often arise precisely because feasible alternatives have been pruned away, materially or imaginatively.  The Bangladeshi girl may “wholeheartedly” endorse early marriage only because the option space she can represent is radically foreshortened.  If one cannot imagine becoming a lawyer, how meaningful is one’s second-order rejection of the desire to stay in school?  

     b) Independence of endorsement:  Frankfurt treats reflective endorsement as insulated from the very forces that shaped the first-order desire.  Yet in oppressive contexts, the reflective faculty itself is socialised and disciplined.  Second-order endorsement is not an independent tribunal but a jury already vetted by patriarchy or class domination.  Wholeheartedness becomes cognitively closed authoritarianism.

Subjectivists reply with a voluntariness condition: if the endorsement is the result of irresistible coercion or manipulation, it is not autonomous.  But recall that adaptive preferences grow in arenas where coercion is soft, pervasive, normalised.  There is no moment at which a manipulator injects the desire; rather, long-term social habituation operates.  Without a robust account of how background power systematically biases endorsement, subjectivist models risk ratifying adaptive preferences as fully autonomous when they are anything but.

3. Content-Based Assessments:  The Lure of Moral Substantivism  

Some philosophers (e.g., Joseph Raz’s perfectionist liberalism, Martha Nussbaum’s capability approach) cut the Gordian knot by stipulating that certain life-plans are objectively better: functioning in health, reasoning, affiliation, practical control over one’s environment.  Preferences that reject or truncate these capabilities are ipso facto autonomy-deficient.  If the child-bride’s preference forecloses her basic capabilities, it cannot be fully autonomous, no matter how reflectively endorsed.

This manoeuvre has intuitive punch and explains the frequent co-occurrence of adaptive preference and deprivation.  Still, it faces two objections:

     a) Paternalism and Respect:  Declaring that a preference is nonautonomous because it contravenes an externally defined list of valuable functions risks collapsing autonomy into moral correctness.  Yet autonomy and ethical propriety are conceptually distinct; one may autonomously choose badly (think of Gauguin’s desertion of family to paint) or nonautonomously “choose” well (Stockholm hostages expressing gratitude to their captors).  

     b) Contextual Relativity:  Content-based criteria often abstract from cultural and material context.  Suppose the Manchester worker, aware of the health hazards, still prefers factory work because she judges any alternative hunger and prostitution worse.  Labeling her preference “nonautonomous” on the basis of its content alone obscures the tragic rationality of choice under unjust conditions.  

Hence content-based accounts risk both moralism and sociological naiveté; they persuade only if one already shares the perfectionist premise.  They identify many adaptive preferences as autonomy-deficient but cannot explain, rather than stipulate, why the deficit attaches to those preferences.

4. Historical-Procedural Accounts:  Tracing the Genealogy of a Preference  

Historical theories posit that autonomy depends not on what one now prefers but on how that preference came to be.  The agent must stand in the right sort of relation to the causal history of her desire.

a) The basic model:  A preference is autonomous if it is the product of processes that respect the agent’s critical faculties—processes untainted by coercion, deception, forced ignorance, or systematic indoctrination.  Robert Young, Laura Ekstrom, and more recently Natalie Stoljar and Serene Khader have defended variants.

b) Advantages vis-à-vis adaptive preference:  The hallmark of adaptiveness is that a constraint not only limits what one can do but boomerangs to shape what one comes to want.  The historical view pinpoints the injury: an oppressive environment filters information, narrows imagination, punishes deviance, rewards docility, and thereby “forces” the agent to confect subjective endorsement.  Even wholeheartedness fails the historical test because the internal pro-attitude is itself the sediment of external domination.

c) Empirical plausibility:  We can recount causal narratives—patriarchal pedagogies, economic vulnerability, testimonial silencing—that explain why certain populations disproportionately endorse stereotypically oppressive options.  These stories, when fleshed out, vindicate the intuition that something went awry in the genesis of the preference.

d) Avoiding moralism:  A historical account can respect idiosyncrasy.  Suppose a woman long exposed to diverse options freely chooses homemaking because she happens to love childcare.  Her preference’s content resembles that of women in oppressive contexts, yet the genesis differs; the historical model yields the right verdict of autonomy.

5. Two Objections to the Historical Account and Replies  

Objection 1: Regress—All preferences are socially formed; where do we draw the line between permissible and autonomy-undermining socialisation?

Reply: The “mere social influence” objection rightly notes that humans are encultured animals, but oppression is not a difference in degree alone; it involves systematic, asymmetrical power that forecloses critical assessment.  The historical view can specify disqualifying conditions: deception, coerced ignorance, adaptive dampening of aspiration, and non-accidental correlation with a subordinated social identity.  These markers separate generic upbringing from autonomy-subverting formation.

Objection 2: Time-slice rescue—What if the agent, aware of her oppressive history, now reaffirms the preference?  Wouldn’t that undo earlier contamination?

Reply:  It depends.  If the reaffirmation is undertaken in conditions that remedy epistemic deprivation—exposure to alternatives, equal respect, space to experiment—then yes, the preference may mature into an autonomous one.  Historical accounts need not eternally taint a desire; they show that current autonomy hinges on whether the agent has genuinely had a chance to scrutinise and, if she wishes, revise the preference.  Where structural conditions still impede that scrutiny, reaffirmation is insufficient.

6. Relational Autonomy as Complement  

Critics note that individual-level historical accounts still picture the agent as a discrete subject who, given the right past, can deliberate in a vacuum.  Feminist philosophers (Mackenzie, Oshana, Stoljar) argue that we also need a relational criterion: autonomy requires ongoing social recognition and non-domination.  Adaptive preferences are often relationally heteronomous—they are sustained by social scripts whose non-compliance incurs sanctions.

Combining historical with relational insights yields a more nuanced diagnosis.  The preference to be a docile daughter-in-law is nonautonomous not only because it was instilled by patriarchal upbringing (history) but also because current power relations punish dissent (relations).  Even if the woman could in principle move to the city and change her mind, the costs are not abstract; they are socially inflicted.  Thus historical accounts, broadened into relational historical accounts, best track both diachronic and synchronic dimensions of autonomy.

7. Clarifying the Autonomy Deficit: Three Dimensions  

The superiority of the historical-relational framework can be seen by parsing autonomy into its constitutive conditions.

     a) Authenticity (are these truly my desires?) – subjectivist accounts emphasise this dimension but fail to explain false consciousness.  Historical-relational accounts tell us when authenticity is corrupted by oppressive internalisation.

     b) Self-governance (can I act on my desires?) – content-based accounts sometimes conflate self-governance with attaining objectively valuable ends.  Historical-relational models focus instead on the agent’s practical authority, highlighting how social penalties restrict governability.

     c) Self-authorization (do I regard myself as the legitimate source of reasons?) – this is jeopardised when an entire social system denies certain groups epistemic authority, leading them to internalise deference.  Adaptive preference is one symptom.  Historical-relational analysis makes explicit this internalised de-legitimation.

8. Policy Implications: From Diagnosis to Remedy  

Why does the correct explanation matter?  If subjectivist accounts were right, autonomy would counsel non-interference whenever a second-order endorsement can be elicited.  Yet this would trap people in adaptive preference cycles, because expansion of material and imaginative options often requires external intervention—education subsidies, affirmative action, consciousness-raising.

Content-based perfectionism, by contrast, might justify heavy-handed paternalism: ban early marriage, outlaw factory work.  Such measures, while improving welfare, can disrespect agency or backfire politically.

Historical-relational analysis supports a middle path:  rectify the background conditions that warp preference formation—inequitable property regimes, discriminatory laws, biased media, lack of safe exit options.  The goal is not to substitute new preferences for old but to create autonomy-conducive environments in which agents can test, affirm, or reject inherited desires.  This generates practical guidance: prioritize option-expansion, deliberative fora, and resistance to penalties for deviance, rather than direct substitution of “correct” preferences.

9. Hard Cases and Residual Ambiguities  

Consider a religious novice who freely enters a cloister, vows obedience, and years later reports contentment.  Some critics think this, too, is an adaptive preference.  Does the historical-relational view declare it nonautonomous?  We must ask: was the novice systematically shielded from secular alternatives, threatened with damnation narratives, denied exit?  If so, autonomy is compromised; if not, the choice may be self-authored.  The historical account is capable of such case-by-case discrimination, unlike crude content-based verdicts that dismiss monastic life altogether or subjectivist deference that ignores early indoctrination.

Another difficulty concerns elites in wealthy societies who adapt downward in smaller ways—preferring cheaper holidays after economic downturns, for example.  Are their preferences nonautonomous?  The answer is typically no, because the historical-relational markers of oppression are absent; constraints in these cases are temporary, transparent, and leave critical capacities intact.

10. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences unsettle the tidy liberal assumption that what people prefer is what is good for them and, more importantly, authentically their own.  The philosophical challenge is to articulate why such preferences are frequently autonomy-deficient without lapsing into moralistic perfectionism or discrediting all socially formed desires.  

Subjectivist models fail because they overlook the fact that reflective endorsement itself can be colonised by oppressive structures; content-based models fail because they collapse autonomy into substantive ideals.  Historical accounts, especially when augmented by a relational understanding of ongoing power dynamics, capture what is distinctive about adaptive preferences: they are the interiorised residue of external domination that pre-emptively deforms the processes of imagination, deliberation, and self-authorization upon which autonomy depends.

Recognising this genealogy allows us both to respect agency and to justify emancipatory interventions aimed at expanding real options and fostering the epistemic conditions under which agents can truly decide for themselves what to want.  The autonomy deficit, then, lies not (or not only) in the content of the adapted preference, nor in the absence of a fleeting endorsement, but in the oppressive history by which the preference came to seem the only live option—and in the social present that continues to entrench that illusion.  Rectifying that history and transforming those relations is the path, not to choosing for others, but to enabling them, at last, to choose for themselves.

question: What makes adaptive preferences—preferences shaped in response to constraints on one's feasible options—less than fully autonomous? Consider whether subjectivist accounts (such as Frankfurt's hierarchical model of desire endorsement), content-based accounts (which evaluate the moral quality of what is preferred), or historical accounts (which examine how the preference was formed) best explain the autonomy deficit that adaptive preferences seem to exhibit, particularly in cases of oppression.
answer:
Adaptive preferences are the preferences that agents come to hold in response to limits—social, economic, political or physical—on what they can in fact do. A woman who ceases to want higher education because her society forbids women to attend university, a Dalit who persuades himself that he really does prefer the “humble” life allotted to his caste, or a prisoner who claims to desire nothing so much as the routine of the cell block have all, in the canonical sense made familiar by Amartya Sen, Jon Elster and Martha Nussbaum, adapted to a deprived feasible set. There is a widespread intuition that such preferences are “less than fully autonomous.” The question is how best to explain this autonomy deficit. Three families of theories are standardly invoked:

1. Subjectivist or internalist accounts, exemplified by Harry Frankfurt’s hierarchical model of endorsement, which ground autonomy in an agent’s reflectively endorsed higher-order desires.

2. Content-based accounts, which hold that autonomy can be defeated by the moral or prudential badness of what the agent prefers.

3. Historical or procedural accounts, which locate deficits in the causal story of how the preference was produced, emphasizing oppression, deception, or coercive socialization.

Which analysis does most justice to the phenomenon of adaptive preferences, especially when these preferences arise under conditions of structural oppression? I shall argue that while each approach captures an important piece of the puzzle, a nuanced historical account provides the most satisfying explanation, but only when enriched by insights borrowed from subjectivist reflection and by a modest, non-perfectionist concern for objectionable content. In other words, we need a historical-procedural view that remains sensitive to what the agent can in principle reflectively endorse under conditions free of domination, and to the objective harms enshrined in certain contents. I develop this claim in four steps. First, I analyse why subjectivist endorsement is insufficient. Second, I explain why sheer appeal to value-laden content is at once too strong and too weak. Third, I defend an historically inflected, social-relational picture of adaptive preference formation. Finally, I show how the three strands can be woven together into an integrated position that both diagnoses autonomy failures and guides emancipatory political practice.

1. The limits of subjectivist endorsement

Frankfurt famously distinguishes first-order desires (to smoke, to sleep, to marry young) from second-order desires or volitions (to want or not want certain first-order desires to move one to action). Autonomy, on this view, resides in a harmony of levels: I am autonomous just insofar as the desire that motivates me is the one I approve of upon reflection. To explain why an adaptive preference is non-autonomous, the subjectivist can say that the oppressed woman does not endorse her desire to forego education; she has merely resigned herself. Yet matters are not so simple. Suppose she does endorse it. After years of persuading herself that women find real fulfilment in domestic work, she forms a wholehearted second-order desire to prefer household labour to bookish study. Frankfurt would then have to count the preference autonomous. However, it still strikes many of us—and arguably strikes the agent herself when imaginatively freed from oppression—as in some sense unfree. 

Proponents of the hierarchical model respond by refining the endorsement condition. They appeal to conditions of “informed and ideally situated reflection.” But this threatens to smuggle in precisely the historical and social constraints the account meant to sidestep, now relabelled as necessary conditions for genuine endorsement. Moreover, the model struggles with adaptive desires that have infiltrated the agent’s higher-order system from the start. If a brutally patriarchal culture inculcates women with the meta-preference “I should want what my father or husband wants me to want,” then an internally coherent hierarchy of desires can coexist with radical heteronomy. Frankfurt himself took heteronomy to involve the will’s being “overborne by forces external to the person.” Yet when external social forces shape my deepest volitional structure, they do not overbear an already-formed will; they constitute it. Hierarchical endorsement, absent further constraints, therefore cannot always explain the felt deficit in autonomy.

2. The temptations and perils of a content test

A second family of theories diagnoses non-autonomy by appealing to the moral disvalue of the preferences themselves. The thought is that wanting a life of servitude, sexual subordination or caste oppression is so substantively defective that the desire cannot be fully one’s own. Some theorists embrace this forthrightly perfectionist line: there are certain forms of life that no rational and self-respecting person could ever freely choose; if someone appears to choose them, we infer a failure of autonomy. Advocates often draw inspiration from Kant’s idea that autonomy involves legislating universal moral law for oneself; a willing that contradicts the conditions of universal respect is self-undermining. 

Content-based diagnoses have bite, particularly in extreme cases. When a victim of childhood abuse claims, apparently sincerely, to want further abuse, many of us immediately suspect that something has gone awry in the formation of that want. But the content test swoops too low and too high. Too low, because it risks labeling non-autonomous any preference whose content strikes some observer as morally unworthy; this is paternalistic and culturally imperialistic, erasing legitimate diversity. Too high, because it cannot distinguish between adaptive preferences and innocent, freely chosen preferences that happen to have objectionable content. A sadist who wholeheartedly wants to torture cats for fun does not display an adaptive preference—he has not accommodated himself to constrained options—but most content theorists will deem his desire non-autonomous notwithstanding. The test thereby loses the specific explanatory connection to oppression and constraint that makes the adaptive preference problem philosophically distinctive.

Moreover, content-based accounts appear helpless when the content is not in itself objectionable but is embraced for wrong reasons. Consider a factory worker in a capitalist economy who comes to prefer consuming cheap fashion rather than fighting for shorter hours. The preference per se—liking clothes—is morally innocent, yet social forces may have shaped it in ways that undermine agency. Content tests are blunt instruments for such subtleties. 

3. Toward a historical-procedural account

Historical views, by contrast, go directly to the genesis of the preference. Joseph Raz, Gerald Dworkin, and, more recently, relational theorists such as Marina Oshana and Andrea Westlund argue that autonomy requires a certain kind of history—one free of coercion, manipulation, indoctrination or systematic deprivation of information. The agent must, in Susan Wolf’s phrase, “be able adequately to appreciate the factual and moral world.” When a woman internalises patriarchal norms under threat of ostracism or violence, the causal process is shot through with oppressive power relations; her resulting preferences, though sincerely embraced, lack the pedigree autonomy demands. 

Historical accounts elegantly capture why a preference that is reflectively endorsed and not objectionable in content can nevertheless smack of heteronomy: the agent’s endorsement itself is a product of domination. They also explain why mere dispositional or behavioural evidence of endorsement is insufficient; what matters is that the endorsement could withstand critical scrutiny were the agent granted the resources that oppression denies her. Further, historical theories avoid content paternalism because they focus on process rather than substance; they leave open that very strange or even morally bad preferences might be autonomous if formed in the right way, as with the free sadist.

Still, a purely procedural history faces difficulties. First, it seems to imply that once the oppressive origins of a preference are wiped from memory or become impossible to unearth, the preference might recover autonomous status. But our moral intuition often says otherwise: the legacy of slavery, caste and patriarchy can scar preferences long after their provenance is obscured. Second, not every causal influence counts as autonomy-subverting; we are all shaped by our upbringing, language, and culture. The challenge is to specify which historical factors matter. If the correct answer is “those involving unjust power,” then we have already smuggled in a moralised content assessment—oppression is morally bad—though at the level of history.

4. A relational enrichment of the historical view

To meet these worries, historical accounts can be supplemented by a relational conception of autonomy. On this picture, what robs adaptive preferences of autonomy is not merely that they were causally produced by oppression, but that they continue to function as vehicles through which oppressive social relations reproduce themselves. The preference for domesticity in a patriarchal society supports and normalises gender hierarchy; the preference for caste humility buttresses a system that degrades Dalits. The autonomy deficit is thus ongoing and relational, not merely genealogical. When the agent acts on such a preference, she is entangled in patterns of domination that limit her ability to subject those patterns to criticism. The history matters because it installs a set of social feedback mechanisms—stigma, material dependence, threats of violence—that block the dialogical processes of interrogation through which autonomous agency would otherwise flourish.

This relational-historical account both explains the persistence of the deficit and offers a principled boundary: only those causal influences that instantiate relations of domination undermine autonomy. Parents who instill in their children a love of music do not dominate them; but a culture that instills women with the conviction that higher education is sinful does dominate. The emphasis on domination resonates with the republican tradition (Pettit) and with feminists (Nedelsky, Oshana) who understand autonomy as insecure under conditions of structurally embedded power asymmetries. What the adaptive preference lacks, then, is not just authentic endorsement, nor just sound content, but freedom from an ongoing social relation that cripples the agent’s critical capacities.

5. Integrating subjectivist insights

Yet we should not jettison the internalist dimension altogether. Autonomy, after all, concerns self-rule; the phenomenology of owning one’s desires is crucial. Historical-relational accounts must therefore explain why adaptive preferences often feel, from the inside, like genuine commitments. The explanation is psychological: oppressive socialisation shapes not only what we want but how we experience wanting. But the feeling of endorsement is epistemically defeasible. An agent may discover, through exposure to alternative viewpoints and solidaristic dialogue, that her second-order volitions are themselves artifacts of domination. Thus, while hierarchical endorsement is not sufficient for autonomy, the capacity for reflective revision remains necessary. Without it, we could not imagine agents emancipating themselves from adaptive preference structures, as countless feminist, anti-racist and queer liberation movements testify. 

A historical-relational theory can therefore incorporate a counterfactual endorsement condition: a preference is autonomous only if the agent could, in conditions free of domination and with adequate epistemic resources, sustain her endorsement. This “conditions of exit” criterion mirrors John Christman’s suggestion that autonomy involves being able to revise one’s preferences when furnished with critical information and social support. It guards against labeling as heteronomous every preference formed under non-ideal circumstances, focusing instead on whether the agent remains open to revising it once liberated from the disabling relation.

6. Why content still matters, but modestly

Finally, we must ask whether any room remains for content-based considerations. I submit that some contents, e.g., self-abnegation that renders dignified life impossible, are incompatible with the kinds of relationships that autonomy presupposes—reciprocal recognition among free and equal persons. Even if a preference for one’s own enslavement were formed without coercion (a fanciful possibility), it would express a stance that repudiates one’s moral status as an equal. That status is among the background conditions for autonomy; repudiating it is a performative contradiction. Thus a thin, non-perfectionist content constraint piggybacks on the historical-relational view: certain preferences are autonomy-robbing because they deny the very normative standing in virtue of which one could be self-governing at all. However, the bar is set high: we invoke content only when it negates the agent’s capacity for agency, not when it merely violates some observer’s taste.

7. Comparative evaluation

We are now in a position to assess the three accounts.

Subjectivist endorsement:
• Strength: highlights the internal perspective essential to self-rule; respects pluralism.
• Weakness: cannot mark as heteronomous preferences whose higher-order endorsement is itself the creature of oppression; struggles with entrenched indoctrination.

Content-based tests:
• Strength: captures our intuition in extreme cases where what is preferred violates basic self-respect.
• Weakness: lapses into moralism and cultural imperialism; fails to track the specific role of adaptive response to constraints; misclassifies independently vicious but freely chosen desires.

Historical-relational account:
• Strength: targets the causal role of domination, explains persistence of autonomy deficits, avoids crude paternalism, dovetails with political analysis of oppression.
• Weakness: needs supplementation to distinguish benign from malignant social influence; risks denying autonomy universally in a non-ideal world; lacks an internalist phenomenology unless enriched.

When supplemented by counterfactual endorsement and a minimal content floor, the historical-relational model inherits the virtues and blunts the vices of its rivals. It shows why autonomy can be damaged without the agent’s awareness, why not every strange or harmful desire is non-autonomous, and why emancipation politics rightly focuses on material and cultural transformation rather than on individual psychology alone.

8. Implications for social policy and political theory

Seeing autonomy through this lens also informs practical responses to adaptive preferences. If the deficit stems mainly from oppressive social relations, then the remedy is not (or not just) paternalistic interference with individual choices. It is collective action to dismantle the structures—legal, economic, ideological—that generate those preferences and keep agents from accessing genuine alternatives. Rather than barring the hijab or banning sex work outright under the banner of protecting women’s autonomy, liberal states should secure conditions under which women can adopt or reject such practices without threat of violence, economic duress or social ostracism. That means education, material resources, robust anti-discrimination policy, and cultural contestation. In turn, development ethics should aim not simply to expand the menu of options (a purely capability-based metric) but to transform the relations that pre-arrange agents’ option rankings in conformity with domination.

Conclusion

Adaptive preferences unsettle familiar liberal pictures of autonomy because they reveal how deeply social power can seep into the wellsprings of desire. Subjectivist endorsement accounts cannot on their own apprehend that seepage; content-based accounts conflate moral appraisal with autonomy appraisal; historical accounts, properly refined, illuminate the core pathology, namely domination’s capacity to colonise preference-formation itself. By combining a relational theory of social power with a counterfactual endorsement condition and a slender content constraint rooted in the very idea of equal moral standing, we gain an explanatory framework that respects individual phenomenology, diagnoses structural injustice, and guides emancipatory practice. Adaptive preferences are less than fully autonomous not because they fail to fit some observer’s moral template, nor because their holders feel ambivalent, but because they are the living traces of domination that continues to stunt the agent’s freedom even as it secures her consent. A philosophical theory that attends to that history and to those relations—while granting the agent the ongoing capacity, under better conditions, to repudiate them—gives the most convincing account of the autonomy at stake.

question: What makes adaptive preferences—preferences shaped in response to constraints on one's feasible options—less than fully autonomous? Consider whether subjectivist accounts (such as Frankfurt's hierarchical model of desire endorsement), content-based accounts (which evaluate the moral quality of what is preferred), or historical accounts (which examine how the preference was formed) best explain the autonomy deficit that adaptive preferences seem to exhibit, particularly in cases of oppression.
answer:
Adaptive Preferences and the Fragility of Autonomy  
                              Subjectivist, Content-Based, and Historical Explanations  

1. The Puzzle  

Oppression does not always announce itself as an external constraint.  Often it works by cultivating in the oppressed a set of desires that dovetail neatly with their restricted social position: the daughter who disavows her wish to study because “girls aren’t good at maths,” the agricultural labourer who declares that “education is useless for people like us,” or the woman in a village that practises female genital cutting who claims to “prefer” the operation.  Economists and feminist philosophers have labelled such desires adaptive preferences: they are preferences that arise, not in spite of the agent’s limited options, but partly because the agent has those limits in view and adjusts her aspirations accordingly.  The intuitive thought is that the resulting preferences—though sincerely held—are less than fully autonomous.  But why?  Three families of answers dominate the literature:  

a. Subjectivist or procedural accounts, epitomised by Harry Frankfurt, locate autonomy in the agent’s reflective endorsement of her first-order desires.  
b. Content-based or substantive accounts hold that certain desires are disqualifying because of what they aim at.  
c. Historical accounts insist that how a desire was formed matters: a preference bred by manipulation, coercion, or oppressive socialisation fails to be self-authored.  

Which of these approaches best diagnoses the autonomy deficit in adaptive preferences?  I argue that (i) purely procedural subjectivism under-diagnoses the deficit, (ii) purely content-based theories over-diagnose it, and (iii) a historically inflected, relational view gives the most precise explanation while avoiding paternalism.  To establish this, I first examine each account on its own terms and then show how a historical-relational synthesis preserves what is compelling in each while repairing their respective weaknesses.

2. Subjectivist Procedural Accounts  

2.1 Frankfurt’s Hierarchy  

For Frankfurt, what distinguishes an autonomous action from a merely volitional one is the presence of a second-order volition that endorses the first-order desire on which the person acts.  A smoker who wants to quit but continues to smoke is not wholehearted.  Conversely, if after reflection she wholeheartedly embraces her smoking, her desire is autonomous, however destructive it may be.  The model is procedural: it does not scrutinise the content of what is desired, nor its causal history.  All that matters is a structure of reflective endorsement free of internal conflict.

2.2 Applying the Model to Adaptive Preferences  

If a woman raised in a patriarchal setting reflectively endorses her desire to undergo genital cutting, Frankfurt would have to deem the desire autonomous—provided it is indeed wholehearted.  The central worry is that the model counts too many adaptive preferences as self-authored merely because the agent has made peace with them.  The longer a person lives under oppressive norms, the more likely she is to endorse the desires those norms make salient; yet that convergence does not dispel the taint of oppression.

2.3 Why Procedural Independence is Not Enough  

Defenders of procedural accounts respond that what matters is whether reflection is free from direct coercion or deception at the moment of endorsement.  But adaptive preferences typically form in contexts where the agent’s imagination of alternatives is systematically stunted long before reflection even begins.  To require that she now “endorse” the fragments left to her is a thin achievement.  Two Frankfurtian resources might be deployed to meet the objection:

a. Higher-order reflection could include a critical appraisal of how the first-order desire came about; if so, agents would repudiate desires they see as products of unjust constraints.  
b. The notion of ‘volitional necessity’ could guard against coercively instilled second-order desires.

Yet in oppressive environments, agents often lack reliable information, social support, or conceptual tools to make such critical appraisals.  Their endorsement is therefore compromised even if it is internally conflict-free.  In short, a purely procedural test of authenticity confuses adaptive peace-of-mind with self-government.

3. Content-Based Accounts  

3.1 Substantive Autonomy Conditions  

Content-based theorists, among them some feminist critics of proceduralism, argue that autonomy requires that what is chosen not be overly servile, self-abnegating, or otherwise morally objectionable.  On these views, a desire to be cut, enslaved, or permanently subordinate is disqualifying precisely because of its content: such desires are incompatible with the agent’s equal moral worth.

3.2 Strengths in Diagnosing Adaptive Preferences  

Content-based standards capture an intuition that proceduralists miss: certain desires seem so deeply at odds with self-respect that they cannot be fully self-authored.  It is thus no accident that paradigmatic adaptive preferences—preferences for genital cutting, for being fed last, for earning less than men—are also desires whose realisation enacts or reinforces one’s social inferiority.  The substantive view explains why adaptive preferences so readily strike outsiders as autonomy-defeating: the content of the preference itself embodies oppression.

3.3 The Paternalism Objection  

But the power of this explanation is purchased at the price of paternalism.  Suppose a woman, well aware of the patriarchal roots of her culture, still sincerely prefers a domestic life.  A content-based theory that invalidates her choice because it is “too traditional” risks arrogating to the theorist the authority to decide which lives are worth choosing.  Moreover, the category of disqualifying desires is notoriously slippery: if a desire for genital cutting is non-autonomous, what about a desire for painful cosmetic surgery in liberal societies?  Content criteria threaten to slide into perfectionism or cultural imperialism.

3.4 An Undergeneration Problem  

Ironically, the same account may under-generate autonomy failures when the content appears innocuous.  A preference for thin bread over thick bread, if adopted under duress or hypnosis, would still be non-autonomous even though nothing is morally suspect about thin bread.  So content alone cannot be the whole story.

4. Historical Accounts  

4.1 The Causal History Requirement  

Historical theories propose that whether a desire is autonomous depends on the causal pathway by which it was acquired.  If a preference is the product of deception, coercion, psychological manipulation, or oppressive socialisation, then it is heteronomous.  However wholeheartedly the subject now embraces it, the original vitiating conditions travel forward and infect present endorsement.

4.2 Advantages Over Proceduralism  

By shifting attention from synchronic endorsement to diachronic formation, historical accounts can capture why adaptive preferences feel inauthentic.  The agent’s preference is not simply made inferior by its content; nor is it redeemed by her current endorsement.  Rather, it is flawed because it traces to a formative process that systematically filtered out alternatives, distorted information, punished dissent, and rewarded compliance.  The sour-grapes fox is not self-governing because his shrinking of desire stems from earlier failed attempts and the anticipation of social ridicule.

4.3 The Problem of Continuing Ownership  

Yet history alone does not settle everything.  We do not wish to say that every preference formed under bad conditions remains permanently tainted.  Many survivors of oppressive upbringing later take ownership of some of their inculcated desires after continuous critical dialogue with them; in doing so they seem to regain autonomy.  Historical accounts need criteria for “immunising” a preference from its origins—criteria that will inevitably involve some current capacities for critical reflection.  Thus historical and procedural elements converge.

5. Comparative Diagnosis  

5.1 Under- vs Over-Idealisation  

Subjectivism sets the bar too low: wholehearted endorsement in conditions of entrenched oppression is insufficient for autonomy.  Content-based accounts set the bar too high: they risk declaring non-autonomous any desire that looks morally problematic from the theorist’s standpoint.  Historical accounts occupy a middle ground, but they require supplementation to explain how present reflection can sometimes rehabilitate a tainted preference.

5.2 Which Explains Adaptive Preferences Best?  

Consider three test cases:  

Case A: A woman in rural Sudan prefers genital cutting and endorses this preference after hearing only pro-cutting testimonies.  
Case B: A well-educated woman in the same community, exposed to global human-rights discourse, still prefers the surgery as a mark of identity.  
Case C: A woman in New York prefers Botox injections to appear youthful.

• Proceduralism counts A and B autonomous (if endorsement is sincere) but cannot explain our stronger intuition of deficit in A than in B, or of any deficit at all in C.  
• Content accounts count both A and B non-autonomous but must also impugn C unless they draw a contentious cultural line.  
• Historical accounts diagnose A as non-autonomous because her preference was formed under massive epistemic deprivation and social control.  B is a harder case: some will judge that her broader exposure partly redeems the preference; others will note residual social pressures.  C, formed in a context of advertising manipulation but also robust alternatives and public critique, may come out autonomous.  The historical view can capture these nuances by examining the specific genealogy of each preference.

6. Toward a Relational-Historical Account  

6.1 Autonomy as Self-Authorship in Context  

Instead of treating autonomy as a property of isolated preferences, a relational-historical account regards autonomy as an ongoing practice of self-authorship within social relations.  On this view, what matters is whether the agent (i) had access to a repertoire of live options, (ii) possessed the epistemic and emotional skills to assess them, (iii) operated in an environment that respected her deliberation, and (iv) retains the capacity to revise her commitments without punitive costs.

6.2 Explaining Adaptive Preferences  

Adaptive preferences fail these conditions in characteristic ways:

a. Restricted option set: oppressive structures narrow what the agent can even imagine desiring.  
b. Distorted feedback: institutional and interpersonal signals punish deviation and reward conformity, impairing the agent’s epistemic self-trust.  
c. Cost prohibitions: choosing outside permissible roles brings threats to safety, economic survival, or social belonging.  
d. Internalised affect: shame and guilt bind the agent affectively to the restricted role.

Because these features are historical and relational, the deficit they produce cannot be seen by looking solely at current psychological endorsement (proceduralism) or only at the intrinsic content of the desire (substantivism).  It is the way in which social power operates over time on the agent’s capacities that undercuts autonomy.

6.3 Normative Payoff  

The relational-historical account explains both why we should hesitate to override an agent’s expressed preference and when we are justified in doing so.  If an intervention aims to expand her option set and deliberative capacities—rather than to impose an alternative content—it respects her autonomy better than simply accepting her adaptive preference at face value.  Moreover, it shows why paternalistic substitution of judgement is misguided: what the agent needs is empowerment of agency, not replacement of ends.

7. An Objection: Are All Preferences Historically Contingent?  

One might object that every preference has a history of social influence; indeed, all desires are shaped by culture.  If historical impurity is disqualifying, then autonomy becomes impossible.  The relational-historical view answers that mere social influence is not the problem; the problem is a distinctive pattern of influence that systematically undermines the agent’s capacities for critical reflection, imaginative freedom, and cost-effective revision.  Not every cultural shaping is autonomy-defeating, only oppressive shaping that closes rather than opens deliberative space.

8. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences illustrate the subtle ways in which oppression colonises the will.  Purely procedural subjectivism mistakes reflective peace for self-government, while purely content-based theories mistake the moral quality of an end for the agent’s authorship of it.  Historical accounts, sensitive to the genesis of desires, come closest to explaining the autonomy deficit, but they must be integrated into a broader relational framework that attends to the ongoing social conditions under which reflection, revision, and endorsement take place.  

Autonomy, properly understood, is neither an instantaneous internal endorsement nor a matter of desiring the “right” things.  It is the lived capacity to navigate, criticise, and if necessary transform the social world that has shaped one’s own identity.  Adaptive preferences are less than fully autonomous because they emerge from histories that cripple that capacity.  Recognising this fact allows philosophers, policy-makers, and activists to respect agency without romanticising the choices that oppression leaves on the table.

question: What makes adaptive preferences—preferences shaped in response to constraints on one's feasible options—less than fully autonomous? Consider whether subjectivist accounts (such as Frankfurt's hierarchical model of desire endorsement), content-based accounts (which evaluate the moral quality of what is preferred), or historical accounts (which examine how the preference was formed) best explain the autonomy deficit that adaptive preferences seem to exhibit, particularly in cases of oppression.
answer:
1. Introduction: adaptive preference and the intuitive autonomy worry  

When Sen and Nussbaum speak of “adaptive preferences,” they have in mind the psychological tendency of agents to adjust their desires downward (or sideways) when the world denies them more attractive options. The classic examples are the fox who declares the grapes sour, the enslaved person who insists that servitude suits her, or the woman in a patriarchal village who claims not to want an education because “it would only unsettle me.” Observers feel an immediate tension. On the one hand these claims are the agent’s own; on the other, we suspect something is missing – some element that would license us to say that the preference is fully her own. In other words, adaptive preferences appear to involve a deficit in autonomy. The philosophical task is to say what, exactly, the deficit consists in.

Three families of accounts compete to articulate that deficit:

• Subjectivist or structural accounts, exemplified by Frankfurt’s hierarchical theory, focus on whether the agent reflectively endorses the preference.  
• Content-based or substantive accounts judge the preference by the moral quality of what is preferred.  
• Historical or procedural–etiological accounts emphasise how the preference was formed and whether the formative process was itself autonomous.

I will argue that historical–relational accounts ultimately identify the autonomy deficit most convincingly, yet that they are strengthened when they borrow insights from the other two traditions. The argument proceeds as follows. §2 reconstructs the subjectivist model and notes its vulnerability to internalised oppression. §3 shows why purely content-based criteria cannot capture the phenomenon without lapsing into moralism. §4 develops the historical alternative and explains how oppressive socialisation damages autonomy. §5 replies to objections that the historical criterion over-pathologises ordinary social influence and collapses into scepticism. §6 briefly sketches an integrated view that preserves the merits of each approach.

2. The subjectivist or structural model: endorsement and its limits  

Harry Frankfurt’s canonical picture portrays autonomy as a matter of hierarchical identification. My first-order desires push me toward various actions; my second-order volitions express which of those motivational states I *want* to move me. If I want to want to study, and that higher-order commitment effectively governs my motivational economy, then the ensuing study session is autonomous; if the higher-order desire is absent or alienated, it is not. The attraction of Frankfurt’s view is its anti-paternalist stance: it looks entirely to the subject’s reflective attitudes, not to external standards or to causal histories the agent herself repudiates.  

Applying this model to adaptive preference, an agent who has come to prefer traditional domesticity over education could in principle autonomously endorse that preference at the second order. Suppose she spends a week in calm self-scrutiny and ends up wholeheartedly identifying with her domestic aspirations. On Frankfurt’s account, the preference is then autonomous, even if outsiders suspect patriarchy did the shaping.

That conclusion is precisely what many feminist theorists find counter-intuitive. Our worry about the village woman was not that she lacked second-order reflection: she might well endorse the domestic ideal with passionate sincerity. Our worry was rather that her horizon of reflection was itself distorted by oppressive norms; the preferences available for endorsement had been filtered before reflection began. Thus, the purely hierarchical model seems to misfire in two ways.

First, it is too quick to treat any higher-order endorsement as sufficing for autonomy, ignoring that reflective capacities themselves are socially conditioned. Someone trained never to imagine herself as a lawyer may endorse her domestic role, but the endorsement issues from a stunted imaginative repertoire. Second, the Frankfurtian agent is conceived in isolation, such that background power relations vanish from view. When internalised oppression becomes invisible, the model risks legitimating domination.

Frankfurt acknowledged a “regress problem” (“why should third-order desires not be required?”), but he believed it was solvable by an appeal to wholeheartedness. The feminist objection, however, is not about regress but about the inputs to reflection: they have been filtered by unequal power. Hence structural endorsement is at best a necessary condition; it is not sufficient to diagnose autonomy in cases of adaptive preference.

3. Content-based or substantive accounts: autonomy and the moral worth of ends  

A second strategy, advanced in distinct registers by Nussbaum, Raz, and sometimes Kantian liberals, holds that a preference is non-autonomous if its content flouts certain objective requirements of flourishing or moral right. Nussbaum’s capability approach, for example, speaks of “deformed desires” when a person prefers what leaves her below a threshold of central human capacities. On this view the village woman’s preference for illiteracy marks a failure of autonomy because literacy is intrinsically valuable to human agency.

Content-based criteria have intuitive bite: they capture cases where an agent calmly wants something that will obviously harm or demean her. Still, the approach faces two challenges.

a) The paternalism challenge. By measuring autonomy directly against a list of objective goods, the theorist risks collapsing the distinction between respecting a person’s choices and evaluating their wisdom. Autonomy traditionally tracks self-rule, not moral rightness. To brand any immoral or imprudent choice ipso facto non-autonomous flattens the conceptual landscape: Socrates’ choice to remain in Athens, knowing it will lead to execution, flouts prudence but hardly seems heteronomous.

b) The possibility of morally neutral yet adaptive preferences. A woman who prefers milder spices because she cannot afford the expensive hot ones exhibits an adaptive preference that looks autonomy-deficient even though the content is ethically neutral. If content alone were decisive, this case would pose no problem, yet the intuitive deficit persists.

Proponents reply that some content-based threshold—e.g., basic capabilities—is only a “floor” for full autonomy; above it, individuals may vary freely. This mitigates the paternalism worry but concedes that content alone cannot explain *all* autonomy deficits. We still need a story about process and history.

4. Historical–relational accounts: tracing the genealogy of preference  

Historical accounts contend that whether a preference is autonomous depends crucially on the conditions under which it was formed. An early version appears in Gerald Dworkin’s requirement that an agent have had “the capacity and opportunity for critical reflection” at the time of acquisition. Contemporary feminist authors—Meyers, Oshana, Benson, and especially Natalie Stoljar—sharpen this idea by emphasising the *relational* nature of autonomy. They insist that social power can so structure formative experiences that certain preferences, though reflectively endorsed, remain products of domination. On this view, the village woman’s preference is less than fully autonomous because it was inculcated by a patriarchal environment that systematically limited her imaginative and practical opportunities.

Several features make the historical approach attractive.

a) It explains why wholehearted endorsement may nonetheless be suspect. If endorsement results from earlier deprivation of alternatives, that endorsement inherits the taint. A child raised never to see a library cannot later, as an adult, disclaim the formative deprivation by a mere act of will.

b) It dissociates the autonomy verdict from the moral value of content. Even a morally innocuous preference (for mild spices) can be autonomy-deficient if it arose through coercive deprivation.

c) It accommodates degrees of autonomy. Because formative influences vary in their oppressiveness, preferences can be more or less autonomous, matching our intuitions that adaptive preferences lie on a continuum.

To make the model precise, however, we need criteria for when social influence crosses the line into autonomy-undermining oppression. Two complementary proposals appear in the literature.

i) Coercion and manipulation. A formative process is disqualifying if it involved coercion, threats, or manipulation that bypassed the agent’s critical faculties. The difficulty here is that many adaptive preferences develop without overt coercion; subtle cultural messages suffice.

ii) Systematic deprivation of options. Stoljar’s “constraint view” therefore adds that a preference is non-autonomous if, during its formation, the agent lacked access to a range of *feasible* alternatives that would have appeared choice-worthy under minimally decent social conditions. This criterion shifts the emphasis from psychological interference to the objective structure of opportunity.

Critics raise two worries. First, ordinary socialisation always limits the range of imaginable options; does the constraint view imply that no one is fully autonomous? Second, the further back we trace etiological lines, the more pervasive domination seems; how can the agent ever regain self-ownership?

5. Objections and replies  

5.1 The over-breadth objection  

If every social influence that shapes preference counted as autonomy-defeating, the concept of autonomy would empty out. But relational theorists need not adopt such a sweeping stance. The key distinction is not between “influence” and “no influence” but between *legitimate* and *illegitimate* influence. Socialisation undermines autonomy when:

• it is systematically aimed at limiting a class of people’s aspirations, and  
• it blocks or penalises the exercise of critical reflection on that limitation.

Under these conditions the formative process is not merely *shaping* but *dominating*. The comparison with democratic persuasion helps: learning civic virtues through discussion informs without foreclosing, whereas patriarchal conditioning forecloses before discussion can occur.

5.2 The historical scepticism objection  

Suppose my current preference for philosophy was partly shaped by a charismatic teacher I encountered by chance. Had I met a different mentor, I might prefer biology. Does that contingency undermine my autonomy? Historical theorists reply that contingency alone is not autonomy-defeating; what matters is whether the influence operated through oppressive mechanisms. Chance is consistent with autonomy; domination is not.

5.3 The diachronic redemption objection  

Can agents autonomously endorse a once-adaptive preference after later critical reflection? Imagine the village woman migrates, encounters diverse options, and *still* prefers domesticity. Many historical theorists allow that subsequent, well-informed reflection can rehabilitate the preference. The autonomy deficit is not metaphysically permanent; it persists only while the causal history remains epistemically hidden or its oppressive roots unacknowledged. Once the agent knowingly re-endorses the preference in a context of genuine alternatives, autonomy is restored.

6. Toward an integrated account  

Although the historical-relational model best captures the intuitive deficit of adaptive preferences, it benefits from borrowing two insights:

From the subjectivist camp it should keep the endorsement requirement. Even after oppressive formation, autonomy cannot be ascribed unless the agent now identifies with the preference. Conversely, if she repudiates it, the preference ceases to express her agency, however benign its history.

From the content-based camp it can adopt a *threshold of practical possibility*. Some preferences—e.g., for self-mutilation under duress—so deeply injure basic capacities that no process, however benign, could ratify them as autonomous. Thus content places outer bounds on what can count as self-rule.

The synthesis yields a tripartite test:

A preference P of agent A is fully autonomous only if:

1. Endorsement: A presently identifies with P after reflectively scrutinising it.  
2. History: P was not formed, nor is it now sustained, by social processes that systematically deprived A of access to relevant alternatives or silenced critical reflection.  
3. Content floor: P does not condemn A to a life beneath the threshold of basic capabilities required for further exercises of autonomy.

Adaptive preferences typically fail at least condition (2) and sometimes (3), even when (1) is satisfied, thereby illuminating their autonomy deficit without erasing the possibility of future redemption.

7. Conclusion  

Why are adaptive preferences—those moulded by constrained options—less than fully autonomous? Subjectivist structural models stall because they ignore oppressive background conditions; content-based models veer toward paternalism and cannot explain valence-neutral cases. Historical–relational accounts, by contrast, trace the deficit to the formative context of domination that narrows imagination and forecloses critical possibilities. Their power lies in recognising that autonomy is not a momentary property of isolated wills but a temporally extended achievement dependent on social arrangements. Still, a complete theory should retain the structural requirement of endorsement and a minimal content constraint to protect the very possibility of future self-rule. The resulting integrated view vindicates our intuition: when agents adapt their desires to unjust constraints, something has gone wrong with self-government—not because their wills lack internal harmony, nor merely because their ends are unworthy, but because the social world has denied them the freedom to want otherwise.
