A decision rule is supposed to issue guidance an agent can act on.  CDT, in the case as stated, has no such stable recommendation.  The agent cannot even finish calculating before the output changes.

b) Violation of ratifiability.  
Richard Jeffrey’s ratifiability requirement says that a rational choice should be such that, having chosen it, you would not wish to revise it on the basis of your new information (in this case, the fact that you will in fact perform it).  The action CDT currently favours (e.g. Aleppo when p > ½) is unratiﬁable, because once you settle on it the prerequisite probabilities shift and it ceases to be recommended.

c) Threat of diachronic Dutch books and money pumps.  
Arntzenius, McCarthy and others have designed betting schemes exploiting the looping recommendations of CDT agents in these set-ups; during each flip of preference money can be extracted.  A decision rule that exposes an ideally rational agent to a sure-loss set of bets is normally deemed defective.

d) Undue dependence on trivial psychological facts.  
The normative status of an act should depend—so many think—on the agent’s evidence and utilities, not on arbitrary features of the contingent path her reasoning happens to take through belief space.  Yet CDT makes your currently favoured city rationally inferior precisely because it is currently favoured.

5. Possible ways of defusing the worry

A defender of CDT might try one of four lines.

i) The “include mixed acts” reply.  
If the option “flip a fair coin and go where it dictates” is added, CDT stabilises on that option.  Since a mixed strategy is causally efficacious in the ordinary sense (the coin toss partly determines the outcome), CDT can recommend it without violating its own principles.

There are two rejoinders.  First, the original story stipulates a forced binary choice; adding a randomizer is changing the case.  Second, even if the randomiser is available, CDT tells you to use it only because you are now 50-50 about doing so, which reinscribes the ratifiability problem one level up.

ii) The “psychological causation” reply.  
One could argue that your decision is causally upstream of Death’s prediction, because the prediction is derived from a model of that very decision.  If so, CDT would instruct you to treat Death’s location as contingent on what you do, in which case both cities come out equally bad and the theory is not unstable.

But ordinary causal direction is forward-pointing in time, and the story insists that Death’s prediction is fixed before the act is chosen.  The dependency is merely evidential, not causal, so this manoeuvre amounts to collapsing CDT into Evidential Decision Theory in this domain, conceding the original distinction.

iii) The “deliberation doesn’t change probabilities” reply.  
Why, the defender might ask, should an agent’s credence that she will go to Damascus change before she finishes deliberating?  An ideal agent assigns probability 1 to acting in conformity with the recommendation of her decision theory; while she is still calculating, she has not yet formed any act-probabilities at all.

This reply conflicts with standard Bayesian models of practical cognition in which an agent has self-locating degrees of belief about her future behaviour even while undecided.  Moreover, recommendations of CDT are often applied to boundedly rational agents for whom the very process of calculating outputs takes time; forbidding interim credences makes the theory normatively silent during that interval.

iv) The “embrace the instability” reply.  
Perhaps rationality really does demand cycling until one lands on the knife-edge.  If so, the phenomenon is a feature, not a bug, showing how subtle rational choice can be.

The problem with this bravado is two-fold.  First, the cycles can in principle be driven arbitrarily many times by arbitrarily small bets, leading to certain loss.  Second, when the deadline for action arrives, the agent will not generally be exactly at the fixed point, so her final act will violate the very standard she claims to follow.

6. Deeper diagnosis: The act-probability feedback loop

Why does CDT exhibit this special sensitivity?  Because it tells us to evaluate act A by looking at Pr(S) for each state S that is not downstream of A.  In the Damascus scenario the salient upstream state—Death’s city—is probabilistically but not causally correlated with A.  And the strength of that correlation is itself a monotonically increasing function of the agent’s credence in A.  (In the symmetric case it is exactly ρp+(1−ρ)(1−p).)  So EU(A) inherits a direct dependence on Pr(A).  Any change in doxastic attitude towards A is mirrored by a change in its expected utility.  Feedback of this kind is absent in paradigmatic decision problems such as Newcomb, because there the predicting mechanism is assumed perfect (ρ = 1), making the dependence discontinuous rather than smoothly varying; CDT simply respects the dominance of one box in that case.  Imperfect prediction exposes the underlying continuity and makes the dependence explicit.

The phenomenon is general: whenever an upstream variable is a (possibly noisy) predictor of the act, CDT’s treatment of that variable’s probability as unconditional ties the quality of the act to the agent’s current self-confidence.  Rasmussen’s “apple path” examples and Arntzenius’s “confusion rockets” all share this structure.

7. Comparison with EDT and other theories

Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) conditions on the act when computing the relevant probabilities.  In Damascus, EDT sees that if you were to go to Damascus (condition on D), then it is almost certain that Death predicted D, so EU(D) ≈ −1000; similarly, EU(A) ≈ −1000.  With symmetric costs it is indifferent between the two.  More importantly, EDT’s conditional probabilities do not vary with Pr(D) itself, so the instability disappears.  (A more sophisticated variant of EDT that uses Jeffrey conditioning yields the same result.)  Thus the dependence of CDT on act probabilities is not an unavoidable consequence of instrumental rationality—it is specific to the causal discounting rule.

Recently, Updateless Decision Theory, Functional Decision Theory, and other “policy-selection” views have been advertised as avoiding the problem altogether, because they do not iterate conditionalisation as deliberation proceeds.  Whether or not one endorses these theories, their existence shows that a different architecture of practical reasoning can handle Damascus cases without feedback whiplash.

8. Is there nevertheless a principled defence of CDT?

One might appeal to a “fundamental principle of causality”: acts cannot alter prior facts.  Since Death’s prediction is in the past, the unconditional probability CDT uses is the right one; nothing else is acceptable.  If the price of that metaphysical principle is deliberative instability, so be it.

Yet the metaphysical intuition is honoured equally by a version of CDT that uses Pearlian interventions: evaluate Pr(S|do(A)).  When the upstream variable is statistically but not causally linked, the do-operator sets that link to zero, yielding a distribution that is entirely independent of P(A).  The resultant theory coincides with EDT’s calm verdict in Damascus.  So one can keep a “causal” outlook while shedding the instability.  In effect, the root cause of the oscillations is not respect for causality, but the ancillary CDT rule “for independent variables, use the unconditional probabilities already in your belief state,” a rule that can be replaced.

9. Lessons and verdict

We can now answer the guiding question.

Yes, CDT’s dependence on the agent’s current probabilities for her own acts is a problem.  The problem is practical, epistemic and theoretical.

• Practically, an agent who follows CDT can enter infinite preference cycles, so the theory fails to supply usable guidance when guidance is most needed.

• Epistemically, CDT endorses choices that are unratiﬁable: once the agent takes herself to have made them, she will know that by her own lights they were the wrong choices.

• Theoretically, the feedback link between P(A) and EU(A) is an artefact of CDT’s rule for handling upstream correlates; other decision rules that respect causal independence avoid the artefact, so it is not a benign feature of any causal view, but a removable blemish on CDT itself.

To be sure, a staunch causal decision theorist can preserve CDT by letting mixed strategies in, or by denying that ideal agents ever have self-probabilities during deliberation, or by biting the bullet on instability.  Each manoeuvre, however, extracts a cost: expanding the menu, distorting plausible doxastic dynamics, or accepting practical incoherence.  Faced with these costs, many have concluded that CDT in its classical guise is inadequate.  Whether one opts for a Pearl-style causal decision theory, a ratifiability-constrained update to CDT, or a more radical departure such as policy selection, the Death in Damascus puzzle shows that the unconditional-probability clause at the heart of CDT cannot be the last word on rational choice.

10. Conclusion

Death in Damascus teaches that when predictions about our choices are only very nearly perfect, CDT ties the evaluation of an act to our moment-to-moment confidence in performing it.  That tie creates cycles and unratiﬁability, and it exposes agents to sure-loss exploitation.  Because other decision theories escape these fates without sacrificing causal scruples, the dependence is best read as a flaw.  CDT, at least in its textbook formulation, therefore needs repair or replacement if it is to serve as a fully adequate guide to rational deliberation.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
Deliberation and Fate: Should Causal Decision Theory Worry about its Sensitivity to the Agent’s Own Act-Probabilities?  

1. Setting the Stage  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells a deliberating agent to evaluate each available act A by the utility she would expect were she to perform A, weighting the possible causal predecessors of A by their unconditional probabilities.  The celebrated “Death in Damascus’’ scenario (from Gibbard & Harper 1978, recast by Ahmed 2014) is designed to make CDT look uncomfortable.  You have an appointment with Death tomorrow.  Death is extraordinarily good at predicting where you will go, though not perfect.  If he predicts you will be in a city, he positions himself there to meet you.  You are currently in Damascus.  If you stay, you expect him to be waiting in Damascus with very high probability; if you flee to Aleppo you expect him to have followed you there with somewhat lower probability, because—so the story goes—Death has a mild antecedent bias for Damascus.  (Call d the probability that Death guesses “Damascus’’ irrespective of your eventual act; d > ½.)  

Crucially, the correlation between your act and Death’s location is endogenous: the better you reckon Death is at prediction, the more tightly you must correlate his location with what you end up doing.  In consequence, the expected utilities of your options are sensitive to your current, in-the-moment subjective probability that you will perform them.  And those probabilities usually shift as you deliberate.  The question is whether that dependence is a defect in CDT.

2. Why the Dependence Looks Puzzling  

Suppose you start out leaning 70-30 toward fleeing to Aleppo.  Since you believe Death is a near-perfect predictor, you also assign roughly a 70-30 credence that he has gone to Aleppo.  Because he prefers Damascus slightly, the numbers are not exactly the same—say you end up with  

P(Death in Aleppo | go to Aleppo) = .97  
P(Death in Damascus | stay in Damascus) = .995  

while the cross-terms (Death in Aleppo | stay) and (Death in Damascus | flee) are tiny.  Let uL be the utility of living, uD that of dying, with uL ─ uD > 0.  For any realistic values, CDT will now tell you that the expected utility of staying put in Damascus (.005·uL + .995·uD) is worse than that of fleeing (.03·uL + .97·uD).  So CDT now recommends flight.

But the moment you take that recommendation seriously, you update: your probability of actually fleeing shoots past 70%.  Conditional coherence pushes up P(Death in Aleppo), because you think he tracks you.  Expected utility differences shrink.  Push the point far enough and a reversal threatens: if the probability of flight becomes 99%, the chance Death is already in Aleppo becomes roughly 99% as well, and Damascus regains the upper hand.  The CDT verdict swings back.  A naïve CDT agent bounces like a ball between the options (“Aleppo is better… no, Damascus is better…’’) and risks interminable dithering.

The bare dependence of the evaluation on P(act) does not yet show CDT is wrong.  All decision theories must describe what happens inside deliberation, and it is unremarkable that one’s changing self-beliefs can move expected utilities around.  Still, many find the oscillatory pattern suspicious, and three distinct worries have been pressed:

   Worry 1: Dynamic instability.  CDT seems unable to converge on a stable decision because its recommendations shift in tandem with credences that themselves respond to its recommendations.

   Worry 2: Diachronic incoherence.  Even if a CDT agent eventually acts, the path to action appears to violate intuitive norms of rational belief updating: her probability for Death’s whereabouts is being driven by fluctuations in an essentially self-referential proposition, namely “I will go to Aleppo’’.

   Worry 3: Exploitability or “money-pump’’ vulnerability.  An external party who can make you reconsider (say by quoting a poem about Damascus every time you plump for Aleppo) can keep you churning indefinitely, extracting small costs each time and leaving you worse off overall.

If any of those worries stick, the dependence of CDT on act-probabilities threatens to be a fatal problem rather than an innocuous feature.

3. The Dynamic Instability Worry  

A fully worked CDT requires the agent to feed in a probability function that is already self-consistent: probabilities for propositions about her future actions must match the causal structure that she believes connects her acts to upstream states.  That means there must be a fixed point where the probability she assigns to “I go to Aleppo’’ equals the probability that emerges after she runs the CDT calculation and chooses accordingly.  In technical terms, her credence function must be ratifiable (Joyce 1999).  If such a fixed point exists, CDT can tell a stable story: form only ratifiable credences, then act on them, and no oscillation occurs.  

Does the Death in Damascus set-up admit a fixed point?  Yes; typically there are two.  One involves certainty of staying, the other certainty of fleeing.  Take the “sure flight’’ point.  If P(Aleppo)=1, the agent must also believe Death is in Aleppo with probability ≈1 (he is almost perfect).  Expected utility is then approximately uD, identical whichever city she is in, so either act is tied.  Ties are usually resolved by indifference, and indifference is consistent with P(Aleppo)=1.  Mutatis mutandis for the “sure Damascus’’ point.  Hence CDT can defend itself: rational deliberators restrict themselves to ratifiable credence states.  Oscillation is a pathology arising only because we imagined an illicit starting point (70-30) that was not self-ratifying.

Two rejoinders are common.  First, it seems psychologically unrealistic to require agents to begin deliberation in a state that is already perfectly ratified.  Realists about bounded rationality will insist that learning often begins with partial credence in competing acts.  If CDT cannot guide such an agent without threatening paralysis, something pragmatic is amiss.  Second, tie situations leave CDT indifferent between mutually incompatible certainties.  Which one should the agent pick?  Absent an answer, the theory lapses into arbitrariness.  So dynamics matter after all.

4. The Diachronic Incoherence Worry  

Orthodox Bayesianism distinguishes between ordinary empirical propositions and self-referential ones about the agent’s own future choices.  The latter, it is argued, should not be treated as “ordinary evidence’’ in the course of updating (Spohn 1977, Levi 1989).  An agent can choose which act to perform, not discover it.  If one buys this divide, treating “my probability of fleeing is 70%’’ as a piece of evidence about where Death is lurking looks illicit.  CDT’s dependence on that figure therefore appears to smuggle in an impermissible form of self-locating information.

The diachronic version of the complaint is that the agent’s evolving P(Death in Aleppo) is driven by nothing in the external world, only by alterations in her own act-probabilities, and hence her belief revision does not track truth.  But Bayesian orthodoxy already countenances such auto-updates whenever you deliberate under Knightian uncertainty about your own actions (see Jeffrey 1965, Skyrms 1980).  Intuitively, if you start leaning toward backing a horse, you should correspondingly raise the chance you will hold a winning ticket, even before you have moved a muscle.  Doing otherwise leaves you liable to a Dutch Book against your own preferences.  So CDT can reply: the complained-of updates are not incoherent; they are the hallmark of rational reflection.

5. The Exploitability Worry  

Ahmed (2014) develops a money-pump in which an omniscient trickster repeatedly offers the CDT agent cheap last-minute travel vouchers to switch plans, harvesting a fee each time the agent flips.  If the trickster can time his offers to moments when CDT favours the opposite city, the agent will always pay.  When morning comes she ends up where she began, minus a pile of fees.  That is intuitively irrational.

Defenders invoke again the ratifiability constraint: an agent who realises the trickster’s scheme will foresee the succession of offers, factor them into her decision model, and settle at a stable credence from which CDT yields a determinate recommendation not to switch.  The dynamic incoherence is an artefact of ignoring the game-theoretic setting, not a flaw in CDT’s core principles.

The exploitability debate turns on empirical assumptions about how difficult it is, psychologically, to hold ratifiable credences in the presence of very predictive opponents.  If humans inevitably wobble, perhaps rationality norms should be forgiving; but that points to a limitation of *any* theory that demands unbounded Bayesian self-control, not of CDT specifically.

6. A Deeper Worry: Counterfactual Fragility  

So far we have talked about shifting probabilities during deliberation.  Another angle moots that the *very idea* of unconditional probabilities for Death’s location, given an act that is strongly correlated with it, is fragile.  CDT instructs us to calculate P(Death in Aleppo | do Aleppo) as if the act could be “surgically’’ overridden while holding fixed the causal past.  Yet in Death in Damascus the predictive success of Death arguably depends on deep facts about the agent’s dispositions; to imagine her suddenly packing for Aleppo while all else stays the same may be metaphysically incoherent.  If so, CDT’s core conditional—“the probability of S were I to do A’’—is ill-defined.  The dependence on act-probabilities then signals a more general counterfactual pathology: the theory asks us to evaluate conditionals whose antecedents cannot be wiggle-roomed independently of upstream correlates.

This line pushes us toward either (a) abandoning CDT in favour of something, like Evidential Decision Theory, that is explicitly correlation friendly, or (b) amending CDT so that it talks not of single-act interventions but of *policy* interventions—stable dispositions that can coherently be supposed different without scrambling the whole web of correlations.  Versions of (b) include Joyce’s (2012) “Evidential-cautious CDT’’ and Menzies-Price’s (1993) view that breaks causes into “structuring conditions’’.

7. So—Is the Dependence a Problem?  

Let us distil the dialectic.

(1) It is undeniable that, given the usual ingredients of Death in Damascus and given CDT’s equations, expected utility for each act is a function of the agent’s credence that she will perform it.

(2) That feature can generate unstable deliberational dynamics if the agent’s initial credence is not already a fixed point.

(3) Such instability strikes many as counter-intuitive, and can be exploited by outside parties in stylised scenarios.  

However:

(4) The instability vanishes once we impose the ratifiability norm that is already implicit in CDT’s demand for self-consistent unconditional probabilities.

(5) Plausible rival theories (e.g. Evidential Decision Theory) face analogous dynamics in anthropic or “psycho-killer’’ cases where the evidential impact of your own decision is huge.

Therefore the crux is whether ratifiability—as opposed to the raw CDT calculus—counts as an ad hoc repair or as an independently motivated rationality requirement.  My view is that ratifiability is well-motivated.  Incomplete, unratified credence states are not yet genuine candidates for action; they are like half-written probability functions, internally infected with a foreseen future revision.  A decision theory’s job begins only once the agent has a fully coherent credence-utility pair.  On that conception, the shifting of expected utilities during the earlier, “proto-deliberative’’ phase is not a recommendation of CDT at all; it is the agent’s own attempt to arrive at such a pair.

Still, the Death in Damascus case teaches an important moral.  In worlds containing superb predictors, the causal counterfactuals on which CDT relies become exquisitely sensitive to how one models the surgical intervention on one’s act.  If the only coherent interventions are at the level of dispositions or mixed strategies, CDT should be reformulated accordingly.  Doing so blunts the dependence of expected utility on instantaneous act-probabilities, replacing it with dependence on the probabilities of adopting whole policies.  At that level, stable and determinate recommendations are restored.

8. Conclusion  

The sensitivity of CDT’s act evaluations to the agent’s on-line probability of performing those very acts is, in itself, not a decisive objection.  It is a predictable by-product of (i) Bayesian coherence and (ii) CDT’s usage of causal, rather than purely statistical, conditionals.  The apparent pathologies it engenders in Death in Damascus dissipate once we (a) demand ratifiable credence states and (b) acknowledge that the correct objects of causal evaluation in strongly predictive environments are policies or dispositions, not momentary choices.

Nonetheless the case is valuable.  It exposes a tension between two desiderata: local, act-by-act causal evaluation and global strategic stability in the face of powerful correlational feedback.  To resolve the tension, champions of CDT must articulate a richer account of counterfactual intervention or embrace policy-level, rather than act-level, decision theory.  Whether one sees that as a modification of CDT or a migration to a new theory will depend on how flexibly one reads the label “CDT’’.  

Either way, the mere dependence of expected utility on self-assignments of act-probability is not the decisive threat; the deeper lesson is about how causal reasoning must be adapted when the world contains minds reading minds.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is usually advertised as a theory that tells us how to choose rationally when the consequences of our acts depend only on the causal up-shots of those acts.  If you are deciding whether to pack an umbrella, CDT instructs you to compute for each alternative its expected utility with respect to the probabilities of states that are not caused by your act—e.g. whether it will rain—and to pick the act with highest causal expected utility.  In ordinary choice problems this procedure is silent about what probability you assign to performing the various acts under consideration.  That fits an intuitive picture of deliberation: first decide which act is best, then perform it.  In ‘‘Death in Damascus’’–style problems, however, the causal probabilities of the relevant states—viz. the city in which Death is waiting—depend on your own probability of acting one way rather than another.  Consequently, the causal expected utility that CDT assigns to ‘go to Damascus’ varies as your degree of confidence that you will go to Damascus varies while you deliberate.  Philosophers have worried that this sensitivity makes CDT dynamically unstable and therefore normatively defective.  The purpose of this essay is to examine whether the dependence in question is really a flaw in CDT, and, if it is, to diagnose exactly why.

I shall proceed as follows.  §2 sets out the Death in Damascus case and shows in detail how the causal expected utilities of the competing acts shift with changes in the agent’s self-probabilities.  §3 articulates three related complaints: the instability complaint, the ratifiability complaint, and the deliberation-crowding complaint.  §4 defends CDT against an over-hasty version of these complaints: the mere fact that expected utilities move with self-probabilities is not yet a reductio of CDT.  §5 argues, however, that when we press the dynamics of deliberation, the dependence yields a genuine incoherence: CDT violates a Reflection requirement that any plausible decision rule must satisfy.  §6 sketches two ways in which a proponent of CDT might try to patch the theory—(i) by adding a ratifiability constraint, and (ii) by endorsing a policy-selection or mixed-strategy version of CDT—and explains why neither fix really remedies the underlying defect.  §7 concludes that the dependence on self-probabilities is indeed a serious problem for orthodox CDT because it prevents the theory from underwriting stable deliberative commitment.  

2. Death in Damascus and the moving target of causal expected utility  

The story, due originally to Donald Davidson and popularised by Bas van Fraassen and Bryson Brown, runs thus.  You know that the Angel of Death is after you and that he is an excellent but not perfect predictor.  If Death predicts you will go to Damascus, he will wait in Damascus; if he predicts Aleppo, he will wait in Aleppo.  You must now decide where to travel.  You also know a quantitative detail: Death guesses Damascus with prior probability 2/3 and Aleppo with probability 1/3.  Moreover, his conditional accuracy is high: if he predicts a city, the chance (from your point of view) that you will indeed go there is 0.9.  The utilities are stark: surviving the day is worth 0, dying is -1.  Travel costs and scenery don’t matter.

Let p be your present subjective probability that you will go to Damascus.  The causal probabilities that CDT asks you to use in computing expected utilities are the prior probabilities of the state ‘Death waits in Damascus’ conditional on your act.  However, because Death’s location is generated by a predictive mechanism keyed to your act, these conditional probabilities depend on p itself:

P(Damascus | go to Damascus) = 0.9 + 0.1·(1-p)           (1a)  
P(Damascus | go to Aleppo)   = 0.1 + 0.9·p               (1b)

Explanation.  If you go to Damascus, there are two routes by which Death ends up there: he predicted Damascus and you complied (probability 0.9), or he predicted Aleppo but you surprised him and went to Damascus anyway (probability 0.1·(1-p)).  A symmetric calculation yields (1b).

Given utilities Survive = 0, Die = –1, the causal expected utilities are just the negatives of the probabilities of meeting Death:

CEU(go-Dam)  = –P(Damascus | go-Dam)                     (2a)  
CEU(go-Ale)  = –P(Aleppo  | go-Ale)  = –(1 – P(Damascus | go-Ale)).  (2b)

Substituting from (1a,b) we obtain

CEU(go-Dam)  = –[0.9 + 0.1(1-p)]       = –0.9 – 0.1 + 0.1p = –1.0 + 0.1p  
CEU(go-Ale)  = –[0.1 + 0.9p]           = –0.1 – 0.9p.

These formulae exhibit the pivotal fact: as p changes during deliberation, both expected utilities shift.  In particular,

• If p < 0.5, CEU(go-Dam) < CEU(go-Ale); CDT prescribes Damascus.  
• If p > 0.5, CEU(go-Ale) < CEU(go-Dam); CDT prescribes Aleppo.  
• If p = 0.5, both acts tie.

Hence, an arbitrarily small swing in your present confidence about what you will do flips CDT’s recommendation.  Nothing else in the set-up changes—neither background probabilities nor utilities—only your self-belief.

3. Three worries about the dependence

3.1 Instability.  Deliberation is a process in which you reflect on reasons and update your confidence about what you will do.  In Damascus, the very act of updating tends to make CDT’s prescription oscillate.  Suppose you start unsure, p = 0.6.  Then CDT instructs you to go to Aleppo.  Recognising that you are now going to Aleppo drives p toward 0, because you become convinced that you will not go to Damascus.  Once p slips below 0.5, CDT now recommends Damascus.  Realising that you are headed for Damascus pushes p back up, making Aleppo preferable again, and so on ad infinitum.  The agent is caught in an endless cycle and never settles on an action.  Decision theory is meant to help you decide; a rule that systematically frustrates decision looks defective.

3.2 Ratifiability.  Richard Jeffrey and Gregory Kavka observed that rational agents should not perform acts that they expect themselves, on reflection, to regret.  An act A is ratifiable when, conditional on deliberatively believing that one will do A, A maximises expected utility.  In the Damascus set-up neither going to Damascus nor going to Aleppo is ratifiable, because believing that one will do it makes the other act appear better.  So CDT recommends acts that cannot be ratified from the inside, violating an appealing internalist desideratum on rational choice.

3.3 Deliberation crowding.  Joyce, Arntzenius, and Sørenson have argued that a decision rule should respect the ‘‘deliberation crowds out prediction’’ principle: learning facts about what you are about to do solely by introspecting your current intentions should not change which act is objectively best.  But in Death in Damascus, acquiring evidence about your own act (via self-probability drift) is the only thing that changes, and yet CDT flips verdicts.  That suggests the theory is inappropriately sensitive to one’s epistemic position rather than the de re structure of the problem.

4. Why the mere dependence is not by itself fatal  

Before condemning CDT we should note that any decision theory that incorporates causal correlations between an act and an external event will exhibit some dependence on the agent’s self-probabilities.  Even Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) shares this feature; in fact, in Death in Damascus EDT delivers exactly the same numbers as CDT, because the only evidence you get about Death’s location flows through your own action.  More generally, whenever the outcome-probabilities are generated by a predicting demon, those probabilities are conditional on what the demon expects you to do, which in turn is correlated with what you in fact do.  A theory that ignored these correlations would be causally obtuse.  So the sheer fact that CEUs vary with p cannot be a decisive objection.

Moreover, we should distinguish two kinds of dependence:

(i) Parameter sensitivity: the expected utility functions contain p as a parameter.  

(ii) Deliberative feedback: the process of computing and responding to those expected utilities causes p itself to move, generating cycles.

Only (ii) threatens practical irrationality.  A theory could be parameter sensitive yet, once a rational agent settles on a self-probability, output a stable recommendation.  The crucial question is whether CDT’s procedure forces rational agents into unstable feedback loops they cannot exit.

5. CDT violates a reflection requirement

To analyse the dynamics, suppose that deliberation proceeds in time-slices t = 1, 2, 3, … .  At each slice the agent has a credence p_t that she will go to Damascus.  She applies CDT to compute CEU_t(Dam) and CEU_t(Ale).  If CEU_t(Dam) < CEU_t(Ale) she forms the intention to go to Aleppo, and vice versa.  A minimal rationality norm, Reflection (van Fraassen 1984), says that one’s current credence in a proposition should equal one’s expected future credence, conditional on nothing more than the passage of time.  Put differently, you should anticipate the way you will update your beliefs.  When Reflection is satisfied, beliefs and intentions form martingales, and deliberation tends toward fixed points.  In Damascus, however, any initial credence other than exactly 0.5 leads immediately to a violation of Reflection.  

Proof sketch.  Let p_1 > 0.5.  Then at t=1 the agent intends Aleppo, so she knows that at t=2 her credence p_2 will plummet below 0.5.  But Reflection requires p_1 = E(p_2 | info at t=1), which is impossible because p_2 is expected to be <0.5.  So the requirements of CDT force the agent into a state that is transparently epistemically incoherent.  

The underlying reason is that CDT uses as inputs unconditional probabilities that are themselves unstable under expected introspection.  In any decision problem where the outcome-probabilities depend smoothly on one’s own future credence, applying CDT locally at each moment will break the martingale structure rational belief demands.  This is not just an artefact of predictor cases; similar phenomena arise in coordination games where one’s move conveys information to others about one’s type.  Therefore, the dependence is a genuine structural defect: CDT’s advice cannot be incorporated into a single self-consistent epistemic plan.

6. Can CDT be repaired?

6.1 Ratifiability filter.  Joyce (1992) proposes that a rational act must both (i) maximise causal expected utility and (ii) be ratifiable.  Because neither pure act is ratifiable, the only remaining candidates are mixed strategies: e.g. flip a fair coin, go to Damascus on Heads.  Indeed, the mixed strategy that assigns probability 0.5 to each city is ratifiable; given that probability, both cities tie and the agent is content.  Adding the ratifiability filter therefore outputs ‘randomise fifty-fifty’.

Does this save CDT?  No.  First, the justification for ratifiability is itself essentially evidential: we avoid choices we would expect to regret.  Bolting that principle onto CDT blurs the clear causal–evidential distinction CDT was meant to preserve.  Second, even with the filter, the decision process is fragile.  A minute deliberative perturbation away from exactly 0.5 reignites oscillation.  Third, mandating randomisation in a life-or-death scenario where a predictor is watching seems normatively suspect: after all, if Death sees the coin land Heads he can station himself accordingly; but if he cannot see the coin, then standard CDT already favoured Damascus or Aleppo depending on p, so the ratifiability move is unnecessary.  In short, ratifiability gerry-rigs CDT rather than vindicating it.

6.2 Policy or mixed-act CDT.  Another idea, due to Jefferys and Skyrms, is to treat the decision problem as one of choosing entire probability distributions over acts—policies—rather than point acts.  In effect the agent announces, ‘‘I will choose Damascus with probability q and Aleppo with 1-q.’’  One then computes causal expected utility for each policy and selects the q that maximises expected utility.  In Death in Damascus the policy that maximises expected utility is again q = 0.5.  Because the expected utility function over q is strictly concave, there is a unique maximum; the deliberation dynamics therefore converge to the mixed equilibrium.  Stability is restored.

Yet this manoeuvre changes CDT’s subject-matter.  The original theory was about choosing acts; this version is about choosing probability measures over acts.  While game theorists are comfortable with mixed strategies, ordinary practical reasoners rarely are.  Moreover, the cure presupposes that the mechanism dictating Death’s prediction is sensitive only to one’s chosen act, not to the randomization device or the announced distribution; but in predictor cases, the demon could in principle observe the whole process.  If Death predicts the probabilities themselves, we iterate the same instability at the next level.  Thus, mixed-act CDT merely displaces the problem.

7. Conclusion  

We can now answer the guiding question.  The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s evolving probability of acting is a problem, not merely an eccentricity, because it defeats CDT’s core practical purpose: to guide deliberation toward a stable, self-endorsing plan of action.  The dependence violates Reflection, undermines dynamic consistency, and forces agents into cycles of shifting intentions.  Attempts to patch CDT by layering ratifiability or by moving to policy choice either abandon CDT’s original rationale or push the instability one step up the meta-ladder.  Hence, unless one is prepared to accept deliberative paralysis or ad hoc repairs, one must concede that orthodox CDT is inadequate for Death in Damascus–style cases.  The lesson is not just parochial: any decision rule that treats one’s own prospective acts as free variables while simultaneously allowing outcome probabilities to track one’s beliefs about those very acts will run into the same difficulty.  The smarter moral is that rational deliberation requires a single unified fixed point of beliefs and intentions—a constraint that CDT, as traditionally formulated, does not respect.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) says that rational agents should choose the available act that maximises causal expected utility.  Roughly,

EUCDT(A) = Σs P(s | **do**(A)) · U(A, s)

where A ranges over the acts under the agent’s control, s over “states of the world,” and P(s | do(A)) is the agent’s unconditional (‘causal’) probability that s obtains, i.e. the probability that s would obtain were A performed, holding fixed only what is causally upstream of A.  In ordinary cases CDT delivers uncontroversial advice because the probabilities of the causally independent states are insensitive to which act one will actually perform: as long as smoking does not causally affect lung cancer, P(cancer | do(smoke)) = P(cancer | do(not-smoke)).  In Newcomb-type problems, however, the act correlates with an upstream predictor, so the unconditional probabilities that go into the CDT calculation depend on the agent’s own credence that she will in fact perform an act.  The “Death in Damascus” story brings this feature into sharp relief.

2. The Death in Damascus case  

A traveller in Damascus is told by an omniscient but not infallible oracle:

   “Death has predicted where you will spend tomorrow.  If he predicts Damascus, he goes to Damascus; if he predicts Aleppo, he goes to Aleppo.  He is not perfect, but he is very reliable, and moreover he has a prior bias toward thinking people stay in Damascus.”

Your utility tomorrow is +10 if you survive, –∞ if you meet Death.  Travelling costs ε > 0.  Because Death tends to guess Damascus, before deliberation you are 75 % confident that his prediction is “Damascus” no matter what you do, and consequently you assign 75 % credence that Death will be in Damascus.  All of that credence is upstream of your act; where you go does not send a signal back in time.  You now deliberate whether to remain in Damascus or buy a ticket to Aleppo.

3. Why the numbers inside the CDT calculation move while you deliberate  

Let P(A) be your current credence that you will end up going to Aleppo.  The unconditional probability that Death will be in Aleppo is the probability that he predicted Aleppo, which by reliability considerations is roughly P(A) · r + (1–P(A)) · (1–r – bias) … in short, the better you think the predictor is and the more likely you think you are to choose Aleppo, the more likely you must judge that Death foretold Aleppo.  Thus:

P(Death in Aleppo) = f(P(A)).  
P(Death in Damascus) = 1 – f(P(A)).

Consequently the causal expected utilities of the acts are

EUCDT(Aleppo) = –ε + (1 – f(P(A)))·10 + f(P(A))·(–∞)  
EUCDT(Damascus) = 0 + f(P(A))·10 + (1 – f(P(A)))·(–∞).

Because f is strictly increasing in P(A), EUCDT(Aleppo) is highest when P(A) is low; EUCDT(Damascus) is highest when P(A) is high.  As you reflect on what these utilities look like, you thereby alter P(A).  A familiar dynamic ensues:

   • You start neutral.  You notice that if you were to stay in Damascus (P(A) ≈ 0), then the predictor probably put Death in Damascus, so going to Aleppo looks better.  
   • On forming the intention to go to Aleppo, you raise P(A) toward 1.  Now you judge it likely that Death predicted Aleppo, so suddenly Damascus looks safer.  
   • Switching your intention back to Damascus drops P(A), flipping the utilities again.

The agent ricochets between the options; there is no probability at which the causal expected utilities tie unless the predictor is exactly 50 % reliable and unbiased.  CDT’s recommendation flips every time the agent’s credence about her own future act moves, and that credence in turn moves whenever the recommendation flips.  The deliberation is unstable; no fixed point is reachable.

4. Is this a defect in CDT?  

A. The guidance complaint  

A decision theory is supposed to guide action.  In Death in Damascus, CDT fails to issue stable advice.  At any moment it produces a recommendation, but it simultaneously guarantees that, were the agent to be guided by that recommendation, she would change her mind an instant later.  That looks like self-defeat: the outputs of the theory cannot be coherently acted upon by a deliberating agent who follows the theory’s own rules for updating beliefs.

The critic need not insist that rational deliberation always terminates; but a theory that, under ideal reflection, predicts perpetual vacillation in otherwise ordinary circumstances seems ill-suited to the task of guidance.

B. Dynamic (in)consistency  

Standard norms of rationality require an agent to be dynamically consistent, i.e. not to ever prefer A to B while foreseeing that, immediately after adopting A, she will prefer B to A on unchanged information.  CDT in Death in Damascus forces exactly such foreseen preference reversals.  The moment the agent leans toward Aleppo she foresees that once the leaning is strong enough she will prefer Damascus.  That violates even weak forms of the “principle of reflection” (van Fraassen) or sophisticated choice consistency (Strotz, Hammond).

C. Dependence on arbitrary credences about one’s own act  

CDT consults the unconditional probabilities of states that are not causally downstream.  But those probabilities sometimes depend on P(A) where A is the very act we are evaluating.  The numerical value of P(A) is not determined by anything outside the agent’s epistemic perspective; it is whatever credence about her own future act she currently contingently has.  That looks epistemically accidental.  Two agents alike in every respect except degree of self-confidence would compute different causal expected utilities from identical background information.  Many take this to show that CDT imports a wrong kind of subjectivity: acts that are intuitively equally risky get different scores merely because the agent is more or less sure which act she is going to take.

D. Exploitability considerations  

If there were bookmakers able to trade with CDT agents on the basis of their unstable preferences, the agents would be susceptible to Dutch books and money pumps: every time the preference flips, the agent would pay a small premium to switch future plans, eventually forfeiting unbounded expected utility.  Susceptibility to sure loss is widely regarded as a mark of irrationality.

E. The tie-breaking retreat  

Defenders sometimes reply: “The rational CDT agent should refuse to deliberate about questions that influence P(A).  She should treat her own choice as exogenous, fix P(A) at ½, calculate both expected utilities, and act on the result.”  But that answer deprives CDT of its selling point—namely, that it tells us how to deliberate rationally given all our information.  Moreover, the rule “never update P(A)” is ad hoc; there was nothing irrational in the traveller’s learning about her own inclinations during honest reflection.

On balance, the dependence on act probabilities looks like a genuine difficulty for CDT.

5. Can CDT be patched?  

Five main repair strategies have been explored:

1. Ratificationism (Eells, Jeffrey, Jackson & Pargetter)  
   An act is rational only if it would still be chosen after taking into account the fact that it would be chosen.  Formally, A is rational if A maximises expected utility when conditionalised on the proposition that the agent chooses A.  In Death in Damascus, conditionalising on Choose-Aleppo raises the probability that Death foresaw Aleppo to near certainty, making Aleppo unattractive; conditionalising on Choose-Damascus has the symmetric effect.  No act ratifies itself, so the theory says that there is no rational option.  While avoiding oscillation, ratificationism collapses into nihilism here; many find that unacceptable.

2. Fixed-point CDT (Joyce)  
   Require that the agent’s credences about her future act be such that the act they render EU-maximising is just that act.  One solves P(A) = g(P(A)), a fixed-point problem.  In Death in Damascus there is no fixed point unless the predictor is exactly 50-50.  Again, when the equations have no solution the theory is silent.

3. Recombinant acts or policy selection (Gibbard & Harper, Skyrms, Yudkowsky)  
   Instead of evaluating single-stage acts, evaluate complete policies mapping possible informational states to actions; causal probabilities are taken with respect to the policy as a whole, which is upstream of the predictor.  Then your deliberation concerns which policy to adopt, not which city to visit.  Because Death tracks tomorrow’s city, not the policy, the probabilities that enter the calculation are policy-independent, curing instability.  That proposal, however, requires enlarging the option set in a way that changes CDT’s content and abandons the act-centrism that originally motivated the theory.

4. Two-box compliant CDT (Ahmed & Price)  
   Augment CDT with a principle of “reflective equilibrium” that disallows reliance on unstable self-predictions.  One variant instructs the agent to treat her own future act as causally upstream of the predictor whenever she knows the predictor’s algorithm is itself sensitive to her dispositions.  But this is to move CDT in the direction of evidential decision theory, undercutting the purported advantage of causal over evidential reasoning.

5. Abandon CDT for EDT or FDT  
   Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) or the more recent Functional Decision Theory (FDT) does not condition on do(A) but on A itself (EDT) or on the algorithm that determines A (FDT).  In Death in Damascus both say “Go to Aleppo; the fact that you are going correlates with Death’s being there, so you want the negative correlation.”  They deliver stable advice.  But CDT partisans typically reject EDT/FDT because of their performance in other cases (Smoking lesion, mechanical blackmail, etc.).

6. Is the problem unique to improbable predictor scenarios?  

Some defenders note that perfectly rational agents are fully self-predictable, so their self-credences should always be either 0 or 1, not intermediate.  If P(A) is 0 or 1, EUCDT(A) is well-defined and stable.  The oscillation arises only for decision makers who are uncertain about their own future act.  But real human agents invariably are uncertain.  A decision theory that works only for idealised perfect predictors of themselves is at best incomplete.

Furthermore, there are ordinary everyday situations—e.g., choosing whether to grab an umbrella when the weather forecast may have used CCTV to gauge how many umbrellas commuters are carrying—in which one’s action is correlated with a past predictor yet one reasonably harbours mixed credences about which act one will perform.  CDT’s instability then matters in practice.

7. Does the instability reflect a deep truth about rational agency?  

A radical interpretation holds that the oscillation is not a bug but an insight: whenever the world contains powerful predictors of our behaviour, we are caught in strategic interaction with them, and the correct rational play may indeed lack a pure-strategy equilibrium.  The “oscillating” CDT agent approximates the mixed-strategy equilibria known from game theory.  On this reading, the agent should randomise; what looks like vacillation is simply the internal implementation of a mixed strategy.

Yet the CDT computation does not recommend a particular probability mix; it makes recommendations that flip unboundedly fast, not the measured indifference of a mixed-strategy equilibrium.  Moreover, Death in Damascus is not a game of simultaneous choice but one of prediction; the mixed-strategy analysis therefore lacks a clear foundation.

8. Philosophical upshot  

The Death in Damascus instability exploits a structural feature of CDT: by purging evidential relations that run through your own choice, CDT forces the probabilities of downstream outcomes to be evaluated in terms of how likely they would be if you performed A.  But in predictor cases, the non-causal correlation between A and the target state is mediated precisely by the fact that you will perform A.  Hence CDT must consult P(A), and as P(A) moves the evaluation moves with it.  Unless the P(A) dependence can be eliminated or rendered stable, CDT will violate the basic desideratum that a decision theory provide consistent, action-guiding prescriptions.

One might try to live with the difficulty, arguing that genuine rationality sometimes is dynamically unstable.  Yet most philosophers, including many defenders of CDT in other debates, judge that rationality should at least permit convergence under ideal deliberation.  The Death in Damascus case shows that unmodified CDT fails that test.

9. Conclusion  

Yes, the dependence of CDT’s advice on the agent’s evolving act probabilities is a problem.  It makes the theory:

   • practically non-guiding, because deliberation never converges;  
   • dynamically inconsistent, forcing foreseeable preference reversals;  
   • epistemically arbitrary, letting momentary self-confidence sway expected utilities; and  
   • prey to exploitability.

Attempts to patch the theory either (a) deprive CDT of its distinctive causal flavour, (b) yield silence in predictor cases, or (c) import new ad hoc constraints on deliberation.  The most promising fixes in effect abandon act-centred CDT for policy-centred or evidential relatives.

For those who regard stability and action-guidance as non-negotiable criteria of rational choice, Death in Damascus is fatal to classical CDT.  At minimum it shows that any defensible causal decision theory must be supplemented with an account of self-locating credence and policy selection that prevents expected utilities from riding on the very probabilities that the agent is in the act of settling.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction: the case and the worry

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) characterises the value of an act A as the sum of the utilities of possible states S weighted by the probabilities P(S│do A) that those states would obtain were A performed.  A central selling-point of CDT is that it tells the agent to ignore merely evidential correlations between her act and earlier, causally independent events.  In Newcomb’s problem, for example, CDT directs you to two-box because, holding fixed what you do, the money is already in the opaque box or it is not.  

‘Death in Damascus’ (van Fraassen 1984; Gibbard & Harper 1978) is intended to turn that virtue against CDT.  Death is an uncanny but fallible predictor of human travel plans.  He is already waiting in whichever of two cities, Damascus or Aleppo, he has predicted you will visit tomorrow.  If you meet him you die; if you avoid him you live.  You now have to choose where to go.

Because Death’s reliability is high but not perfect, the unconditional probability that he is now in Damascus depends on your current credence that you will in fact go to Damascus: if you think you are likely to go to Damascus you should also think it likely that Death predicted as much and is waiting there.  Conversely, if in the course of deliberation you start leaning towards Aleppo your credence that Death is in Aleppo should rise.  CDT therefore instructs you to calculate the expected utility of each act with probabilities that shift as your own probability of performing that act shifts.  It can consequently deliver changing, indeed oscillating, recommendations while you deliberate.  Is that a defect of the theory?  I shall argue that it is.

The discussion proceeds in four steps.  (§2) I make the dependence on act-probabilities explicit with a simple model. (§3) I explain why that dependence threatens CDT’s ability to give stable and action-guiding advice. (§4) I consider three popular responses on behalf of CDT and explain why each is unsatisfactory. (§5) I generalise the moral: the problem is not local to ‘Death in Damascus’ but reveals a structural instability in orthodox CDT whenever an agent’s credence in her own act is evidentially relevant to pay-offs.  I conclude that CDT, as usually formulated, must be revised or replaced.

2. Why the numbers shift

Suppose Death’s reliability is 0.9 and, when he is uncertain, he is disposed to guess Damascus.  More precisely,

P(Death guesses correctly) = 0.9  
If you will go to Damascus, P(Death in Damascus) = 0.9.  
If you will go to Aleppo, P(Death in Damascus) = 0.1.

Let q be your present subjective probability that you will go to Damascus.  Because Death’s prediction was made before you contemplated the problem, nothing you now do can causally influence where he is.  CDT therefore instructs you to use the unconditional probability that Death is in Damascus, which by the law of total probability is

P(Death in Damascus) = 0.9 q + 0.1 (1 – q) = 0.1 + 0.8 q. (1)

Since you live if and only if you avoid Death, the expected utility (in lives saved) of going to Damascus is

EU(Damascus) = 1 – P(Death in Damascus) = 0.9 – 0.8 q. (2)

By parallel reasoning the expected utility of going to Aleppo is

EU(Aleppo) = 0.1 + 0.8 q. (3)

The two expected‐utility lines are graphed in Figure 1: they are straight lines with opposite slopes that cross at q = 0.5.  If, at some point in deliberation, you assign q > 0.5, equation (2) makes Damascus look worse than Aleppo, so CDT tells you to head for Aleppo; if q < 0.5 CDT says go to Damascus; if q = 0.5 CDT is indifferent.

But now notice the feedback loop.  Suppose you start with q = 0.6.  CDT then tells you to go to Aleppo.  Recognising that you are about to commit to Aleppo will drive your credence that you will go to Damascus down; perhaps you revise q to 0.4.  With q = 0.4, (2) says Damascus is now safer, so you switch your intention to Damascus, which pushes q back above 0.5, and round you go again.  Nothing external changes; only your self-locating credence does; yet CDT’s recommendation flips incessantly.

3. Why that is a problem

a.  Advice that defeats deliberation  
A decision theory is supposed to guide an agent from uncertainty about what to do to a definite act.  CDT’s guidance here is self-undermining.  As soon as the agent forms an intention the theory uses that very fact as input to overturn its own advice.  Deliberation degenerates into an infinite regress, or, if decision must be made at a fixed deadline, into an essentially arbitrary tie-breaker.  That is not mere pedagogical discomfort; it violates what Bratman (1999) calls the stability constraint on practical reasoning: a rational plan should tend to resist reconsideration in the absence of new external information.

b.  Dependence on a purely endogenous magnitude  
Expected utility should depend on how the world might turn out, not on the agent’s fleeting second-order beliefs about which act she will choose.  Consider two psychologists hidden in adjacent rooms, each running through exactly the same explicit reasoning but with different unspoken hunches about what they will do.  CDT, as modelled above, can decree that act A is rational for one and act B is rational for the other, even though their evidence about the external world is identical.  That looks uncomfortably like making rationality hinge on an introspective whim.

c.  Dynamic inconsistency and money-pump vulnerability  
Because the agent’s preference ordering changes predictably with her own shifting intentions, a cunning third party could exploit her.  Offer her, each time the pendulum swings to Damascus, the option to pay a small fee to lock that choice in; once locked in, the expected utility calculation flips, so she will pay again to unlock it—and so on, trading herself into the ground.  The possibility of a guaranteed sure-loss sequence of voluntary trades shows that the underlying preference pattern is dynamically inconsistent (McClennen 1990).

d.  Violation of reflection  
According to van Fraassen’s Reflection Principle, your future probability assignments, conditional on your anticipation of them, should constrain your present probabilities.  CDT in this case violates Reflection in the following sense: you know that if you were to come to be certain of going to Damascus you would take Aleppo to be safer, and vice versa, yet you cannot anticipate ever reaching a stable credence that you can endorse now.  That undermines the coherence of your overall epistemic state, and coherence is one of CDT’s own classical justifications.

Hence there is a genuine difficulty, not a merely psychological nuisance: CDT fails to issue coherent and stable prescriptions in circumstances it can foresee and in which other plausible theories (e.g. ‘Evidential Decision Theory’ or ‘Policy-based CDT’) do not melt down.

4. Can the causal decision theorist evade the problem?

Response 1.  The ‘end-of-deliberation’ defence  
Joyce (1999) suggests that act probabilities are well defined only at the end of deliberation, when they collapse to 0 or 1.  At that point CDT will recommend Damascus if you finally choose Damascus and Aleppo if you finally choose Aleppo; so there is no oscillation.  But that is unhelpful ex ante.  The theory is being appealed to precisely in order to reach the end of deliberation; telling the agent that CDT will agree with whatever choice she lands on removes the normative content.  Moreover, the defence does not generalise to mixed strategies deliberately chosen, e.g. spinning a coin; in mixed strategies the relevant act probabilities are not 0 or 1 even at the moment of choice.

Response 2.  Treat the choice variable as causally downstream  
One might object that the earlier calculation mistakenly treats Death’s location as causally independent of your present decision, whereas in truth your decision today is evidence about your earlier mental processes, which in turn partly caused Death’s prediction.  But CDT’s charter was precisely to insulate decisions from such purely evidential links.  Once we allow backward-directed evidential influence to count as causal for decision purposes, CDT collapses into Evidential Decision Theory, losing the very feature that let it two-box in Newcomb’s problem.

Response 3.  Ratificationism  
Jeffrey and Skyrms propose that a rational act should be one that would remain the preferred act even after you learned that you had decided to perform it.  In formal terms, an act A is ratifiable if A maximises expected utility conditional on the information ‘I shall do A’.  In Death in Damascus no pure act is ratifiable: learning you will go to Damascus makes Aleppo preferable and vice versa.  The only ratifiable option is a mixed strategy that makes your probability of going to each city equal, breaking the link with Death’s asymmetric prior bias.  Ratificationism therefore avoids instability, but only by demanding randomisation in a situation where, intuitively, one city—Aleppo—is genuinely safer given Death’s predilection for Damascus.  So ratification fixes the stability defect at the cost of sometimes issuing recommendations (expensive randomisation devices, etc.) that strike many philosophers as over-sophisticated and counter-intuitive.

5. The general moral

The problem is not limited to quirky prediction tales.  Any scenario with the following three features will trigger the same instability:

1.  The utility of an act A depends on some state S not causally downstream of A.  
2.  The agent believes that S is probabilistically correlated with her choice of A.  
3.  The strength of that correlation is itself a function of her credence that she will choose A.

Examples abound in social choice, bargaining, and self-locating belief.  In cooperative dilemmas, for instance, your inclination to cooperate is evidence that your counterpart, who can often read the same subtle situational cues you rely on, will also cooperate.  CDT under conditions (1)–(3) becomes sensitive to transitory, essentially endogenous mental states and therefore fails the basic convergence requirement for a decision procedure.

Notice also that the instability has nothing to do with indeterminism.  Even if human choice were physically deterministic, as long as the agent is uncertain about what she will do she faces the same self-referential loop.

Thus the dependence of CDT’s expected-utility numbers on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities is not an innocuous artefact; it prevents CDT from functioning as a practicable theory of rational action.

6. Conclusion: what next?

We have seen that, in Death-in-Damascus cases, the causal decision theorist’s expected-utility calculation treats a purely inner, deliberative magnitude—the agent’s credence in her own act—as an input variable, with the result that the theory’s advice cannot stabilise.  That violates several core norms of agency: action-guidance, dynamic consistency, introspective indifference, and the Reflection principle.  Three putative repairs—waiting until credences collapse to 0/1, redescribing evidential dependence as causal, and adopting ratificationism—each save part of CDT’s spirit at the cost of abandoning other parts or delivering dubious prescriptions.  

Accordingly, the dependence on act-probabilities is indeed a serious problem for orthodox CDT.  If we wish to retain the causal insight that only downstream effects should matter, we must reconceive the unit of choice (perhaps as a whole policy rather than a single act) or adopt a hybrid theory that allows limited evidential feedback without re-introducing Newcombian anomalies.  Until such a reconstruction is in place, Death in Damascus stands as a reductio of CDT in its classical form.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) was forged to avoid the counter-intuitive prescriptions of Evidential Decision Theory in Newcomb-type problems.  Its core principle is simple: when deciding, ignore mere evidence about what will happen and attend only to what your choice can causally influence.  The expected utility of an act A is therefore calculated with probabilities that are unconditional on A for any state S that is not causally downstream of A.  In ordinary cases this recipe works smoothly, but the Death in Damascus story forces us to notice something easily overlooked: the unconditional probability of a state often depends on the agent’s own probability of performing the act.  Once that dependence is acknowledged, CDT’s recommendations can flip back and forth as the agent’s deliberative credences migrate.  Is that a vice in the theory?  I shall argue that it is a serious, though not necessarily fatal, difficulty because it frustrates CDT’s aim of giving determinate, action-guiding advice to a reflective deliberator.  I then examine and find wanting several strategies CDT-defenders have proposed to defuse the worry.

2. The Death in Damascus set-up  

A traveller must decide whether to go to Aleppo or Damascus.  Death, a reasonably but not perfectly reliable predictor, will travel to whichever city he predicts the traveller will choose; if he meets the traveller, the traveller dies.  We are told two further details.  First, Death is more prone to guess Damascus than Aleppo—say, ceteris paribus he guesses Damascus with probability .6.  Second, his reliability is high but imperfect—suppose that conditional on his guessing the city you actually go to, his success rate is .9 (and .1 otherwise).  

Represent the acts as A (go to Aleppo) and D (go to Damascus).  The crucial feature is that the unconditional probability that Death is in Aleppo equals the probability that he both guessed Aleppo and was right, which depends on your probability of choosing Aleppo, call it p.  For concreteness:

P(Death in Aleppo) = .6(1–p)(.1) + .4p(.9).  
P(Death in Damascus) = .6(1–p)(.9) + .4p(.1).

Your utility if you meet Death is –100; if you avoid him, +0 (the cities are otherwise equally attractive).  Expected utility therefore becomes:

EU(A) = –100 × P(Death in Aleppo).  
EU(D) = –100 × P(Death in Damascus).

Notice that P(Death in Aleppo) is an increasing function of p, whereas P(Death in Damascus) is a decreasing function of p.  Thus if, when you start deliberating, you assign p = .1, EU(A) is low (Death probably waits in Damascus, where you are unlikely to go) and CDT advises Aleppo; but if you begin with p = .9, EU(D) is higher (Death now likely waits in Aleppo), so CDT prescribes Damascus.  In between there is a fixed point—roughly p = .5—at which the two expected utilities tie.  If during reflection you drift across that knife-edge, CDT’s verdict reverses.  The recommendations are sensitive to one’s endogenous probability of acting.

3. Why that sensitivity looks worrying  

A decision theory is supposed to guide deliberation.  A theory that treats its own output as a moving target seems unable to get deliberation started, for the advice it issues at t1 may evaporate by t2 once the agent’s brain notices the advice and updates her act-probabilities.  The problem recurs:

Step 1: “Given my current credence p = .3 of choosing Aleppo, Aleppo maximises causal expected utility.”  
Step 2: “But recognising Step 1 pushes p toward 1, for I now lean strongly to Aleppo.”  
Step 3: “Given p ≈ 1, Damascus maximises causal expected utility.”  
Step 4: “Recognising Step 3 pushes p back toward 0 …”

Nothing in CDT blocks this oscillation.  The agent, treated as a perfect expected-utility calculator, becomes trapped in a deliberative churning.  That threatens two desiderata:

a. Action guidance: A decision theory should tell a reflective agent what to do, not merely what would be best conditional on whichever unstable credence she happens to have.  

b. Diachronic rationality: Rationality should not demand that an agent intend simultaneously incompatible acts at successive fine-grained moments of reflection.  CDT seems to court such diachronic incoherence.

4. A familiar analogue: ratifiability  

The phenomenon is structurally identical to the problem Richard Jeffrey and Allan Gibbard called ‘ratifiability.’  An act is ratifiable if, after conditionalising on the information that you are going to perform it, you would still want to perform it.  In Death in Damascus no act is ratifiable unless your act-probabilities sit exactly at the fixed point; that dependence is what fuels instability.  Jeffrey concluded that rational choice requires picking a ratifiable act, but CDT by itself gives no guarantee that a ratifiable option exists or is uniquely favored.

5. First attempted defence: “So what?  CDT just reports the facts.”  

A CDT-defender might reply: the theory is not in the business of micro-managing your deliberation.  It tells you, relative to whatever unconditional probabilities you in fact have, what causally promotes your ends.  If those probabilities change, of course the recommendation may change, but that is no more puzzling than an economist’s advice changing when market conditions change.  

This reply misses the mark.  Market conditions are external to the agent’s act; here the probabilities that shift are themselves functions of the advice.  Because recognising the advice is causally upstream of the act, CDT’s recommendations are self-referential in a way that sabotages their capacity to settle the matter.  The oscillation is not an incidental feature of exotic cases; it flows from CDT’s central clause, which instructs us to evaluate acts against unconditional probabilities that themselves depend on the agent’s current credences about her act.

6. Second defence: “Treat act-probabilities as 0 or 1.”  

David Lewis proposes that a rational agent at the moment of decision should regard her chosen act as certain: once deliberation culminates in choice, P(A) is 1 for whichever act she in fact performs.  On that proposal CDT never compares acts at intermediate credences and therefore delivers a determinate answer: whichever city you end up picking must, ex hypothesi, have been optimal given credence 1.  

The manoeuvre is question-begging.  It presupposes that deliberation can legitimately jump to certainty without justification.  But why should a rational agent snap to P(A) = 1 rather than P(A) = 0?  In Death in Damascus both limiting distributions are available.  Lewis’s rule merely suppresses the instability by fiat, renouncing CDT’s promise to ground choice in prior beliefs.

7. Third defence: ratifiability or equilibrium constraints  

Another response is to supplement CDT with a ratifiability condition: choose an act only if, conditional on the information that you are going to do it, you still prefer it.  Equivalently, seek a fixed point of the mapping from act to deliberatively updated preferences.  In Death in Damascus, that requires the agent to set p at the equilibrium where EU(A) = EU(D).  CDT then becomes stable.  Yet the cure is worse than the disease.  

First, nothing within CDT yields that extra norm; it is an extraneous rationality requirement grafted on to repair an inadequacy.  Second, equilibria may fail to exist or may not be unique.  Third, even when a unique equilibrium exists (as here), ratifiability can mandate acts that are dominated by feasible alternatives.  Gibbard and Harper’s Wizard example illustrates a case in which only a sub-optimal act is ratifiable.  A decision theory that demands taking dominated options cannot be the last word on rationality.

8. Fourth defence: model additional nodes  

Perhaps the defect lies not in CDT but in a crude causal model.  If we treat the agent’s ‘decision variable’ as causally upstream of both the act and Death’s prediction, we can condition on that variable instead.  Then Death’s location becomes independent of the ultimate act, and CDT yields the intuitively correct recommendation (‘choose Aleppo, because Death’s bias toward Damascus makes Aleppo safer’).  

While more sophisticated causal modelling sometimes rescues CDT, in Death in Damascus the proposal backfires.  The variable ‘my decision’ is precisely what is at issue; its distribution is just the contentious p.  Plugging it into the graph re-introduces the same instability at one remove.  One can always add further upstream nodes—“my subconscious intention,” “the neuronal firing pattern at t–ε”—but unless some stage is exogenously fixed, the worrisome self-dependence re-emerges.  CDT offers no principled way to identify an ultimate exogenous choice-variable.

9. Why the problem is serious  

We can now articulate the objection more clearly.  CDT is meant to capture instrumental rationality: choose the act with the highest causal expected utility, calculated relative to the agent’s total current beliefs.  In Death in Damascus, the total belief state includes a probability distribution over the very acts being evaluated.  Because the expected-utility ordering of the acts is itself a function of that distribution, the theory becomes:

(i) circular—my grounds for choosing A depend on how firmly I already believe I will choose A;  
(ii) unstable—small, epistemically irrelevant perturbations in p can flip the ranking;  
(iii) action-unguiding—the procedure does not converge to a recommendation from generic starting points.

A parallel can be drawn with decision procedures that condition on unreliable self-locating evidence, leading to Dutch Book vulnerabilities.  The CDT agent here is dutch-bookable: a clever bookmaker could exploit her oscillations by offering conditional bets tied to momentary credences.  That is at odds with the money-pump avoidance rationale that originally motivated expected-utility decision theories.

10. Is the phenomenon confined to exotic predictor cases?  

One might concede the instability yet dismiss the scenario as philosophically irrelevant—after all, real-world predictors are never so artfully correlated with our choices.  The concession is too quick.  Any situation where an outside observer forms expectations that correlate (imperfectly) with our action—stock markets anticipating a firm’s investment, political opponents guessing a negotiator’s strategy, romantic partners predicting each other’s next move—instantiates the same structure.  The agent’s unconditional probabilities about the observer’s behavior will typically be sensitive to her own inclinations.  So the instability is not a laboratory curiosity; it shadows decision-making wherever one’s intentions are legible to others.

11. A better moral: shift from act-probabilities to policy-probabilities  

One promising revisionary idea is to index expected utility not to acts but to complete policies, where a policy specifies what the agent would do in each possible information state.  The policy you pick at the start of deliberation is under your direct rational control; the particular act performed is then determined by the policy together with the information realised.  Because the policy itself need not covary with the act probabilities inside the decision problem, the circular dependence evaporates.  

Implementing the proposal, however, would require CDT to forsake its simple act-level maxim and adopt the more complicated schema of Functional Decision Theory or Updateless Decision Theory, which weigh subjunctive dependencies between policies and predicted outcomes.  That shift retains the spirit of causal reasoning but abandons the letter of traditional CDT.  In effect, recognising the Death in Damascus instability pushes us beyond CDT to a newer, policy-based framework.

12. Conclusion  

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s current act-probabilities is not a benign quirk.  It undermines CDT’s claim to provide stable, context-invariant guidance for reflective deliberators.  Attempts to dismiss the difficulty either assume away deliberation, import extraneous ratifiability norms, or relocate the instability without resolving it.  The root of the problem is CDT’s act-based criterion, which leaves it entangled in self-referential credences whenever others can predict the act.  A satisfactory decision theory should instead evaluate policies or choice-mechanisms whose probabilities are not themselves hostage to moment-by-moment shifts in deliberation.  Unless CDT is re-engineered along those lines, the Death in Damascus case exposes a genuine, deep-seated flaw in the theory.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act.
