This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells a deliberating agent to choose the act that maximises causal expected utility.  To calculate that figure, the agent is instructed to imagine performing the act by means of a “do‐operator” (an intervention that sets the act’s value), to hold fixed every variable that is not causally downstream of that intervention, and then to take an expectation with respect to the resulting probability distribution.  When the causal graph is uncomplicated, this procedure delivers clear, stable advice.  Trouble arises, however, in cases where (i) some earlier predictor has formed a fairly accurate opinion about what the agent will do, (ii) the world is arranged so that the agent’s prospects depend on that prediction, yet (iii) that predictor’s opinion is not itself causally downstream of the act.  “Death in Damascus” is the paradigm.

1.  The case and CDT’s recipe

The story has four salient variables.

A   ∈ {Aleppo, Damascus} – the act you will in fact perform tomorrow.  
L   ∈ {Aleppo, Damascus} – the location at which Death will be waiting for you tomorrow.  
S   ∈ {live, die} – survival.  S = live iff A ≠ L.  
U   = utility.  Normalise to 0 for death, 1 for survival.

Death chooses L before you decide, attempting to predict A.  He is highly reliable – say 90 % – but not perfect, and he has a mild bias for guessing Damascus when in doubt.  For definiteness, let  

   P(L = Dam | A = Dam) = .9,   
   P(L = Dam | A = Aleppo) = .2.

These numbers are ex ante chances fixed by the mechanism that produces Death’s prediction; they do not themselves vary as you deliberate.  CDT therefore says:

EU(Aleppo) = P(S = live | do (Aleppo)) = 1 − P(L = Aleppo | do (Aleppo)),  
EU(Damascus) = 1 − P(L = Damascus | do (Damascus)).

Because L is chosen before your act and is not causally downstream of it, the conditional “| do(A = x)” simply deletes the outgoing arrows of A while leaving L distributed exactly as above, with probabilities that depend only on the actual but not‐yet‐realised value of A.  Formally,

P(L = Dam | do (Aleppo)) = .2,   
P(L = Alep | do (Damascus)) = .1.

Those numbers appear to give the straightforward recommendation: go to Aleppo (EU = .8) rather than Damascus (EU = .9 survival risk, hence EU = .1).  So where’s the fuss?

2.  Why the utilities seem to depend on your current credence in A

The worry begins once we notice that the model just sketched is not yet complete from the point of view of a deliberating agent.  An omniscient spectator can attach a single sharp objective chance to “A = Aleppo,” but you, the agent, are trying to decide which city to visit.  As you deliberate, you form – and revise – a subjective probability P*(A = Aleppo).  That subjective probability is relevant because your current mental state is one of the cues Death’s predictor used when he formed his earlier judgment.  The more confident you now are that you will go to Damascus, the more confident you should also be that Death headed for Damascus.  More precisely, you typically accept

P(L = Dam | A-probability p) = .9p + .2(1 – p).

That is the same formula we wrote above but with the objective chance “p = P(Aleppo)” replaced by your own live estimate of that chance.  Insert that function into the EU calculation and you obtain

EU(Aleppo) = 1 – [.9(1−p) + .2p] = .1 + .7p,  
EU(Damascus) = 1 – [.9p + .2(1−p)] = .8 – .7p.

The expected utilities are affine functions of p with opposite slopes.  When p < .5, Aleppo’s EU (.1 + .7p) is less than Damascus’s (.8 – .7p); when p > .5, the inequality reverses.  Consequently CDT’s ranking flips at p = .5.  But your own probability p is hardly fixed: it is precisely what you are in the process of settling.  A tiny shift of credence across the .5 boundary makes the theory swing from “Damascus is mandated” to “Aleppo is mandated.”  That, in turn, shifts your intention, which in turn shifts your credence, which flips the recommendation back, and so on.  The upshot is an endlessly oscillating piece of advice – exactly the “instability” that has bothered many commentators since Richter’s original statement of the puzzle.

3.  The instability spelled out

Suppose you start the evening thinking you are 70 % likely to flee to Damascus.  Then:

p = .7 → EU(Dam) = .8 – .7(.7) = .31,  
EU(Alep) = .1 + .7(.7) = .59.

So CDT orders you to go to Aleppo.  Recognising that injunction, however, pushes your subjective p sharply downwards.  Perhaps your posterior is now p = .3.  Recompute:

p = .3 → EU(Dam) = .8 – .7(.3) = .59,  
EU(Alep) = .1 + .7(.3) = .31.

Now Damascus is favoured.  Your probability of Damascus surges; the ranking re-flips.  Nothing stabilises.  If we idealise your reasoning as perfectly precise and instantaneous, there is literally no fixed point: for every p other than .5 the act ranking is the reverse of what would be needed to keep p in place, and at p = .5 the outcomes are tied, leaving CDT with no strict recommendation at all.

4.  Why this looks like a problem

A decision theory is supposed to be action-guiding: it should be able to issue a recommendation that the agent can publicly commit to and carry out.  CDT in Death-in-Damascus fails to meet that criterion.  It does not merely say “the options are tied” (which would be acceptable indecision).  Rather, it makes its own guidance depend on a number the agent cannot keep fixed while attending rationally to that very guidance.  The advice is self-undermining.

In addition, the oscillation implies dynamic inconsistency.  A principle of rational deliberation, endorsed by most decision theorists, is that if you are about to perform an act A because you take it to maximise expected utility, you should not expect yourself, seconds hence, still to be deliberating between A and some rival B on grounds that A has ceased to look best.  Yet CDT tells you precisely that in Death-in-Damascus: commit to Aleppo and you thereby acquire evidence making Damascus look better, so you must plan to rethink; commit to Damascus and you must plan to rethink again.  No coherent executable plan is possible.

Finally, the dependence of utilities on act-probabilities violates a more abstract desideratum: separability.  One would like a decision rule to rank acts by features of the acts and of the environment that are themselves independent of which act is going to be chosen.  CDT is usually advertised as enjoying exactly that virtue: unlike Evidential Decision Theory, it cares only about the causal consequences of the act, not about what the act evidentially indicates.  But here CDT’s ranking is controlled by p, which is nothing but evidence about which act is going to be chosen.  In this setting CDT slides toward the very evidentialism it was designed to avoid, yet in a way that prevents it from providing stable guidance.

5.  Can CDT escape?

Several responses are available to the causal theorist.  Each incurs its own cost.

5.1  “Fix the probabilities ex ante”

One might insist that the probabilities used in the EU calculation are not the agent’s shifting credences but the objective chances that obtain prior to deliberation.  Perhaps, an hour ago, before you focused attention on the problem, the chances were: P(Aleppo) = .5 by symmetry; hence EU(Alep) = EU(Dam) = .45.  Those numbers stay put; deliberation must not treat its own evolving partial resolutions as evidence.  In effect, you refuse to conditionalise on information about your present intention.

The difficulty is motivational.  Rational agents normally do learn from introspection.  If while deciding you become 80 % sure you will chicken out and stay in Damascus, it is irrational to continue to attach only 50 % credence to that very proposition.  Forbidding an agent to use readily available information about her own forthcoming behaviour looks ad hoc.

5.2  “Deliberation crowds out prediction”

A related line, found in David Lewis and in Stalnaker, emphasises that the predictor is finished and gone; Death’s location L is already set.  During deliberation you therefore cannot influence L; you can only learn something about it.  Since the objective chance of L is now fixed, the true probabilities in the EU formula are insensitive to how your credence in A fluctuates.  Hence the instability is merely epistemic, not practical.

But in Death-in-Damascus the predictor’s reliability depended precisely on the accessibility of your then current mental state – the one you occupy right now.  Introspection lets you acquire new evidence about what the predictor saw.  So it is no mere epistemic mirage; your changing self-knowledge really is correlated with L.  CDT itself licences conditionalisation on any earlier event that is not downstream of the do-operator, and the contents of your own head are such an event.  Lewis’s “crowding out” therefore conflicts with CDT’s own unconditionalising instruction.

5.3  “Treat the problem at the policy level”

Some causal decision theorists move from act evaluation to policy evaluation.  Instead of asking “Aleppo or Damascus?” they ask “adopt the policy of going where Death least expects, or adopt some other policy?”  A policy is chosen now, and CDT is applied to that choice.  Because “choice of policy” stands well upstream of Death’s prediction, no backwards correlation arises.

The move helps here but not in general.  By stretching the decision variable far enough back in time one can always push more and more of the world into one’s causal future, making CDT’s unconditional probabilities stable.  Doing so, however, robs CDT of the very methodological clarity that made it attractive: the clean link between local acts and local causal consequences.  In addition, the policy that maximises causal EU in Death-in-Damascus is “enter a randomiser and follow its output,” which feels like a merely technical fix rather than a vindication of causal reasoning.

5.4  “Replace CDT”

Many philosophers take Death-in-Damascus style instability as one more datum favouring alternative theories – most prominently Functional Decision Theory (FDT) or Updateless Decision Theory (UDT).  Those theories evaluate an act by holding fixed not only the act’s causal consequences but also the subjunctive implications of the algorithm that produced it.  In our case, they say “If the decision algorithm outputs Aleppo, Death almost certainly predicted Aleppo; so Aleppo spells doom.  If it outputs Damascus, Death probably predicted that; again doom.  Since either output gives the same value, you may pick arbitrarily or flip a coin.”  The recommendation is well defined and unchanging.

6.  Assessing the balance

Does the instability we have charted amount to a fatal objection to CDT?  Three criteria are relevant.

(1) Action guidance: A satisfactory decision rule must yield stable advice an agent can implement.  
(2) Evidentiality: The rule should not let its verdict vary with purely evidential correlations it purports to ignore.  
(3) Dynamic consistency: Rankings issued at time t should not systematically undermine themselves at t+1.

On all three counts, CDT misfires in Death-in-Damascus unless its proponent adopts one of the auxiliary strategies sketched in §5.  Yet each strategy abandons something central – introspective learning, the neat causal recipe, or the theory itself.  That looks like a serious defect.

7.  Objections answered

“Aha,” says the causalist, “your instability is an artefact of idealisation.  Real people’s credences are never so precise that an infinitesimal update flips a practical verdict.”  True, but what matters is not behavioural smoothness but the theory’s prescriptions for perfectly ideal agents.  A standard of rational choice should not place an upper bound on cognitive acuity merely to save itself.

“It is not CDT’s job to tame self-predictive feedback; that is a special epistemic difficulty.”  Again, CDT officially instructs agents to use their best unconditional probabilities of states not downstream of the act.  In self-referential settings, those probabilities are ipso facto sensitive to the agent’s evolving perspective; so the difficulty is endogenous to CDT.

8.  Conclusion

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on act-probabilities in Death-in-Damascus is indeed a problem.  It drives the theory into an oscillating, self-defeating pattern of advice, undermines action guidance, violates dynamic consistency, and reintroduces an evidential flavour that CDT was meant to exclude.  The defender of CDT can respond only by restricting agents’ use of introspection, by shifting the level of choice so far upstream that the phenomenon disappears, or by embracing a different decision theory altogether.  None of these manoeuvres is cost-free; the second and third amount to abandoning core tenets of CDT.  Insofar as a decision theory ought to be stable under rational self-reflection, the Death-in-Damascus instability marks a genuine flaw in standard Causal Decision Theory.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. The setting

The Death in Damascus puzzle is purposely simple. The world contains only two salient variables.

     A  ∈ { go to Damascus, go to Aleppo }                        (your act)
     D  ∈ { Death in Damascus, Death in Aleppo }                  (where Death is)

If you and Death end up in the same city, you die (utility = –1).  
If you end up in different cities, you live (utility = +1).

Death has made his choice before your deliberation finishes.  He tries to predict where you will go, and he is good but not perfect.  Formally, let

     r  =  Pr(D = same city as you)  =  reliability of prediction     (0.5 < r < 1)
     b  =  Pr(Death guesses Damascus when he guesses wrongly)         (0 ≤ b ≤ 1)

To bring out the instability, fix numbers: r = .9 and b = .8.  So when Death is right he is right 90 % of the time, and when he is wrong he tends to pick Damascus four times out of five.

2. How CDT computes the options

Causal Decision Theory instructs you to evaluate each possible act A = a by the expected utility it would cause, using probabilities for variables that are not causally downstream of the act but are nonetheless uncertain.  In Death in Damascus the location of Death is not causally affected by where you finally go – his decision is already made – so CDT tells you to compute

     V(a)  =  EU(A = a)  =  (+1)·Pr(D ≠ a)  +  (–1)·Pr(D = a)

and then choose whichever act has the larger V-value.

Where do the probabilities in that formula come from?  CDT prescribes the unconditional probabilities – the ones you hold in your actual epistemic state – because, speaking causally, the act makes no difference to D.  But those unconditional probabilities are strongly correlated with how likely you currently think you are to go to each city, exactly because Death is a good predictor.

Let  p  =  Pr(A = Damascus)  be your present, pre-choice credence that you will end up in Damascus.  Basic probability and the reliability figures give

     Pr(D = Damascus)  =  r·p  +  (1–r)·b·(1–p)                 (1)
     Pr(D = Aleppo)    =  r·(1–p) +  (1–r)·(1–b)·p               (2)

Plugging (1)–(2) into the value formula yields

     V(Damascus)  =  (1–2·Pr(D=Damascus))
                   =  1 – 2[r·p + (1–r)·b·(1–p)]                (3)

     V(Aleppo)    =  1 – 2[r·(1–p) + (1–r)(1–b)p]               (4)

Notice the crucial fact: both V(Damascus) and V(Aleppo) are functions of p.  
Shift your credence about your own future act, and the expected utilities – hence CDT’s prescription – shift along with it.

3. The oscillation

Plug in the numbers r = .9 and b = .8:

     V(Damascus)  =  1 – 2[.9p + .02(1–p)]  =  1 – 1.84p – .04
                   =  .96 – 1.84p

     V(Aleppo)    =  1 – 2[.9(1–p) + .08p]  =  1 – 1.8 + 1.76p
                   =  –.8 + 1.76p

Set V(Damascus) = V(Aleppo) to find the crossover point:

     .96 – 1.84p  =  –.8 + 1.76p      ⇒      p*  ≈  .515

Interpretation:

• If you currently put more than 51.5 % credence on going to Damascus (p > p*), CDT tells you to go to Aleppo, because V(Aleppo) > V(Damascus).

• If instead you currently put less than 51.5 % credence on going to Damascus (p < p*), CDT tells you to go to Damascus.

So the following loop emerges.  Suppose you begin the evening thinking p = .7.

     1. Since p > p*, CDT says “go to Aleppo”.
     2. Recognising that advice, you lower p; now perhaps p = .3.
     3. But then p < p*, so CDT reverses itself: “go to Damascus”.
     4. You raise p again; and the cycle repeats.

Because your credence p is endogenous to your deliberation, no stable recommendation is ever reached.  In Ahmed’s vivid phrase, CDT becomes “unmoored”.  Something that calls itself a decision theory seems unable to tell you what to decide.

4. Why the dependence looks troubling

A. Guidance failure  
A normative decision theory is supposed to guide action here and now.  That requires a determinate mapping from an agent’s total epistemic state to a choice.  If small, predictable variations in that very state wipe away the mapping, the theory offers no usable guidance.  CDT in Death in Damascus exhibits exactly that pathology.

B. Circularity  
To apply CDT you need the unconditional probabilities of states not downstream of the act.  Yet those unconditional probabilities are themselves calculated by conditioning on your current best guess about what you will do.  Deliberation therefore feeds back into the inputs of the value formula whose output is supposed to settle deliberation.  That is a straightforward circularity: the output variable appears, unacknowledged, among the inputs.

C. Dynamic inconsistency  
Suppose, heroically, you execute CDT literally.  At each instant you pick the act with the higher V-value relative to that instant’s p, implement it, and treat the decision as final.  Because your p drifts while you think, a CDT-following agent will flip-flop – drive halfway to Damascus, change her mind, turn toward Aleppo, change again, ad infinitum.  She is dynamically inconsistent even though her preferences never change.

D. Ratifiability problem  
Jeffrey proposed that rational choices should be “ratifiable”: the act you choose must remain the act that maximises expected utility once you know that you have chosen it.  In Death in Damascus, no mixed act (p strictly between 0 and 1) is ratifiable; only the extremal options p = 0 or p = 1 are.  CDT therefore pushes you toward dogmatic self-certain choices on pain of violating its own insistence on ratifiability.  That looks epistemically perverse: why must rational agents feel certain about what they will decide before they have decided?

E. Sensitivity to irrelevant mental parameters  
Whether you assign yourself 52 % or 48 % credence of going to Damascus may reflect trivial features: what neurological noise the fMRI picked up, what time you glanced at the clock.  It is hard to see how such gossamer facts should alter which concrete city you ought to flee to when Death is in pursuit.  Yet CDT says they do.

5. Is there a rescue line for CDT?

Defenders of CDT have tried three main responses.

Response 1: “Ignore self-locating probabilities.”  
One can decree that rational deliberators should treat their own future act as causally open and therefore assign it no probability until the moment of choice.  Call this the “0/0 view”: before the decision both Pr(A = Damascus) and Pr(A = Aleppo) are undefined, so the dependence shown above never arises.

The difficulty is that perfectly ordinary Bayesian updating obliges you to have some credence distribution over any proposition you recognise is meaningful.  Treating A as probability-free makes your epistemic state non-Bayesian, and CDT is meant to be a Bayesian decision theory.

Response 2: “Adopt a ratifiable credence.”  
A second idea is to pick a fixed point of the value-equations: choose the credence p that makes the act with that credence best.  In our numerical example p* ≈ .515 is such a fixed point; commit to p* and the oscillation ceases.

But p* prescribes a mixed act: “go to Damascus with probability 51.5 %, otherwise to Aleppo”.  Unless you already own a true random-number generator and are willing to let it steer your very footsteps, that advice is unusable.  In realistic cases agents do not possess the hardware needed to realise the mixed strategy that ratifies itself.

Response 3: “CDT only cares about ex ante priors.”  
One might insist that the relevant unconditional probabilities are those you had before deliberation started.  Snapshot the priors, feed them to CDT once, obtain a recommendation, and stick to it no matter how your self-locating credences shift afterwards.

Technically that avoids the loop.  But it means the very first, arbitrary tremor in your unreflective priors fixes an irrevocable decision.  If you were initially almost indifferent and then, on calm reflection, became convinced that you are almost certainly headed to Damascus, the theory refuses to let you change your mind, for the inputs are frozen.  That sits poorly with the intuition that better, later evidence should be allowed to matter.

6. Two deeper reasons the dependence is fatal

(i) Lack of separability.  
In ordinary causal modelling we hold that if X is not causally downstream of A, then Pr(X) is determined by background factors B that screen-off A.  Therefore Pr(X) should not change merely because the agent gains information about A.  CDT in Death in Damascus violates this separability assumption.  The reason is that the agent’s epistemic access to her own dispositions is itself a conduit of information about X.  A theory that ignores that epistemic conduit misclassifies which variables are effectively “downstream”.

(ii) Mislocated notion of control.  
CDT is built around the idea “control what you can causally influence”.  Yet an agent’s probability of acting one way rather than another is something she can influence immediately, by shifting attention or resolve.  So it is not causally inert.  When CDT treats p as exogenous, it mislocates the boundary of agential control, thereby producing ill-defined choice situations.

Formal theories that do locate the boundary correctly – Functional Decision Theory (FDT) or Updateless Decision Theory (UDT) – evaluate acts by considering the consequences of the abstract decision function they implement, not of the act-token they finally take.  As a result their recommendations in Death in Damascus do not depend on p and remain stable: go to Aleppo, because the decision process that chooses Aleppo causes Death to predict Damascus often enough to make Aleppo safer.  Whatever one thinks of those rival theories, their very possibility shows that CDT’s dependence on p is not inevitable.

7. Putting it together

The dependence of CDT’s output on the agent’s live credence in her own act is worrisome for three interconnected reasons.

1. Pragmatic: It deprives the theory of action-guidance by generating deliberative oscillation.

2. Epistemic: It forces agents either to violate Bayesian norms (by having no credence in their own act), or to embrace dogmatic certainty for the sake of ratifiability, or to freeze their priors against later evidence.  None of these options is epistemically attractive.

3. Theoretical: It exposes an internal tension between CDT’s causal creed (“use probabilities for things your action cannot influence”) and the epistemic reality that learning about your likely action is often the best way to learn about those very things.  The theory’s instructions presuppose that the two kinds of learning come apart, but in Death-like cases they inseparably intertwine.

A decision theory that fails on guidance, pulls against Bayesian epistemology, and relies on an independence that patently does not hold in cases with reliable predictors seems seriously compromised.  The defect is not cosmetic; it stems from CDT’s core commitment to evaluate acts in causal isolation from the decision process that selects them.  When the world contains devices that predict that very process, isolation is impossible, and CDT’s dependence on p is the visible symptom.

8. Conclusion

Yes, the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s evolving probability of performing the very act under evaluation is a problem – arguably a fatal one.  It produces circular deliberation, undermines the theory’s practical guidance, and reveals that CDT’s method for importing probabilities into expected-utility calculations misrepresents causal structure in predictor-laden environments.  Until CDT is revised so that its prescriptions are insensitive to trivial flux in self-locating credence, or until it supplies a principled way to fix those credences that does not violate Bayesian norms, it remains ill-equipped to handle Death in Damascus and related cases.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is, at bottom, a recipe for selecting the act that maximises expected utility when the expectation is taken with respect to probabilities of outcomes that are not causally downstream of the act.  In ordinary choice situations this prescription appears both intuitive and stable: one attaches probabilities to states of the world, utilities to the possible consequence-pairs ⟨act, state⟩, computes each act’s expected utility, and picks the act with the highest score.  Trouble begins, however, in so-called “self-referential” choices—situations in which the utility of an act is itself a function of the agent’s current credence that she will perform that very act.  The classic Death in Damascus case belongs to that family.  When probabilities of states depend upon what the agent thinks she is going to do, the CDT machinery can generate shifting, even oscillating, recommendations as the agent updates on her own unfolding deliberation.  Many philosophers have therefore asked whether CDT’s sensitivity to these doxastic oscillations is a flaw in the theory, and if so, how deep a flaw it is.  

My aim is to say that the dependence on act probabilities is indeed a serious problem for (standard) CDT.  First, I shall rehearse the Death in Damascus set-up in enough detail to make vivid the moving parts and to show exactly where the self-reference arises (§2).  Second, I argue that CDT’s dependence on interim credences undermines three desiderata any decision theory should respect: (i) deliberative stability, (ii) action-guidance, and (iii) diachronic rationality (§3).  Third, I consider and rebut two prominent replies on behalf of CDT—appeals to (A) the doctrine of ratifiability and (B) a “stage-setting” conception of deliberation (§4).  I close by sketching the broader moral: solving the Death in Damascus puzzle pushes us either towards some form of Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) or towards new hybrid theories that “scrub out” an agent’s higher-order uncertainty about her own act from the evidential base used in expected-utility calculations (§5).

2. Death in Damascus and the Self-Referential Utility Table  

2.1 The basic story  

Death, a moderately reliable predictor but not infallible, is waiting in whichever city he has predicted you will visit tomorrow.  You may either remain in Damascus or flee to Aleppo.  Let p be the unconditional probability, from Death’s point of view, that he predicts Damascus; assume p > 0.5.  Let ε be the (small) probability that Death guesses wrong.  Your utilities are simple: survival is worth 0 utils, death is –1000 utils, and the minor costs of travel are negligible.  Under CDT you must compute for each act A ∈ {stay in Damascus, flee to Aleppo} the expected utility  
EU(A) = Σs P(s | do(A)) · U(A, s),  
where the sum ranges over states not causally downstream of A.  Here the relevant state is “Death predicted Damascus” (call it D) or “Death predicted Aleppo” (¬D).  

2.2 Where the self-reference creeps in  

Why should your credence that Death predicted Damascus depend on your credence that you will go to Damascus?  Because Death’s predictions are themselves based on facts—including psychological facts—about you.  If, while deliberating, you come to regard going to Damascus as extremely unlikely, you should correspondingly reduce the probability that Death has predicted Damascus.  And vice versa.  The simplest way to model this is by letting  

P(D) = p · q + (1 – p) · (1 – q) + noise,

where q is the agent’s current credence that she will go to Damascus and “noise” represents the possibility ε that Death mispredicts.  The exact functional form is not crucial; what matters is that as the agent’s doxastic state shifts during deliberation, her conditional probabilities P(D | do(Damascus)) and P(D | do(Aleppo)) will move in tandem.

2.3 The instability  

Suppose you start unbiased: q = 0.5.  Because p > 0.5, you initially assign P(D | do(Damascus)) > P(D | do(Aleppo)), hence EU(Aleppo) > EU(Damascus).  CDT says: go to Aleppo.  But the moment you resolve to flee, your credence that you will go to Damascus collapses, so you now judge that Death very probably predicted Aleppo.  This in turn lowers the expected utility of Aleppo, perhaps to the point where Damascus is now preferable.  Noticing this, you start to reconsider.  As you reconsider, your credence of ending up in Damascus rises, and with it so does P(D | do(Damascus)); the expected utilities flip again.  The upshot is a decision rule that chases its own tail.

3. Three Problems Generated by the Dependence on Act Probabilities  

3.1 Deliberative instability  

A choice procedure is deliberatively unstable when the very act of applying the procedure predictably upends its own recommendations.  CDT in Death-style cases has exactly this property: computing EU(A) changes the probabilities feeding into that very computation, thereby changing the result.  A rational choice rule should settle deliberation, not inflame it.  Otherwise we get sorites-like infinite oscillations or, more realistically, arbitrary resolution by brute psychological fatigue rather than normative force.

3.2 Loss of action-guidance  

A decision theory is useless if, at the moment of action, it cannot tell you what to do.  In Death in Damascus, CDT can generate live period-by-period advice like “If you’re about to go to Damascus, go to Aleppo; but if you’re about to go to Aleppo, go to Damascus.”  That is not guidance; it is a regress.  Worse, the regress infects any institutional implementation of CDT.  Imagine an AI agent running CDT routines that update millisecond by millisecond: without an added “commitment device” the program would strobe between Aleppo and Damascus until an external interrupt forced execution.

3.3 Diachronic incoherence  

Arguably, rationality requires a kind of diachronic coherence: your time-sliced selves should not foreseeably disagree in ways that lead to predictable losses.  But CDT’s recommendations depend on transient credences about its own output, so earlier selves cannot rely on later selves to follow CDT once they have updated.  In the long run, this can be shown to generate so-called “money pump” or Dutch book vulnerabilities (see Briggs 2010).  An agent who will predictably flip choices can be exploited by an informed bettor who offers sequential bets on where she will end up.

4. Two Pro-CDT Replies and Why They Fail  

4.1 The ratifiability manoeuvre  

Jeffrey (1983) suggested that rational agents should only choose acts that are “ratifiable”: an act is ratifiable just in case, having chosen it, the agent would not regret the choice on the basis of the very beliefs that choice would engender.  In Death-like cases, neither Aleppo nor Damascus is ratifiable, so the theory withholds recommendation.  Hitchcock (1996) and Joyce (2012) push this line: the decision theory is not at fault; the scenario is one in which no act is ratifiably maximal.

Yet this response undermines the ambitions of CDT.  For one, it empties the theory of prescriptive force in precisely the puzzling cases where guidance is needed most.  Second, ratifiability is cheap: any agent free to tweak her credences can make almost any act unratifiable, e.g. by vowing to form beliefs after acting that make her regret.  Third, in simpler Newcomb-style cases, forbidding unratifiable acts rules out two-box­ing, thereby sliding CDT surreptitiously into the camp of EDT—an outcome most CDT defenders reject.

4.2 The “stage-setting” conception of deliberation  

Another move says: treat the agent’s current act-probabilities as fixed parameters during each “stage” of deliberation, so at stage n the agent asks “Given that I am α-likely to do Damascus, which act is best?” and then updates to stage n + 1 with (possibly) new α′.  On this picture, CDT does not flip-flop at a single stage; instead, the agent marches through a sequence of determinate recommendations until she reaches a fixed point α* where the recommendations stabilise.

The difficulty is that in realistic Death cases no fixed point exists except in measure-zero circumstances (e.g., ε = 0).  Any α that makes Aleppo look best causes α to jump, which in turn makes Damascus best, which sends α back, ad infinitum.  Without a fixed point, the stage-setting version leaves the agent in permanent limbo.

Moreover, the stage-delimiter itself is ad hoc.  Why say the agent is forbidden from taking into account the predictable updates her very next cognitive micro-events will bring?  Such blindness violates the requirement that the agent use all available information, including information about her own cognitive dynamics.

5. The Larger Moral: Beyond Standard CDT  

The pathology exposed by Death in Damascus is not a mere technicality.  The very spirit of CDT is to quarantine the deliberative act from the evidential bearings that act’s probability has on the world.  But when the act’s probability is part of what determines upstream states (via predictors, rival agents, future selves, etc.), the quarantine collapses.  The result is either paralysis or oscillation.

One moral is that the CDT/EDT dichotomy is too crude.  We need decision rules that:  
  (i) rely on causal structure (so as not to over-weight “spurious” evidential correlations); but  
  (ii) also treat facts about our own dispositions, credences, and likely actions as legitimate evidence about the world when those facts are indeed correlated with outcome-relevant states.

Several hybrid theories attempt to satisfy both desiderata.  Joyce’s (2012) “causal‐evidential” model lets the agent use probabilities from whatever of her own psychological states are causally upstream of the act; Skyrms’s (1990) deliberation dynamics framework adds an equilibrium condition akin to Nash equilibrium; and the burgeoning literature on “policy selection” (Yudkowsky & Soares 2017) chooses whole policies rather than moment-ary acts, thereby side-stepping self-referential flip-flops.  Each of these approaches recognises that the root defect lies in CDT’s refusal to let probabilities of acts serve as ordinary evidence about the pre-act world.

6. Conclusion  

Standard CDT’s dependence on act probabilities in Death-style cases is not a benign quirk but a genuine defect.  It violates deliberative stability, betrays the action-guidance function of decision theory, and breeds diachronic incoherence that a clever opponent can exploit.  Ratifiability and staged deliberation attempts do not rescue CDT without draining it of its distinctive content.  A more adequate decision theory must integrate, rather than ignore, the evidential significance of an agent’s own dispositions and deliberative states.  Whether that integration takes the form of EDT, a causal-evidential hybrid, or a policy-level criterion is an open research frontier; what is clear is that unmodified CDT cannot cope with Death in Damascus.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. The setting  

‘Death in Damascus’ (due to Gibbard & Harper 1978) is by now a familiar companion to Newcomb-type problems. You have two options, go to Aleppo or go to Damascus. Death, who is almost perfectly reliable, has already predicted which city you will choose and has positioned himself in that city. You strongly prefer life to death, and you have no other reason to favour either town. You also know one further empirical regularity: when Death is uncertain he shows a slight bias for predicting Damascus.  

Let the utilities be:

Life = 0  
Death = −1000.  

Let p be your current subjective probability that you will in fact go to Damascus (so 1 − p is the probability you will go to Aleppo). Let ε > 0 be Death’s bias for guessing Damascus when the evidence is exactly balanced. Then, given the reliability of the prediction mechanism, the conditional probability that Death will be in Damascus, were you to go to Damascus, is high (say 0.99); the conditional probability that he will be in Damascus, were you to go to Aleppo, is only the small bias ε. Expressed in the usual CDT notation:

EU(Damascus) = −1000 × 0.99 ≈ −990  
EU(Aleppo)   = −1000 × ε.

So far, Aleppo is the clear winner. But that was calculated on the supposition that you really might still go to either city. CDT tells you to pick the act with greater causal expected utility. The trouble begins when you try to follow that advice.  

Suppose you see the above numbers and resolve to head for Aleppo. In that very moment your own probability p that you will go to Damascus plummets. But Death’s method for predicting you is sensitive (let us stipulate) to exactly that probability: the more decisively you opt for Aleppo, the more confidently Death predicts Aleppo instead of Damascus. After all, Death is picking up on the same evidential cues about your deliberation that persuaded you. Consequently the conditional probabilities that figured in the earlier calculation shift. Now, given your newly firm resolve, the subjunctive probability that Death would be in Aleppo if you went to Aleppo is nearly 0.99, and the chance he would be in Damascus if you went to Damascus is merely ε. Re-calculating:

EU(Damascus – second pass) = −1000 × ε  
EU(Aleppo – second pass)   = −1000 × 0.99.

So the moment you finish deciding for Aleppo it becomes rational, by the same CDT lights, to switch to Damascus! Of course the same dance will repeat if you now decide for Damascus. CDT appears to generate an endless oscillation or, at best, compel you to search for a mixed strategy (roughly p = 0.5) that is a fixed point of the dependency. That picture—of your choice-probabilities feeding back into the causal probabilities and thus into the very criterion by which you choose—is what motivates the worry: does the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on your shifting act-probabilities show that something is amiss with CDT?

2. Why CDT cares about those probabilities in the first place  

The central idea of CDT is simple: evaluate each act by the expected utility of the possible causal outcomes that would obtain were you to perform that act. To operationalise the idea we need conditional probabilities P(Outcome | do(Act))—not ordinary evidential probabilities but ‘subjunctive’, ‘causal’ or ‘interventionist’ probabilities. In uncomplicated cases those probabilities are entirely independent of the agent’s current credence that she will perform the act. The probability that turning the key would start the car, conditional on turning the key, is taken to be a simple matter of how ignition systems work, not a function of how likely you think you are to turn the key.

However, two wrinkles complicate the Death in Damascus scenario.

a) There is a highly reliable predictor whose method is to exploit whatever information is available about your dispositions.  
b) You, the agent, know that fact and you are perfectly rational: as your credence in choosing any given act changes, you update your model of what information is available to Death.

Because Death’s presence in a city is not causally downstream of your act—it is fixed before you move—the causal probabilities legitimately depend on what evidence Death had, and that evidence includes any reliable clue to how the deliberation is concluding. In effect, P(Death in Damascus | do(Damascus)) really is near 1 if you are in fact extremely likely to do Damascus, but it can fall below ½ if you become extremely likely to do Aleppo. So the conditional probabilities are not exogenous; they vary with your own act-probabilities.

3. The instability phenomenon  

Put schematically:

EU(D) = u(Death) × q(p)  
EU(A) = u(Death) × r(p),

where q(p) is the probability Death is in Damascus given you do D and given that your present credence in doing D is p; r(p) is the analogous probability conditional on A. Under plausible assumptions q is increasing in p and r is decreasing in p. When p is small, EU(D) > EU(A); when p is large, EU(A) > EU(D). The point p* at which they tie is a fixed point. If you are at any p ≠ p*, CDT instructs you to move away from it, but as soon as you move CDT instructs you to move back. Hence cycles or oscillation.

Why is that a problem? Three lines of criticism have been advanced.

3.1 Practical guidance  
A decision theory is supposed to help agents decide. Cycling forever is not deciding. If following CDT literally causes deliberation never to terminate, CDT flunks the action-guidance test.  

3.2 Dynamic or diachronic inconsistency  
Suppose there is some small cost to delaying departure (e.g., the last bus leaves at noon). The oscillation wastes time and resources. An agent who accepts CDT at t₁ but knows she will still be a CDT-agent at t₂ can predict that she will reverse herself, so she now prefers to pre-commit to whatever avoids the oscillation. But CDT provides no license for such pre-commitment, because at each moment shifting is preferred. That kind of time inconsistency is taken by some to reveal irrationality in the rule.

3.3 The ‘wrong kind’ of dependence  
Intuitively, whether Death is waiting in Damascus should not depend on the gossamer psychological fact of exactly how probable you, the agent, currently take Damascus to be—at least not in the way CDT is forced to acknowledge. The worry is that CDT has made the act/outcome partition too fine-grained: by making the causal probability conditional on your whole belief state it has smuggled the agent, qua deliberator, back into the state description, undoing the point of separating act from state.

4. Is the complaint decisive?  

Friends of CDT have replied along two main avenues.

4.1 The ‘Nickel’s worth of wisdom’ defence  
David Lewis, Joyce and others stress that CDT is a decision rule, not a deliberation procedure. The rule is: pick the act with greatest causal expected utility. The rule makes no mention of how you come to learn what the relevant probabilities are. In normal life we compute them once, sufficiently early, and then act. If you insist on re-computing after every flicker of inclination you are misusing the rule. The right implementation is: use your prior, pre-deliberative probability p₀ that you will go to Damascus. p₀ may be 0.5; maybe it is 0.4; whatever it is, plug it in, compute EU once, and go. On that reading CDT does not generate oscillation; you do.

This reply invites two rejoinders. First, why privilege the ‘pre-deliberative’ credence p₀? If CDT tells me that, conditional on going to Aleppo, Death will almost surely be there, and that is news I did not previously incorporate, why should I ignore it? Second, consider an ideally reflective agent who begins at p₀, instantaneously performs the CDT calculation, and thereby learns that going to Aleppo is best. A microsecond later the same perfectly reflective agent recognises that, conditional on her now firming up for Aleppo, Death will learn that fact and appear in Aleppo. Stability is lost even in the limit of ideal reflection.

4.2 Ratifiability and mixed strategies  
Jeffrey, Skyrms and Harper introduce the notion of a ratifiable decision: an act is ratifiable if, after you learn that you will perform that act, CDT still recommends it. In Death in Damascus the only ratifiable choice is a mixed strategy that leaves Death guessing—roughly p = ½. CDT thus counsels randomisation. If you can truly toss a fair coin undetectably, EU(D) = EU(A) = −500, whereas any pure strategy hands Death the sure kill. In that light the instability is not a bug but a feature: the oscillation is your deliberative system groping for the unique ratifiable plan, viz. a 50-50 mixture.

This line mitigates the guidance objection: CDT does tell you what to do—adopt the mixed strategy. But it faces its own criticisms.

a) Are mixed strategies always feasible? You must be able to flip a coin that Death cannot observe, otherwise the Predictor will merely predict the outcome of the flip.  

b) Even if randomisation is feasible, is −500 the best one can do? Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) says, ‘go to Damascus’ (because seeing yourself go to Damascus is good evidence that Death predicted Damascus; since Death picks the same city you do, you will probably live). In the classic variant EDT seems to yield 0 expected disutility, beating CDT’s −500. CDT partisans will of course dispute EDT’s reasoning, but the mere fact that the ratifiable CDT recommendation is dominated under a plausible rival theory re-ignites the worry that CDT misfires.

5. Diagnosing the heart of the matter  

I submit that the deepest source of discomfort is neither the practical oscillation nor the mixed-strategy verdict in itself. It is that the causal probabilities are allowed to depend on a datum—the subjective probability of the very act under evaluation—that an ordinary causal model would treat as an artefact of the modelling process, not as a variable in the world.

Imagine drawing the usual directed acyclic graph. There are nodes for your underlying preference, for your deliberation procedure, for the act (which city to visit), for Death’s prediction, and for the outcome (live/die). A properly interventionist reading of CDT requires us to cut incoming arrows into the Act node when we evaluate P(Outcome | do(Act)). That is what makes the probability ‘causal’ rather than ‘evidential’. But in Death in Damascus, if we formalise the predictor’s epistemic access as an arrow from Deliberation to Prediction, and if we treat Deliberation as including p, then cutting incoming arrows into Act is not enough. Prediction still depends (via Deliberation) on p, which in turn depends on the act’s own causal expected utility. The probability calculus becomes reflexive. Stated differently, CDT’s way of removing the backflow of information from the act to earlier states breaks down in the presence of ultra-accurate predictors precisely because our own deliberative instability gives the predictor something to go on. That reveals a structural limitation in CDT’s formal recipe.

6. Three possible morals  

6.1 Strengthen CDT’s formal machinery  
One could sharpen the interventionist semantics: when evaluating P(Outcome | do(Act)) we do not merely cut arrows into Act; we also sever any arrows from subjective probabilities (or the internal intellectual state) that are themselves functions of Act. In effect we hold fixed not only the physical details of the past but also the agent’s information state. That manoeuvre regains stability at the cost of stipulating that a certain psychological variable is exogenous. Some will object that the stipulation is ad hoc and violates transparency: perfectly informed agents really do expect their decisions to correlate with predictors.

6.2 Accept ratifiability and live with randomisation  
Another reaction is to bite the bullet: yes, CDT’s prescriptions depend on p, but the correct CDT agent searches for a fixed point (ratifiable plan) and adopts it. The dependence is then harmless because it is neutralised at equilibrium. On this view the only genuine mistake is to imagine you can evaluate acts at probabilities other than their equilibrium value. The cost is that CDT now requires existence and uniqueness of fixed points; yet in some games no mixed strategy is ratifiable, leaving CDT silent.

6.3 Abandon CDT for a different decision rule  
The oscillation phenomenon is taken by some to motivate alternatives such as Functional Decision Theory (FDT) or Updateless Decision Theory, which evaluate acts by holding fixed the algorithm that produces the act rather than the bare physical motion. By evaluating at the level of policy (or of the program you run) the dependence on transient act-probabilities disappears. The same algorithm that outputs ‘Damascus’ yields survival, hence the theory straightforwardly recommends Damascus and beats CDT’s −500. If one is convinced that the Death problems generalise, then this is a reason to reject CDT altogether.

7. Assessment  

Is the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on current act-probabilities, in Death in Damascus-style cases, a genuine problem? I think it is, because it shows that CDT delivers unstable or under-determined guidance precisely in situations where the correlation between one’s act and upstream predictors is both foreseeable and decision-relevant.  

The practical oscillation is not the deepest difficulty—after all, we could stipulate that agents adopt the first-pass calculation or randomise in proportion to their credences. The underlying flaw is conceptual: CDT’s way of separating causes from evidential correlations fails when the correlation flows through the agent’s own predictive capacities. Stated more generally, CDT treats the agent as an isolated causal node, but in Predictor scenarios the agent is transparently a piece of a larger algorithm that the Predictor samples. The agent’s subjective probability of acting one way rather than another is not a mere modelling artefact; it is an objective regularity in the world, one that the Predictor exploits. Hence the causal probability distribution is endogenously linked to that subjective probability, and CDT’s equations become self-referential. Any rule whose key quantity is well-defined only after we have solved a fixed-point problem not guaranteed to have a solution looks theoretically fragile.

Could a refined CDT repair the defect? Possibly. But the repair would have to block the self-reference without simply stipulating ignorance or forbidding reflection. That seems difficult without moving in the direction of policy-level or algorithm-level evaluation—in short, without ceasing to be CDT as ordinarily understood.

8. Conclusion  

The Death in Damascus example reveals that CDT’s causal expected utilities can depend on an agent’s shifting act-probabilities. That dependence is not merely an oddity; it forces CDT into either practical instability or a retreat to mixed strategies that leave it dominated by rival theories in the same circumstances. The root of the trouble is that CDT’s interventionist conditionals cannot cleanly separate an act from the epistemic state that gives rise to the act when powerful predictors are in play. Unless CDT finds a principled way to excise that reflexivity, its claim to be the correct theory of rational choice remains in doubt.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Introduction

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is usually praised for two related virtues.  First, it directs the agent to ask the question that seems most relevant to rational choice: “If I were to perform act A, what causal consequences would probably follow, and how valuable would they be?”  Secondly, it appears to escape the kinds of self– defeating feedback that beset purely evidential rules; by conditioning only on the counter-factual supposition that the act is performed, CDT is supposed to insulate deliberation from merely evidential correlations between one’s choice and matters outside one’s causal reach.

The “Death in Damascus’’ problem (often called “the prophet puzzle’’ in the contemporary literature) threatens both virtues at once.  Because Death’s location is highly, but not perfectly, correlated with​ which city the agent will eventually visit, the unconditional probability of each possibility (Death-in-Damascus versus Death-in-Aleppo) is a function of the agent’s own current probability of performing the act.  As the agent’s probability of going to Damascus slides up or down during deliberation, the very numbers CDT uses to calculate expected utilities slide with it.  That means the act that looks best by CDT’s lights can oscillate back and forth.  In the limit, an ideally reflective CDT-agent looks in danger of paralysis, or of landing on an arbitrary act for no deeper reason than that she happened to start her deliberation with one prior credence rather than another.

Is that dependence on act-probabilities a flaw in CDT?  I shall argue that it is, for two reasons.  First, the oscillation phenomenon shows that CDT, as ordinarily formulated, fails to deliver stable and unambiguous guidance to a deliberating agent in a perfectly ordinary class of decision problems—those in which the world is highly correlated with, but not causally downstream from, the agent’s act.  Second, the root of the instability reveals something deeper: CDT draws its probabilities from the agent’s total prior credence function, yet that credence function contains endogenous variables—the probabilities of the very acts being chosen—that are determined only at the end of deliberation.  Unless CDT is supplemented with an extra rule for fixing those probabilities, it is normatively incomplete.

2. The structure of the case

Let the pay-offs be simple: survival is worth 1, death is worth 0.  Death listens to an imperfect but better-than-chance predictor.  The predictor’s accuracy is 60 %, and—crucially—it has a built-in inclination to guess “Damascus’’ when in doubt.  Formally:

P(Death waits in Damascus | agent goes to Damascus)   = 0.6  
P(Death waits in Aleppo   | agent goes to Aleppo)     = 0.6  
P(Death waits in Damascus | agent goes to Aleppo)      = 0.4  
P(Death waits in Aleppo   | agent goes to Damascus)    = 0.4

Furthermore, when the predictor is uncertain about which city the agent will pick it is slightly more likely to forecast Damascus.  We can model that by letting the unconditional probability that Death chooses Damascus be a convex combination of the two conditional probabilities just stated:

P(Damascus) = 0.6·P(agent goes to Damascus) + 0.4·P(agent goes to Aleppo)

Denote the agent’s current subjective probability of going to Damascus by x.  (So P(go Dam.) = x; P(go Aleppo) = 1 – x.)  Then

P(Death in Damascus)  = 0.6x + 0.4(1 – x) = 0.4 + 0.2x  
P(Death in Aleppo)    = 1 – (0.4 + 0.2x)    = 0.6 – 0.2x

Because Death’s position is outside the agent’s future light-cone, CDT instructs us to use the unconditional probabilities just displayed when we compute the causal expected utility of each act.  Given the binary utility scale, the causal expected utility of going to Damascus is simply the probability of survival conditional on going to Damascus, i.e. the chance Death is in Aleppo:

EUc(Damascus)   =   P(Death in Aleppo)   = 0.6 – 0.2x

EUc(Aleppo)     =   P(Death in Damascus) = 0.4 + 0.2x

Notice the symmetry: if EUc(Damascus) is larger at some value of x, EUc(Aleppo) will be larger at the complementary value 1 – x.  Solve for the indifference point:

EUc(Damascus) > EUc(Aleppo)   
  ⟺ 0.6 – 0.2x  > 0.4 + 0.2x  
  ⟺ 0.2  > 0.4x  
  ⟺ x  < 0.5

Thus:

• If the agent currently assigns less than 0.5 credence to her going to Damascus, CDT tells her to go to Damascus.  
• If the credence is greater than 0.5, CDT tells her to go to Aleppo.  
• If the credence is exactly 0.5, CDT is indifferent.

But the moment the agent follows CDT’s advice and firmly resolves on an act, her self-credence in that act jumps to (approximately) 1.  Hence, if she began with x < 0.5 CDT recommended Damascus; the moment she forms the intention to go to Damascus, x surges to 1, flipping the inequality and making Aleppo the new recommendation.  If she now endorses that new recommendation her credence pivots back to 0, and so on.  CDT’s deliberative guidance is therefore dynamically unstable.

3. Three immediate reactions

a. “Real agents merely pick an act and stop.”  One might insist that rational agents, once they discover an act that maximises expected causal utility given their current probabilities, should immediately adopt that act with certainty, and that they should not reopen deliberation afterward.  But if the agent is ideally rational she also knows that in doing so she will change her own act-probabilities, and hence she can foresee that the very adoption of a firm intention will undermine the reason for adopting it.  An ideal CDT-agent, being fully reflective, cannot ignore that fact.

b. “The oscillation is a pathology of self-prediction, not of CDT.”  Yet nothing exotic is required to generate the instability—only an ordinary correlation between what the agent will do and some outcome beyond her causal control.  Predictors, forecasters, market traders and strategic opponents supply such correlations in realistic situations.  If CDT lacks stable advice in all those cases, that is CDT’s problem.

c. “Perhaps the right solution is to treat acts as evidentially impossible.”  Some proponents of CDT (notably Skyrms and Joyce in different ways) have suggested that a rational agent should assign probability 0 or 1 to whichever act she will in fact perform; any non-extreme credence in one’s own future act reflects an occult form of self-doubt ruled irrational by the very norms of deliberation.  If so, x must be either 0 or 1 throughout deliberation, making one of the two expected-utility functions undefined, and the instability evaporates.  But the move is dialectically costly.  CDT was sold as a theory that merely instructs us how to turn given credences into choices; now it is telling us, on pain of irrationality, what those credences must be.  Moreover, it is implausible that perfectly rational creatures can never be genuinely uncertain which of two evenly matched options they will pick—as though Buridan’s ass must be irrational simply for not yet knowing which bale of hay it will wander toward.

4. Why the dependence is a genuine problem

4.1  Dynamic inconsistency

The hallmark of a sound decision theory is that it issues advice that an agent can follow through reflective equilibrium—that is, advice whose rationale survives the agent’s own awareness that she is about to follow it.  CDT’s advice in the Damascus case, however, is self-undermining.  Whatever choice-probability x obtains at an early stage of deliberation, CDT recommends an act that will move x to a new value that reverses the recommendation.  That is a species of dynamic inconsistency.  Dynamic inconsistency is familiar in time-inconsistent preference orderings (hyper-bolic discounting, preference reversals, etc.), but here the inconsistency arises not from changing utilities but from the way CDT embeds changing probabilities into its own decision rule.  And it is endemic, not exceptional: any predictable correlation between acts and outcomes that lie outside their causal influence will have the same structure.

4.2  Normative incompleteness

CDT tells us: “For each act A, compute EUc(A) = Σs P(s)·U(A, s), where the sum runs over causal-parents-of-A.’’  But in a case like Damascus the unconditional state probabilities P(s) are themselves functions of the probabilities of the very acts whose utilities we are trying to evaluate.  CDT therefore maps the agent’s credence vector into itself.  Nothing in standard CDT stipulates where in that moving landscape the agent’s credences should settle.  A theory that produces mutually inconsistent recommendations for different admissible starting points lacks a fixed-point and so is normatively incomplete.  Until CDT is supplemented with additional principles—ratifiability, reflection stability, policy selection, what have you—it does not yield a single, determinate answer to the decision problem.

4.3  Illusion of control revisited

Some defenders hold that the agent should set x = 1 for whichever act maximises causal expected utility, where maximisation is now done holding x fixed at 1.  In effect CDT becomes:

Choose the act that would best achieve your objectives on the supposition that you determinately choose it.

But that is tantamount to ignoring the evidential information your act carries about outside matters, even when you know that your act has no causal leverage over them.  The oscillation in the Damascus story occurs precisely because CDT strives both to respect and to ignore the correlation: it uses the unconditional (hence correlation-laden) probabilities P(s), yet it pretends that choosing but not performing an act does nothing to those probabilities.  That is an illusion of control in the opposite direction: the agent treats the probabilities as though she could freeze them by a fiat of deliberative will.  In the real world she cannot; conditional on her eventually acting one way, the environment is already configured in a matching way.  CDT’s prescription therefore suffers from an evidential blind spot: by focusing exclusively on causal influence, it ends up treating predictable evidential correlations as if they could be wished away.

4.4  Loss of money pumps and Dutch books

Instabilities in a decision rule often manifest as Dutch-book vulnerability.  Imagine a wily bookmaker who can observe or reliably infer the agent’s current act-credence x.  While x < 0.5 she can sell the agent at a fair price an insurance contract that pays one util if Death is in Aleppo; the agent, thinking she is headed for Damascus, values that contract at exactly EUc(Damascus) = 0.6 – 0.2x and buys it.  Now persuading the agent to form the intention to go to Damascus bumps x to 1 and reverses the valuation; the agent wants to undo the purchase, selling the contract back at EUc(Aleppo) = 0.4 + 0.2x = 0.6.  The bookmaker pockets 0.2 utils.  The cycle can be repeated arbitrarily often.  The point is not merely that CDT permits money pumps (indifference theories do too), but that the dependence on act-probabilities furnishes the exploiter with a lever to pump money in real time, revealing a structural weakness of the decision rule itself.

5. Proposed repairs and why they fall short

5.1  Ratifiability

Jeffrey’s ratifiability principle says that a rational act must be such that, were one to learn that one will perform it, one would still endorse it.  In Damascus the only ratifiable mixtures are x = 0.5 (where the agent is indifferent) and perhaps x = 1/2 under infinitesimal trembles.  That solves the oscillation, but at the cost of recommending indecision—going neither to Damascus nor to Aleppo with certainty, but dithering in a half-hearted mix.  Few take that to be a satisfactory verdict.

5.2  Policy-choice CDT

Another tack is to shift the unit of evaluation from single acts to whole decision policies.  A policy, roughly, is a function from possible information states to acts.  The agent therefore adopts ex ante a policy that maximises expected causal utility and then executes the policy without further deliberation.  Because the act-probabilities are fixed by the policy, not by online deliberation, oscillation is avoided.  Policy-choice CDT thereby reproduces one of the main insights of Functional Decision Theory and Updateless Decision Theory.  Yet that is to concede that standard, act-by-act CDT is inadequate; the dependence on act-probabilities is precisely what forces the policymaker upgrade.

5.3  Evidential decision theory

EDT, of course, cares only about P(s | A) rather than P(s).  In the Death in Damascus set-up, conditioning on A makes Death’s location strongly (though not perfectly) correlated with A.  EDT therefore recommends *going where you least expect to go*, the exact opposite of CDT’s first recommendation.  EDT thus sidesteps oscillation by leaning hard into the correlation.  However, EDT has its own well-known problems (Smoking Lesion cases, etc.) and so shifting from CDT to EDT just swaps pathologies rather than curing them.

6. The deeper conceptual lesson

Why is the dependence of CDT’s expected utilities on act-probabilities so corrosive?  The root difficulty is that CDT generically assumes that the agent walks into the decision problem with a fully formed probability distribution over states of the world, including agencies’ own acts.  But those acts are not part of the exogenous state of nature; they are endogenously chosen in light of the very decision rule whose inputs the distribution is supposed to supply.  When the world is correlated with the act, the boundary between what is given and what is generated collapses.  CDT tries to use the same distribution for two incompatible roles: evidential guide and causal yardstick.  In Damascus the clash becomes visible, but the structural mismatch is present wherever the world “knows’’ something about what the agent will do.

The correct moral, I submit, is that a decision rule must be reflexive: it must model not only how the world causally reacts to the act, but also how the world probabilistically co-moves with the agent’s decision-making process itself.  CDT, in its standard act-centred form, refuses to countenance those reflexive links, so it is forced into an awkward dance with its own changing act-probabilities.  The resulting instability is the symptom.

7. Conclusion

Standard, act-by-act Causal Decision Theory instructs us to evaluate each available act using unconditional state probabilities.  In Death-in-Damascus-style cases those probabilities co-vary with the agent’s own changing credence about which act she will perform.  The upshot is substantive instability: CDT’s recommendation flips each time the agent updates her self-prediction, yielding dynamic inconsistency, Dutch-book vulnerability, and ultimately normative incompleteness.  Remedies such as ratifiability or policy-level choice either yield unsatisfactory indecision or amount to abandoning the act-centred version of CDT altogether.  Hence the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s current act-probabilities is indeed a serious problem—serious enough to motivate a re-examination of the foundations of causal decision-making itself.

question: Causal Decision Theory (CDT) evaluates acts by their expected utility, calculated using unconditional probabilities for states not causally downstream of your act. In 'Death in Damascus'-style cases, where you must choose between going to Aleppo or Damascus knowing that Death awaits in whichever city he predicted you would visit (with predictions being reliable but imperfect, and Death having a tendency to guess Damascus), the utility of each act depends on your current probability that you will perform that act. This means CDT's recommendations can shift as your act probabilities change during deliberation. Is this dependence on act probabilities a problem for CDT, and if so, why?
answer:
1. Framing the difficulty  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) begins from a seemingly simple idea: when I am weighing acts, I should ask which act would causally bring about the best expected outcome.  Formally,

      EU(a) = Σs  P(s | do a) · U(outcome of a in s),

where the sum ranges over “states of the world” s that are not causally downstream of the act a.  The probabilities P(s | do a) are supposed to be the unconditional, pre-act probabilities of those states; unlike Evidential Decision Theory, CDT refuses to conditionalise on the act itself when computing those numbers.

In ordinary cases this machinery behaves nicely.  Whether I turn the kettle on has no causal effect on today’s weather, so the probability of rain appears in the same position in the expected-utility formula whichever act I am evaluating.  But in so-called “Death in Damascus” scenarios things are less tidy.  There is only one causally independent state that really matters, namely

      sD  =  Death is waiting in Damascus
      sA  =  Death is waiting in Aleppo.

Yet my probability for sD and sA is not fixed in the way the probability of rain is.  Because Death is a good predictor, my own credence that I will go to Damascus raises my credence that Death will be in Damascus.  Consequently the probability figures CDT feeds into its expectation formula depend on my current state of deliberation.  If, half a second ago, I was 70 % inclined to head for Damascus, I will enter P(sD)=.7 into the table and get the advice “Go to Aleppo!”.  Having now pivoted toward Aleppo, I will recompute, see that P(sD)=.3, and obtain the advice “Go to Damascus!”.  The recommendations oscillate with my shifting credence.

The question is whether this dependence is an embarrassment for CDT, and if it is, what exactly goes wrong.  The rest of the essay pursues three lines of argument.

2. First worry: loss of deliberative stability  

A decision theory should guide a deliberator from uncertainty about what to do to a settled intention.  “Deliberative stability” means that once I arrive at the act the theory recommends, I no longer have a motivation (generated by the very same theory) to reopen the question.  CDT in the Death in Damascus set-up fails that test.

To see the contrast, imagine I am choosing whether to raise an umbrella.  CDT says:

      EU(raise)   =  0.9·(stay dry)  +  0.1·(awkward to carry)
      EU(not)     =  0.1·(get wet)   +  0.9·(hands free),

numbers pulled from the background weather forecast.  Either I judge EU(raise) > EU(not) or vice-versa; once the comparison is done, the inputs do not change merely because my intention has crystallised.

In Death in Damascus there is no analogous “exogenous” forecast.  The only serious evidence about where Death will be comes from the very pattern of intentions I am currently forming.  A moment’s reflection shows why that undermines stability.  Let p be my current credence that I will pick Damascus.  CDT then writes:

      EU(Damascus)  =  p·(live) + (1–p)·(die).
      EU(Aleppo)    = (1–p)·(live) +  p·(die).

Assuming Death is worse than survival, EU(Damascus) < EU(Aleppo) precisely when p > ½, and the inequality flips the other way when p < ½.  But deliberation is the very process of shifting p.  So whichever action currently looks best will immediately push p in the opposite direction, revoking itself.  The algorithm never reaches a fixed point unless p stalls exactly at ½.  CDT thereby fails the “guidance” test: it cannot deliver a stable intention unless the agent succeeds in a delicate act of self-manipulation (adopting precisely a 50 % mixture), an act for which the theory gives no general recipe.

The defender of CDT might reply that instability is not always fatal.  In economic models it can be rationally required to randomise among equilibria; “mixed strategies” are ubiquitous in game theory.  Couldn’t the CDT-guided agent simply toss a fair coin and so achieve p=½?  Two rejoinders:

a. Mixed strategies that emerge from game-theoretic reasoning are supported by a vertex: once I have publicly committed to the mixture, each pure deviation is disincentivised by the other player’s optimal response.  In Death in Damascus there is no strategic opponent whom I can predictably sway by pre-committing.  Death has already made his prediction.  So declaring “with probability ½ I shall go to Damascus” achieves nothing.

b. CDT, as usually formulated, is a theory about which act to perform, not about which lottery over acts to implement.  Randomising is an additional act.  But whether randomisation helps depends on my credence that I will randomise, thrusting us back into the same regress.

Hence the first problem for CDT is that, in these predictor cases, it loses its practical traction.  A theory whose recommendations bounce around faster than I can implement them is of little use as an action-guiding tool.

3. Second worry: unratifiable advice  

Richard Jeffrey (and later, Skyrms, Gibbard and Harper) distinguished between an act’s being recommended and its being ratifiable.  An act is ratifiable when, conditional on learning that I am about to perform it, I would still regard it as the best choice.  In Death in Damascus no pure act is ratifiable under CDT.  Suppose I reach the point where I know I shall go to Damascus.  Then I know p≈1, and EU(Damascus) is worse than EU(Aleppo).  So the very information that I am choosing Damascus de-ratifies Damascus.  Likewise if I learn I am heading to Aleppo.  Ratifiability failure suggests that following CDT will place me in a position where, on the brink of acting, I believe that a switch would improve expected utility.

Some philosophers, e.g. Jeffrey and Joyce, have urged “ratification” as an additional constraint on rational action.  Others deny its necessity but concede that gross failures of ratifiability generate cognitive dissonance: CDT makes me think, all things considered, that whatever I in fact am doing is sub-optimal.  That verdict is, at the very least, epistemically uncomfortable.  The underlying reason is again the dependence of EU on the shifting self-probability p.

4. Third worry: the corruption of unconditional probabilities  

The heart of CDT is the do-operator: P(s | do a) should be the probability of s when we hold fixed that a is performed by a causal intervention.  The whole point of the intervention metaphor is to break causal links from a to states that precede or are causally independent of a.  But in Death in Damascus it turns out to be devilishly hard to impose the intervention in one’s belief state.  If during deliberation I become confident I will go to Damascus, then, given what I know about the predictor, I automatically become confident that Death predicted Damascus yesterday.  The two propositions may be causally independent, but they are not epistemically independent.  Somehow I must resist updating on my own intention if I am to keep the do-probabilities fixed.  The resulting cognitive exercise—mentally “clamping” the act while simultaneously bracketing all the information that intention provides—looks psychologically impossible.

So we face a dilemma:

• Either the agent uses true unconditional probabilities, and those inevitably vary with her current beliefs about her imminent behaviour, blowing up deliberative stability.

• Or she tries to imagine what her probabilities would be if she deleted the evidential link between her action and Death’s prediction.  But then she is no longer using her real credences, contradicting the personalist spirit of CDT.

A theory that demands psychological tricks its adherents cannot execute is, arguably, normatively defective.

5. Could the problem be dismissed as an artefact?  

Perhaps the dependence on act probabilities is not a deep flaw but a peculiarity of highly artificial predictor stories.  Two counterpoints.

First, predictor stories are not rare curiosities: they exemplify any situation in which other agents (human or algorithmic) form beliefs about what I will do and act on the basis of those beliefs.  Stock markets, diplomacy, auction design, and everyday social life teem with such feedback loops.  If CDT stumbles whenever my action is correlatively entwined with earlier predictions, it is in trouble far beyond philosophy seminars.

Second, the instability arises even without a prescient demon.  Consider a variant: you have a mild psychological bias toward whichever city you think less dangerous.  As you lean toward Damascus you relax, start guessing that Death will be in Aleppo, which in turn reinforces the inclination to Damascus—and vice-versa.  Again, the relevant probabilities are self-referential.  The puzzle is structural, not contingent on supernatural predictors.

6. Replies on behalf of CDT  

Several manoeuvres have been proposed to shield CDT.

6.1  Commitment to a policy rather than a momentary act  

Why not evaluate whole policies—rules mapping information states to acts—instead of single acts?  Let π be a policy: “If my present credence p exceeds ½ go to Aleppo, otherwise go to Damascus.”  Plugging π into CDT yields a unique expected utility because π’s specification removes the feedback loop: knowing the rule fixes how acts correlate with Death’s earlier prediction.  Once a policy is in place, one never re-evaluates mid-deliberation.

Two problems:

a. Standard CDT does not quantify over policies; introducing them is a substantive revision, nearer to “Updateless” or “Functional” Decision Theory.

b. Even if policies are admitted, which one should I adopt now?  The same instability infects the choice of policy unless a higher-order commitment is already in place.  The proposal pushes the problem up a level.

6.2  Ratifiable CDT (Joyce 2012)  

Jim Joyce suggests that rational agents should restrict attention to ratifiable acts: acts that would still be preferred upon learning that they are about to be performed.
