On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction: the intuitive worry

Suppose Samantha notices that a stranger has been badly injured in a traffic accident. She immediately applies first aid, calls an ambulance, and waits with the victim until help arrives. When later asked why she did all this she replies, quite sincerely, ‘Because it was the morally right thing to do.’ Some spectators think her answer reveals admirable single-mindedness; others find it oddly chilly. They would have preferred her to say that she acted out of compassion for the stranger’s pain. The second reaction lies behind the charge that a merely de dicto desire—to do whatever is right—can never ground fully admirable conduct. Where is Samantha’s concern for the concrete human being in front of her? Where is the warmth or love or sympathy that, many believe, gives morality its point? Acting ‘from duty alone’, these critics say, smacks of moral fetishism or alienation.

In what follows I defend the claim that a pure desire to do what is right can, in at least some cases, suffice for moral worth. To make that plausible I undertake four tasks: (i) clarify what it means to act from the motive of duty, distinguishing de dicto and de re moral motivation; (ii) reconstruct the main anti-Kantian objections—fetishism, motivational poverty, and alienation; (iii) show why those objections are not decisive by developing a positive account of how a de dicto moral motive can display sensitivity to the very same considerations that its critics prize; and (iv) explain why such action is, on that account, genuinely praiseworthy.

2. De dicto versus de re moral motivation

Philosophers often distinguish two kinds of moral desire:

• De re: a first-order concern for the particular features that make an action right—e.g., the injured stranger’s pain, a friend’s need, an environmental disaster.  
• De dicto: a higher-order, content-neutral desire that one’s conduct conform to whatever morality demands; the focus is on rightness ‘under that description.’

Kantians typically valorise the de dicto desire. Kant claims that an action has ‘moral worth’ only if it is done ‘from duty’—that is, because one recognises and is moved by the thought that duty requires it. Critics, however, suspect that leaving everything at the de dicto level gets things backwards: morality is about concrete persons and interests, not about rightness in the abstract. On their view, to care merely about ‘the right’ is like admiring a painting solely because one was told it is valuable, rather than because one sees its beauty.

3. The standard objections

a) Fetishism (Smith, Arpaly, Railton)  
The moral fetishist is unhealthily pre-occupied with a property—rightness—as such. Like someone attracted not to persons but to the fact that they wear police uniforms, the fetishist focuses on a formal feature and is blind to what gives that feature point. Sympathy, friendship, love or justice are thereby slighted.

b) Motivational impoverishment (Stocker’s ‘schizophrenia’)  
Michael Stocker argues that modern moral theories make agents schizophrenic: they recommend that we do loving things for our friends, yet they tell us that the ultimately correct motive is to maximise utility or do one’s duty. Such detachment prevents genuine human relationships. To visit a friend in hospital only because duty calls is to fail the very ideal of friendship.

c) Alienation (Williams)  
Bernard Williams worries that moral theories which demand a standing readiness to set aside one’s personal projects in favour of an abstract impartial standard alienate the agent from her identity-conferring commitments. Acting merely from duty thus threatens an existential dis-integration.

4. Two preliminary clarifications

First, the debate is not over whether duty can coexist with sympathy or love. Everyone agrees that Samantha could be moved simultaneously by compassion and by the thought that it is right to help. The narrow question is whether the latter motive alone can ever suffice for moral worth when the former is absent.

Second, ‘suffice’ does not mean ‘always best.’ It means ‘good enough for full moral praise in at least some circumstances.’ ∎

5. A Kantian-inspired defence

I submit that pure dutiful agency can be morally admirable because it embodies three interconnected excellences.

5.1. Practical recognition respect

Stephen Darwall distinguishes ‘appraisal respect’ (a warm attitude of esteem) from ‘recognition respect’ (a disposition to treat something as setting constraints on one’s conduct). To act from duty is to give recognition respect to the moral law. One thereby acknowledges the equal authority of every person’s claims, including those who fail to grip one’s sympathy. When Samantha helps the stranger merely because it is right, she demonstrates a laudable non-partial responsiveness to persons as such. Far from slighting the concrete victim, she honours him precisely as a bearer of moral standing, and she does so independently of contingent affective ties.

5.2. Reliability under partiality-defeating conditions

Sympathy is unstable: we feel it more for the nearby than for the distant, more for the cute than for the unlovely. A de dicto moral desire functions as a stabiliser that keeps moral performance on track when first-order sentiments misfire. Think of a triage doctor exhausted after 48 hours; her empathic reserves are drained, but her sense of duty keeps her equitably treating each patient. The very impersonality of the motive is what secures dependability. Moral worth plausibly increases with the robustness of one’s responsiveness to the right-making reasons; therefore an impartial de dicto desire, by counteracting parochial biases, can ground praiseworthy steadiness.

5.3. Second-order evaluative guidance

Even when de dicto desire is the sole occurrent motive, it need not be ignorant of the concrete grounds of rightness. It can operate as a second-order directive: ‘Do whatever the reasons demand.’ To execute that instruction the agent must attend to, weigh, and be guided by the first-order reasons themselves—otherwise she could not reliably identify which act is right. Duty, so understood, is no blind fetish; it is a standing commitment to practical reason. Acting from duty thus manifests the agent’s rational capacities: sensitivity to evidence, capacity for impartial justification, and responsiveness to critique.

6. Replying to the three objections

a) To fetishism: The above shows that the dutiful agent’s focus on rightness is not an erotic fixation on an inert property; it is a respect for the set of considerations that constitute rightness. The de dicto desire is like a good scientist’s desire for truth: it is formally defined, yet it directs the scientist to concrete empirical facts. A doctor who wants ‘the correct diagnosis’ is not alienated from her patient’s symptoms; on the contrary, that very desire makes her attend carefully to them. Likewise, a desire that one’s conduct be right sends one straight into the thick of real human concerns.

b) To motivational impoverishment: Visiting a friend solely from duty might indeed betray something defective about the friendship. But that verdict presupposes the special role that love ought to play in that particular relation. Not every moral context is like friendship. In many cases—paying taxes, jury duty, rescuing strangers—what morality requires is precisely an impersonal stance. Praiseworthiness varies with role. The worry confuses a species of partial relationship-value with the genus of moral value.

c) To alienation: A standing commitment to do what is right is not an alien force; it is an integral component of practical identity. Christine Korsgaard argues that reflective beings inevitably act under some conception of what is normatively warranted; the moral law, when endorsed, becomes part of the self. Hence doing one’s duty is not self-betrayal but self-constitution.

7. The Markovits thesis: good will as de dicto

Sarah Paul and Julia Markovits sharpen the defence: what matters is not the object of the desire (a de re property) but the quality of will reflected in how the agent responds to the reasons she believes decisive. A de dicto moral desire embodies the good will because it shows that the agent is moved by moral reasons as such. Provided her belief about what morality requires is correct and non-accidental, the resulting act has moral worth.

Yet one might object: two agents can share a de dicto motive while one stumbles onto the truth and the other tracks it competently. Here we reach an important refinement: moral worth demands reason-responsiveness, not lucky conformity. If duty moves Samantha to act but she could easily have mistaken what duty demanded in slightly different circumstances, her action is less praiseworthy. A desire to do what is right must be embedded in a broader virtue of conscientiousness—attentiveness to morally relevant facts, openness to criticism, willingness to correct error. Fetishism is avoided not by importing sympathy but by enriching the de dicto motive with epistemic virtues.

8. Why de dicto motivation sometimes outshines de re

Consider three scenarios.

8.1. The impartial rescuer  
Dana dislikes the victim (perhaps the victim had earlier wronged her) and feels no sympathy. Nonetheless, the thought ‘A person is gravely at risk; it is my duty to help’ moves her to act. Most will agree that Dana is morally worthy—perhaps more so than someone who helps only because she happens to like the victim.

8.2. The justice-driven juror  
Ethan serves on a jury involving a defendant whose ethnicity he distrusts; his gut pulls him toward conviction. Yet Ethan is moved by the desire to do what is right, so he carefully examines the evidence and votes for acquittal. His sole motive is duty. It would be perverse to withhold praise on the ground that he lacked warm feelings toward the defendant.

8.3. Moral uncertainty  
Fiona faces a policy decision involving complex climate data. No concrete sentiment offers guidance. Her motive is: ‘I must adopt whichever policy is morally best, all things considered.’ She commissions further research, weighs competing arguments, and chooses the option with the strongest impartial reasons. De re benevolence is too unspecific here; de dicto conscientiousness is what drives the morally serious inquiry.

These cases illustrate that the impersonality of duty can not only suffice but sometimes rescue moral deliberation from the partiality and opacity of first-order sentiments.

9. Objection: Couldn’t a fanatic equally act from a de dicto moral desire?

Indeed, the terrorist who blows up a market ‘because it is morally required’ is also acting from duty as he conceives it. Must we praise him? No. The sufficiency thesis is conditional: the motive of duty suffices for moral worth only if (i) the agent’s substantive moral belief is correct (or at least epistemically reasonable), and (ii) the belief is held and acted upon with the right kind of reflection and respect for others as rational equals. Fanaticism fails both tests: its beliefs are false and its deliberative posture excludes critical engagement. The fanatic’s will is bad not because it is de dicto but because it is irrational and disrespectful.

10. Objectivity, fallibility, and humility

The de dicto desire has another virtue: it incorporates a structural humility. One who is essentially committed to ‘whatever is right’ acknowledges that she might be mistaken about particular cases; hence she stays alert to reasons, argument, and evidence. In contrast, an agent who is simply moved by sympathy may, when corrected about the implications of her act, reply, ‘But I feel so sorry for him!’ Moral progress across history often depended on agents whose paramount motive was to do what was right and who therefore allowed new arguments—about slavery, women’s suffrage, animal cruelty—to overturn comfortable intuitions.

11. Integration with other motives

The strongest defence of duty need not recommend motivational monism. A mature moral agent integrates de dicto and de re concerns. But integration entails hierarchy: when sympathy clashes with duty, duty rightly overrides. The charge that pure duty involves a lack of ‘warmth’ mistakes sufficiency for exclusivity. A motive can be sufficient for praise without being optimal for all-things-considered human flourishing. Analogously, knowing how to drive safely is sufficient for being a good driver, even if knowing also how to enjoy scenic routes makes one a better driver still.

12. Why such conduct is praiseworthy

Praiseworthiness supervenes on the agent’s quality of will—her dispositions to recognise, weigh, and respond to moral reasons. A pure desire to do what is right embodies four commendable features:

1. Impartiality: It respects persons as equals, not as objects of sentimental preference.  
2. Stability: It guides action when emotions falter or mislead.  
3. Reflectivity: It incorporates openness to evidence and self-correction.  
4. Self-governance: It manifests the capacity to act from principle rather than impulse.

These characteristics are constitutive of moral virtue; praise is therefore fitting.

13. Conclusion

The accusation that the motive of duty inevitably produces moral fetishism mistakes a formal description of the motive for its substantive operation. When properly understood, a de dicto desire to do what is right is neither blind nor bloodless: it expresses respect for persons, keeps action aligned with impartial reasons, and embodies the intellectual humility necessary for moral learning. Because these attributes bear directly on the moral worth of action, we are justified in praising agents who act solely from duty, at least when other virtuous motives are unavailable or unreliable. What ultimately matters is not whether the spring of action is abstract or concrete, but whether it conduces to a rational, respectful, and stable responsiveness to moral reasons. In that respect the Kantian insight stands: good will—conceived as the steadfast commitment to do what is right—remains a sufficient, though not exclusive, ground of moral worth.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Few doctrines in moral psychology have been as resilient—or as embattled—as the Kantian thought that an action’s worth depends on its being done “from duty.”  The view appears, on the one hand, to capture something exalted in ordinary moral admiration: we praise the person who keeps a painful promise because she must, not because she happens to relish doing so.  Yet many contemporary philosophers—from Michael Stocker’s charge of “moral schizophrenia,” to Michael Smith’s complaint of “moral fetishism,” to Susan Wolf’s portrait of the “moral saint”—maintain that a merely de dicto longing to do whatever morality requires is impoverished.  Morality, they say, is about concrete relational goods: relieving a child’s fear, respecting a colleague’s autonomy, preserving a friend’s life.  Someone who helps simply because “that is what morality calls for” appears estranged from what truly matters in the situation.  

This essay argues that the de dicto motive of duty can, by itself, suffice for moral worth.  I do not claim that it is always superior to more concrete motives, nor that agents with richer emotional repertoires could not be better.  I claim only that exclusive reliance on duty need not rob an action of praiseworthiness.  I defend this thesis in four steps.

1. I first analyze the distinction between de dicto and de re moral motivation and their connection to moral worth.  
2. I reconstruct three principal objections: the fetishism objection, the alienation objection, and the epistemic impotence objection.  
3. I then supply four positive arguments showing why a pure motive of duty can ground moral worth: (a) its rational structure expresses recognition of moral authority; (b) it secures impartial reliability; (c) it embodies a valuable form of second-personal respect; and (d) it displays a distinctive kind of practical wisdom.  
4. Finally, I explain how the dutiful agent avoids fetishism and alienation by embedding her de dicto commitment in a broader practical identity, even while the de dicto desire alone does the motivational work on a given occasion.

Throughout, I assume a broadly Kantian conception of moral worth: an action is morally worthy when it expresses the agent’s virtuous character—where virtue is understood in terms of responsiveness to reasons—in a way for which the agent can be appropriately praised.

2. De dicto vs. de re motivation  

Let us sharpen the oft-invoked contrast.  An agent acts from a de re moral motive when she is moved by the very considerations that make the action right.  If she visits her elderly neighbor because she cares about his loneliness, the loneliness—the de re content—directly motivates her.  By contrast, an agent acts from a de dicto moral motive when what moves her is the propositional attitude, “that this is the morally right thing to do,” irrespective of which first-order considerations make it right.  She wills the right as such.

Two clarifications are essential.

a. The distinction concerns the content that motivates, not the agent’s cognitive access.  One can fully know why an act is right and still be moved by the abstract normative status rather than by the concrete facts.  

b. De dicto motivation need not be egoistic or heteronomous.  The agent does not say, “I want to score moral points,” but “I must do what morality requires”—a desire shaped by a conception of herself as subject to moral law.  

3. Three objections to de dicto sufficiency  

3.1 Moral fetishism (Smith)  
Smith claims that being moved simply by the rightness of an act treats rightness as a fetish object: it fixes motivation on a “moral property” instead of the substantive features—others’ suffering, broken promises—that confer the property.  That, he contends, betrays a failure to respond to the world’s morally salient features.

3.2 Alienation (Stocker and Wolf)  
Stocker’s well-known hospital example imagines a friend visiting only “because it is my duty.”  The patient feels alienated: the friend’s visit inherits a chill, lacking warmth or concern.  Wolf further argues that an exclusive preoccupation with doing the morally best thing crowds out non-moral goods, crippling the agent’s capacity for friendship or humor.

3.3 Epistemic impotence  
Finally, critics worry that a de dicto desire is too indeterminate to guide action.  Morality requires grasping which concrete considerations matter; an abstract “do the right thing” cannot, by itself, tell us what to do.  It therefore cannot explain timely, sensitive performance.

I take these objections seriously.  The defense of dutiful sufficiency must show (i) that rightness-regarding desire is not fetishistic, (ii) that it can incorporate respect and concern in ways that avoid alienation, and (iii) that it is epistemically efficacious.

4. Four positive arguments  

4.1 Recognition of moral authority  

At the heart of morality—especially on Kantian lines—is the idea that moral demands are categorically authoritative.  To be moral is, first, to recognize that authority and, second, to will in accordance with it.  A de dicto desire to do what is right precisely embodies that recognition: it is the standing disposition to let moral considerations govern choice, whatever they turn out to be.  When such a disposition issues in action, the action manifests the agent’s principled self-governance.  That fact alone merits praise, for it displays a fundamental virtue: respect for the moral law.

Importantly, the de re motives the critics champion (sympathy, love, solidarity) acquire moral salience precisely because, rightly structured, they track what morality requires.  If so, then the primary locus of moral worth cannot be the concrete sentiment per se, but the agent’s responsiveness to normative reasons.  The de dicto motive enables that responsiveness in its most general form.  We can thus see it as the architectonic virtue undergirding all others: a commitment to give decisive weight to moral reasons across circumstances.

4.2 Impartial reliability  

Second, an exclusive motive of duty can secure a robustness that concrete sentiments often lack.  Sympathy, for instance, is known to be partial: we empathize more with those who resemble us or whose faces we can see.  Friend-concern favors intimates; love favors lovers.  While such partiality is not always vicious, there are many cases—distributing scarce medicine, adjudicating rights—where morality asks us to bracket them.  Because a de dicto motive tracks rightness rather than affect, it can motivate correct action when concrete affections misfire or are silent.  Its impartiality underwrites reliability, the very feature Kant stresses in the case of the melancholy philanthropist who aids others despite lacking any sympathetic feeling.  That reliability is itself praiseworthy, for it makes the agent a trustworthy bearer of moral responsibility.

Note that reliability is counterfactual: we esteem the dutiful person not merely because she helped today, but because we believe she would help tomorrow even if the victim were someone she disliked.  A purely de re sympathetic motive cannot guarantee that; the de dicto one can.

4.3 Second-personal respect  

A third virtue of acting from duty is that it can manifest a distinctive form of respect for persons, captured nicely by Stephen Darwall’s “second-personal” account of moral obligations.  To act from duty is, inter alia, to recognize another’s authority to demand certain treatment from one.  That recognition is not primarily a matter of being moved by their welfare (a benevolent stance) but by the claim they are entitled to press (a deontic stance).  When I keep a promise because it is right, I acknowledge you as a co-rational agent whose expectations impose genuine constraints on me.  That form of regard can be absent in purely de re motivations focused on welfare.  The dutiful promiser conveys, “You matter as a self-governing person,” not merely, “I care about your happiness.”  Respect is a moral good, and its expression is a fitting ground for praise.

4.4 Practical wisdom under uncertainty  

Finally, the epistemic objection can be turned on its head.  In real decision making, we often face morally relevant facts we only dimly grasp; our affective responses are noisy.  A standing policy of doing what is right functions as a kind of higher-order control, guiding deliberation toward discovering the relevant concrete reasons.  Philosophers sometimes depict the de dicto desire as one that floats free of such discovery, but an intelligent moral agent treats it as a demand to engage in conscientious inquiry: “I aim to do what is right; therefore I must determine what is right here.”  Having such a higher-order aim is epistemically fruitful, not impotent, analogous to a scientist’s commitment to believe what the evidence supports.  The motive of duty thus expresses practical wisdom: it integrates motivation with the regulative ideal of correct action.

We can put the point in terms of counterfactual sensitivity: if, after investigation, the agent learned that the concrete facts made a different act right, the pure de dicto motive would seamlessly redirect her will.  De re motives, tied to specific features, need not; sympathetic feeling for this child’s distress will not, by itself, redirect to saving two strangers elsewhere.  The capacity to track moral truth across informational updates is a virtue we properly admire.

5. Defusing the objections  

5.1 Against fetishism  

Why is de dicto rightness not a fetish?  Because the dutiful agent values rightness not as an alluring property but as the property of being supported by decisive reasons.  The fetishist’s desire is insensitive to why the act is right; the dutiful agent’s desire, properly understood, is defined by the norm that the reasons in favor of the act are sufficient.  That concept is not a “shallow evaluative property” in Smith’s sense; it is a reference to whatever reasons there are, thus implicitly encompassing the concrete features.  To call that stance fetishistic is to confuse a higher-order appreciation of reason’s authority with an obsession over an occult object.

5.2 Against alienation  

Does duty alienate friends?  Sometimes—but it need not.  Nothing in the claim “I help you because it is right” precludes also communicating warmth.  Moreover, consider the symmetric case where what morality requires diverges from personal affection—delivering unpleasant truths, terminating an unsafe friendship, or reporting a colleague’s misconduct.  Here the friend may rightly appreciate that one is acting from duty; affection alone would be suspect.  Far from alienating, the sense that another will treat me justly even when the chips are down can deepen trust.

Still, Stocker’s phenomenology has a point: exclusive verbal avowal of duty can feel cold.  The solution is not to deny duty’s moral worth but to note that praise and interpersonal comfort are different goods.  A surgeon might save a life with perfect skill and win moral admiration even as her bedside manner leaves something to be desired.  Similarly, the dutiful agent may be praiseworthy though not maximally amiable.  And nothing prevents cultivating both duty and warmth; the fact that the latter sweetens the act does not show that the former is insufficient for moral worth.

5.3 Against epistemic impotence  

When critics claim that “do what is right” is too thin to guide conduct, they mistake an abstract maxim for a full deliberative process.  In practice, the agent who holds herself to the standard of rightness deploys whatever empirical and normative resources she has to figure out what rightness entails.  The commitment is not content-less; it is a directive to perform that very figuring-out.  Thus the dutiful motive is instrumentally and epistemically effective.

6. A qualified sufficiency thesis  

The conclusion so far is conditional: acting solely from the desire to do what is right can suffice for moral worth provided the desire (i) is suitably informed, (ii) issues in correct action, and (iii) is robustly sensitive to moral reasons.  Why add these conditions?  Because a bare wish to be moral, without reliable sensitivity to reasons, is insufficient; it degenerates into wishful thinking.  But when the conditions obtain, the de dicto motive itself grounds moral worth.

Two further qualifications merit mention.

First, sufficiency is not optimality.  A richly virtuous agent may integrate de re motives—compassion, gratitude, solidarity—alongside duty.  Such integration can enhance the value of her acts.  My claim is only that their absence does not negate worth.

Second, sufficiency is restricted to moral worth, not aesthetic or relational value.  An action can be morally commendable yet lack affective grace; Stocker’s patient may still feel unloved.  Morality is one evaluative dimension among many.

7. Comparative cases  

Consider three cases to consolidate the argument.

Case A: Melancholy benefactor.  Ann is chronically depressed and feels no sympathy.  Seeing a drowning child, she is moved solely by her resolve to do what duty demands, and she rescues the child.  The act is clearly right.  The de dicto motivation stems from an internalized recognition that others’ lives impose obligations.  It seems harsh to deny moral praise simply because Ann did not feel compassion.  Her perseverance against motivational impediments may even enhance our admiration.

Case B: Principled judge.  Ben recuses himself from a lucrative case involving a friend because he believes judicial impartiality is required.  He is not motivated by affection for the opposing party; indeed, he dislikes them.  His sole motive is respecting the right.  Most of us regard his decision as exemplary, not morally deficient.  The praise attaches to his principled stance—the de dicto motive.

Case C: Charitable epiphany.  Cara reads that malaria nets save lives.  She feels no immediate compassion (the victims are far), but she believes morality requires giving.  She donates.  Here, the de dicto motive is epistemically fruitful: it pushes her to seek information about effective charity.  Again, withholding praise seems implausible.

These cases illustrate that pure duty can produce moral worth without fetishism or alienation.

8. Objections and replies  

Objection 1:  The agent who acts from duty alone cannot be praised because if she were convinced—however mistakenly—that morality permitted wrongdoing, she would do it.  Her praiseworthiness therefore rests on luck that her belief aligns with moral truth.

Reply:  The same “epistemic luck” infects de re motives.  A sympathetic agent who falsely believes euthanasia relieves suffering may wrongly kill.  Moral worth generally presupposes sufficient epistemic justification; the dutiful agent is no worse off.

Objection 2:  De dicto motivation is too easily mimicked by hypocrites who profess love of the right while secretly pursuing self-interest.

Reply:  Hypocrisy is a problem of sincerity, not of the motive’s structure.  We can distinguish genuine de dicto desire—demonstrated by consistent counterfactual behavior—from mere profession.  Sincere duty passes the test.

9. The larger picture: autonomy and the unity of virtue  

Why does the sufficiency thesis matter?  Because it emphasizes an aspect of moral agency crucial to autonomy: the capacity to be governed by self-conscious moral principles.  Aristotelian sentimentalists and Humeans rightly celebrate the ethical importance of cultivating appropriate emotions, but they risk sidelining our status as law-givers for ourselves.  A mature moral life integrates feeling with principle, yet principle retains final authority.  Upholding the sufficiency of dutiful motivation protects that authority.

Moreover, the thesis sheds light on the unity of virtue.  Virtues are unified insofar as they reflect a single practical orientation: the orientation of treating moral reasons as decisive.  The de dicto motive is the abstract form of that orientation.  When this form is present and efficacious, the agent already instantiates the core of virtue, even if some peripheral excellences (cheerful beneficence, graceful speech) are absent.

10. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct.  Such action is praiseworthy because:

1. It manifests recognition of morality’s categorical authority and thus expresses a fundamental virtue of principled self-governance.  
2. It secures impartial reliability, enabling agents to do right where concrete sentiments fail or mislead.  
3. It embodies a second-personal form of respect for persons, treating them as bearers of claims, not mere loci of feelings.  
4. It displays practical wisdom, directing inquiry under conditions of uncertainty and ensuring counterfactual sensitivity to moral reasons.

The traditional worries of fetishism, alienation, and epistemic thinness lose their grip once we appreciate that a well-formed de dicto motive implicitly encompasses an understanding of the concrete reasons for right action and expresses a valuable moral identity.  While integrating richer emotional motives can enhance moral life, their absence does not deprive dutiful action of worth.  The cold-blooded promise-keeper, the melancholic philanthropist, and the impartial judge each merit our praise, for in acting from duty they vindicate the sovereignty of morality within human agency.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction: the dialectic

That a purely “de dicto” desire—“to do what is right, whatever that is”—could ground morally worthy action is a thesis with illustrious defenders and equally illustrious critics. Kant is standardly read as claiming that only the motive of duty confers moral worth, yet the post-Kantian literature is replete with worries that an agent moved solely by duty would be moralistic, self-involved, or alienated from the very values morality is supposed to protect. Opponents charge that genuine moral worth requires motivation by the concrete considerations that make an act right (e.g. compassion for the suffering, fidelity to friends), not by the abstract consideration that it is morally required.

I shall argue, first, that acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth. Second, I explain what makes such action praiseworthy: (i) it manifests a distinctive form of valuing—respect for the moral, as such—that is itself among the basic moral virtues; (ii) the de dicto form of motivation better secures reliable responsiveness to the whole range of moral reasons in agents with limited epistemic access and fallible affective tendencies; and (iii) it expresses moral autonomy, the capacity to guide oneself by principles one endorses on reflection. These features jointly meet the plausible conditions for praiseworthiness without succumbing to the fetishism or alienation worries.

2. Clarifying the issue

2.1 De dicto versus de re motivation  
Call a desire de re when it is directed at a particular property or object: “I desire that my friend prosper,” “I desire that no one suffer.” A de dicto desire, by contrast, targets whatever property qualifies under a description: “I desire to do what morality requires, whatever that turns out to be.” The critics grant that de dicto desire is often present alongside de re concern—but insist it cannot by itself ground worth.

2.2 Moral worth and praiseworthiness  
We praise agents, roughly, when (a) they do the right thing, (b) their success is non-accidental—i.e. explained by capacities that systematically track the right-making reasons—and (c) those capacities are motivationally attributable to the agent in a way that reveals her values or character. The crucial question, then, is whether a bare desire to do what is right can explain (b) and satisfy (c).

3. The charge of moral fetishism

Michael Smith, following Stocker and Railton, gave the classical articulation: someone moved solely by the fact that donating benefits the poor “because it is the right thing to do” seems to fetishize rightness; she treats the moral property as an object of intrinsic fascination and thereby stands affectively at arm’s-length from the poor themselves. Such an attitude allegedly misrepresents morality’s point, which is to protect and promote concrete goods and relationships. Moreover, a fetishist’s motivation seems fragile: if she ceased caring about “rightness” she would have no reason to keep her promise or aid the needy.

These intuitions are powerful but not decisive. They trade on two assumptions: (A) the motive of duty is affectively cold; (B) it abstracts away from the very considerations that make an act right. Both assumptions can be resisted.

4. Why de dicto motivation can suffice

4.1 The value of respect for the moral as such  
First, morality plausibly includes a higher-order value: that agents act out of respect for moral requirements. We do not want beneficent psychopaths whose good deeds are mere accidental side‐effects of private urges; we prefer that agents see the moral domain as providing decisive reason. The de dicto desire manifests precisely this respect. Thus, far from being alienating, it engages a moral value: principled regard for moral authority. Respect for law, for promise-keeping as such, or for persons as ends are all higher-order moral attitudes; they cannot be reduced to first-order de re concerns without loss.

4.2 Reliability and epistemic humility  
Second, human agents are cognitively limited: we confront partial information, tempting biases, and conflicts of interest. A commitment to do whatever morality requires operates as a regulative second-order desire, continually checking whether our de re sympathies track the wider moral landscape. I might feel no spontaneous compassion for distant strangers, yet my de dicto commitment leads me to recognise their claims. The motive therefore promotes reliable responsiveness to all right-making reasons, not merely the subset my affections happen to latch onto.

4.3 Autonomy and principled self-government  
Third, acting from duty exhibits moral autonomy—the capacity to guide one’s conduct by principles one endorses on reflection rather than by contingently given impulses. Autonomy is itself of deep moral significance. When someone returns a lost wallet just because she sees that it is required by honesty, she demonstrates that she can bind herself by reasons she recognises, rather than by fear, favour, or sentiment. That capacity merits praise.

5. Meeting the conditions of praiseworthiness

5.1 Non-accidentality  
Suppose Carla gives ten per cent of her income to famine relief solely because she wants to do her moral duty. Her cognitive route is: “According to the best moral theory I can discern, X is required; therefore I shall do X.” The explanatory connection between her motive and the right act is robust: had morality required slightly less, she would have given slightly less; had it required a wholly different kind of sacrifice, she would have shifted accordingly. That systematic sensitivity underwrites the counterfactual reliability praiseworthiness demands.

5.2 Attribution to the agent’s values  
Is Carla’s motive attributable to her? Yes: it flows from her practical identity as someone who puts moral reasons first. Just as we praise the affectionate parent whose actions flow from love, we can praise the conscientious agent whose actions flow from principled respect. That the content of her desire is described abstractly does not undermine its depth or authenticity.

5.3 Costs, effort, and strength  
Praised acts often involve costs overcome. The de dicto desire can supply motivational force even when de re affection is absent, and so may require greater sacrifice. The soldier who rescues civilians because “it’s my moral duty” despite fear and no personal connection seems eminently praiseworthy.

6. Answering the fetishism and alienation worries

6.1 Not affectively cold  
A person whose central motive is “to do what is right” need not be emotionally barren. The higher-order commitment frequently co-exists with sympathetic concern. One can value morality abstractly and also value particular persons. Yet even if concrete emotions are lacking, principled action is not disfigured. Think of the shy donor who feels no warmth but will not walk past injustice.

6.2 The right ordering of motives  
Critics take the concrete goods to be explanatorily prior: one helps because others suffer. But the moral point may precisely be that agents acknowledge valid claims whatever their affections. Respect for persons sometimes requires bracketing personal likes. The fetish charge therefore presupposes a parochial partialist ethic—they object that pure duty insufficiently mirrors their favourite first-order virtue. An impartial morality, however, vindicates the de dicto motive.

6.3 No misrepresentation  
Does principled motivation mischaracterise morality? Only if morality’s sole point is to promote welfare or friendship. That is contestable. Many moral theories (Kantian, contractualist, deontological pluralist) give autonomous recognition of right its own intrinsic value. Thus the critic’s premise is theory-laden.

7. Objections and replies

Objection 1: De dicto agents must know what is right; but moral disagreement shows we rarely do.  
Reply: The motive is “to do what is right as best I can discern,” involving conscientious deliberation, openness to evidence, and willingness to revise belief. These epistemic virtues themselves attract praise.

Objection 2: Praising duty-motivated action discourages the cultivation of proper sentiments.  
Reply: Nothing prevents a pluralist account: we can praise both kinds of motive. In domains like emergency medicine or public administration, de re empathy is unreliable; duty fills the gap. A society that valued only warm feelings would be dangerously sentimental.

Objection 3: De dicto desire is second-personal; it regards morality as an external constraint, not as flowing from one’s own projects, leading to self-alienation.  
Reply: Yet Kantian autonomy precisely integrates moral law with the will. The agent endorses the principle as her own. Far from alienating, it unifies.

8. Comparisons with de re motivation

Are there respects in which de re concern yields greater worth? Sometimes. An act motivated by both compassion and duty may display richer virtue. But sufficiency is weaker than optimality: the presence of one ground (duty) can be enough to merit praise even if another (empathy) would add further merit.

A useful analogy is epistemic virtue. The mathematician who believes a theorem because she rigorously proved it is epistemically laudable. If she also happens to find the theorem beautiful, that adds aesthetic value but is not required for epistemic credit. Likewise, principled moral motivation secures the moral credit; supplementary sentiments add flourish, not fundament.

9. Implications for moral education

Taking the sufficiency of duty seriously affects pedagogy. We should teach children not only to feel for others but also to recognise that there are things one must do whether or not one feels like it. The capacity to adopt a de dicto moral stance is a developmental achievement, enabling adolescents to transcend peer pressure and in-group bias. Cultivating such a stance partly explains the social value of explicit moral rules.

10. A hybrid picture

While defending sufficiency, it is wise to acknowledge that human agents function best with a repertoire of motives. In daily life, de re sentiments often work faster and more vividly; de dicto commitment acts as a backstop and calibrator. The hybrid view honours the intuitions behind the fetish charge without conceding its exclusivity claim.

11. Conclusion

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth. Such action:

1. Manifests respect for the moral as such, itself a basic moral ideal.  
2. Ensures reliable responsiveness to the full domain of moral reasons amidst our epistemic and affective limitations.  
3. Expresses moral autonomy and principled self-government.  

These features satisfy the standard conditions for praiseworthy agency. The familiar charges of fetishism and alienation rest on contestable empirical claims about affect and on theoretical assumptions about what morality is “really about.” Once those are rejected, the motive of duty emerges not as a pale substitute for genuine concern but as a central pillar of moral excellence.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
Can the bare desire to do what is morally right—the motive that Kant called acting “from duty”—be enough to make an action morally worthy? Or must the morally admirable agent be moved instead (or additionally) by the concrete, first-order values that make the action right, such as another’s need, the beauty of a natural environment, or the trust placed in her by a friend? This dispute, which runs from Hume through Kant to contemporary virtue ethics, pits two pictures of moral motivation against one another. One picture—call it the Kantian picture—holds that what the agent must fundamentally care about is rightness itself, treating the moral law as the decisive practical consideration. The other—call it the particularist or value-acquaintance picture—claims that genuine moral concern must be for the very goods, persons, and relationships that morality is “about.” A person who frames her reasons at one remove, treating them as reasons because “that’s what morality requires,” is said to exhibit alienation (Stocker) or moral fetishism (Railton). 

I shall argue that acting solely from the de dicto desire to do what is right can indeed suffice for moral worth. The claim is not that all admirable actions arise this way, nor that motives of affection, sympathy, and friendship are morally inferior. Rather, the contention is that an agent whose entire motivational story is “I did it because it was the right thing to do” can be praiseworthy provided certain further conditions are met. Those conditions turn on how we understand the desire to do what is right. Properly construed, that desire is not an occult fixation with an abstract property; it is a second-order concern to regulate one’s will by the balance of moral reasons, whatever they turn out to be. Such a concern embodies respect for persons, expresses the agent’s autonomy, exhibits reliability across changing circumstances, and shows responsiveness to the full range of morally relevant considerations. Hence it captures many of the dimensions of virtue that critics allege it overlooks.

1. Two Kinds of Desire for the Right

We must begin by distinguishing two attitudes that can both be described as a “desire to do what is right.”

a) A merely de dicto desire: “I want, of any action whatever, that it be morally right.” This attitude may leave me completely ignorant of what makes an action right. I might be disposed to phone a hotline and comply with whichever directives the operator pronounces “morally obligatory,” much as someone fetishises a designer label without grasping the qualities that make a garment good.

b) A principled de dicto desire: “I want, in acting, to respond correctly to the moral reasons that there are.” This attitude is formal—concerned with rightness in general—but at the same time essentially reasons-responsive. In order to satisfy the desire, I must possess or seek the correct understanding of those first-order reasons and allow them to guide my choice. 

The fetishism charge has bite against the first attitude. Yet it is the second attitude that Kantians have in mind when they speak of acting from duty. Kant’s agent asks of every maxim whether it can be willed as universal law and lets the answer settle the practical question. That requires comprehending which features of her maxim matter morally—for instance, whether it involves treating others as mere means. Hence the principled de dicto desire does not float above concrete values; it fixes the deliberative standpoint from which those values must be appreciated.

2. Why Critics Doubt the Sufficiency of Duty Alone

Three influential lines of criticism dominate the literature.

i) The alienation objection (Stocker, Wolf): Morality is about people, their needs, and their projects. An agent who acts only “because it is right” is out of touch—imagine visiting a sick friend solely from duty rather than friendship. The friend, it is said, will rightly feel estranged.

ii) The fetishism objection (Railton, Hursthouse): If one prizes actions for possessing a mysterious property of rightness, one’s motivational pattern resembles the fetishist who loves an object because it is “the latest model,” not because of its real qualities. This seems neurotic and aesthetically unattractive.

iii) The epistemic objection (Arpaly, Smith): To identify what is right, one must appreciate the very considerations that make it right. If one already appreciates those considerations, they will motivate directly; if they do not, the claim that one still “desires the right” becomes suspect or empty.

The force of all three objections, I submit, depends on construing the duty motive as merely de dicto. Once we switch to the principled conception, the putative defects largely vanish.

3. Respect as the Core of the Duty Motive

Kant introduced the idea of acting from duty to capture a fundamental form of respect for persons: one governs oneself by a law that one and all can share. Far from being an esoteric property, rightness just is what can be willed from the standpoint of each rational agent. When I regulate my conduct by that law, I thereby treat every other rational being as an equal co-legislator. 

This motive is not indifferent to concrete goods; rather, it ensures that my concern for any concrete good is consistent with equal concern for all others. In contemporary parlance, it is a second-order, impartial concern. Such impartiality carries distinct moral value that cannot be reduced to sympathy or friendship. Someone who rescues a stranger at significant cost displays a form of moral commitment that sympathy alone rarely secures, for sympathy tracks felt closeness, not the claims of right.

4. Understanding and Reliability

Suppose Sophie leaps into the river to save a drowning child solely because it is morally obligatory. Does she understand why it is obligatory? If Sophie is acting from the principled duty motive, she must. The categorical imperative forbids treating a person’s life as expendable; that is the concrete ground of obligation. Sophie’s grasp of that ground need not assume the motivational role—her desire for rightness is still the proximate cause—but it informs her contentful representation of what counts as “the right thing.” Absent that content, the de dicto desire would have nothing to latch onto.

Because the desire to do what is right is defined by a standing commitment to be guided by moral reasons, it provides a robustly reliable motive. Sympathy is often fickle; friendship partial; aesthetic appreciation selective. The duty motive, by contrast, extends to any case where the moral law applies. When circumstances change, the dutiful agent adapts. That reliability, Kant thought, is precisely what makes the good will “good without limitation.”

5. Alienation Reconsidered

Yet what of the sick-friend case? Imagine Mary visiting her hospitalized colleague. She feels no affection for him; their relations are cordial but not intimate. Still, she knows that calling on him is the right thing—he is lonely, she can cheer him. Does her admission, “I came because it was my duty,” chill the encounter?

Whether alienation arises depends on social context, not on the motive’s moral worth. Mary might wisely say, “I wanted to see how you’re doing,” thereby making manifest the concrete values (his welfare) that duty directed her to honor. Nothing in the duty motive prevents her from communicating those values; indeed, realizing them is her very aim. What would alienate is the agent who parades her moralism as a badge of superiority: “I dislike you, but duty calls.” That attitude is objectionable, not because duty motivates, but because the agent fails to integrate duty with a concern for the other’s feelings—in Kantian terms, she violates a duty of respect.

Notice, then, that alienation criticisms conflate two questions: Which motives make an action worthy? and How should motives be expressed? Even if friendship is psychologically the warmer motive to display, it does not follow that acting solely from duty is less virtuous.

6. Fetishism Dissolved

The fetishism objection asks: Why care about “rightness” as such? The answer is that rightness is a practical role property—being what one ought to do. Every deliberating agent necessarily cares about what she ought to do, on pain of practical irrationality. The duty motive thus generalizes a structural feature of agency: taking some consideration as decisive. When the relevant domain is morality, the decisive consideration is moral rightness. To call this a fetish is to mistake a constitutive feature of rational agency for a neurotic quirk.

The fetish comparison also misrepresents what provides motivational force. The label-lover chooses the hand-bag because of the label, indifferent to the bag’s craftsmanship; the duty-lover chooses the action because of the moral law, but that law is itself determined by craftsmanship-like features: the action’s effects on welfare, autonomy, trust, and so on. Hence the comparison inverts the explanatory order.

7. The Epistemic Dimension

Adverting to rightness is permissible only if the agent possesses adequate epistemic justification. Otherwise the desire is irrational or reckless. Yet this condition, far from undermining the sufficiency of duty, strengthens it: an agent who successfully acts from duty is guaranteed to have exercised moral understanding. When that understanding is hard-won—say, the agent overcomes self-interest or group prejudice—it is especially praiseworthy. Sympathy might prompt correct action even in the ignorant; duty cannot.

8. Four Criteria of Moral Worth and How Duty Satisfies Them

Let us now ask what makes an action morally worthy at all. Several theorists propose the following dimensions (adapted from Arpaly, Sobel, Skorupski):

1) Responsiveness to moral reasons.
2) Stability and reliability across contexts.
3) Exercise of practical autonomy.
4) Expressive fit with the moral facts (that is, the motive should match what is valuable about the outcome).

We can now see why the duty motive, suitably construed, satisfies each.

1) Responsiveness: By definition, the agent takes moral rightness as decisive. She is therefore motivated exactly when and because the moral reasons obtain.

2) Stability: Because the desire to do right is not tied to contingent affections or moods, it persists across different beneficiaries and circumstances.

3) Autonomy: The agent acts on a self-endorsed principle rather than on inclinations given by nature or society.

4) Expressive fit: Respecting rightness is a way of respecting the persons and values that constitute rightness. The motive therefore fits the value of those persons and goods, even if it does not take the same phenomenal form as affection.

9. Case Studies

Consider two cases to illustrate sufficiency.

Case A: The Impartial Rescuer. Yolanda sees two drowning strangers, one of whom resembles her daughter. Sympathy pulls her toward the look-alike; duty tells her to aid whichever child she can reach in time. She calculates impartially and saves the child she can reach. Her only motive is that doing so is morally required. Intuitively, Yolanda is praiseworthy precisely because she subordinated partial feeling to duty. Her dutiful motive explains why we admire her.

Case B: The Conscientious Judge. Omar must sentence a defendant who reminds him of his late father. Out of personal affection he wants to be lenient, but he recognizes that justice demands a harsher sentence. He sentences accordingly, moved solely by duty. Again, his conduct is admirable; if he had been moved by sympathy, it would have been corrupt. 

These cases exhibit moral worth in circumstances where other motives would have been morally dangerous. That establishes that duty can be sufficient, even if not always necessary.

10. Duty, Virtue, and the Integration Thesis

A common reply is that the best moral character integrates motives: the virtuous person is moved both by direct concern for others and by duty. I agree; integration is ideal. But does that show that duty alone cannot suffice? No. A single virtue can be instantiated in varying degrees. The person who possesses only the core ingredient yet lacks the complementary sentiments still merits praise, though perhaps less than the fully integrated saint.

Moreover, some roles—judge, juror, public official—must sometimes suppress partial affections. In them, the duty motive has pride of place. It would be perverse to demand warm fellow-feeling from a tax auditor or military commander in every decision. Moral worth here depends precisely on acting from duty in abstraction from first-order sympathies.

11. A Worry about Moral Rigidity

Might a purely dutiful agent become rigid, insensitive to context? Only if her conception of rightness is crude. The categorical imperative is not a mechanical rule but a test requiring sensitivity to particular facts. Likewise, contemporary consequentialists who desire to maximize the good—another de dicto motive—must learn a vast array of empirical details to act rightly. Their success depends on flexibility, not rigidity.

12. Why the Duty Motive Is Especially Praiseworthy

Let me now advance a positive thesis: acting solely from duty is not merely sufficient but often especially admirable because it manifests three virtues:

a) Self-control: One overcomes contrary inclination. That effort signals commitment.

b) Impartial respect: One treats all persons as equals, resisting the pull of favoritism.

c) Moral identity: One’s practical identity is tied to the moral law. To use Korsgaard’s phrase, one achieves unity of agency through autonomy.

Sympathy and friendship are morally valuable, but they do not guarantee these virtues. When they coincide with duty, their value is enhanced; when they conflict, duty’s value comes to the fore.

13. Remaining Limits

I do not claim that duty suffices for maximal moral excellence. It suffices for moral worth in the sense of deserving praise for a particular act. A person who reliably acts from duty but never feels sympathy may still be flawed—cold, perhaps. Virtue ethics rightly celebrates richer emotional attunement. Yet we can acknowledge that richer ideal while granting that the bare, principled desire to do right passes the threshold of worth. After all, moral appraisal is scalar.

14. Conclusion

Critics of the duty motive are right to warn against a stilted, label-loving form of moralism. But that caricature targets a truncated version of the motive. A more charitable and philosophically sophisticated account sees the desire to do what is right as a second-order commitment to live in accordance with moral reasons. Such a commitment demands understanding, grounds reliability, expresses respect, and secures autonomy. Actions issuing solely from that commitment therefore possess moral worth. They are worthy not in spite of but because of their formal orientation: by making rightness the decisive practical consideration, the agent situates herself within the moral community as a responsible co-legislator, demonstrating precisely the kind of self-respect and respect for others that morality is about. Far from being alienated or fetishistic, she embodies the core of moral agency.

On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction: the dispute over “moral fetishism”  

Ever since Kant insisted that only actions “from duty” possess genuine moral worth, critics have worried that the purely dutiful agent is aiming at the wrong target. Bernard Williams’s “one thought too many,” Michael Smith’s “fetishism” objection, and Henson’s charge of “moral alienation” all develop the intuitive complaint that what matters, morally speaking, is what right-making considerations are about—welfare, justice, promises kept—not the abstract fact that an act is right. If I dive into the river to save a stranger because she will drown, my apparent virtue seems fuller-blooded than if I leap in merely because “duty calls.” According to the critics, an agent moved only by a de dicto desire to do whatever is right suffers from a kind of motivational misalignment: she does the right thing, but out of the wrong reasons, or at least impoverished ones.

The question therefore presses: can acting solely out of a desire to do what is morally right ever suffice for moral worth? I shall argue that it can. Properly understood, a de dicto desire to do what is right (i) can be suitably sensitive to the very considerations that make an action right, (ii) manifests a distinctive and important form of moral agency—respect for the authority of morality—which itself contributes to praiseworthiness, and (iii) escapes the charge of fetishism once we distinguish fetishistic concern with a property from reverential concern with a normatively authoritative status. To establish these claims, I first clarify the de dicto/de re distinction and the structure of the fetishism objection, then show why an exclusive de dicto motive need not be blind to concrete right-making facts, and finally explain what makes such dutiful action admirable in its own right.

2. De dicto versus de re moral desires  

In contemporary semantics a de re desire is directed toward some particular feature or object under a specific description: I may want, de re, that this person’s life go well, or that promises be kept. A de dicto desire, by contrast, has only the content expressed by the general proposition. Thus the de dicto moralist wants only that “I do what is morally right,” whatever rightness may consist in. Because the desire is “thin,” it can in principle be combined with any first-order moral outlook and therefore does not itself encode concern for, say, welfare or fairness.

The fetishism objection exploits precisely this thinness. Imagine two rescuers:

(a) Care-Lydia sees a drowning child, is moved by empathetic concern for his suffering, and jumps in.  
(b) Duty-Max sees the same child, reflects that saving the child is morally required, desires (de dicto) to do what duty demands, and jumps in.

Both act correctly; yet many share the intuition that Lydia’s motive is morally worthier. If Max cares purely for “the right,” does not this betray a kind of emotional or moral deficiency—a failure to appreciate why saving a child matters?

3. Why the fetishism objection overstates its case  

3.1. Respect for rightness is not a mere fetish  

A fetish, in the relevant sense, is an irrational attraction to an object’s property that is not itself normatively significant. The worry is that “right-as-such” is being treated like a talisman: the agent fixates on it while neglecting what underlies its value. Yet rightness is not morally inert: it is the property of being what one ought to do, all things considered. To desire to do what one ought is precisely to be guided by practical reason’s verdict. Respecting that verdict differs from fetishistically pursuing, say, coins because they are shiny. Coins’ shininess is not reason-giving, but rightness is. The charge of fetishism therefore equivocates between a fascination with a normatively powerless property and acknowledgement of a property whose essence is to mark what there is decisive reason to do.

3.2. De dicto concern can incorporate de re sensitivity  

Second, nothing in the psychology of Max the dutiful requires that he be insensitive to the concrete facts that make an action right. Indeed, to believe that saving the child is morally required, Max had to represent and assess those very facts: the child’s life-threatening situation, the low cost to himself, the absence of morally overriding considerations. So long as he is rational, his general desire “to do what morality requires” operates through recognition of substantive moral considerations. The difference between Max and Lydia is not that Max fails to take account of the child’s peril but that his final motivational endpoint is respect for the moral demand those considerations generate. The fetishism charge therefore mislocates the deficit: abstractness about one’s ultimate motive does not entail blindness to first-order reasons in deliberation.

3.3. The practical limits of empathy and partiality  

Moreover, exclusive reliance on de re motives such as empathy, friendship, or special concern can be morally problematic. These motives often run out—in cases of distant strangers, future people, or conflicts among loved ones. A de dicto commitment to rightness supplies both impartiality and stability where de re motives falter. Thus, even if Lydia’s motive appears warmer in the single rescue scenario, a Max-type agent may prove more reliable across the wide moral landscape. Reliability in responsiveness to moral reasons is itself a dimension of virtue and a source of praiseworthiness.

4. How a purely dutiful motive can bestow moral worth  

4.1. Expressing responsiveness to moral reasons  

Nomy Arpaly and others have argued that moral worth tracks responsiveness to moral reasons: an act is praiseworthy when the agent acts because she recognizes the moral reasons that apply. A de dicto desire to do what is right precisely makes the agent responsive to the fact that p is what morally ought to be done. Provided the belief “p is right” is true and non-accidental (i.e., reached by sound moral cognition), the agent’s conduct satisfies Arpaly’s condition. What matters is the explanatory connection: the moral fact explains the action via the agent’s recognition. That recognition can take the abstract form “this is right.” Therefore, duty-based motivation can ground moral worth as effectively as—or in some contexts more effectively than—particularistic motives like sympathy.

4.2. Manifesting respect for persons as ends in themselves  

Kant held that treating humanity as an end requires acting from duty rather than merely in conformity with duty. The dutiful agent does not treat others well simply because she happens to care for them; she does so out of recognition that they possess a moral standing that commands respect irrespective of personal inclination. Acting from the motive of duty therefore contains an egalitarian message: it affirms the equal authority of each person’s claims upon us. This moral stance is praiseworthy in a distinctively Kantian sense; it displays a commitment to justice that is not hostage to contingent feelings.

4.3. Upholding the authority of morality  

When an agent acts solely from duty, she acknowledges morality as holding overriding normative authority. Such acknowledgment is constitutive of mature moral agency. To confer praise is, among other things, to evaluate agents for how they orient themselves to this authority. Even if Lydia’s empathic motive is admirable, it remains psychologically possible for her to be swayed by partiality or fatigue. Max’s de dicto motive underwrites a principled steadiness: he does the right thing because it is right, period. Praise is apt insofar as the act manifests this principled steadiness, something we value independently of warmth or emotional resonance.

5. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: The dutiful agent lacks the appropriate emotional engagement; moral worth demands integration of affect.  
Reply: We must distinguish moral worth from moral beauty. To be emotionally rich is aesthetically and interpersonally attractive, but moral appraisal primarily concerns the quality of an agent’s will—her responsiveness to moral reasons and respect for moral law. Duty suffices for that. Nothing prevents an ideal agent from combining de dicto and affective motives, but the presence of the latter is not necessary for praiseworthiness.

Objection 2: A solely de dicto motive can be epistemically risky: the agent may misidentify what is right.  
Reply: Moral worth is conditional on the agent’s belief tracking the truth in a non-accidental way. When Max is reliably sensitive to the reasons that in fact make acts right, the epistemic worry recedes. Fetishistic fixation would indeed be problematic if it led to scrupulosity or moral error, but that is a failure of moral epistemology, not of the de dicto motive itself.

Objection 3: The praiseworthiness of dutiful acts is merely second-best; ideally we would integrate duty with de re concern.  
Reply: I grant that an integrated motivational set may exhibit a richer virtue. Yet “second-best” does not mean un-praised. The question is whether duty alone can suffice, and sufficiency does not require optimality. A meal can be nourishing without being sumptuous; likewise, a dutiful action can be praiseworthy without being the most admirable conceivable.

6. Comparative cases illuminating the issue  

Case A: The principled vegetarian  
Clara refrains from eating meat solely because she believes it is morally wrong to cause unnecessary animal suffering. She feels no particular empathy for animals; indeed, she finds pigs unattractive. Nonetheless, her unwavering adherence to vegetarianism amidst social pressure manifests moral resolve. We rightly attribute moral worth to her abstention, precisely because it springs from her respect for what she takes to be a moral requirement.

Case B: The fair-minded judge  
Judge Lopez is unmoved by warm feelings toward the litigants before her. Her principal concern is to do what justice requires. She meticulously applies the law and moral principles because they are right, not because she sympathizes with either party. Rather than diminishing her praiseworthiness, this distance from personal sentiment underscores her commitment to the rule of law and the moral value of impartiality.

Case C: Williams’s husband  
Williams envisioned a husband who rescues his wife from drowning because she is his wife, not “because it is the right thing.” Suppose, however, that the husband rescued her precisely because it was morally required—say, because he had a special obligation as her spouse. Far from being “one thought too many,” his explicit recognition of the moral dimension exemplifies respect for the normative weight of marital commitments. His motive is not chilly; it is principled.

These cases show that de dicto motivation can coexist with, and often enhances, morally relevant attitudes such as integrity, impartiality, and steadfastness.

7. The structure of praiseworthiness  

An action earns praise when it issues from (i) a disposition that is stably responsive to genuine moral reasons, (ii) an agent who acts freely and knowingly, and (iii) a motivational orientation that acknowledges the authority of those reasons. A de dicto desire to do what is right satisfies all three so long as (a) the agent’s moral beliefs are reliably formed and (b) the desire is motivationally efficacious. That is enough for moral worth. Empathy, affection, or compassion may add further dimensions of admirability, but they are not mandatory.

By analogy, consider intellectual virtue. A mathematician motivated by the desire “to believe whatever is mathematically true” is intellectually admirable even if she lacks a special fascination with, say, topology. Her respect for truth, generic though it is, manifests the proper epistemic orientation. Similarly, the agent who simply wants to do what is right exemplifies the proper practical orientation.

8. Reconciling duty with richer moral psychology  

Although I have defended the sufficiency of duty, nothing in my argument denies the value of integrating de dicto and de re motives. Indeed, mature virtue likely fuses them: compassion aligns with the recognition of others as ends, and love of justice dovetails with the resolve to do what is right. What matters is that the presence of other motives is a contingent enrichment, not a conceptual requirement for moral worth.

This conclusion harmonises with Kant’s suggestion that acting from duty is necessary “at least when” inclination is absent or countervailing. If we add that acting from duty is sufficient when inclination is absent, then we see why purely dutiful acts deserve praise. They testify to the agent’s capacity to let moral reasons govern her will even in emotional neutrality.

9. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct. The standard fetishism objection overlooks three central points: (1) rightness is itself a normatively potent property, so desiring to track it is not fetishistic; (2) a de dicto moral desire typically involves, and even requires, cognitive engagement with the first-order considerations that make an action right; (3) such a motive uniquely manifests respect for the authority of morality, impartiality, and principled steadiness—features independently constitutive of praiseworthiness. Consequently, while we may celebrate the warmth of empathy and the richness of particular attachments, we should also recognise and commend the distinctive virtue of the dutiful agent whose guiding star is simply: do what is right.

answer:
Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right be enough for moral worth? Philosophers of approximately Kantian sympathies have said “yes,” but a more recent chorus—Bernard Williams, Michael Stocker, Susan Wolf, Samuel Scheffler, Jonathan Dancy, and others—urges “no.”  They argue that an exclusive concern to “do the morally right thing” is empty, fetishistic, or alienating unless it is grounded in the concrete values that make an act right: compassion for a friend, appreciation of beauty, reverence for truth, and so on.  In their view, an agent who rescues a drowning child merely “because it’s the right thing” fails to manifest the sort of responsiveness that morality properly demands; the agent’s focus on rightness-as-such is at best second-best and at worst pathological.  

I defend the sufficiency claim.  Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can, under certain conditions, confer full moral worth.  The defense proceeds in five stages.

1. Clarifying the target: what “acting solely from duty” really means.  
2. Distinguishing three charges embedded in the fetishism critique.  
3. Arguing that each charge misfires once we understand de dicto motivation more precisely.  
4. Offering a positive account of why pure dutifulness is praiseworthy.  
5. Explaining why mixed or “properly plural” motives may often be better, without undermining the sufficiency thesis.

Throughout, I use “duty motive” and “de dicto motive” interchangeably: a practical commitment whose content is simply that one perform whatever act is morally required, where the rightness of the act is characterised under the abstract description “morally right.”

1.  What is it to act solely from duty?

Negative characterisation.  The dutiful agent’s decision is not guided by empathy, personal affection, aesthetic relish, prudential gain, or any other concrete value.  Those factors may be present in the situation, but they are not what moves her; they are screened off, as it were, by her conscious discounting.  

Positive characterisation.  The agent instead acts because (i) she judges that morality requires φ-ing, and (ii) in the face of competing attractions θ, she wills to φ simply on the ground that morality so requires.  She possesses a standing practical disposition of the following form:

     (Duty)  If I judge that my Φ-ing is morally required, then (ceteris paribus) I will Φ.

Crucially, this principle is self-consciously adopted and reflectively endorsed.  The Kantian calls it “reverence for the moral law.”  One useful modern gloss (from Christine Korsgaard) is that the rightness-judgement functions as a rationally authoritative call: in recognising the requirement, the agent at the same time recognises herself as bound.  Her motive is thus a practical commitment to act on what she rationally recognises as required.

Now, mere heedlessness or blind conformity should not be conflated with acting from duty.  The dutiful agent has deliberated; she has formed the judgement “φ-ing is morally right” by consulting the relevant concrete considerations.  After all, how could she arrive at that all-things-considered verdict otherwise?  The claim that she acts solely from duty therefore means: once the judgement has been formed, the decisive motivational push derives from the content “this is right,” not from any further attraction to the child’s welfare, the beauty of saving a life, etc.

2.  Three separate accusations of the fetishism camp

A.  Epistemic shallowness: a de dicto motive is blind to what really makes the act right and therefore unreliable.  

B.  Evaluative narrowness: even if the act turns out right, the motive fails to appreciate what has value; hence it expresses a deficient moral sensibility.  

C.  Affective alienation: by bracketing concrete concern, the agent stands at an unhealthy emotional distance from persons and projects; life guided in that manner is cold or self-undermining.

Although often run together, the charges are conceptually distinct.  The first is about knowledge, the second about value-appreciation, the third about psychological health.  I will argue that (A) misdescribes how de dicto motivation works; (B) confuses motivational sufficiency with reason-giving sufficiency; (C) confuses what is desirable in general with what is necessary for moral worth.

3.  Reply to the three charges

A.  Epistemic shallowness

Someone who wants only to do “whatever is morally required” must still figure out what that is.
