Accordingly, she has to attend to the very same concrete considerations that right-makers such as compassionists or utilitarians emphasise: the presence of suffering, the fairness of distributions, promises incurred, etc.  The de dicto desire therefore necessarily comes packaged with a second-order methodological commitment: “Find out, as best you can, which concrete considerations make actions right.”  It does not handicap the agent’s epistemic access; rather, it harnesses it, because she will be reliably motivated to gather relevant moral information.  She might not be moved by each consideration directly, but she is motivationally open to their being right-makers.  The epistemic worry thus collapses.

Perhaps the critic will now say that if the dutiful agent notices the drowning child only because she is scanning for “morally salient features,” she is still defective: her salience-detection mechanism is functioning, but the sentimental content is missing.  That is precisely the evaluative narrowness worry.

B.  Evaluative narrowness

Consider two rescuers: Clara saves the child out of empathic concern, Daniel out of sheer reverence for moral rightness.  The fetishism complaint is that Daniel fails to value what matters—the child’s life—for its own sake.  The complaint entails a substantive metaethical thesis: that moral worth hinges on loving the valuable for the reasons that make it valuable.  Why accept that thesis?

A first answer appeals to Lockean or Aristotelian ideas about moral education: aiming at the right for its own sake is a fallback, whereas fully developed virtue involves loving the good.  Yet note that this tells us what an ideally virtuous person would find satisfying, not what minimum condition confers praiseworthiness on an act.  Even Aristotelians sometimes say that continence—a person who obeys right reason while still at odds with her desires—is morally worthy, albeit less attractive than full virtue.  If continence can be morally worthy, a fortiori dutiful action can be.

A second answer weaponises the fitting-attitude model: if what makes Clara’s action right is the child’s welfare, then the fitting motive is concern for that welfare; anything else is unfitting.  This is too quick.  The concept of “fitting motive” bears two interpretations:

   i.  fit as “accurately representing the value,”  
   ii. fit as “appropriately responding in practice to the value.”

The Kantian can concede (i) but deny that (ii) requires the same psychological representation.  Responsiveness-to-value can be mediated through de dicto acknowledgement of its authority.  After all, in science we respond correctly to reality through formal inferential rules, not always through intuition of the phenomena.  Analogously, de dicto dutifulness responds to the worth of persons through the normative intermediary “they have a right,” even if no warmth of feeling is present.

C.  Affective alienation

Wolf’s well-known “Moral Saint” argument portrays the life led wholly under the banner of moral rightness as bland, joyless, and ultimately alienating.  But the question before us is not whether such a life is desirable as a blueprint for flourishing; it is whether, in a given decision, being moved solely by rightness suffices for the moral worth of that decision.  Wolf’s target is the comprehensive ideal; the sufficiency thesis is local.  Moreover, cases in which natural affection is absent (e.g., clinical depression blocking empathy) show that agents can be psychologically constrained while still admirably hanging on to the sole motive left available: “this is the morally right thing to do.”  Far from being alienated, such agents display steadfast allegiance to the moral community despite their affective impediments.  That seems eminently praiseworthy.

4.  The positive case for dutiful praiseworthiness

Four considerations make purely dutiful action worthy of moral esteem.

4.1  Respect for the moral law as an equalising stance

Kant’s central insight is that practical reason demands that each person treat every other as a free and rational agent whose claims are of equal authority.  To act from the thought “this is morally required” is to locate oneself within the space of such equality; it is the adoption of a standpoint from which no one’s particular interests count for more just because they are nearer.  This respect-based motive has distinctive moral resonance: it acknowledges the generality and impartiality of moral reason.  Clara’s empathy toward the drowning child is admirable, but empathy famously tracks similarity and proximity; respect, by contrast, is structurally universal.  When de dicto dutifulness overrides partiality, it exhibits a moral achievement: resisting personal preference in the name of a principle that applies to all.

4.2  Reliability and diachronic stability

Concrete fellow-feeling is contingent and fickle.  We are strongly moved by identifiable victims and by those within our circle, not by statistical lives or distant strangers.  A standing disposition to do whatever is right, precisely because it is impersonal, offers a form of reliability across contexts.  That reliability is morally valuable: think of a judge who, unimpressed by any defendant’s charming personality, sentences only according to justice; or a guardian of public funds who cannot be bribed by friendship.  Such agents may exhibit no warmth, yet we rightly praise their incorruptibility.

4.3  Expression of self-governance

Praiseworthiness implicates not just what we do but how we do it.  An act prompted by emotion can fail to manifest the agent’s capacity for autonomous practical reasoning; it might be more like a reflex than a choice.  Acting from the explicit recognition of moral rightness, by contrast, makes clear that the agent has guided herself through rational deliberation.  This full, reflective ownership of action is a locus of moral worth.  Indeed, even when emotional motives concur with duty, an additional reflective endorsement is normally expected.  In gratitude we do not merely feel; we decide that repayment is owed.  De dicto dutifulness foregrounds that decisional moment.

4.4  Solidarity with the moral community

Performing an act because “it’s the right thing” signals one’s willingness to answer publicly for it under the shared currency of moral reasons.  That signalling matters: it reassures others that they can rely on one, and it reinforces the social practice of giving and asking for moral reasons.  A private sentimental motive lacks this communicative quality.  Hence dutiful action plays an indispensable role in sustaining the very institution of morality.

These four points show that acting solely from duty is not a moral consolation prize; it realises distinctive values—equality, reliability, autonomy, and solidarity—sufficient for praise.

5.  Reconciling the sufficiency thesis with the attractions of richer motives

Everything said so far is compatible with the thought that, other things equal, moral agents should cultivate the concrete sentiments that track value more directly.  An Aristotelian might say: pure dutifulness is virtuous continence, but virtue proper adds right-aligned desire.  I can happily grant that continence-plus-desire is better than continence alone.  What matters is that continence alone clears the bar for praiseworthiness.

The sufficiency thesis also allows room for hybrid motivational structures.  One might be moved in the first instance by sympathy, yet underwrite sympathy’s authority by recognising that sympathy itself is morally required.  Conversely, one might be led by duty in hard cases, while allowing congenial sentiments to do most of the day-to-day motivational work.  Such ecumenism does not threaten but rather illustrates the central claim: pure de dicto motivation suffices, even if it is sometimes complemented by more particular sentiments.

6.  Possible objections and replies

Objection 1:  The content of “morally right” is too indeterminate; thus a de dicto motive is vacuous.

Reply:  The content is indeterminate only prior to deliberation.  Once the agent has judged that Φ is required by morality, she possesses a determinate content: Φ.  She might be mistaken, but that vulnerability afflicts any motivation.  Moreover, the de dicto stance includes the procedural norm “test my judgement against critical reflection and evidence,” which guards against vacuity.

Objection 2:  An agent who lacks spontaneous concern reveals a flaw of character; how can flawed character produce praiseworthy acts?

Reply:  Moral worth attaches primarily to acts as expressions of will, not to global character evaluations.  One can be praiseworthy in a specific choice even while falling short of full virtue overall.  Besides, the charge assumes that lack of sentiment is always a defect—sometimes it is a psychological limitation not of the agent’s choosing.

Objection 3:  Pure dutifulness invites moral fanaticism: if an agent’s rightness-judgement is mistaken, she will doggedly pursue wrong ends.

Reply:  The same holds for any strongly motivating internal value.  Fanaticism is not peculiar to the duty motive but to the absence of critical reflection.  A properly Kantian outlook contains the meta-norm of revisability: “Act only on maxims you can will as universal laws.”  That meta-norm internalises critical reason and thus guards against fanaticism.

7.  Closing illustration

Imagine two doctors in a triage unit during a pandemic.  Doctor A is hounded by exhaustion; her compassion circuits are nearly burnt out after weeks on shift.  All that keeps her sorting patients in line with the impartial protocol is the thought: “This is the morally right procedure; deviating would wrong my patients.”  Doctor B, still emotionally buoyant, is moved by her vivid sense of each person’s suffering.

Both save the same lives.  To praise only Doctor B seems perverse.  Doctor A’s steadfast adherence to duty under emotional depletion is, if anything, more admirable.  Her motive is exclusively de dicto.  Yet the act has full moral worth, illustrating the sufficiency of the duty motive.

Conclusion

The thesis that pure dutifulness suffices for moral worth survives scrutiny.  The fetishism critique conflates epistemic access, value-appreciation, and psychological well-being.  Once disentangled, none undermines the moral credentials of the de dicto motive.  On the positive side, acting from the desire to do what is right distinctively manifests respect for persons as equals, reliability across contexts, self-governance, and solidarity with the moral community.  Such features are fully capable of making an act praiseworthy even when no other motive is present.

This conclusion does not dethrone the moral significance of concrete sentiments.  Sympathy, friendship, and love remain central to a flourishing human life.  The claim is more modest: when concrete sentiments flag or are overruled, a bare but firm allegiance to moral rightness can carry the day—and when it does, the deed is not merely permissible but worthy of praise.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice for moral worth? Many philosophers—most famously Kant’s sympathetic interpreters, but also their critics—answer “no.” The dominant worry is that someone moved only by a de dicto desire to do whatever morality requires is insufficiently related to the very features that make her action right. As Julia Annas quips, “[I]f all you really want is to keep your moral nose clean, you have missed what morality is about.” This worry, variously labeled “moral fetishism” (Smith), “alienation” (Stocker), or “moral schizophrenia” (Williams), has led several contemporary theorists to abandon the Kantian idea that motive of duty alone can ground moral worth.

I shall defend a qualified yes: an agent’s action can be morally praiseworthy if her sole proximate motive is the abstract desire to do what is right. The defense has three steps:

1. Clarify what a de dicto desire to do the right thing amounts to.  
2. Show that such a desire, properly understood, can incorporate sensitivity to the concrete right‐making considerations that critics think are required.  
3. Explain how this sensitivity, together with certain epistemic and volitional virtues, yields moral worth without reducing to the “fetishized” footing critics fear.

Along the way I address three major objections: (i) the fetishism objection (Smith/Herman), (ii) the alienation objection (Stocker), and (iii) the motivational necessity of particularistic concern (Railton, Arpaly). My conclusion is that a pure motive of duty can be morally worthy because it can function as a second‐order regulative commitment that coordinates the agent’s first‐order practical reasoning in a way that manifests respect for the moral law. When it plays that role, the motive is no mere fetish but a rational disposition that integrates the agent’s will with the very values that ground morality.

I. What is it to act “solely from a desire to do what is morally right”?

“Desire” and “solely” need careful handling. A simplistic reading is that the agent’s only motivating state is the propositional attitude: “I desire that I φ iff φ is morally obligatory.” All concrete facts—e.g., that φ relieves Sophie’s anxiety—are motivationally inert; they move the agent only via the detour “relieving anxiety is morally required.” That kind of agent seems pathological—robotic, affectless, and epistemically precarious. But two clarifications blunt this initial worry.

First, the “sole” motive can be understood as the agent’s highest‐order decisive motive rather than the only psychological state in play. A Kantian agent may feel empathy, enjoy others’ happiness, or shudder at suffering; yet when she acts, she does so because she judges the action right, not because she enjoys or dislikes certain outcomes. Empathy and sympathy can be present as inclinations, but they are not granted final normative authority. This diluted “sole” is common in Kant’s Grundlegung: to act from duty is to act “for the sake of the law,” even if one also happens to take pleasure in performing the act.

Second, the de dicto description need not be content‐blind. Christine Korsgaard emphasizes that an agent can adopt the moral law as her practical identity. If so, the law’s general prescriptions are not empty placeholders; they implicitly encode the agent’s substantive grasp of concrete values. Likewise, Mark Schroeder argues that a de dicto desire derives motivational force from the agent’s background understanding of what morality requires. In effect, the de dicto/de re distinction collapses at the level of practical reasoning: to desire to do what is right just is to desire to realize whatever antecedently strikes one as the morally relevant features of the situation. Thus, an agent with only the abstract desire can still deliberate about the particulars. The abstraction need not entail motivational blindness.

II. How a pure desire to do what is right incorporates concrete right‐makers

Critics object that de dicto motivation lacks “direction‐of‐fit” to the world’s value. But consider a structurally similar case outside morality. A theoretical reasoner has a de dicto desire to “believe what is true.” She forms specific beliefs by aiming at truth, deploying epistemic virtues, and correcting errors. We do not criticize her for lacking a particularistic desire to believe that p, q, and r; her higher‐order epistemic motive is precisely what rationally guides her toward each specific truth. So too in practical reasoning. A standing desire to do what is right equips one to appreciate, track, and respond to concrete moral reasons, just as a standing desire to believe what is true equips one to track evidence.

This analogy highlights three capacities that mediate between the abstract motive and concrete right‐makers:

1. Epistemic Sensitivity. The agent must competently identify what morality requires in her circumstances. If her rightness judgments are systematically off, her de dicto motive is defective.  
2. Instrumental Reliability. She must reliably translate her moral judgments into effective action. Otherwise the motive is motivationally inert.  
3. Counterfactual Robustness. Across a range of situations, changes in right‐making features should lead to corresponding changes in judgment and action. This is Fischer and Ravizza’s “reason‐responsive” profile, applied to moral motives.

These capacities supply the missing link: an agent who cares only about “doing what is right” but systematically fails to grasp or act on concrete right‐makers is not praiseworthy. When, however, the capacities are in place, nothing further is needed. Concern for Sophie’s welfare manifests itself not as a separate desire but as part of what the agent’s moral theory recognizes as rightness‐conferring. The motive of duty functions as a regulative ideal that keeps the agent’s deliberation attuned to the moral landscape.

III. Why the pure motive can generate moral worth

Granting that a de dicto desire can in principle incorporate sensitivity, does it generate a distinctive kind of moral worth—one that competes with or even surpasses more concrete motives like sympathy? The Kantian tradition says yes; indeed, it claims that only duty yields full moral worth. I will not press that bold thesis. I argue the modest claim that the pure motive suffices for praiseworthiness because it expresses two agent‐centered excellences:

A. Respect for Persons as Rational Agents  
To act solely from duty is to treat others (and oneself) as ends and never merely as means, because the moral law’s content is determined by principles that all rational agents can will. The agent’s de dicto motive thus demonstrates an attitude of respect not reducible to sympathy or benevolence. She does not act for the sake of gratifying her fellow‐feeling or her favorite values; she acts out of deference to a shared norm of freedom. This attitude is intrinsically valuable and plausibly warrants praise.

B. Integrity of Practical Identity  
Harry Frankfurt notes that what we care about reflectively constitutes who we are. A general commitment to morality integrates the agent’s will around a stable core, enabling her to resist temptation, coordinate projects, and answer the question “Who am I?” with “Someone who does the right thing.” That integration is an excellence in agency, akin to aristocratic courage or Aristotelian prudence. Agents who display it are apt objects of admiration.

While the benevolent agent who rescues Sophie because he loves her scores high on benevolence, he may lack the robust commitment displayed by an agent who would rescue any stranger because it’s right. Praiseworthiness thus tracks the breadth and steadiness of one’s dispositions as well as their sentimental warmth.

IV. Replies to the main objections

1. The Fetishism Objection (Michael Smith; Barbara Herman)  
Smith claims that a “moral fetishist” is like someone who keeps her partner’s letters in a locket—valuing the wrong thing. But the analogy misfires. The fetishist values the locket as an object detached from its significance; the moral agent values the right action precisely because of its moral significance. Herman worries that abstract motivation shows indifference to the victim’s plight. Yet Kantian duty can incorporate empathetic understanding instrumentally: concern for Sophie’s distress is the reason the action counts as a duty. If I save her only because the law says so, and the law says so because of her distress, I thereby save her because of her distress. No fetish ensues.

2. The Alienation Objection (Michael Stocker)  
Stocker imagines a hospital visitor who declares, “I’m here because it’s my duty, not because I care about you.” Such explicit avowals alienate friends. But the Kantian agent need not avow her motive, nor need she lack care. She may visit partly from sympathy, yet regard duty as the authoritative ground. Even if she did act from bare duty, her friend’s preference for a sympathy‐based visit is an interpersonal, not a moral, evaluation. Moral worth and likability come apart; cooking a tasty meal from duty can still be praiseworthy, though perhaps chillier.

3. The Particularist Concern Objection (Peter Railton, Nomy Arpaly)  
Railton’s “sophisticated consequentialist” loves his friends as such; if he loved them only as loci of utility he’d be defective. Arpaly argues that moral worth attaches to action responsive to the morally salient features “for the right reasons.” But again, a de dicto desire can guide responsiveness. What matters is that the action is non‐deviantly caused by the right reasons; whether those reasons are encoded in a de dicto representation (“do what’s right”) or a de re representation (“help Sophie”) is irrelevant if the causal path passes through accurate moral cognition.

V. A Positive Model: Duty as Second‐Order Governance

To consolidate the defense, consider a hierarchical model of the will:

Level 0: Sensory/sentimental impulses (fear, sympathy, anger)  
Level 1: First‐order practical judgments about what to do in particular situations  
Level 2: Second‐order commitments that govern how Level 1 judgments are formed

A pure motive of duty operates primarily at Level 2. It is a standing policy: “Form and endorse Level‐1 judgments that best accord with the moral law.” This policy evaluates candidate reasons, sets priorities, and triggers self‐scrutiny when inconsistency looms. On this model:

• The motive is substantive. Its content is the moral law’s content.  
• It is motivational. It directs the formation and execution of Level‐1 judgments.  
• It is praiseworthy. It manifests volitional virtue—steadfastness, impartiality, and responsiveness.

Because Kantian duty resides at Level 2, its praiseworthiness does not hinge on the presence or absence of Level‐0 sentiments. It is compatible with, but not dependent on, benevolence. And by shaping Level‐1 deliberation, it ensures the agent’s decisions track the concrete right‐making facts. The “alienation” fear dissipates: Sophie’s welfare matters because the Level‐1 judgment “Help Sophie” flows from the Level‐2 policy’s application to the concrete fact of Sophie’s distress.

VI. Limits and Qualifications

Although I have argued that a sole motive of duty can suffice, I grant two caveats:

1. Epistemic Fallibility. A moderately informed but error‐prone agent may be less praiseworthy than a sentimental agent whose feelings reliably track rightness. A false moral belief, no matter how conscientious, can undermine worth. So duty’s sufficiency is conditional on reasonable epistemic competence.

2. Virtue as an Ideal. Aristotelian virtue integrates cognition, emotion, and action seamlessly. Pure duty may secure right action but fail to perfect character. Moral worth, on some rich virtue‐ethical conceptions, demands a harmonious soul. My claim is only about praiseworthiness in the narrower deontic sense, not about full human flourishing.

VII. Conclusion

A purely dutiful action—one motivated decisively by the desire to do what is morally right—can indeed be morally praiseworthy. The key is to understand the motive, not as a content‐less fetish, but as a second‐order regulative commitment that incorporates epistemic sensitivity to concrete right‐makers and expresses respect for persons and integrity of will. When these conditions obtain, the abstract desire suffices, and the familiar objections lose their sting. Caring about the rightness of one’s actions is not a distraction from morality; it is a sophisticated mode of being moral. Morality is, after all, about doing what is right—sometimes for no other reason than that it is right.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction: What Is at Issue?

One of the oldest disagreements in moral psychology concerns the source of a good deed’s “moral worth.” Kantians traditionally insist that the best deeds are done “from duty,” whereas many contemporary virtue-ethicists, sentimentalists and even some Kantians worry that the pure motive of duty leaves an agent “morally alienated” from the concrete values that make the action right. The abstract desire to “do what morality requires” (a de dicto desire) allegedly reveals an objectionable moral fetishism: the agent loves morality in the way a stamp-collector loves stamps, rather than loving the people, goods and relationships morality is about.  

Is the worry well-founded? I shall argue that, yes, acting solely from duty can suffice for moral worth, provided we understand both (i) what the de dicto desire really amounts to in a self-conscious, rational agent and (ii) what kind of credit moral worth involves. I defend a broadly Kantian answer enriched by contemporary work by Nomy Arpaly, Sarah Buss and Sarah McGrath: the praiseworthiness of dutiful action lies in the quality of will the agent manifests—namely, a steadfast practical commitment to the authority of moral reasons—and not primarily in the phenomenology of warm fellow-feeling. Far from being fetishistic, such a motive embodies epistemic humility, impartial respect and responsible agency.  

The discussion proceeds as follows. Section 2 clarifies the de dicto / de re distinction. Section 3 presents three standard objections to the sufficiency of the duty motive (fetishism, motivational inadequacy and alienation). Section 4 answers these objections. Section 5 develops a positive account of why pure duty motivation merits praise. Section 6 responds to remaining concerns and draws three upshots for moral education.

2. De Dicto Versus De Re Motivation

Following Mark Schroeder, a de dicto desire has the propositional content “that I do what is morally right,” whereas a de re desire is directed at a particular right-making feature—for example, the other person’s welfare, fairness, promise-keeping, etc. In ordinary life the two frequently overlap: my concern for fairness (de re) may be part of my more general concern to “do the right thing” (de dicto). The philosophical question is whether an agent whose psychology contained only the de dicto element could still act with full moral worth.

Notice two background assumptions:

A1. Moral worth tracks the quality of will revealed in the action.  
A2. An agent can possess a de dicto desire in either a superficial or a deeply reflective way.  

A superficial de dicto desire might be: “I want to keep my moral record clean because I care about my moral reputation.” That clearly earns no special credit. The question before us concerns reflective, unconditional avowal of morality’s authority—the Kantian motive.

3. Three Objections to the Sufficiency of Duty

Objection 1. Fetishism (Smith, Slote, Dancy). To prize “right-ness as such” is like prizing “goldenness as such.” It misconceives morality’s point, which is to protect and promote concrete goods.

Objection 2. Motivational Inadequacy (Williams). A bare wish to do right is too indeterminate to guide conduct. One must consult the reasons that make an act right; hence motivation by those reasons is necessary.

Objection 3. Alienation (Stocker). Someone who visits her sick friend only because “it is the right thing to do” slighted the friend’s personhood; the friend will feel not cared for but used as an occasion for moral self-congratulation.

4. Answers to the Objections

4.1 The De Dicto Desire Need Not Exclude De Re Appreciation

Suppose I rescue a drowning child on the sole ground that “this is morally required.” Does that psychological state rule out my seeing why it is required—namely that a child’s life is in danger? No. The content of my desire is general, but its practical implementation obviously engages my recognition of the concrete fact. Critics often conflate “exclusive” and “sufficient.” To say a motive is sufficient for moral worth is not to say it precludes other motives or that the agent is blind to right-making reasons. A high-level commitment can integrate lower-level concerns analogously to how “winning the game” guides a basketball player: he still focuses on dribbling, passing and shooting, though these subordinate ends have value only within the higher-level practical identity of an athlete. Similarly, the duty-bound agent recognizes the child’s welfare as a morally relevant consideration within her overarching commitment to right action.

4.2 Epistemic Humility and Guidance

Contra Williams, a de dicto commitment can supply definite guidance by functioning as a standing decision-procedure: “Act on whichever reasons turn out objectively to be morally decisive.” In situations of uncertainty or conflicting intuitions, the de dicto desire motivates an agent to inquire, deliberate and seek advice, precisely because she wants to get morality right. Thus its apparent indeterminacy is another form of responsiveness, not impotence. Indeed, many historical moral advances—abolitionism, women’s suffrage—were led by individuals who trusted the authority of morality in abstraction from the particular social norms of their day. Their de dicto motive pushed them to ask, “Are we really treating people as morality requires?” without yet possessing a fully articulated de re picture.

4.3 The Social Phenomenology of Respect

Stocker imagines the sick friend rebuking the dutiful visitor: “You only came because it was right!” But contrast two ways of acting from duty:

i. Hypocritical duty: the agent is reluctantly dragged by an external ought.  
ii. Wholehearted duty: the agent identifies with the moral demand and therefore with the friend’s legitimate claim.  

In case (ii) the visitor’s quality of will is not cold or alienating; it is precisely respect. Immanuel Kant describes such respect as “a feeling produced by reason” that acknowledges the other’s status as an end in herself. Modern empirical work on testimonial injustice confirms that being treated with principled respect—having one’s rights and dignity acknowledged—often matters as much as warmth.

5. A Positive Account: Why Pure Duty Merits Praise

5.1 Control and Credit

To be praiseworthy an action must manifest something under the agent’s rational control. De re affections—likes, sympathies, particular attachments—are partly contingent givens of temperament and circumstance. By contrast, the reflective commitment to treat moral requirements as decisive is an achievement of practical reason. Thus duty qualifies the agent for praise in a deeper sense: it shows who she has made herself to be.

5.2 Impartiality and Fairness

A central moral ideal is impartial concern. De re motives risk distortions: I may feel more sympathy for the nearby child than for the distant refugee, or for the pretty victim than the plain one. The de dicto desire, by tying my will directly to the normative property of right-ness, corrects these biases. The agent who acts because “it is what morality demands” treats like cases alike, and that is a virtue.

5.3 Stability and Reliability

Compassion waxes and wanes; friendship can sour. But the agent guided by duty is predictably moral across contexts. Sarah McGrath argues that the disposition to respond correctly to moral reasons, whatever they are, is a higher-order reliability trait and accordingly more creditable.

5.4 Autonomy and Self-Legislation

Kant famously holds that humanity’s distinctive dignity lies in self-legislation: accepting the moral law because one has rationally recognized it as binding. This autonomous stance is invisible to an observer looking only at affectionate feelings, yet it is the very feature that expresses our status as free moral agents rather than mere conduits of sentimental energy. Those who manifest it deserve esteem.

6. Replies to Remaining Worries

6.1 Isn’t Caring Morally Required?

One might object that morality itself requires us to cultivate direct concern for others, so the de dicto agent falls short of her own ideal. Two replies: (a) The question is sufficiency, not ideality; an action can be fully worthy even if alternative motives might have been better still. (b) The second-personal structure of duty actually embodies a form of caring: valuing others under the description “bearers of moral claims” is a distinctive mode of concern.

6.2 Moral Schizophrenia?

J. B. Schneewind warns that splitting motive from value risks incoherence: how can one desire to do A because it is right without also desiring the features that make A right? The answer invokes hierarchical integration. Just as the scientist values truth and therefore seeks empirical evidence, the moral agent values rightness and therefore is responsive to welfare, fairness, etc. The subordinate motives are derived rather than independent, but they are nonetheless affectively alive within deliberation.

6.3 Supererogatory Acts

Consider a bystander who risks her life to save strangers “because it is the right thing.” Is she less heroic than one who feels overwhelming sympathy? Plausibly she is more heroic, precisely because she overcomes natural self-interest not through accident of emotion but through principled choice. The concept of duty thus explains, better than any sentimentalist account, why such deeds inspire admiration.

7. Practical Implications

First, moral education should cultivate the habit of reflecting, “What morally ought I to do?” rather than relying exclusively on spontaneous empathy. Second, public institutions can reinforce citizens’ respect for moral norms by making procedures transparent and reason-giving, thereby supporting the de dicto motive. Third, juridical blame should focus on whether agents demonstrated disregard for morality’s authority, not on whether they lacked warm feelings.

8. Conclusion

Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth. The abstract, de dicto orientation is neither fetishistic nor alienating when properly understood. It expresses autonomous willing, impartiality, reliability and a distinctive form of respect for persons. Such qualities warrant praise not because they devalue concrete goods, but because they secure those goods under conditions where sentiment and partiality are unreliable. The moral law is no mere stamp collection; it is the form of freedom itself, and those who act from duty manifest that freedom in its most admirable guise.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
Can the bare desire to “do the right thing” ground morally worthy action, or must praiseworthy agents be moved by the concrete values that make an act right—love, concern, respect, benevolence, solidarity?  Over the past half-century, a chorus of critics—Bernard Williams (“one thought too many”), Michael Stocker (“moral schizophrenia”), Susan Wolf (“moral saints”), Nomy Arpaly, Jonathan Dancy and many others—have answered “no.”  Their guiding thought is that the motive of duty, understood de dicto as a generic desire to perform “whatever morality requires,” is too thin, too abstract, to connect an agent to the real point of morals.  Acting from duty alone allegedly reveals a fetish for moral rightness, a kind of aestheticised regard for purity of will that crowds out the humane sentiments that morality is about.  

Yet this verdict is not forced on us.  In what follows I argue that (1) de dicto moral motive can in principle suffice for moral worth; (2) when it does, its worth stems from the distinctively human achievement of recognizing and governing oneself by authoritative normative reasons; and (3) the standard objections—alienation, motivational thinness, and “one thought too many”—rest on an unduly impoverished picture of what the motive of duty can be and of the variety of ways in which agents may relate to right-making considerations.

I. Clarifying the target: de dicto and de re motives  

Call a motive de re when it is directed at the very features that make an action right: I pull you from the river because I want to save your life, not because I have the thin thought “saving lives is the right thing to do.”  A de dicto motive, by contrast, takes the form “I want to do whatever morality requires, whatever that turns out to be; and this (it turns out) is what morality requires.”  Two warnings are in order.  First, the de dicto motive need not be contentless: typically an agent forms a concrete judgment—“helping her now is my duty”—and is moved by that.  Second, de dicto and de re motives can of course coexist.  The critic’s claim is that the de dicto motive, on its own, is never enough for moral worth.  My question is whether that is true.

II. Two conceptions of moral worth  

One conception—call it the “rich content” view—holds that an act has moral worth only if the agent’s motive appropriately mirrors the right-making considerations.  Kant sometimes sounds like a proponent: the worth of an action, he says, lies in its being done “from duty” rather than from any “inclination.”  Yet influential neo-Aristotelians read him, plausibly or not, as insisting that the motive be the correct moral principle, not the agent’s generic respect for morality.  In either case, matching motives to moral truths is the key.  

The rival conception—call it the “normative control” view—locates moral worth instead in the agent’s reliable governance by reasons she takes to be authoritative.  What matters is that she respond to the right reasons because they are right, even if the psychological route by which she responds abstracts from their concrete features.  On this view a de dicto motive can suffice, so long as it functions as a modality of rational self-government.

III. An analogy with theoretical reason  

Imagine a mathematician who sets out to prove whatever follows from the axioms.  Faced with a conjecture, she does not form a burning desire for that particular theorem; her animating aim is “to believe what the axioms entail.”  Nobody accuses her of “epistemic fetishism.”  We praise her intellectual virtue precisely because she allows truth-tracking norms rather than idiosyncratic attractions to drive belief.  Mutatis mutandis, why should we condemn the moral agent who allows moral norms as such to guide action?  To do so can manifest a parallel form of practical rationality: the capacity to subject one’s will to impartial, authoritative standards.  

IV. The case for praiseworthiness  

1. The value of principled reliability.  An agent whose will is fixed on “doing what is right” is often more reliably responsive to moral reasons than one whose motives are piecemeal affections.  Concern only for friends may falter when strangers suffer; sympathy may be swamped by irritation.  The de dicto agent, by contrast, need not wait for sentiment: she has in place a standing, intrinsically moral motive.  Reliability, of course, is not the whole of moral worth, but it is undeniably part of why we value moral dispositions.

2. The achievement of reflective endorsement.  Human beings are not merely loci of sentiment; we are reflective creatures who can step back, ask what we ought to do, and regulate ourselves accordingly.  Exercising that capacity is intrinsically admirable.  Acting from duty manifests a kind of practical self-legislation: I acknowledge a claim on me that is not reducible to my contingent likes and dislikes, and I freely bind myself to it.  That achievement is praiseworthy even when the claim I acknowledge is only “this is right,” rather than “this will aid her welfare.”

3. Respect for persons in general.  De dicto moral motive may encode respect not for this or that person’s welfare, but for the moral status of all persons as such.  Kant’s “practical standpoint” treats each rational agent as a lawgiver in the kingdom of ends; the will determined by duty therefore expresses equal respect.  That respect, though abstract, is hardly alienating; it is a way of showing regard for every person’s claim to be treated justly.

V. Meeting the objections  

A. “Moral fetishism”: the charge that de dicto motive is wrongly focused on a property—rightness—that lacks intrinsic value.  

Reply: first, rightness is not a mysterious non-natural property but shorthand for the set of objectively authoritative reasons.  Wanting to comply with authoritative reasons is no more fetishistic than wanting to eat nutritious food because it is healthy.  Second, the critic slides illicitly from “the agent cares about rightness” to “the agent cares only about rightness.”  Nothing prevents a de dicto agent from also caring about concrete values; the question is whether caring also, or even primarily, about rightness diminishes moral worth.  I deny that it does.

B. “Alienation”: the agent who saves his wife “from duty” seems alienated from his personal relationship with her.  Williams’s celebrated case: thinking “it’s my duty” is “one thought too many.”  

Reply: The worry conflates moral worth with expressive adequacy inside particular relationships.  My love for my partner had better show up somewhere in my motivational set—but it need not be the sole or even decisive motive at the critical moment.  Suppose my partner and a stranger are both drowning; only one can be saved.  My de dicto sense of duty instructs me that I may permissibly favor my partner.  Acting on that judgment involves both love and duty; to say the second is “one thought too many” ignores that responsible agents of integrity do sometimes reflect on moral permissibility inside intimate engagements.  Moreover, there are contexts—public office, professional roles—in which reference to duty shields us from morally illicit partiality.  A judge who sentences fairly “because it is her duty” does not exhibit alienation; she manifests fidelity to the public reason that legitimates her authority.

C. “Motivational thinness”: de dicto desire lacks the motivational oomph that concrete concern supplies.  

Reply: Empirically dubious: history brims with activists whose generic commitment to justice powered immense sacrifice.  Even if duty is sometimes motivationally weaker than emotion, sufficiency for moral worth concerns not strength but kind.  A quiet but effective motive can fully ground praise.

VI. When duty fails  

My thesis is not that duty always suffices.  Three categories mark failure:

1. Epistemic negligence: if I make no effort to ascertain what duty requires and simply act on guesswork, the de dicto motive is undercut.  Moral worth demands at least minimally competent uptake of moral reasons.  

2. Bad faith: if I treat “duty” as a post-hoc rationalisation for what really moves me (fear of blame, social image), then the apparent de dicto motive is a mask.  Then praise is unwarranted.  

3. Higher-order defeaters: in specific relational contexts, acting solely from duty can rightly be criticised when a richer motive is expected and would have been available without moral cost.  A soldier who writes a condolence letter to a fallen comrade’s family strictly “because it is his duty” may convey coldness.  No contradiction arises: one can grant that such action is morally permissible and minimally worthy while still holding that it falls short of excellence.  

VII. The Kantian pedigree strengthened  

Kant’s notorious claim that only actions undertaken from duty have moral worth has often been interpreted as de dicto.  But Kant’s own illustrations—shopkeeper, philanthropist—show he worries not about abstractness per se but about whether the agent’s motive is conditioned on coincident inclination.  The central Kantian idea is that the moral law must be recognized as binding “for the sake of the law.”  That is practically identical with a de dicto motive.  If the law is genuinely moral, not merely conventional, then de dicto adherence to it is exactly what respect for persons requires.  Far from fetishistic, it testifies to autonomous rational agency.

VIII. Comparative virtues  

Virtue ethicists often object that an exclusive focus on duty misses the centrality of character.  But the regulative ideals of virtue and duty are not mutually exclusive.  A virtuous agent, as Julia Annas argues, is one who sees what reasons apply and is motivated by them as such—in effect, by duty.  Conversely, commitment to duty can cultivate virtues: honesty, temperance, courage, justice.  The supposed dichotomy stems from a too-narrow reading of both traditions.

IX. Agency, autonomy, and self-respect  

Modern moral psychology emphasises autonomy: the capacity to act on principles one has reflectively endorsed.  Acting from de dicto duty is a paradigm exercise of autonomy: one filters desires through practical judgment, aligning oneself with what one takes to be objectively required.  This activity underwrites both self-respect and respect for others.  In Nelson Mandela’s prison writings, he insists he was moved above all “by a sense of duty to the people.”  We do not find this morally impoverished; we find it heroic.  Mandela’s case also illustrates how de dicto duty often goes hand in hand with love, solidarity, and other concrete motives; yet the very fact that duty could sustain him when other motives might falter shows its independent moral worth.

X. Synthesis: plural bases of moral worth  

The sensible conclusion is pluralistic.  Morally worthy action can be motivated in at least three principal ways:

1. By de re concern for the valuable features that make the act right (empathy, friendship, care).  
2. By de dicto concern to do what moral reasons require (duty).  
3. By hybrid structures that combine (1) and (2).

Each basis has comparative advantages and limitations.  Their coexistence enriches moral life; none is universally superior.  The attempt to rule out (2) as always inadequate underestimates the breadth of human moral agency.

XI. Practical upshot  

In education and character development we should cultivate both sensitivity to concrete values and principled commitment to doing the right.  Teaching children simply to follow moral rules without instilling sympathy risks dryness; teaching them only to care about others without anchoring that care in principled respect risks parochial bias.  Mature agents need both: the heart that feels and the will that resolves.

XII. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct.  Such action is praiseworthy because it manifests (a) reliable responsiveness to authoritative reasons, (b) the distinctive human achievement of reflective self-governance, and (c) respect for persons in their capacity as rational ends in themselves.  The standard objections—fetishism, alienation, motivational thinness—either misconstrue the nature of de dicto motive or mistake contingent shortcomings for conceptual flaws.  De dicto duty is no less genuine, no less admirable a moral motive than compassion or friendship; it is one vital strand in the rich tapestry of the moral life.  The challenge for each of us is not to choose between duty and concrete concern, but to integrate them so that, come what may, we can both feel the pull of others’ needs and stand ready, simply and firmly, to do what is right.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right be enough for moral worth? In this essay I argue that it can: a de dicto desire to do the right thing, even when no other motive is present, can fully ground moral praiseworthiness. I begin by clarifying the notions at stake (§1). I then reconstruct the two most influential objections—the “moral-fetishism” charge that the agent’s gaze is fixed on an abstract property rather than on the concrete features that matter (§2), and the “alienation” worry that duty-only agents are estranged from the values morality serves (§3). The heart of the essay (§4) provides a three-part reply: (A) a conceptual argument that a de dicto desire cannot be successfully acted on unless the agent is appropriately responsive to right-making considerations; (B) a normative argument that treating rightness as an independent source of motivation constitutes a distinctive form of respect for persons; and (C) a practical argument that the duty motive yields especially reliable, situation-proof moral conduct. I close by distinguishing moral worth from other evaluative dimensions (lovability, admirability, saintliness) and sketching why additional motives can enhance, though are not required for, praiseworthiness (§5).

1. Clarifying the Question

1.1 De dicto vs. de re desire. A de re desire to help Maria concerns that very person: “I want to help her.” A de dicto desire to do the morally right thing is contentless with respect to particulars: “I want to do whatever is right.” Our question is whether that second, more abstract desire can make an act worthy of praise when it operates alone.

1.2 Moral worth. I adopt a broadly Kantian notion: an action has moral worth when it is attributable to the agent as a response to moral reasons—when it manifests the agent’s commitment to doing the right thing because it is right. Moral worth is distinct from (i) the action’s rightness, which concerns what ought to be done, and (ii) the agent’s moral character in the thick sense that includes warmth or charm. The shopkeeper who gives correct change merely to build reputation acts rightly but without moral worth; the one who does so “for the sake of duty” has moral worth.

1.3 The sufficiency claim. I defend:

Sufficiency Thesis: An action produced solely by the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to act rightly—possesses moral worth.

I remain neutral on whether the duty motive is also necessary for moral worth, or whether mixed motives diminish worth. My target is the common claim that duty alone is inadequate.

2. The Moral-Fetishism Objection

The label originates with Barbara Herman and Michael Smith. The charge is roughly this:

1. Morally commendable agents are motivated by what makes an act right (other-regarding concern, fairness, promise-keeping).  
2. A pure duty motive is aimed at rightness as such, not at those concrete considerations.  
3. Acting from the duty motive therefore exhibits a “fetishistic” fascination with an abstract property, leaving the agent insensitive to the real-world values morality tracks.

Compare someone who weds you because you are “my legally assigned spouse,” not because of love or companionship. Something seems off: the relation is valued only under a formal description, not for its substantive goods. Likewise, the critic says, morality is about people’s needs, avoidable suffering, freely given consent; the duty-bound agent fixates on a thin label—“the right”—and thus misses what morally matters.

3. The Alienation Objection

Susan Wolf’s famous “Moral Saints” essay epitomises the second worry. The dutiful person, especially in Kant’s austere portrait, appears chilly, joyless, estranged from friends, art, and humor. Even if she does no wrong, her life seems diminished; other motives (love, sympathy, excitement) have been crowded out by an impersonal commitment to the moral law. The result is an agent alienated not only from her personal projects but from the very individuals her actions are supposed to help. She helps the needy because “duty demands it,” not because she cares about them. Can such help be fully commendable?

4. Three Replies in Defence of Duty

4.1 Conceptual reply: Implementing a de dicto desire requires tracking the right-making reasons.

Suppose Ann decides “I will do what is morally right.” To realise this aim she must ask, in each concrete choice, “What would be right here?” That further question pushes her to consider precisely the welfare, dignity, justice, or fidelity facts that determine rightness. A mere label cannot guide action; the agent needs a grasp of its extension. That grasp can be practical rather than theoretical—tacit sensitivities, habits of attention, empathetic imagination. But without responsiveness to those concrete features, the agent could not reliably satisfy her de dicto desire. She would fail in her own terms.

An analogy: desiring to hit the bullseye is abstract compared with desiring to let the arrow fly at 47.8° given the wind. But the archer who genuinely wants to hit the bullseye will adjust for wind and distance; otherwise the desire is idle. Likewise, a morality-aiming agent must track what morality concretely requires.

This undermines Premise 2 of the fetishism argument. The de dicto desire, by its own logic, entails engagement with right-making reasons. It is not a substitute for them but a higher-order orientation that organises and prioritises them. True, the content of the desire is schematic, but its satisfaction conditions are richly textured.

4.2 Normative reply: Valuing rightness qua rightness expresses respect for persons.

Why is the right thing right? Standardly because it treats persons with appropriate regard: it protects their interests, honours their autonomy, or realises fair distributions. But the question before us is motivational: What is praiseworthy about being moved by the fact that an action is morally required? My answer: a duty motive expresses the judgment that other persons are sources of binding reasons independently of my contingent feelings toward them. By taking “the right” as an unconditioned reason, the agent affirms the equal authority of moral claims across all persons and contexts.

Contrast two rescuers. Beth pulls a stranger from a river because she feels sudden compassion; Claire pulls him out because she recognises he has a claim on her assistance—“It was the right thing to do.” Suppose both act promptly and skillfully. Beth manifests a valuable capacity for sympathy; Claire manifests a valuable capacity for recognizing and responding to moral reasons. Each capacity merits praise, but the second conveys a distinctive form of respect. Sympathy’s motivational force may vary with distance, salience, or group membership; recognition of rightness does not. In that way, the duty motive embodies a commitment to persons as such, avoiding partiality and arbitrariness.

Critics sometimes retort that real respect must involve personal concern, not cold compliance. Yet we ordinarily see that principled action is a way of taking others seriously. Imagine someone who cheerfully violates your property rights whenever it benefits her friends, explaining, “Don’t worry—I still like you.” You would likely prefer the dutiful neighbour who restrains herself because it is wrong to trespass, even if she feels little warmth. The normative truth that persons are owed fair treatment is itself a value we care about others upholding. Acting for that reason is therefore praiseworthy.

4.3 Practical reply: The duty motive supplies stability where concrete sentiments falter.

Many right-making considerations trigger motivational resonance only intermittently—sympathy when the victim is vivid, gratitude when the benefactor is present, environmental concern when a glacier melts on screen. A de dicto desire to act rightly functions as a regulative backup system. It motivates when first-order sentiments are weak or silenced by fatigue, fear, or self-interest. Kant’s point in the “dry misanthrope” example is not that benevolence lacks value, but that a sense of duty is reliably action-guiding even when one is tired, hurt, or depressed.

Reliability is not a trivial virtue. Imagine you need someone to execute your last will. You want a friend who will persevere though the document is dull, though beneficiaries are strangers, though no one is watching. The agent who is governed by the categorical imperative is predictably steadfast. That robustness underlines why we praise the duty motive. Morality’s authority is supposed to be unconditional; a desire that mirrors that unconditionality is especially apt.

5. Objections Reconsidered

5.1 Is it still fetishistic?

One might reply: Even if a de dicto desire must consult right-making facts, the agent’s occurrent motive can remain the thin fact that the act is right, not the thicker facts about need or consent. Something is lost in moral psychology: the rescuer should be moved by the victim’s peril, not by the abstract status of obligation.

I grant that additional motives often enrich an action’s meaning. It is better when the parent feeds her infant out of love as well as duty. Yet we must separate two claims:

(Enhancement) Concrete concern can add value.  
(Sufficiency) Absence of such concern robs the act of all moral worth.

My defence targets Sufficiency, not Enhancement. Moral worth is secured once the agent acts for the right reason with adequate understanding. Nothing in that picture denies that supplementary motives may render the act more admirable or the agent more lovable.

5.2 Doesn’t the victim prefer benevolence?

Sociological studies show that help accompanied by warmth is typically perceived as more welcome. But moral worth is about the agent’s stance toward duty, not about what sort of aid the recipient would most enjoy. From the first-person point of view, what makes my act praiseworthy is that I respond to an authoritative claim. The recipient’s preference shapes the content of that claim—no one wants to be treated like a “bundle of duties”—yet the motivational spring that secures compliance can still be duty.

In fact, many victims care deeply that helpers recognise their rights. A disabled passenger may prefer assistance grounded in respect for her autonomy rather than pity. Acting from duty communicates: “You are owed this, not merely the object of my sentiment.”

5.3 Epistemic arrogance?

Another worry: claiming to act from duty presumes certainty about what morality requires. If that certainty is misplaced, praiseworthiness evaporates. Here we must refine the account. A conscientious duty-motive includes appropriate epistemic humility: the agent aims to do what is right and, recognising her fallibility, seeks evidence, listens to testimony, considers disagreement. Acting “from duty” need not entail dogmatism; it might involve delayed judgment, inquiry, and revision. What matters is that the inquiry is undertaken because the agent is committed to getting morality right.

5.4 Do costs matter?

Following Kant, many hold that moral worth increases when the agent overcomes contrary inclination. The sufficiency thesis as stated does not deny that. An act from duty can involve cost (the merchant resists temptation) or no cost (the cheerful helper). Either way, the source of praiseworthiness is the agent’s responsiveness to moral reasons. Cost can amplify the evidence for that responsiveness, but the motive’s presence, not its strenuousness, is the fundamental ground.

6. Broader Landscape: Morality and the Mixed Motive

Emphasising the sufficiency of duty invites a misconception—namely, that philosophers who defend it valorise icy rigorists. That would be an error. Most of us hope for lives in which duty, sympathy, friendship, aesthetic joy, intellectual curiosity, and playful spontaneity interweave. Moral worth is only one mode of evaluation among many; a rich human life includes but also surpasses it. The present thesis is a modest conceptual point: when other motives are absent or even contrary, the duty motive can shoulder the full justificatory burden.

Consider the solitary whistle-blower who exposes corruption despite feeling no love for the victims and no personal benefit—indeed at great personal cost. The abstract judgment “This is the right thing to do” sustains her. To deny her moral worth because her motive lacks warmth seems perverse. Her act may be precisely the exemplary case of moral praiseworthiness.

7. Conclusion

The charge that a pure duty motive is hollow misunderstands both its functional structure and its ethical significance. Structurally, a de dicto desire to act rightly cannot guide behaviour without recognition of the very right-making particulars critics worry are ignored. Normatively, treating morality as a source of binding reasons in its own right is a powerful way of respecting persons as equals. Practically, the duty motive ensures steadiness where fickle sentiments fade. For those three reasons, an action done solely from duty can possess full moral worth.

This conclusion neither denigrates benevolence nor romantic love. It simply places the duty motive on the honours list alongside them. Morality’s authority sometimes demands that it be front and centre. When it is, and when an agent responds wholeheartedly to the thought “This is what is right,” we have all the ingredients needed for genuine moral praiseworthiness.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
1. Introduction  

When we praise someone for acting well, we usually have in mind not only what she did but also why she did it. The utilitarian who rescues a drowning child in order to maximise aggregate welfare and the sentimental friend who jumps in out of love both elicit admiration, while the cynical politician who does the same in hope of favourable press strikes us as morally wanting. Philosophers have long tried to articulate what sort of motivational structure underwrites moral worth. One prominent view—defended by Kant but resisted by many contemporary writers—holds that acting “from the motive of duty,” that is, from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right, is sufficient for the highest moral worth. The opposing camp claims that this “duty motive” is too abstract, and that genuine moral worth requires motivation by the very concrete considerations that render the act right (the child’s danger, a friend’s distress, an oppressed person’s dignity, etc.). Otherwise, the agent allegedly displays a form of moral fetishism, a chilly allegiance to “morality” rather than to the people and values morality is about.

My aim is to defend a qualified “yes”: acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice for moral worth, provided that the agent’s abstract concern is epistemically and practically well-formed. I will argue, first, that the de dicto motive, properly understood, is not a fetishistic stance but a second-order regulative commitment whose content already includes sensitivity to the right-making features of actions; second, that the duty motive secures distinct virtues—reliability, impartiality, and integrity—that are themselves good-making; and third, that the familiar objections either misunderstand the psychology of the de dicto desire or mistakenly presume a zero-sum rivalry between duty and concrete concern. I conclude that we have good reason to regard pure dutiful action as praiseworthy, though in ordinary human agents it will rarely occur without some admixture of more particular motivations.

2. De dicto versus de re moral motivation  

Let us begin by clarifying the target. A de re moral desire takes the form “I want to ϕ because of C,” where C is some concrete consideration that makes ϕ the right thing to do—say, “because it will relieve Sam’s pain.” A de dicto moral desire is instead “I want to do what is morally right.” On its face the latter appears content-thin; it refers to rightness without specifying what makes the relevant act right.

Yet the de dicto-de re contrast can be drawn in two importantly different ways.

a) Strict psychological reading. Here the content of the agent’s motivating desire is only the thin proposition “that I act morally rightly.” The agent has no further motivational grip on more specific right-making facts.

b) Hierarchical or guidance reading, associated with Harry Frankfurt’s distinction between first- and second-order desires. On this model the de dicto desire functions as a higher-order commitment: “Whatever ultimately makes an action right, I commit myself to acting for those reasons.” It governs the agent’s first-order deliberation by directing her to search for and respond to the right-making features. Such an agent can act from duty alone even though her practical reasoning inevitably traverses concrete considerations, which she now treats as derivative of her de dicto commitment.

Kantian ethics adopts something closer to (b). Kant repeatedly notes that respect for the moral law necessarily manifests itself through obedience to its material dictates—one cannot simply recite “I do the right” while ignoring what the Categorical Imperative demands in a given case. Hence understood, the duty motive does not bypass substantive moral reasons; it coordinates them.

3. The charge of moral fetishism  

The worry of “fetishism” (often associated with Michael Smith and Julia Markovits) can be distilled into three claims:

(1) Descriptive. A pure duty-moved agent attends only to the fact of rightness, not to the valuable features that make the act right.

(2) Normative. Morally admirable agents ought to care about those valuable features; failing to do so evinces an objectionable detachment or alienation.

(3) Explanatory. Because the duty motive blocks appropriate sentimental engagement, such agents are less reliable at producing good actions across contexts.

If these claims are correct, acting solely from duty would not qualify for moral worth, or at least not as much as acting from concrete concern.

4. Why the duty motive can suffice for moral worth  

I now present three lines of defence.

4.1 The duty motive as a second-order gatekeeper  

A primary task of moral motivation in finite, fallible agents is to organise the welter of competing first-order impulses—self-interest, partial affection, momentary passions—so that conduct remains answerable to moral requirements. A de dicto desire admirably fills this gatekeeper role. It does not replace first-order sensitivity to people’s needs or to justice; rather, it authorises and disciplines it. When one acts solely from this motive, one’s first-order affective responses are themselves recruited under the guidance of duty: “This child’s welfare is a reason for me because morality recognises it as such, and I am committed to morality.” Therefore the “thinness” objection misfires. The agent is motivationally related to the child’s welfare, but that relation is mediated by her standing commitment to do what morality requires.

4.2 Reliability across contexts  

Because duty is a second-order commitment, it enjoys a kind of robustness that more particular concerns often lack. Specific affections, sympathies, or utilitarian calculations may fluctuate with mood, proximity, or cognitive load. The dutiful agent, by contrast, possesses a stable practical identity: she acts as morality dictates, even when the beneficiaries are unknown or when no sympathetic affect is triggered (e.g., future generations, statistical victims). This reliability is itself a moral virtue. We prize the doctor who treats each patient conscientiously, not only those she happens to like. Consequently, when the doctor acts “just because it is right to render aid,” that is precisely what makes her trustworthy and so praiseworthy.

4.3 Integrity and equal respect  

Finally, the duty motive embodies a valuable internal relation to one’s own rational agency. To will an action as right because it is right is to affirm one’s status as a free, self-legislating agent responding to reasons that any similarly situated agent can in principle appreciate. This stance secures both integrity (one acts from principles one can own) and equal respect (one acknowledges the standing of all agents subject to the same principles). These are not empty formalities. In moral tragedy—when duties conflict with powerful personal attachments—the capacity to act for the right reason, even at great cost, is what we honor. Sophie’s refusal to betray a colleague under totalitarian threat, based solely on the principle that betrayal is wrong, is paradigmatically admirable.

5. Replies to the main objections  

5.1 “But the duty-bound agent doesn’t care about people!”  

A standard illustration is the helpful neighbor who assists you “only” because it is her duty, not because she cares about you. Intuitively this seems cold. Yet careful phenomenology suggests otherwise. The duty-bound neighbor’s motivational story is: (i) People’s welfare morally matters; (ii) My neighbor’s current welfare is at stake; (iii) I therefore assist, out of commitment to what morally matters. This agent does care about you, though the caring is structured by her principled allegiance rather than by contingent affection. The perceived coldness arises when we artificially strip away step (i) or (ii); but those steps are essential to a Kantian reading of duty.

5.2 The alienation worry  

Bernard Williams argued that moral theories that demand impartial adherence can alienate agents from their personal projects and relations. However, the duty motive need not forbid personal projects; it merely subjects them to a higher-order test of permissibility. Indeed, genuine friendship arguably benefits from such regulation. A friend who refuses to lie for you when lying would harm innocent others may strain your immediate interest but ultimately honors both you and the moral community. Her stance says: “I respect you enough to treat you as a moral equal, not as someone on whose behalf I would sacrifice innocent third parties.” That is the opposite of alienation.

5.3 Epistemic sensitivity  

A subtler objection notes that the de dicto desire might encourage excessive moral deference: the agent consults authorities or social consensus rather than critically engaging with concrete facts. Yet one can distinguish between motivational content and epistemic method. Nothing in the desire “to do what is right” licenses lazy deference; on the contrary, it should spur diligent inquiry into what rightness demands. An agent who treats hearsay as sufficient evidence that ϕ is right thereby manifests not an excess of duty but a defect of epistemic virtue.

6. Synergy rather than competition  

Although I have defended the sufficiency of the duty motive, I do not claim it is always morally preferable to act from duty alone. Often the richest moral agents integrate the de dicto commitment with a flourishing repertoire of sentiments—empathy, love, solidarity. But these are complements, not replacements. The Kantian can happily grant that an action motivated both by duty and by sympathy may carry an added aesthetic or relational value. All I deny is that the presence of duty sans sympathy necessarily renders the act morally inferior. Sometimes, given human limitations, the duty motive is precisely what ensures right action when sympathy falters.

7. Two test cases  

Consider first the professional judge who must impose a harsh but just sentence on a defendant. Whether or not the judge feels compassion, we regard her as duty-bound to uphold justice; we do not impugn her moral worth if her primary motive is “because it is my duty.” Indeed we distrust judges who let personal feelings override duty.

Second, imagine a pandemic in which volunteers are desperately needed for vaccine trials. Alex signs up solely because he believes it is the morally right thing to do. He has no relatives at risk, feels no special sympathy for strangers, and is not excited by adventure. Nonetheless he endures weeks of discomfort. It seems counterintuitive to withhold praise here. Alex’s dutiful motive, free of egoistic or tribal bias, is admirable precisely because it testifies to the impartial moral point of view.

8. A virtue-theoretic reconstruction  

Those still wary of Kantian language may prefer a virtue-ethical gloss. On that view, what makes a trait a virtue is that it reliably aligns action with the morally right and is motivated by appropriate perception of the good. The duty motive can be redescribed as the virtue of conscientiousness: a stable disposition to seek out and comply with moral reasons. Far from being a cold fetish, conscientiousness is a central civic virtue; societies could not function if people helped others only when they happened to feel warm sentiments. Thus even virtue ethics, once freed from caricature, recognises the praiseworthiness of dutiful action.

9. Limits and qualifications  

I have defended the moral sufficiency of pure duty, but three caveats are in order.

a) Psychological development. In children and moral novices, abstract duty detached from feeling may be brittle. Cultivating empathy and habituated concern is often pedagogically necessary for someone later to sustain the de dicto commitment under stress.

b) Pathological scrupulosity. An agent whose duty motive degenerates into obsessive guilt or self-punishment may do what is right but in a spirit that undermines her own flourishing. Aristotelian eudaimonia reminds us that moral worth coexists with competing values, including psychological health.

c) Misguided moral codes. Finally, if an agent’s moral beliefs are gravely mistaken, acting from duty can lead to evil. The sufficiency claim presupposes basic moral reliability; otherwise we risk praising the ideologically fanatical. But this is no special problem for duty motivation—misguided sympathy or love can do equal harm.

10. Conclusion  

Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth. Properly understood, the duty motive is not an alien, contentless fetish, but a second-order regulative commitment that integrates and disciplines first-order practical reasoning. It confers distinctive virtues of reliability, impartiality, and integrity, allows agents to navigate the diversity of moral life without undue dependence on variable sentiments, and signals equal respect for all moral persons. While a fully ideal agent may harmonise duty with rich particular affections, none of this diminishes the praiseworthiness of the person who, faced with a hard choice, acts simply because it is the right thing to do.

question: Many philosophers have argued that the motive of duty—understood as a de dicto desire to do what is morally right—cannot suffice for moral worth. On their view, praiseworthy agents must be motivated by the concrete considerations that explain why their actions are right (such as concern for others' welfare), rather than by an abstract concern for morality as such. Critics charge that agents motivated solely by duty exhibit a kind of moral fetishism or alienation from what morality is really about. Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? If so, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy?
answer:
Can acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right suffice as a motive for morally worthy conduct? I shall argue that it can. The desire to do the right thing “de dicto,” when properly understood, embodies (i) an appropriate form of respect for the moral law, (ii) the right kind of responsiveness to moral reasons, and (iii) a reliable disposition to act rightly across a wide range of circumstances. These three features make such dutiful action praiseworthy even when no further concrete motive—such as sympathy, friendship, or beneficence—plays a decisive role. The familiar charge of “moral fetishism” misconstrues the architecture of dutiful motivation and fails to appreciate how an abstract concern with rightness can preserve and express the very values that morality is “really about.”

I. Framing the Dispute

Philosophers distinguish two ways in which an agent might care about morality. An agent can care about morality “de re,” being moved by the very features that make an act right (for instance, Jane helps an injured stranger because she is moved by the stranger’s suffering). Alternatively, she can care “de dicto,” being moved by the fact that the act is morally right, whatever its right-making features happen to be. The critics of dutiful motivation insist that while de dicto concern may yield correct action, it cannot ground moral worth. Bernard Williams, Michael Stocker, and other virtue theorists contend that exclusive reliance on formal duty displays a kind of moral alienation: it turns the agent’s attention away from the concrete human goods—flourishing, friendship, relief of suffering—that morality tries to protect.

Kantians, by contrast, famously claim that acting from duty confers a distinctive moral worth that other motives, however amiable, cannot secure. Yet even within Kantian circles there is disagreement about what “acting from duty” really comes to.
