Contemporary Kantians such as Barbara Herman and Markovits maintain that an agent acts from duty only when she is motivated by the right-making considerations themselves, not merely by the abstract thought that an act is right. So, the dispute is alive even within Kant’s camp.

My strategy will be to defend a minimal but robust notion of de dicto dutiful motivation and show why it meets the standards of moral worth. The defense proceeds in four steps:

1. Clarify what a properly formed de dicto desire to do what is right involves.
2. Show that such a desire guarantees sensitivity to the very considerations the critics think are important.
3. Argue that praiseworthiness depends primarily on this kind of sensitivity and reliability, not on the particular first-order motive tokens present.
4. Defuse the accusation of moral fetishism by exposing its equivocations.

II. What Is It to Desire “to Do What Is Right”?

A common caricature portrays the duty-bound agent as someone who mutters, “I must do the morally correct thing,” while having no idea or concern about why the act is correct. Such an agent would indeed be culpably oblivious. But this is not what a genuine de dicto desire to do what is right consists in.

The desire can be analysed as a standing, higher-order commitment:

D: For any situation S, if φ-ing is the morally right thing to do in S, then I shall φ.

There are three crucial points about D.

a. Cognitive component. To act on D, the agent must form some belief about what the right thing is in her circumstances, and that belief must derive from a genuine exercise of moral judgment. So acting under D presupposes responsiveness to the grounds of moral rightness.

b. Deferential, not blind. The agent does not fetishize the mere label “morally right.” Rather, she adopts a policy of doing whatever the best moral reasons dictate. In this way, D is analogous to a scientist’s policy “to believe whatever the best evidence supports.” Nobody thinks the scientist thereby fetishizes truth; instead, we see the policy as expressing a proper respect for evidence.

c. Dynamically integrated. D is not an inert principle added onto life’s routines. It shapes deliberation, attention, and emotional dispositions. A person governed by D will, in virtue of wanting to do the right thing, cultivate the capacities—empathy, discernment, impartiality—that are needed to recognize what rightness requires.

III. Sensitivity and Moral Worth

Most philosophers now agree that moral worth involves more than mere right action. A helpful recent formulation is:

Responsiveness Condition (RC): An action has moral worth only if the agent’s motive makes her responsive to the facts that render the action right.

Does D meet RC? Yes. Although the agent’s ultimate aim is de dicto (“act rightly”), the practical route to that aim travels through the right-making considerations. She must notice the suffering stranger, grasp its moral significance, and recognize aid as a requirement of beneficence. Otherwise, she cannot identify aid as “the right thing.” So the same process of recognition that a virtue theorist prizes is required by D itself.

An analogy: Suppose I vow to follow the advice of the best medical authorities because I want to stay healthy. When I decide to exercise more, I do so in virtue of concrete medical reasons about cardiovascular fitness. My de dicto desire (to follow medical advice) funnels through de re reasons (exercise benefits health). Similarly, the desire to do what is morally right funnels through the substantive grounds of rightness.

Thus, RC does not discriminate between de dicto and de re motives. Both can satisfy it or fail, depending on the quality of the agent’s reasoning. A cold bureaucrat who declares “It’s the rule” without understanding why exhibits poor responsiveness. But the failure is epistemic, not structural: her grasp of what duty demands is shallow. The remedy is fuller moral understanding, not abandonment of duty as a motive.

IV. Reliability Across Cases

Another dimension of moral worth concerns reliability: Is the agent disposed to track moral reasons across varied scenarios, including those where her natural sympathies may run counter to them? The de dicto motive scores well here. Because the object of D is rightness itself, the motive is relatively stable in the face of changing first-order incentives. Sympathy is a valuable sentiment, but sympathy can flag when beneficiaries are distant or unappealing. A pure philanthropist animated by D will keep her commitments even when she feels no warmth. That reliability is itself praiseworthy; it reflects a kind of moral steadfastness or integrity.

A well-known worry holds that such steadfastness can shade into rigidity. But steadfastness only becomes vice when it ceases to be responsive: when it persists despite decisive reasons to the contrary. Because D’s very content links action to reasons, the agent is protected from blind rigidity. She will persist only so long as she judges the action right.

V. Fetishism Reconsidered

Bernard Williams introduced the “fetishism” charge against utilitarian and Kantian motivations: the agent allegedly treats moral rightness as a fetish object detached from human concerns. Let us diagnose two equivocations in the charge.

1. Conflating ultimate and proximate motivation. The fetishism story implies the agent is moved solely by the fact that an act is right, and not at all by its human consequences. But as we saw, a de dicto motive operates via the agent’s recognition of those very consequences. They are not motivationally idle; they are the indispensable route to identifying the act as right.

2. Mistaking critical distance for alienation. Moral agents sometimes need to step back from their immediate sentiments in order to judge impartially. That critical distance can feel cold when compared with spontaneous affection, but it is not alienation. Imagine a parent who forces herself to punish her child fairly despite intense favoritism. She may experience the demand of duty as abstraction, yet we do not judge her alienated. We admire her capacity to let rightness overrule bias.

The upshot is that the fetishism charge goes through only if we imagine dutiful agents who, perversely, refuse to acknowledge any ground for rightness beyond its being right. But such creatures are either conceptually impossible (because rightness is always grounded in something) or epistemically defective (they do not know what makes acts right). Neither case undermines the coherent ideal of de dicto duty bounded by understanding.

VI. The Ecology of Motives

Some contend that a wholly duty-driven life would be emotionally impoverished even if individually dutiful acts possess moral worth. I agree. Human virtue is plural; we rightly prize love, friendship, compassion, humor. Nothing in D excludes these supplementary motives. The claim I defend is conditional: when D operates alone—say, because compassion is momentarily absent—it is sufficient, though not always optimal.

Think of mountaineering equipment. A rope that can bear your weight is sufficient to keep you from falling, even if redundancy would be better. Similarly, de dicto duty suffices for moral worth even if a richer motivational ensemble would be ideal.

VII. Kant and Contemporary Kantians

Does my defense simply echo Kant? Partly, but it parts company with some modern readings. Kant writes that an action has “genuine moral worth” only when done “from duty” and “contrary to inclination.” Critics reply that Kant thereby exalts self-denial. A more charitable reading is that Kant chooses “against inclination” cases because they make the presence of duty vivid. He never denies that sympathetic acts can be dutiful and morally worthy; he claims only that we cannot tell whether sympathy alone would have moved the agent. The textual debate is complex, but on the charitable reading Kant is no fetishist. The motive of respect for the moral law embodies reverence for rational nature, not slavish rule worship.

Contemporary Kantians such as Herman offer a stricter view: acting from duty requires being motivated by the right-making considerations themselves, not by the abstract thought that the act is right. My counter-proposal is ecumenical. The strict view is one way of filling in D, but not the only way. What matters is reliable responsiveness; whether the agent experiences it as a concern for rightness or for the specific grounds is secondary.

VIII. Two Objections and Replies

Objection 1: De dicto duty cannot discriminate between competing moral theories. An agent might desire to do what she falsely believes is right (say, racist moral code) and still satisfy D. So D is morally blind.

Reply: All accounts of moral worth confront the problem of mistaken belief. Sympathy can be misinformed too. The correct fix is a truth-connection clause: praiseworthiness requires that the agent’s moral judgments be at least minimally accurate or non-culpably mistaken. This condition is independent of whether the motive is de dicto or de re.

Objection 2: Exclusively dutiful agents lack moral joy; they perform burdensome self-sacrifices and thereby manifest an impoverished character.

Reply: Joy is indeed valuable, but not constitutive of moral worth. Consider a firefighter who, exhausted and afraid, drags victims from a burning building solely because he judges it his duty. That act is paradigmatically praiseworthy. If later he grows to love the thrill of rescue, so much the better; yet the initial dutiful act was not deficient. Moreover, many agents experience a deep, even if quiet, satisfaction precisely in living up to duty. So the picture of joyless drudgery is empirically dubious.

IX. The Positive Value of De Dicto Duty

I have so far argued for sufficiency; let me end by highlighting the affirmative virtues of dutiful motivation.

1. Autonomy: The agent acts on reasons she can, in principle, share with every rational being. This universalizability embodies respect for others as equals.

2. Integrity: Because D is content-neutral regarding personal attachments, it helps agents resist corrupting pressures (tribalism, nepotism). It acts as a moral gyroscope.

3. Reflective equilibrium: De dicto concern encourages deliberation about moral principles, fostering moral development and reducing unexamined bias.

4. Civic reliability: In pluralistic societies, we often lack shared emotions. A common commitment to do what is right supplies a bridge across divergent sympathies.

X. Conclusion

The desire to do what is morally right, taken in abstraction, can look bloodless. Yet abstraction is not necessarily detachment, and impartiality is not indifference. A properly formed de dicto motive requires and cultivates sensitivity to the substantive values—welfare, justice, respect—that make acts right. It renders the agent reliably responsive to moral reasons across changing contexts. Because moral worth consists in acting for the right reasons with reliable responsiveness, dutiful action, even when driven solely by that abstract desire, suffices for praise.

This conclusion should not be read as a rejection of the virtues lauded by the critics. Compassion, friendship, and solidarity are central components of a well-rounded moral life. My claim is merely that when, for whatever reason, those richer motives fall silent, the humble desire to do what is right can still carry the day—and we do well to admire the moral strength it displays.

answer:
Acting Solely from Duty: Fetishistic Formalism or Paradigm of Moral Worth?

1. Introduction  

Imagine a harried physician in a field hospital. Exhausted and numb, she no longer feels compassion surge when a new casualty is rushed in; what nonetheless propels her to sterilise her instruments and operate is one fixed thought: “This is what morality requires of me.” Is her performance still worthy of praise? Many contemporary moral psychologists and virtue theorists say no. To act well, they insist, is to be animated by the very considerations that make the act right—concern for the soldier’s pain, love for humanity, solidarity with the wounded. A merely de dicto desire “to do the morally right thing” allegedly reveals a moral fetishism: the agent’s attention clings to an abstract property (rightness) rather than to the people, needs or values that confer that property. In what follows I argue that, appearances notwithstanding, a pure duty motive can indeed suffice for moral worth. Far from being a cold formalism, such an orientation manifests a distinctive form of respect for persons, an expression of autonomous self-government, and a reliable sensitivity to moral reasons. When these features are present, the dutiful agent merits praise even if no other concrete sentiments accompany her act.

The essay proceeds in five steps. Section 2 clarifies the distinction between (a) acting from the concrete right-making considerations and (b) acting from the abstract thought that the deed is right. Section 3 surveys the main objections: Stocker’s “schizophrenia of modern ethical theories,” Railton’s charge of alienation, and Blum’s account of moral perception. Section 4 develops a Kantian-inspired defence: respect for the moral law is not contentless but embodies a second-personal acknowledgement of every rational agent’s authority. Section 5 explains why this motive can track concrete reasons without fetishistic mediation, drawing on contemporary work on de dicto versus de re desires and on the epistemic role played by second-order principles. Section 6 responds to remaining worries about coldness and motivational reliability, before Section 7 concludes.

2. De dicto and De re Moral Motivation  

A motive is de dicto if it is directed at a proposition under a general description: “I want to do whatever is morally required.” By contrast, a motive is de re if it latches onto some particular feature of the situation: “I want to prevent that child’s pain.” The present debate asks whether the first kind of desire, by itself, can make an action morally worthy. Two preliminary remarks matter.

First, in any realistic agent the two kinds of motivation are usually interwoven. An ordinary helper may think “That child is suffering, so I must act; that’s the right thing to do.” Nonetheless, for philosophical clarity we can isolate limiting cases where only one desire is causally efficacious.

Second, “solely from duty” need not mean “without knowledge of the concrete facts.” A surgeon who operates because it is required is not ignorant of the patient’s plight; she simply does not care about it as such. Her caring takes the abstract form “Whoever needs me, I must help.” Critics claim that exclusive reliance on this form is deficient.

3. Three Lines of Critique  

3.1 Michael Stocker: Motivational Schizophrenia  
Stocker imagines a friend who visits one in hospital solely because friendship demands it. We would feel chilled: the visitor’s eye is on a moral ledger, not on us. Modern moral theories, Stocker concludes, induce a “schizophrenia” between the reasons they acknowledge (friend-promotion, benefit) and the motives they commend (duty). Because harmony between reasons and motives is part of our common-sense ideal, acting from duty alone is morally second-best.

3.2 Richard Railton: Alienation  
Railton’s worry is that deontic motives estrange us from the worldly goods that make life meaningful. If a spouse kisses her partner “out of duty” rather than affection, something deep has gone wrong. Morality should integrate rather than supplant human attachments; otherwise it alienates us from ourselves and from others.

3.3 Lawrence Blum: Moral Perception  
Blum argues that caring motives enable direct perception of morally salient features. One who cares about a child perceives its vulnerability more readily than the cold moralist. Hence purely de dicto orientation threatens practical reliability: lacking the right sentiments, the fetishist may frequently misjudge or overlook what morality in fact requires.

Taken together, these three critiques seek to establish that a motive of duty is (a) affectively impoverished, (b) personally alienating, and (c) epistemically unreliable—and thus cannot ground full moral worth.

4. A Kantian Reply: Respect as Substantive  

Kant famously claims that “nothing can be called good without qualification except a good will,” and a good will acts “from duty.” Many commentators, following Barbara Herman and Allen Wood, have shown that for Kant the motive of duty is not a vacuous abstraction but the agent’s recognition of the unconditional authority of every rational being. To act from respect for the moral law is to acknowledge others as ends in themselves, to bind oneself by principles that any similarly situated rational agent could endorse.

Four aspects of this view counter the fetishism charge.

4.1 Second-Personal Structure  
Duty is not a fascination with a mysterious property called “rightness.” It is acceptance of demands that arise in the second-personal stance, what Stephen Darwall calls the “moral standpoint.” When I help the wounded soldier because duty requires it, I respond to her claim on me as a fellow rational agent. That is a concrete relational attitude, not an occult attraction to the Form of the Good.

4.2 Practical Universality  
Because respect abstracts from idiosyncratic attachments, it secures impartiality. This is not a bug but a virtue: it ensures that patients receive help whether or not the doctor happens to feel compassion that day. Reliability here flows from principle rather than feeling.

4.3 Inner Freedom  
Duty-based action expresses autonomy: the agent governs herself by reasons she can recognise as valid irrespective of inclination. Autonomy, many hold, is an intrinsically valuable achievement, worthy of praise even when other sentiments are absent.

4.4 Integration Rather than Exclusion  
Kant does not prohibit additional motives. Sympathy may “prepare the way” for duty even if only respect has determining causal force. Hence respecting duty need not crowd out affection; it simply guarantees that in cases of conflict the moral law prevails.

These considerations undermine the thought that duty is an empty or fetishistic motive. But does it suffice for moral worth on its own?

5. De dicto Desire without Fetishism  

Philosophers such as Mark Schroeder distinguish two ways a de dicto desire might function. The fetishistic version treats “rightness” as a magnetic property divorced from reasons. The virtuous version functions as a higher-order disposition: “I desire, of any available action φ, to φ if and only if φ is supported by the balance of moral reasons R.” This metadesire is substantive because its satisfaction conditions implicitly import whatever first-order reasons there are. Wanting to do what morality requires, in this sense, just is a standing commitment to respond appropriately to all right-making features, even if those features are not what one currently finds motivating in a first-order way.

To see this, compare epistemic motivation. A mathematician may be moved solely by love of truth: “I want to believe what is mathematically correct.” We do not rebuke her for failing to be aroused by the content of each theorem. Indeed we praise her intellectual integrity. Similarly, why should we censure a moral agent whose overriding concern is that her behaviour answer to whatever moral reasons there are? The charge of fetishism sticks only if we assume that responding to right-making reasons requires being affectively attracted by them. But desiring to conform one’s will to them is precisely one way—arguably the most direct way—of responding.

6. Addressing Worries about Coldness and Reliability  

6.1 Coldness  
Critics fear the coldness of pure duty because they confuse motivational sufficiency with evaluative supremacy. To say duty alone suffices for moral worth is not to deny that richer motivational textures often add value. A friend moved by affection and by duty is, all else equal, better. But sufficiency is a lower bar than optimality. A stripped-down engine can still power the car.

Moreover, duty itself embodies a recognition-respect that is anything but icy. When the surgeon treats each soldier with equal care because each is a legislator in the kingdom of ends, she accords them a dignity higher than any sentimental preference could guarantee. Victims often crave precisely this: not pity, but recognition of their full moral status.

6.2 Reliability  
Empirical literature on “moral identity centrality” shows that those who self-conceive in moral terms are more consistent in helping behaviours across contexts. The de dicto commitment acts as a cognitive filter, prompting its bearer to seek out the operative moral facts. In contrast, empathy is situationally fragile. Thus concern for duty may be more, not less, reliable.

Of course, a purely abstract do-gooder can misapply her principles. Yet the same holds of sentiment-driven agents, whose partialities and biases are well documented. The solution in both cases is moral education and critical reflection, not displacement of one motive by the other.

6.3 Integrity and Non-Accidentality  
An action possesses moral worth only if it non-accidentally conforms to moral reasons. The agent must act because of those reasons, not merely in line with them. A de dicto orientation satisfies this requirement: the agent’s explanatory reason is “it is morally required,” exactly the fact that makes the action right. Contrast an agent who helps because of a lucky impulse. Here the connection is accidental though the outward behaviour coincides. Duty therefore secures the tight explanatory nexus demanded by traditional accounts of moral worth.

7. Three Test Cases  

a. The Impartial Benefactor. A philanthropist is unmoved by vivid TV footage of famine victims but donates because reason tells him it is obligatory. His funds save thousands. Most would applaud, even if we might also wish he felt compassion. Praise is especially warranted because he would have donated had the cameras been off; his motive is principled, not publicity-driven.

b. The Scrupulous Judge. A judge finds a defendant repugnant but sets this aside, decides according to law, and cites his duty to uphold justice. That motive suffices for praiseworthy judicial conduct; indeed any contrary sentiment would be suspect. The case illustrates contexts where duty is the uniquely appropriate ground.

c. The Exhausted Carer. Returning to our field surgeon: when fatigue dulls her empathy, only duty keeps her at the operating table. We do not strip her of moral worth for lacking vivacious compassion; we honour her steadfastness.

These scenarios suggest that common moral practice already credits duty as sufficient—so long as the agent’s commitment is genuine and effective.

8. Alienation Revisited  

Does a duty-bound life estrange one from the goods of love and friendship? Not if the agent’s commitment to morality itself includes a commitment to cultivate such goods where appropriate. Kant urges beneficence, gratitude and sympathetic participation in others’ joy precisely because the moral law obligates us toward the ends of others. Thus treating morality as supreme does not preclude, but rather systematises, our engagement with substantive values.

Moreover, autonomy itself is a good in human life. Persons value being related to one another as free and equal, not as passive recipients of sentiment. A world in which every helper could honestly say “I served you because you are a rational being with inviolable claims” would not be alienating; it would be a world of recognised dignity.

9. The Second-Order Advantage  

A purely sentiment-driven agent must hope that her emotions reliably track moral reasons—but emotions are partial and narrow-band. A de dicto orientation is self-corrective. When the agent suspects that her habitual principles misfire, the very desire to “do what is right” demands that she revise them. Hence duty, though abstract, possesses an internal mechanism of critical checking that first-order motives typically lack.

10. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: De dicto duty is too formal to guide action.  
Reply: Formal desire functions together with deliberative procedures that identify the relevant principles; guidance emerges from their conjunction. Analogy: “Act so as to maximise expected utility” is abstract, yet when joined with evidence and calculation, it guides decisions.

Objection 2: Praiseworthiness requires warmth; duty lacks it.  
Reply: Warmth is an aesthetic or interpersonal desideratum, not a necessary condition of moral worth. We admire firefighters who rescue strangers from burning buildings whether their hearts brim with fellow-feeling or not. Their courage and sense of duty suffice.

Objection 3: Duty can be neurotic, stemming from authoritarian upbringing.  
Reply: When duty springs from fear or heteronomous conditioning, moral worth is indeed absent. My claim is conditional: if the agent’s commitment is autonomous and understood, then it suffices. Pathological variants are excluded by the autonomy condition.

11. Concluding Synthesis  

Moral worth, I have argued, consists in acting because of the facts that make an action right. A de dicto desire to do what morality requires can realise this condition in a non-accidental, autonomy-expressing manner. Far from fetishistic or alienated, such motivation affirms the equal authority of persons and exhibits a universal concern untainted by parochial bias. While richer motivational palettes often add value—friendship enriched by affection, family life by love—the austere commitment to duty is a moral bedrock, capable on its own of sustaining praiseworthy conduct when other motives falter. We therefore should not rescind our admiration from the over-worked surgeon, the even-handed judge, or the principled philanthropist simply because their animating thought is, “This is what morality requires.” In such cases the motive of duty is not a pale substitute for genuine concern; it is a distinct and dignified form of genuine concern—concern for persons as such, under the moral law. That, I submit, is enough for full moral worth.

question: Some philosophers argue that in order for a mental state to be based on epistemic reasons (and thereby have an epistemic status as justified or unjustified), the subject must be consciously aware of those reasons. This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
1. Introduction  

The basing relation is what links the propositional reasons one possesses to the doxastic attitudes one adopts. If S believes that p because S believes that q and (q → p), then S’s belief that p is based on those reasons, and—other things equal—qualifies as justified. A natural thought, entrenched in much of the epistemological tradition, is that basing is an essentially conscious, deliberative affair. It seems that the believer must in some sense “take” q and (q → p) to support p if p is to be epistemically grounded in that support. Yet research in cognitive science paints a very different picture of the mind’s operations. Perceptual modules, statistical learning mechanisms, and fast heuristics routinely generate beliefs and judgments that are epistemically respectable even though the subject lacks any conscious grasp of the information-processing that produced them. Are such outputs genuinely based on reasons, or do they merely causally arise from non-rational mechanisms?  

Answering this question forces us to adjudicate between two broad theses.  

A. The Awareness Requirement (strong form): For S’s attitude toward p to be epistemically based on the reason r, S must consciously represent r as supporting p. Absent such awareness, the attitude is not justified (or at best only accidentally correct).  

B. The Unconscious Basing Thesis: Conscious awareness is not required. What matters is that the relevant information plays the right explanatory and counterfactual role in the cognitive system that produced the attitude; conscious endorsement is optional.  

I will argue that the strong Awareness Requirement is untenable. A weaker accessibility condition is defensible, but once the details are filled in, the position collapses into a form of reliabilism or competence epistemology that concedes basing can occur without occurrent awareness. Thus lack of consciousness does not, in general, preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on reasons.  

2. Motivations for the Awareness Requirement  

Why think consciousness is necessary? Three intertwined considerations dominate the literature.  

a. Transparency and First-Person Authority. Intuitively, when we ask ourselves why we believe as we do, the reasons seem “intellectually transparent.” I can cite the evidence in support of p, and it is natural to suppose that my ability to avow those grounds is partly constitutive of the belief’s justification.  

b. Deontic Intuitions. Many epistemologists conceive justification on the model of epistemic permissibility or responsibility. If being justified is akin to not violating an intellectual obligation, then it must be something within the agent’s purview—something the agent could in principle heed or disregard. Conscious basing satisfies this demand; sub-personal causation apparently does not.  

c. The Taking Condition. John Turri, Susanna Siegel, John McDowell, and others maintain that genuine reasoning involves the subject’s “taking” one proposition to support another. This “taking” is alleged to be conscious or at least poised for conscious endorsement. Without it, the transition from reasons to conclusion is brute, not rational.  

3. Three Problems for the Strong Awareness Requirement  

Each motivation has force, but all run into trouble once we examine actual cases of belief formation.  

Problem 1: Perceptual Justification. When I perceive a red cup, my belief that “there is a red cup in front of me” is surely justified. Yet few of us are consciously aware of the complex reasons (retinal stimulation patterns, low-level edge detection, color constancy mechanisms) that sub-serve that belief. The proponent of the Awareness Requirement will reply that the relevant reason is simply “I see a red cup,” a fact available to consciousness. But what does “I see” add? If it is merely the experience itself, then the subject is not aware of a proposition that serves as a premise; rather, the experience non-conceptually presents the object. Our ordinary perceptual beliefs appear justified by processes of which we have no reflective grasp.  

Problem 2: Implicit Statistical Inference. Consider the airline baggage screener who, after thousands of exposures, becomes highly reliable at distinguishing dangerous from benign images but cannot articulate the cues she relies on. Or the “chicken sexer” who accurately sorts male from female chicks within milliseconds. Their judgments manifest a competence shaped by experience; the underpinning information is appropriately responsive to evidence; yet it eludes consciousness. If conscious awareness were required, we would have to brand these agents’ beliefs unjustified, a verdict that flies in the face of both intuitive and theoretical desiderata.  

Problem 3: Computational Tractability. From a cognitive-scientific perspective, most of the mind’s epistemic labor occurs below the level of conscious awareness. If epistemic status tracked only what rises to the surface, justification would be hostage to the severe bandwidth limitations of consciousness (about 40–60 bits per second). We would have to declare the bulk of our perceptual, memorial, and linguistic beliefs unjustified. Such skepticism is not only implausible; it undermines the practical purpose of epistemic evaluations.  

4. Distinguishing Kinds of Awareness  

Defenders of the Awareness Requirement often retreat to weaker notions. They may concede that occurrent phenomenology is unnecessary, insisting instead on:  

• Access Awareness: The subject could, by reflection, become aware of the reason.  
• Virtual Awareness: The reason is represented in working memory, though attention may not be focused on it.  
• Dispositional Awareness: The subject possesses the concepts needed to bring the reason to consciousness if asked.  

Yet each weakening dilutes the original thesis. Access awareness collapses into something like mentalist evidentialism: what matters is that the subject’s total mental life contains the reason, where “mental” ranges over occurrent and dispositional states. But once dispositional states count, most sub-personal representations will qualify, provided they are appropriately integrated with the person-level system. The awareness constraint thus ceases to exclude unconscious basing and loses its critical bite.  

5. Causal vs. Doxastic Basing  

It is common to distinguish two senses of “because” in epistemology.  

• Causal basing: r caused S to believe p.  
• Doxastic basing: S believes p because S takes r to support p.  

The Awareness Requirement attaches to doxastic basing. However, many epistemologists now argue that doxastic basing, so construed, is neither necessary nor sufficient for justification. Timothy Williamson notes that a true clairvoyant who consciously “takes” random inner hunches to certify distant events is not justified, whereas a normal perceiver whose brain causally tracks the environment is. Causal relevance can confer justification when the cause instantiates the right epistemic function, even if the subject is not aware of it.  

6. Control, Responsibility, and Credit  

A lingering intuition is that epistemic praise or blame must latch onto features under the agent’s control. If I am blind to my own reasons, how can I deserve credit for believing well? Virtue reliabilists reply that credit accrues to competences rather than to conscious performances per se. An archer earns praise for hitting the target even if much of the motor execution is automatized. Likewise, an epistemic agent merits credit when her cognitive faculties—shaped by training, evolution, or deliberate practice—reliably link truth-conducive reasons to beliefs. Conscious reflection can enhance or impair these competences, but is not the sole locus of epistemic agency.  

Nor is the absence of consciousness tantamount to lack of control. Automatic processes are typically flexible, learnable, and subject to higher-level modulation. The baggage screener can recalibrate her standards after feedback, indicating that she retains indirect control over the inferences her system draws. Control is distributed across time and levels of processing, not confined to moment-to-moment awareness.  

7. The Epistemic Role of Conscious Reflection  

Although I reject the claim that consciousness is required for basing, the phenomenology of reasoning still has epistemic value. Conscious reflection serves at least three functions:  

1. Error Correction. Explicit reasoning can uncover conflicts, detect defeaters, and override heuristics prone to systematic bias.  
2. Communicability. Justification often matters in social contexts—testimony, pedagogy, scientific explanation—where reasons must be articulated. Awareness facilitates this transmission.  
3. Systematic Expansion. Complex, multi-premise reasoning exceeding the capacity of intuitive systems demands deliberate symbol manipulation.  

Thus consciousness is a virtue amplifier, not a sine qua non of epistemic status.  

8. A Competence-Constitutive Account of Basing  

How, then, should we understand basing without awareness? I propose the following sufficient condition:  

CB (Competence Basing). S’s belief that p is epistemically based on r just in case:  
i. r is represented (consciously or unconsciously) within S’s cognitive system;  
ii. The system contains a competence that maps representations of type r to belief that p in a way that is sensitive to the epistemic relation between r and p;  
iii. The mapping is appropriately integrated with S’s higher-level cognitive economy (e.g., defeaters can be registered; the belief can guide action; S can, given normal prompting, update or withdraw p when r changes).  

Condition (ii) secures non-accidentality: the competence must treat r as a reason, not merely as a cause correlated with p. Condition (iii) ensures personal-level ownership. Basing, on this view, is realized by the functioning of reasons-sensitive competences, and these competences need not issue in conscious awareness at the time of belief formation.  

This account explains why the airline screener’s judgment is justified: it is the manifestation of a finely-tuned visual-categorization competence sensitive to diagnostic cues. It also explains why the clairvoyant is not justified: the mechanism linking her hunches to distant truths is not a competence responsive to reasons; it is an uncontrolled, epistemically opaque faculty.  

9. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The Taking Objection. Without conscious “taking,” no genuine reasoning occurs; the competence story reduces reasons to causes.  

Reply: The key is to distinguish between subpersonal causes that merely covary with truth and subpersonal capacities that are themselves reasons-responsive. A competence embodies an internal model of the world, encoding conditional dependencies (often probabilistic). When that model is exercised, the system proceeds because it treats the input as evidence. In virtue-theoretic terms, it manifests “epistemic sensitivity”—a form of taking, albeit one not always available to introspection.  

Objection 2: The Swamping Problem. If justification rests solely on reliable competences, then knowledge and justified belief reduce to reliability, failing to account for the special value of epistemic achievements that involve understanding one’s grounds.  

Reply: The competence view does not deny that reflective awareness adds epistemic value; it denies only that such awareness is necessary for minimal justification. We may define higher-grade statuses—understanding, wisdom, reflectively endorsed knowledge—that require consciousness. But ordinary justified belief, sufficient for most practical purposes, can be achieved without it.  

Objection 3: The New Evil Demon. A victim of a Cartesian demon may have all the same conscious experiences yet lack reliable competences. If reliability is necessary, the view incorrectly withholds justification.  

Reply: The competence account can be internalist about possession of the competence rather than about its external success. What matters is that the cognitive system functions as it ordinarily does given its design environment, not that it happens to succeed in the actual world. The demon victim’s perceptual system is still epistemically apt in this sense; its failures are due to adversarial manipulation, not to defects in the competence. Thus justification is preserved.  

10. A Taxonomy of Epistemic Statuses  

The debate often conflates distinct normative categories. We can sharpen matters by distinguishing:  

• Prima facie Justification: absence of defeaters, competence functioning properly.  
• Reflective Justification: the agent can cite (some of) her reasons on demand.  
• Understanding: grasp of the explanatory nexus linking reasons to conclusion.  

On this hierarchy, conscious awareness is necessary for reflective justification and understanding, but not for prima facie justification. The latter suffices for knowledge on many theories, whereas the higher statuses ground deeper intellectual virtues.  

11. Implications for Modular and Automatic Processes  

Research on face recognition, syntax parsing, intuitive physics, and causal inference supports the conclusion that humans possess myriad domain-specific systems that extract structured information and draw inferences without conscious oversight. Denying epistemic standing to these outputs would gut human cognition of warrant. Instead, we should treat these systems as legitimate bearers of reason-guided competences. They forge the substructure upon which deliberate reasoning later builds.  

However, not all automatic processes are epistemically benign. Confirmation-bias modules, stereotype activation, and wishful‐thinking mechanisms also operate unconsciously but are responsive to motivational cues rather than to truth. The competence framework distinguishes the epistemically virtuous from the vicious by focusing on what the system is functionally tuned to do: track truth versus serve self-enhancement goals.  

12. The Future of Epistemic Agency  

Accepting unconscious basing reshapes our conception of intellectual responsibility. Epistemic self-improvement is not restricted to polishing explicit argumentation; it includes cultivating automatic competences (e.g., improving statistical intuitions, debiasing perception) through training, environment design, and social scaffolding. The locus of responsibility shifts from momentary conscious acts to long-term regulation of one’s cognitive architecture.  

Moreover, as artificial intelligence integrates with human cognition, many of our “reasons” will be processed by external prostheses opaque to introspection. An epistemology that ties justification to occurrent awareness risks obsolescence. Competence-centered theories accommodate these developments: what matters is that the combined human-machine system embodies truth-tracking competences and remains sensitive to defeaters, not that the human can verbalize every computational step.  

13. Conclusion  

Conscious awareness of one’s reasons is epistemically valuable, but it is not the litmus test for basing. The strong Awareness Requirement falters in the face of everyday perceptual belief, skilled expertise, and the empirical realities of cognition. A more plausible picture sees basing as the manifestation of reasons-responsive competences, many of which belong to fast, automatic, and frequently unconscious systems. Such competences confer prima facie justification provided they are properly integrated into the agent’s cognitive economy and remain amenable to higher-level monitoring and correction.  

Thus lack of conscious awareness does not, in itself, preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on reasons. What is essential is that the reasons be appropriately processed by epistemic competences whose function is to connect truth-indicative information to belief. Conscious reflection refines, articulates, and sometimes overrides these processes, but it need not be present at the moment of belief formation for justification to arise.
