Phenomenologists (e.g., McDowell, Audi) emphasise a distinctive “appearing-true” phenomenology that accompanies conscious appreciation of reasons, marking them as normative.  

Each line of thought has force, but each admits of challenges once we attend to real-world cognition.  

4. Empirical Counter-Cases  

4.1 Implicit Inference in Perception. Perceptual psychologists routinely model vision as probabilistic inference from sensory input to distal causes. When you see a red tomato, your brain integrates information about wavelength distributions, lighting conditions, depth cues, and prior probabilities. Most of this occurs in cortical areas to which you lack introspective access. Yet the resulting perceptual belief (“there’s a red tomato”) is paradigmatically justified. To deny that it is based on the brain’s reasons—light of wavelength λ reflected from the object, etc.—seems metaphysically extravagant.  

4.2 Expert Pattern Recognition. Consider “chicken-sexers,” wine tasters, or chess grandmasters. Through prolonged exposure they acquire an ability to classify tokens with impressive reliability and speed, long before they can articulate the cues they use. Gary Klein’s firefighters decide whether to abandon a burning building by running mental simulations that remain beneath consciousness. If the awareness requirement were correct, we would have to say that the expert’s judgment is unjustified—or at best accidentally correct—until she introspectively discerns the underlying reasons. That is counter-intuitive and contrary to our practice of crediting expertise.  

4.3 Everyday Automaticity. Ordinary language comprehension involves syntactic parsing, disambiguation, and pragmatic enrichment, none of which is phenomenally accessible in detail. But we still regard the resulting beliefs as epistemically warranted, assuming the linguistic environment is co-operative.  

In each domain, lack of conscious access does not seem to strip the belief of its epistemic pedigree. What these cases suggest is that basing can be subpersonal yet still normatively relevant.  

5. A Non-Conscious Basing Account  

How might one reconcile non-conscious basing with normative epistemology? A promising strategy generalises ideas from reliabilism while preserving a role for reasons.  

5.1 The Reliable-Reasoning Hybrid.  

(i) Basing condition: S’s belief that p is epistemically based on R if (a) R (a propositional content or informational state) causally sustains S’s belief via a process that embodies the rational connection between R and p, and (b) the process is reliably sensitive to the rational relevance of R.  

(ii) Justification condition: S’s belief is prima facie justified if it is based (in the above sense) on a set of true rationally-supportive propositions.  

On this view, conscious awareness is sufficient but not necessary for (a) and (b). When the agent is aware that R obtains and infers p, the condition is obviously met. But when a visual module executes Bayesian updating, the internal mapping embodies the same rational support: likelihood ratios trigger posterior probability estimates. Reliability ensures that accidental correlations are weeded out.  

5.2 Personal-Level Ownership. To meet the “responsibility” objection, we add an ownership constraint: although the inferential steps can be subpersonal, the resulting belief must be integrated into the agent’s personal-level economy in a way sensitive to higher-order correction. That is, if S acquires defeaters or learns that the process is generally unreliable in the present context, she is required (on pain of epistemic blame) to revise or withhold the belief. Ownership, not initial awareness, secures the agent’s normative standing.  

5.3 Functional Accessibility vs. Phenomenal Awareness. Instead of requiring “accessibility on demand” in the sense of immediate introspection, we can require functional accessibility: the informational basis is stored in such a way that it can, with effort or under prompting, be brought to consciousness or at least to explicit representation. Many modular outputs satisfy this. Experts often learn to articulate their implicit criteria when they undertake reflective training. Even when articulation fails, post-hoc testing can reveal sensitivity to the relevant evidence, supplying confirmation that the belief was produced for the right epistemic reasons.  

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The Explanatory Gap. How can subpersonal events be “reasons” rather than bare causes if the agent does not treat them as such? Reply: The distinction between reason and cause is normative, but normativity can be grounded in role rather than phenomenology. A cause counts as a reason when its causal operation maps onto the logical support relation in the relevant environment. An inference engine that encodes Bayes’ Rule treats likelihood ratios as weightier than mere salience, even if the agent is oblivious to the code.  

Objection 2: No Epistemic Credit Without Awareness. Credit theories insist that knowledge requires cognitive agency not mere happenstance; automatism seems to remove agency. Reply: Agency admits degrees. The agent trains or maintains the relevant module, keeps herself in a conducive environment, and stands ready to heed error signals. That suffices for partial credit. Moreover, attributability does not require transparent deliberation; otherwise we would deny knowledge of perceptual basics to young children or animals.  

Objection 3: The Swamping Problem. If reliability alone suffices, why not dispense with reasons altogether? Reply: The hybrid proposal preserves reasons at the explanatory level: what mediates reliability is the implicit tracking of evidence. A purely brute reliable process (say, a clairvoyant faculty) lacks that evidential mediation; it would fail condition (a), because the causal path would not embody the rational connection between input and output. The difference between a clairvoyant and a chicken-sexer is precisely that the latter’s process covaries with reasons in virtue of discriminating features that are evidence, whereas the clairvoyant’s faculty is a black box.  

Objection 4: The Diachronic Challenge. Suppose S cannot, even in principle, access or reconstruct the subpersonal grounds. Then S cannot defend the belief under critical scrutiny, and so lacks second-order justification. Reply: This reveals a distinction between basic and reflective justification. Basic justification attaches at the time the belief is formed. Reflective justification concerns how S responds to challenges. A belief can be basically justified yet vulnerable to reflective defeat. The framework accommodates this: expert snap-judgments are basically justified; but if S is later pressed for reasons and cannot supply any, rational humility may require suspension.  

7. Varieties of Epistemic Assessment  

Zooming out, we can systematise different normative statuses:  

1. Basic (first-order) justification: grounded in non-deviant, reliability-plus-rational-tracking processes, independent of awareness.  
2. Reflective entitlement: requiring that the agent can, upon reflection, reconstruct or locate the basis.  
3. Responsibility or blameworthiness: governed by whether the agent is disposed to heed defeaters and to monitor her cognitive capacities.  

Conscious awareness is crucial for (2) and (3), but not for (1). Since a belief’s status as “epistemically justified” often targets basic justification, lack of awareness need not preclude epistemic basing.  

8. Conciliatory Notes and Residual Limits  

The conclusion so far vindicates non-conscious basing, yet it would be rash to claim that awareness is never required. Three residual roles remain:  

a. High-Level Theoretical Reasoning. Complex, multi-premise deductions, policy decisions, and conceptual analyses often exceed the capacity of subpersonal modules; conscious deliberation is indispensable.  

b. Epistemic Self-Improvement. Reflective access allows agents to diagnose systematic biases, recalibrate heuristics, and share reasons with others—important for the social dimension of epistemic norms.  

c. Defeater Management. While initial formation can be unconscious, later confrontation with counter-evidence frequently demands conscious engagement.  

Thus the best position is pluralist: awareness is not necessary for initial basing, but it is instrumentally and normatively valuable for the ongoing governance of belief.  

9. Conclusion  

Does lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons? The answer is No. Empirical evidence and theoretical considerations jointly show that subpersonal processes can instantiate the basing relation in a manner sufficient for basic justification. The motivations behind the awareness requirement—guidance, non-accidentality, normativity—can all be met by appealing to reliable, rationally-sensitive processes and by linking personal-level responsibility to higher-order correction rather than to initial awareness. Conscious access remains significant for other epistemic goods (reflective assurance, communal transmission, self-regulation), but it is not a prerequisite for basing itself. Accordingly, modular, automatic cognition can play an authentic epistemic role, and epistemology must make room for the pervasive, subterranean intelligence of the mind.

question: Some philosophers argue that in order for a mental state to be based on epistemic reasons (and thereby have an epistemic status as justified or unjustified), the subject must be consciously aware of those reasons. This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
In contemporary epistemology the notion of an epistemic basing relation plays the pivotal role of connecting an agent’s reasons with the doxastic attitudes that those reasons are supposed to support. One of the most vexed issues about basing is whether the subject must be consciously aware of her reasons for the resulting belief to be justified. The view that some form of consciousness is required has illustrious defenders—Roderick Chisholm, Laurence BonJour, Richard Feldman and Earl Conee all defend versions of access internalism under which a subject’s justification depends on what she is “internally” in a position to know or grasp on reflection. But their stance sits uneasily with a picture of the mind that attributes much ordinary and scientific cognition to modular, automatic, and frequently unconscious processes. If, as cognitive science suggests, a large fraction of our perception, language‐processing, and even ordinary inference is accomplished subpersonally, then it looks as if consciousness is at best sporadic and often epiphenomenal; yet in those very episodes the resulting beliefs seem justified or unjustified in recognisably epistemic ways. The core question, therefore, is whether lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons precludes a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons. I shall argue that it does not. Conscious awareness has an important but non-basic role to play: it can enhance the quality of basing by enabling second-order assessment, but epistemic basing itself—understood as the relation that turns available reasons into the grounds of belief—can occur wholly subpersonally and unconsciously. I first clarify the dialectic, then examine four arguments offered for the consciousness requirement; finally I advance a positive picture of subpersonal basing, defend it against two pressing objections, and end with an account of why conscious reflection, though dispensable for basing, remains epistemically valuable.

1. Clarifying the dialectic

Call the Consciousness Requirement (CR): Necessarily, if S’s belief that p is justified by reasons R, S is (or could be upon reflection without new experience) consciously aware of R. Its denial is AC (Anti-Consciousness): Some beliefs can be justified by reasons R even though S lacks the relevant conscious access.

CR combines two theses: (i) conscious accessibility suffices for justification; (ii) conscious accessibility is necessary for basing. Only (ii) concerns us. Many externalists deny both, but one could accept (i) and reject (ii): awareness is sufficient but not necessary. To evaluate (ii) we need a clearer conception of basing. Every viable theory must secure two desiderata:

a. Causal condition: R must causally influence the formation or sustainment of the belief that p.
b. Rational condition: The influence must be of the right kind—roughly, a respect of the dependency that constitutes rational support.

A pure causal theory satisfies (a) but not (b), since deviant causal chains can meet (a) without conveying justification. A pure psychologised reason‐relation risks collapsing (b) into (i), rendering subpersonal processes irrelevant. The challenge is to hold on to both.

2. Four arguments for a consciousness requirement

2.1 The responsibility argument
Epistemic justification plausibly grounds epistemic responsibility: we criticise an agent for believing irresponsibly when she declines to heed counterevidence or forgoes grounds available to her. Responsibility, the argument continues, presupposes control, and control in turn demands conscious awareness of what one is doing. Therefore justified beliefs must spring from reasons the agent can consciously recognise.

This argument conflates two notions of responsibility. There is accountability responsibility—our practice of blaming, praising, demanding reasons—which indeed presupposes the capacity to give reasons on demand. But there is also attributability responsibility: the sense in which a belief expresses the subject’s epistemic character and is assessable as epistemically good or bad even if the agent cannot offer a defence. Suppose I form a belief that a car is red based on ordinary colour vision; when later challenged under unusual bluish lighting, I am initially at a loss to explain why I believed the car red, yet the belief was perfectly in order. I may acquire accountability later by reflecting on colour constancy, but my lack of initial awareness does not undermine the attributability of justification. Responsibility at this more basic level does not require contemporaneous awareness; it requires only that the belief flows from epistemically reliable and reasons-responsive mechanisms that are part of the agent.

2.2 The regress argument
If unconscious reasons could justify, one might press: what justifies the subject in relying on those reasons? If the subject is not aware of them, she cannot be justified in taking them to be good; hence either a vicious regress or an explanatory gap. Conscious awareness purportedly halts the regress: once S “sees” that her premises support the conclusion, no further story is needed.

But the regress here is illusory. A basing relation is not a belief in reasons; it is a non-doxastic causal‐cum-rational relation. When you visually perceive a tomato, the retinal stimulation causes a perceptual representation which in turn causes the belief “there is a tomato.” The justificatory work is performed by the reliability of the chain and by the fact that the perceptual state embeds information that tomatoes are present. No additional meta-justification is required. Conscious awareness of the percept might help one recognise that the percept is good evidence, yet the evidentiality is already there, contained in the informational content of the perceptual state. The regress ends at subpersonal informational links, not at conscious inspection.

2.3 The phenomenological argument
Discerning reasons, some claim, has a characteristic feel: the “aha” of seeing that p follows from q, or the seeming that one’s sensory experience presents a table. Justification supervenes on such seemings; without them there is no “for-me-ness” and hence no justificatory force for the subject.

While epistemic seemings do furnish paradigm cases of conscious basing, their phenomenology is at best a contingent mark, not an essential feature. Consider blindsight patients who lack phenomenal vision in a blind field yet can reliably guess the presence of shapes. Are their guesses unjustified? If a normal perceiver’s belief is justified by the same information stream, the mere absence of visual phenomenology in blindsight cannot by itself rob the information of its epistemic character—unless we adopt an implausible phenomenalist chauvinism. Similar points apply to implicit statistical learning: one can detect a complex pattern without noticing how one does so, yet the pattern’s presence is genuine evidence.

2.4 The dialectical argument
Internalists maintain that justification is essentially perspectival—something the subject can appreciate. In epistemic debates we rely on the method of “citing reasons,” so any adequate theory must preserve the ordinary practice of asking people why they believe as they do. Thus conscious access is indispensable to the concept of a reason.

This argument confuses having a reason with citing a reason. The practice of asking for reasons is reparative: it serves to check whether a person’s belief formed properly; it is not constitutive of basing itself. A competent agent can often supply proxy reasons ex post; yet even when she cannot, we do not automatically dismiss the belief. When the car mechanic says, “I don’t know—I just hear the engine and can tell the timing belt is off,” we grant some justification provided her track record is good. She cannot cite the acoustic regularities, but her auditory module has registered them subpersonally. The dialectical practice presupposes that such tacit reasons exist and are lawfully connected to beliefs, otherwise requesting verbal reasons would neither confirm nor undermine them.

3. A positive model: Subpersonal reasons and teleological causation

To make AC plausible we need a positive picture that honours both causal and rational requirements. I sketch a teleofunctional model:

Step 1: Information‐bearing states. Cognitive systems generate internal states that carry information about the environment. A perceptual representation R carries the information that p iff, under normal conditions of the system’s proper functioning, R occurs only when p is true.

Step 2: Functional mapping. The system has been selected—by phylogeny, ontogeny, or learning—to use R as a premise in producing belief that p (or some related proposition). This teleofunctional mapping endows the causal link with epistemic significance: the link exists for the purpose of tracking truth.

Step 3: Basing. S’s belief that p is based on reasons R when (i) the causal history of the belief token includes R in the etiology; (ii) R bears information that p; (iii) condition (ii) is the very teleofunction for which R is exploited by S’s cognitive system. When these obtain, the belief is epistemically justified to the degree that the mapping is reliable and environment-congruent.

Conscious awareness need not enter, for the crucial work is done by information content and proper function. When awareness is present it can itself be an information‐bearing state, enhancing reliability via metacognitive monitoring; but it is not mandatory for basing.

4. Defence against two objections

4.1 The cognitive integration objection
One might grant that subpersonal information can guide behaviour, yet deny that it counts as the subject’s reason. Reasons must be agentially integrated—available for rational control, inference, and deliberation. Subpersonal modules are too encapsulated to satisfy agential integration, so their outputs are at most causes, not reasons.

Reply: Agential integration is not binary but graded. Visual information is initially processed in V1, then in higher areas, eventually delivering a conceptualised percept to working memory, which can figure in explicit reasoning. At each stage the information is more integrated; yet justification accrues already early on. When you glance at a bird and immediately believe it is a robin, the first milliseconds involve encapsulated processes, but the resulting belief is yours. The ownership of a cognitive event derives from the fact that it belongs to the coordinated information-processing architecture that embodies the subject’s epistemic agency. Ownership does not require contemporaneous introspective access, only that the process be integrated into the standing disposition to revise beliefs in the light of further information. Modular outputs typically satisfy this disposition, as shown when new sensory evidence corrects the belief.

4.2 The New Evil Demon variant
Imagine a subject in an evil demon world whose perceptual modules function normally but whose environment is systematically deceiving. Because proper function teleology is environment-relative, it appears her subpersonal reasons fail to be truth-conducive, yet intuitively her beliefs are still justified. Do we not need conscious awareness to salvage her justification?

We should decouple teleology from actual reliability and attach it instead to “normal functioning according to design plan,” where the design plan is specified by evolutionary history or learning history, not by the current environment. The demon victim’s modules still possess the function of truth tracking even though frustrated. What matters is that the cognitive system aims at truth; awareness adds nothing. Thus subpersonal basing survives demon scenarios.

5. The epistemic value of consciousness

Although the lack of conscious awareness does not preclude basing, consciousness plays important epistemic roles:

a. Error correction. Metacognitive access allows higher-order monitoring that can veto or revise first-order outputs. This reduces susceptibility to certain biases, thereby indirectly elevating justification.

b. Communicative coordination. Conscious reasons can be shared, teaching others to track truth; this enhances group epistemics.

c. Reflective extension. Complex symbolic reasoning requires working‐memory manipulation of explicit items; here conscious awareness is functionally indispensable, not for justification per se but for widening the range of justifiable beliefs.

Hence awareness is instrumentally but not constitutively tied to basing.

6. Conclusion

The intuition that reasons must be consciously accessible derives from conflating our practices of asking for reasons with the metaphysics of possession of reasons. A closer look at perception, implicit inference, and automatic cognition reveals vast realms where agents enjoy epistemic standings without concurrent awareness of the grounds. A teleofunctional information-theoretic account secures the causal and rational dimensions of the basing relation while omitting a consciousness requirement. Conscious access strengthens and extends our epistemic repertoire, but its absence need not bar a belief from being properly based. Therefore, lack of conscious awareness does not preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on its reasons, though it may diminish the agent’s capacity for higher-order appraisal and dialectical defence.

question: Some philosophers argue that in order for a mental state to be based on epistemic reasons (and thereby have an epistemic status as justified or unjustified), the subject must be consciously aware of those reasons. This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
Automatic Minds and the Space of Reasons  
                             Does Conscious Awareness Matter for Epistemic Basing?  


1. Introduction  

Philosophers working in epistemology and the philosophy of mind agree on at least one fundamental point: the difference between a lucky true belief and a justified true belief is that the latter is related to the subject’s epistemic reasons in the right way.  The nature of that “right way”—the basing relation—has proved notoriously elusive.  Among the most entrenched proposals is the “Awareness Principle”:  

      Awareness Principle.  A mental state S of a subject x is epistemically based on a reason r only if x is consciously aware of r (or of the fact that r is a good reason for S).  

If the principle is correct, then modular, automatic, or otherwise unconscious cognitive processes cannot by themselves confer epistemic justification; at most they provide the raw materials on which conscious, reflective reasoning operates.  Conversely, if unconscious basing is possible, then large swathes of human (and animal) information-processing—perception, language comprehension, memory retrieval, statistical learning—fall squarely within the “space of reasons.”  

My aim in what follows is to assess whether lack of conscious awareness precludes epistemic basing.  I shall proceed in five stages.  (i) I clarify the target notions of ‘reason’ and ‘basing.’  (ii) I present the main argument for the Awareness Principle.  (iii) I raise three lines of challenge: from subpersonal cognition, from ordinary unreflective reasoning, and from normative adequacy.  (iv) I sketch a positive model—“The Dual-Level Account”—that explains how unconscious basing can nonetheless be distinctively epistemic.  (v) I defend the model against two worries: deviant causation and the loss of personal-level rationality.  The conclusion is that conscious awareness is not necessary for epistemic basing, though it plays an important regulative role.

2. Reasons, Motivations, and Basing  

We must distinguish among:  

a. Explanatory or motivating reasons: the considerations in light of which the subject forms or maintains her attitude.  
b. Justifying reasons: the facts that make the attitude epistemically appropriate.  
c. The basing relation: the relation that must obtain for the first kind of reasons to coincide with, or at least align with, the second.  

A paradigm case: I see steam rising from the street and believe that it just rained.  The perception of steam is my explanatory reason; the fact that steam is evidence of recent precipitation is my justifying reason.  For the belief to be justified, the perception must not only cause the belief but do so in an epistemically proper way—not via hypnosis, wishful thinking, or some way that bypasses my epistemic agency.  

The Awareness Principle is best understood as a claim about explanatory reasons: unless I am consciously aware of r, r cannot be the consideration “in light of which” I adopt S.  A status-tracking element is added: only if r is the right sort of reason (truth-conducive, undefeated, etc.) does S become justified.  In short, awareness is supposed to be a gatekeeper that prevents mere causal explanation from counting as epistemic basing.

3. The Case for Awareness  

Proponents of the Awareness Principle offer at least four intertwined considerations.

3.1. Phenomenological Intuition  

When I consciously deliberate—“It is cloudy, so I should bring an umbrella”—the feel of actively endorsing the premise as my reason seems constitutive of rational belief-formation.  In the absence of any such phenomenology, the belief would seem unreasoned or, at best, a lucky hunch.

3.2. Agential Control  

Epistemic responsibility, on many accounts, requires that the believer exercise control over her cognitive attitudes.  Control, in turn, seems to demand awareness of what one is doing.  One cannot be blameworthy (or praiseworthy) for relying on considerations of which one has no inkling.

3.3. Transparency of Justification  

An internalist dictum holds that whenever a subject is justified, she must have access—via reflection—to what justifies her.  Without access, there would be an in-principle gap between justification and the agent’s perspective, violating the idea that justification is a perspective-dependent status.

3.4. The Regress Worry  

If basing could occur unconsciously, how do we ensure it is not “deviant” causation?  The easiest way, advocates say, is to require that the subject herself be able to cite the reason.  That gives us an explanatory stopping point.

Although powerful, each of these lines of thought is contestable.  Let us examine three broad families of counterexamples and then draw some lessons.

4. Three Challenges to the Awareness Principle  

4.1. Subpersonal Cognitive Science  

Human vision is mediated by multiple encapsulated subsystems that convert proximal stimulation into richly articulated percepts.  I open my eyes and automatically form the belief “There is a red cup on the table.”  The process is swift, involuntary, and (largely) inaccessible to consciousness.  Yet the belief is paradigmatically justified, and it is justified because it is based on the visual information delivered by those subsystems.  If awareness of each contributory representation were required, virtually no perceptual belief would be justified.

One might object that while we are unaware of the intermediate processing, we are aware of the visual appearance—the cup’s looking red—and that appearance is our conscious reason.  But empirical work on change blindness and rapid-scene perception shows that we often fixate on a target without any stable phenomenology of color, shape, or location.  Still, the resulting beliefs are supported by reasons: retinal stimulation, feature detection, probabilistic inference, etc., none of which is consciously available.

4.2. Ordinary Unreflective Reasoning  

Consider a skilled chess player who, after a quick glance at the board, moves a bishop and later articulates, “It just felt like the right move.”  Subsequent analysis reveals that the move blocks a discovered attack and sets up mate in three.  The player’s choice was not blind luck; it was informed by tacit pattern-recognition acquired through thousands of prior games.  Here again, the justificatory basis is present—structural features of the position—yet conscious awareness is absent at the moment of decision.

The same holds for driving, speaking a native language, or diagnosing a familiar illness.  We rely on statistically grounded representations that rarely rise to the level of awareness.  To declare all such beliefs unjustified until we rehearse them in inner speech would flout common epistemic practice.

4.3. Normative Adequacy and Epistemic Defeat  

Imagine a competent but lazy detective who receives excellent testimony that the suspect is innocent yet, without consciously thinking about the testimony’s content, retains her belief in guilt.  Later she is challenged and becomes aware that the testimony defeats her earlier evidence.  Only then does she revise her view.  It seems right to say the detective’s belief was unjustified after the defeating testimony arrived, even during the period when she lacked conscious awareness of it.  But if awareness were necessary for defeat as well as positive justification, we could not explain the loss of entitlement.  This suggests that epistemic statuses supervene on reason-relations that may outrun conscious access.

5. A Dual-Level Account of Unconscious Basing  

How, then, can we preserve the intuition that justification is reason-dependent while allowing unconscious basing?  I propose the following model.

5.1. Personal vs. Subpersonal Levels  

Call mental states “personal-level” when they are attributable to the agent as such—beliefs, desires, intentions—and “subpersonal” when they belong to the information-processing subsystems posited by cognitive science.  Personal-level states need not be conscious (e.g., standing beliefs I’m not thinking about), but they are available for rational control and report.  Subpersonal states typically are neither.

5.2. The Basing Constraint  

A personal-level belief B is epistemically based on reason r just in case:  

(i) r is represented by some component of the subject’s cognitive system;  
(ii) the tokening of r non-deviantly causes B via a process that functions to track the truth relative to the relevant domain;  
(iii) the process is part of the subject’s overall epistemic agency, in the sense that it is integrated with other belief-forming mechanisms and subject to higher-level regulation (e.g., attention allocation, learning, error correction).  

Condition (i) allows r to be personal-level or subpersonal; conscious awareness is optional.  Condition (ii) screens off deviant causal chains.  Condition (iii) grounds responsibility: although the agent may not be aware of r, she can in principle monitor, test, or recalibrate the system that produces B—much as she can decide to wear her glasses or adjust the lighting to improve vision.

5.3. Epistemic Justification  

Justification accrues to B when its subpersonal basing process is (a) reliably truth-conducive in normal conditions and (b) not defeated by available information.  The defeat clause respects cases like the lazy detective: unheeded but registered testimony can undermine earlier warrant.

The Dual-Level Account thus honors the role of reasons while rejecting the claim that reasons must be occurrent in consciousness.

6. Replies to Two Objections  

6.1. Deviant Causation Revisited  

Suppose a subject is hypnotized: the hypnotist utters “The sky is blue,” which non-consciously triggers the subject to believe “It will rain tomorrow.”  Condition (ii) is violated because the process does not function to track the truth of weather propositions; it is an accidental causal chain.  Hence the belief is not based on the utterance in the epistemic sense, even though it is causally dependent.  Conscious awareness is unnecessary; functional teleology does the work.

6.2. Loss of Personal-Level Rationality  

Critics worry that if subpersonal processing suffices, rationality is no longer the agent’s achievement.  But notice: on the Dual-Level Account, epistemic agency involves controlling the conditions under which one’s automatic modules operate, deciding whether to rely on them, and integrating their outputs with further reasoning.  A driver who turns on the cruise control is still accountable for reckless speeding; likewise, a believer who entrusts perception or memory remains epistemically responsible.

Moreover, consciousness can still enhance rationality.  When the chess master later analyzes the position in slow motion, she may discover higher-order reasons that override her first impulse.  The theory does not deny value to reflective awareness; it denies only its necessity for every instance of basing.

7. Weighing the Arguments  

Let us return to the considerations adduced for the Awareness Principle.

   Phenomenology: While the phenomenology of conscious inference is compelling, it is a guide to only a subset of justification.  Much of cognition lacks distinctive phenomenology yet is obviously epistemic.  

   Agential Control: Control can be indirect, operating through adoption, maintenance, and revision of cognitive policies (e.g., trusting vision, distrusting gossip).  Indirect control suffices for responsibility in many domains (consider reliance on calculators or instruments).

   Transparency: Internalism need not require presently conscious access; dispositional access, the ability to call reasons to mind if needed, is enough.  Vision satisfies dispositional access insofar as one can, by attending and reporting, make some justificatory features explicit.

   Regress: The non-deviance and teleology conditions proposed above provide a principled stopping point without appealing to consciousness.

Hence the cumulative case for the Awareness Principle is undercut.

8. Where Does That Leave Modularity?  

Fodor famously characterized modules as domain-specific, informationally encapsulated, and mandatory in operation.  On the Dual-Level Account, a module can supply epistemic reasons—edge-detectors in the visual system deliver information about boundaries; the language module produces syntactic parses.  To the extent the modules are the product of evolution and individual learning aimed at veridical representation, their outputs qualify as prima facie justifiers.  Defeaters arise when the module’s normal operating conditions are not met (e.g., poor lighting, ambiguous sentences), and higher-level monitoring can take this into account.

Thus modularism and reason-responsiveness coexist: modules generate reasons, higher cognition regulates their deployment.

9. Broader Implications  

The debate touches on several other philosophical issues.

   Animal and Infant Cognition: If consciousness were necessary for basing, non-linguistic creatures could never be justified, an implausible conclusion given the sophisticated perceptual discriminations and learning they exhibit.

   Epistemic Defeat and Bias: Implicit biases sometimes distort the uptake of evidence despite being unconscious.  Recognizing these biases as epistemically significant (negatively) reinforces the idea that what happens below the surface of awareness matters.

   Extended and Embodied Cognition: If justification can arise from processes that exceed conscious access, then the tools and environments we exploit may literally become part of our epistemic machinery.

10. Conclusion  

Lack of conscious awareness does not in itself preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on reasons.  What matters is that the state be produced and sustained by truth-tracking processes integrated into the subject’s cognitive architecture and open to rational regulation.  Conscious awareness is valuable: it enables higher-order evaluation, deliberate revision, and the articulation of reasons to others.  But it is not the sine qua non of epistemic basing.  Our automatic minds operate within the space of reasons, silently yet responsibly guiding us through the world.

question: Some philosophers argue that in order for a mental state to be based on epistemic reasons (and thereby have an epistemic status as justified or unjustified), the subject must be consciously aware of those reasons. This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Philosophers who locate epistemic normativity in the space of reasons typically add a further thesis about the “basing relation”: a belief, intention, perceptual judgment, or other cognitive state is epistemically justified only if it is based on the right reasons.  A natural—and historically influential—thought is that basing must be transparent to the subject: if your belief that p is epistemically well-grounded, you must be able to tell, by conscious reflection, what it is that speaks in favor of p.  This “conscious access requirement” (CAR) fits comfortably with Cartesian and classical empiricist pictures of the mind, on which the sort of items that can justify—ideas, impressions, evident truths—are themselves paradigmatically occurrent and consciously accessible.  In the last half-century, however, cognitive science has delivered a picture of the mind saturated with modular, automatic, and sub-personal information-processing routines.  Ordinary human reasoning is shot through with tacit inferences, probabilistic computations, and pattern recognitions that never rise to the level of introspective visibility.  The question is whether, in light of this, we should retain the CAR or conclude that a mental state can be epistemically based on considerations of which the subject is entirely unaware.

I shall argue for a moderate negative answer: lack of occurrent conscious awareness does not in itself disqualify a mental state from being epistemically based on a reason; nevertheless, some form of reason-responsiveness that is, in principle, cognitively available to the subject is necessary for full-blown epistemic justification.  The argument proceeds in five steps.  (1) I distinguish three separable notions of awareness relevant to the issue.  (2) I review the main motivations for the CAR and show that each admits of a weaker formulation that does not entail occurrent consciousness.  (3) I then present three lines of empirical and conceptual evidence—implicit perception, expert skill, and developmental reasoning—that strongly suggest non-conscious basing.  (4) I outline a dispositional, functional account of the basing relation that accommodates these cases while preserving the normative core of reasons.  Finally, (5) I respond to three prominent objections, concerning epistemic responsibility, skeptic-proof access, and the alleged collapse into externalism.

2. What Sort of ‘Awareness’ Is at Issue?  

Discussions of CAR often run together different gradations of access.  We need at least the following distinctions.

   a. Occurrent phenomenal awareness: one is presently experiencing the reason—e.g., a conscious visual appearance or a silent inner assertion.  

   b. Reflective accessibility: even if the reason is not occurrent, one can, upon reflection, bring it to mind and articulate it, given normal cognitive resources.  

   c. Rational sensitivity: one’s cognitive system is disposed to form, sustain, revise, or withhold the belief in ways that track the reason, whether or not one could articulate this tracking.

The strong CAR equates epistemic basing with (a).  More moderate internalist views accept (b).  Externalist or virtue-epistemological views typically rest content with (c).  The controversy is thus not binary but triadic.  My target is the strong claim that absence of (a) is fatal to basing; I will remain open to, though critical of, the weaker claim that absence of (b) suffices.

3. Why Think Basing Requires Occurrent Awareness?  

Three main considerations motivate CAR.

   i. The phenomenology of deliberation.  When we consciously weigh considerations—e.g., evidence that it will rain—we find ourselves reaching the belief that it will rain precisely because the conscious reasons strike us as supporting the conclusion.  This introspective template encourages the generalization that all justified belief is produced by such phenomenally accessible support.

   ii. Responsibility and epistemic evaluation.  Justification, on many internalist views, concerns what the subject can be asked to provide in defense of her belief.  If one has no idea what one’s reasons are, so the thought goes, one cannot properly take responsibility for one’s belief.

   iii. The “new evil demon” and “brain in a vat” scenarios.  Epistemic justification is supposed to be independent of worldly luck; what matters is how things appear from the subject’s internal point of view.  Conscious mental life seems the right level of description for fixing that point of view.

Each motivation is powerful, but none is decisive once we recognize the three-way distinction from §2.

   i’. Phenomenology shows that some conscious deliberation is reason-guided; it does not show that all guidance must be conscious.  Indeed, by parity, many consciously deliberated moves in chess rely on tacit pattern recognition the player could not formulate.

   ii’. Responsibility plausibly requires the capacity to answer to criticism, not the actual presence of articulated reasons at every moment.  An agent may be responsible for her driving even while operating largely on “muscle memory.”

   iii’. What matters in demon-world cases is the information available to the subject’s cognitive system, not necessarily the deliverances of introspective consciousness.  The envatted subject’s nonconscious perceptual modules are in the same evidential predicament as her conscious imagery.

Hence CAR, in its strong form, outruns its own motivations.

4. Empirical and Conceptual Pressure on CAR  

4.1 Blindsight and Implicit Perception  

Patients with blindsight reliably guess the presence, shape, or motion of stimuli in their blind field while sincerely reporting no visual experience.  On a CAR reading, their “guesses” cannot be epistemically grounded, for the subjects lack awareness of the visual information.  Yet the guesses are not random; they track environmental regularities via the very sensory-motor routes that, in ordinary cases, yield justified perceptual belief.  If epistemic basing must be conscious, then blindsight subjects “get it right” merely by accident, an implausible conclusion given the systematic reliability and modality-specific sensitivity of their responses.

4.2 Skilled Cognition and Expert Intuition  

Grandmaster chess players may instantly label a position as “dangerous,” or radiologists may pick out a tumor “at a glance.”  When pressed, they often cannot articulate the specific features that constitute their evidence; the recognition is automatic, holistic, even affect-tinged.  Nonetheless, these recognitions are grounded in statistically robust pattern learning across thousands of cases.  To deny that the resultant beliefs are justified because the experts cannot make the reasons conscious would detach epistemic status from the very competence that underwrites the experts’ authority.

4.3 Developmental and Everyday Reasoning  

Young children, second language learners, and even educated adults frequently employ syntactic, semantic, and probabilistic regularities in speech and practical reasoning without articulate knowledge of the rules.  Grown speakers of English rarely can state the rule blocking “the asleep child” although they follow it flawlessly.  To insist on occurrent awareness would imply that most linguistic and inferential capacities operate outside the sphere of epistemic evaluation—again, a price too high.

In each domain, sub-personal processes generate states that are sensitive to truth-conducive patterns and integrate with higher cognition; they manifest reason-responsiveness in sense (c) without (a) or even (b).  CAR, therefore, is empirically unmotivated.

5. A Dispositional-Functional Account of Basing  

We thus seek an alternative that secures two desiderata: (1) an epistemologically rich role for unconscious processes; (2) the normative idea that justified belief is belief held for good reasons.  I propose the following.

Dispositional Basing Thesis (DBT):  
A mental state M of subject S is epistemically based on reason R iff  
(1) R is a content that is represented somewhere in S’s cognitive economy;  
(2) the tokening of R non-deviantly causes or sustains M in virtue of its representational content;  
(3) S is disposed, under normal conditions of reflection and attention, to treat R as a pro tanto epistemic consideration for M.

Clause (1) accommodates sub-personal representation; clause (2) secures the explanatory, non-accidental link characteristic of basing; clause (3) restores a weak internalist dimension: although S need not be aware of R at the time of belief formation, S could, in principle, come to recognize and endorse R’s epistemic bearing upon reflection.

How strict is (3)?  The relevant modality is not “conceptually reflective at any moment,” but “reachable by the agent’s own cognitive resources.”  Crucially, this does not require articulable verbalization.  An athlete might justify her belief that the play will develop to the left by replaying a mental image rather than stating a proposition.  What matters is that the agent possesses capacities enabling her to re-identify, monitor, and where appropriate correct the link between R and M.

DBT thus predicts:

   • In blindsight, ordinary reflection does not yet avail; but if neuroplasticity or training enables the patient to become conscious of the formerly subliminal information, her epistemic standing improves—a result consonant with clinical reports.  

   • The radiologist can, with effort, isolate salient low-level features (spiculation, asymmetry) even if not initially explicit.  The dispositions exist, if only partially.  

   • For grammatical competence, adults can often learn to state the rule when prompted with multiple examples, indicating an underlying cognitive potential to make explicit what was implicit.

DBT therefore preserves the insight that reasons matter to thinkers while acknowledging that much reasoning is “dark.”

6. Replies to Objections  

Objection 1: Epistemic responsibility demands actual, not potential, articulate reasons; otherwise, subjects can never be held to account.  

Reply: Accountability is scalar.  We blame the driver who, though failing to check his blind spot, could have done so with minimal attention more than the one whose steering column suddenly locked.  Similarly, a believer who could, but will not, reflect on her evidence is more culpable than one who lacks the capacities.  DBT accommodates gradable responsibility: full justification requires not just dispositional basing but also reasonable responsiveness to challenges, which can be absent even when the initial formation was basing-appropriate.

Objection 2: Without conscious access, we cannot discriminate cases of genuine basing from deviant causal chains or environmental luck; hence DBT collapses into brute reliabilism.  

Reply: The worry equates accessibility with discriminability.  Yet clause (2) of DBT already rules out deviant causes by demanding content-sensitive causation; the representational content of R must figure in the causal explanation of M.  This is a higher bar than bare reliability.  A clairvoyant belief that p caused by random neural firings does not qualify, since the intermediate cause fails to represent the relevant grounds.  The requirement of contentful causation is a mark of reasons-based basing, not mere statistical covariation.

Objection 3: The view makes justification hostage to cognitive architecture; a creature unable to render its tacit reasons explicit would never be justified.  

Reply: Hostage, perhaps, but reasonably so.  Epistemic norms apply to creatures capable of occupying the space of reasons—minimally, being able to adjust beliefs in light of considerations.  If an organism’s architecture forbids any such adjustment, it is a candidate for reliability-based warrant, not reason-based justification.  DBT draws a principled line between sub-doxastic mechanisms that contribute to reasons and those that supplant them.

7. Conclusion  

The lure of the conscious access requirement stems from a laudable concern to keep epistemic appraisal within the agent’s own rational purview.  Nonetheless, a strict identification of basing with occurrent awareness conflicts with an overwhelming body of cognitive scientific data and leads to implausible exclusions of expert, skilled, and developmental cognition from the justificatory realm.  By recognizing that basing is fundamentally a matter of content-driven causal explanation, plus a moderate demand for reflective potential, we preserve the normative authority of reasons while integrating the reality of modular and automatic cognitive processes.  Lack of conscious awareness, therefore, does not preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on reasons, provided the subject’s cognitive system both registers those reasons and is, in principle, able to appreciate their bearing.  The upshot is a pluralistic epistemology that sees conscious reflection as one, but not the only, locus of rationality.

This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Whether conscious access to one’s reasons is required for epistemic justification sits at the intersection of epistemology, philosophy of mind, and the cognitive sciences. Internalists about justification often maintain that whenever a belief is epistemically justified the subject must in principle be able to become reflectively aware of the considerations that make the belief rational. Otherwise, so the worry goes, the “basing” relation between reasons and belief would be an unintelligible black box: the subject would no longer be the epistemic agent but a mere locus in which sub-personal mechanisms generate attitudes that happen to track truth. In contrast, externalists, as well as philosophers sympathetic to cognitive science, emphasize that many paradigm cases of justified cognition—ordinary visual perception, rapid mathematical estimation, linguistic comprehension—are executed by domain-specific, largely automatic modules that typically bypass consciousness. Must we then conclude that perceptual beliefs, or other outputs of modular processing, lack epistemic status until they are reflectively endorsed? That conclusion appears both phenomenologically implausible and normatively unattractive: surely I am justified in believing there is a cup on the table even before I stop to think about the similarity space of cups or the reliability of my visual system.

In what follows I argue that lack of conscious awareness of one’s reasons does not in general preclude epistemic basing—all that is required is that the reasons play the right etiological and counterfactual roles in guiding, sustaining, and potentially revising the attitude. Consciousness can enhance epistemic status by enabling second-order monitoring, but it is neither necessary nor sufficient for basing. I proceed in five stages. (1) I unpack the concept of epistemic basing and diagnose why many are tempted to build consciousness into it. (2) I offer positive arguments, rooted in cognitive science and ordinary epistemic practice, for sub-doxastic basing. (3) I respond to three influential objections: the “no guidance” objection, the “de-personalization” objection, and the “responsibility” objection. (4) I articulate an alternative, ecumenical picture: the Hierarchical Basing Model, on which conscious and non-conscious reasons can both ground justification, though at different explanatory levels. (5) I close with implications for epistemic normativity and for ongoing debates about the reach of “rationality without deliberation”.

2. What is epistemic basing?  

The basing relation is meant to capture the difference between (a) merely having good reasons available and (b) holding a belief because of those reasons. Two constraints dominate the literature.

A. Causal-etiological constraint: The reasons must appropriately cause or sustain the belief.  
B. Guidance constraint: The reasons must be poised such that, had they been different or defeated, the belief would have been withdrawn or modified.

Constraint (A) is usually uncontroversial; (B) carries heavier explanatory load, for it secures the link between reasons and rational agency. Now, why think consciousness is required? Because consciousness seems to provide the subject with a unified, accessible workspace in which reasons can be entertained, compared, and weighed; only conscious, occurrent contents appear suited to satisfy (B). If I am not even aware of R, how could R guide my believing that p?

But equating guidance with conscious appreciation over-intellectualizes everyday cognition. Many skills—language comprehension, face recognition, skilled driving—exhibit sophisticated, flexible sensitivity to reasons despite the agent being unaware of the operative information. The driver does not consciously calculate friction coefficients when braking, yet her pedal pressure is exquisitely responsive to such parameters. Similarly, a visual module can be sensitive to luminance gradients and occlusion cues that function as reasons for positing a contour. The fact that this sensitivity is implemented sub-personally does not, on its own, expel it from the space of reasons. Unless we are prepared to deny that such processing confers justification at all, we should look elsewhere for the criterion of epistemic basing.

3. Positive case for non-conscious basing  

a. Perception as prototypical epistemic source  
Perceptual experience delivers non-inferential justification for empirical beliefs. Yet most of the information that underwrites perception—edge detection, stereoscopic disparity, motion parallax—is unavailable to consciousness. What we consciously experience is the resulting scene, not the subpersonal computational steps. Nevertheless, if new sensory evidence arrives (say, the lights turn on and I now see clearly that the “cup” is a cleverly painted rock) my perceptual belief immediately updates; the earlier subpersonal reasons are replaced. This flexible updating satisfies the guidance constraint. Hence the belief was based on reasons, even if I was never aware of them.

b. Implicit statistical reasoning  
Gigerenzer’s “fast and frugal heuristics” research shows that ordinary agents reliably track Bayesian structures in the environment without explicit calculation. For example, physicians who employ the “take-the-best” heuristic often reach diagnoses that approximate optimal Bayesian inferences. The physicians could rarely articulate the likelihood ratios their behavior reflects, yet the predictive success and systematic error-correction manifested over time demonstrates that their beliefs are sensitive to statistical reasons.

c. Experimental evidence from blindsight and unconscious priming  
Patients with blindsight report no conscious visual experience in their scotoma, yet can reliably guess shapes and directions at rates far above chance. Importantly, their confidence adjusts in line with objective reliability: when the stimulus is degraded, accuracy and confidence both drop. The best explanation is that information about stimulus quality operates as a reason modulating credence even in the absence of visual phenomenology. Likewise, subliminal priming can make subjects more cautious in lexical decision tasks when error likelihood is high. Again, non-conscious reasons guide behavior.

4. Answering objections  

Objection 1: The No-Guidance Objection  
“Without conscious awareness, reasons cannot be cited by the agent in explanation, hence they cannot guide epistemic life.”

Reply: Guidance need not be reflective. What matters is counterfactual sensitivity: if the evidential situation were different, would the belief change? Subpersonal mechanisms that update credence when sensory error signals occur satisfy that standard. Consider artificial neural networks: they “attend” to features that alter weightings during training. Though they lack consciousness, their outputs are guided by reasons in the weak, etiological sense. Human cognitive architecture incorporates analogous modules that remain under executive control. I may not know which micro-cues my face-recognition system uses, but I can decide to rely on it or to seek corroboration under uncertain lighting, thereby integrating non-conscious reasons into my personal-level rational agenda.

Objection 2: The De-Personalization Objection  
“Epistemic justification concerns persons, not subsystems. If the relevant grounds are hidden from the person, the state is at best sub-personal and so not genuinely epistemic.”

Reply: Persons are constituted by interacting levels of representation. The boundary between personal and sub-personal is porous. What distinguishes personal-level states is typically their availability to practical reasoning and verbal report, but these features admit of degrees. Procedural memory and affective appraisal often lie below the threshold of reportability yet still contribute to our unified agency. Epistemology must reflect the graded architecture of mind rather than impose a dichotomy. Moreover, the fact that I can retroactively inspect, challenge, or override the deliverances of a module reinstates personal-level ownership.

Objection 3: The Responsibility Objection  
“If reasons are unconscious, the subject cannot be held epistemically responsible for their beliefs; hence such beliefs cannot be justified.”

Reply: Responsibility also comes in degrees. We routinely hold people responsible for inattentive beliefs (“You should have noticed the warning sign”), even though the unnoticed stimuli were not conscious. The crucial factor is whether the agent had reasonable control measures available: double-checking, suspending judgment, seeking testimony. A pilot relying on automatic instrumentation is justifiably so, provided the instruments are reliable and standard operational protocols endorse their use; if the gauges malfunction and the pilot ignores available cross-checks, responsibility kicks in. Thus, unconscious basing can coexist with normative appraisal anchored in broader agency.

5. The Hierarchical Basing Model  

To reconcile intuitions about personal rationality with the empirical reality of modular cognition, I propose a hierarchical picture.

Level 0: Sub-doxastic evidential relations. Information-format carry micro-reasons (edges, optical flow, phoneme transitions). These relations are constitutive of perceptual competence.

Level 1: Doxastic but pre-reflective states. Perceptual appearances (“It looks red”) encode summary reasons generated at Level 0. These appearances justify basic beliefs without conceptual mediation.

Level 2: Reflective awareness. The subject can, when prompted, token higher-order representations: “My belief is based on how it looks,” or, with more training, “Because the hue matches canonical red under standard lighting.”

Justification accrues already at Level 1; Level 2 adds metacognitive endorsement, affording increased resistance to defeat and greater epistemic responsibility. Importantly, the basing relation at Level 1 is not eclipsed when Level 2 is absent. Infants and non-human animals, for instance, can have perceptually justified beliefs though they lack the linguistic resources for explicit citation.

This model honors internalist intuitions by positing that, in principle, some grounds can rise to awareness, while granting externalists that sub-personal reliability is the primary engine of justification. It also diagnoses conflicting intuitions: when we focus on Level 2 cases, basing appears to require conscious citation; when we attend to Level 0-1, basing seems automatic. Both perspectives capture genuine layers of cognitive architecture.

6. Two further considerations  

a. The opacity of inference. Cognitive psychology suggests that even paradigmatic conscious reasoning is opaque. When asked why they chose a particular consumer item, subjects confabulate. If confabulation undermined basing, hardly any belief would qualify. Hence requiring accurate conscious access would render justification unattainable, an implausible skeptical conclusion.

b. Evolutionary plausibility. Natural selection likely favored fast, resource-light heuristics that bypass conscious bottlenecks. If only consciously supported beliefs were justified, most animal cognition, including much of human perception, would fall outside the domain of epistemic evaluation. A richer, evolutionarily informed epistemology must take non-conscious basing seriously.

7. Implications and conclusion  

If the arguments above are sound, the landscape of epistemic evaluation widens. First, debates about inferentialism versus dogmatism in perception need not hinge on whether perceptual reasons are conceptually available; non-conceptual, non-conscious reasons can suffice. Second, virtue-theoretic accounts of knowledge gain traction: what matters is the agent’s overall competence, many components of which operate below awareness. Third, the analysis supports the growing literature on implicit biases: some such biases are epistemically unjustified precisely because the sub-personal processes generating them are systematically unreliable, not because they are unconscious per se.

To the initial question—does lack of conscious awareness preclude epistemic basing?—the considered answer is No. Conscious awareness is neither necessary nor sufficient for basing. It is not sufficient, because one can consciously rehearse spurious reasons and thereby believe unjustifiably. It is not necessary, because sub-personal mechanisms can satisfy the etiological and guidance constraints central to rational basing. What ultimately matters for epistemic status is the integration of information in ways that tend to promote truth, remain sensitive to defeaters, and stand ready for higher-order scrutiny when the agent’s practical and epistemic context demands it. Consciousness enriches but does not constitute that integration.

Therefore, modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing, and ordinary perceptual and linguistic beliefs are justified well before, and independently of, any reflective awareness of their grounds. Far from undermining our epistemic agency, the mind’s hidden layers are indispensable allies in our pursuit of knowledge.

question: Some philosophers argue that in order for a mental state to be based on epistemic reasons (and thereby have an epistemic status as justified or unjustified), the subject must be consciously aware of those reasons. This poses a challenge for views that hold that modular, automatic cognitive processes can involve genuine epistemic basing. Does lack of conscious awareness of one's reasons preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on those reasons?
answer:
1. Introduction

Whether one must be consciously aware of the grounds on which one believes in order for that belief to be epistemically based is a dispute that sits at the confluence of epistemology, philosophy of mind, and cognitive science. On one side stand “access internalists,” who insist that a justificatory link between a state and its reasons must be accessible to the subject at the level of consciousness. On the other side stand a growing group of naturalistically inclined philosophers who, in light of mounting evidence about sub-personal, automatic, and modular cognition, deny that such access is necessary. The question is not merely academic: it bears on how we should understand expertise, implicit bias, perceptual justification, and even the rationality of animals and infants. In what follows I will (i) unpack the terminology, (ii) reconstruct the principal arguments for the awareness condition, (iii) develop challenges to that condition from both empirical findings and theoretical considerations, (iv) articulate a middle position that I call the “Dispositional Awareness View,” and finally (v) respond to the most salient objections.

2. Key Concepts

(a) Epistemic reason. I shall use ‘reason’ in the normative sense: a consideration that counts in favor of a belief’s truth, and possession of which can confer justification on that belief. ‘Evidence’ is the paradigmatic subclass of epistemic reasons.

(b) The basing relation. For a belief to be justified because of a reason, it is not enough that the reason exists; the subject’s belief must be based on it in the right way. Paradigm cases are conscious inferences (e.g., “I see puddles; therefore it rained”); these secure a “transparent” link between reason and belief.

(c) Conscious awareness. This is occurrent phenomenal awareness of the relevant reason or of the fact that the reason supports the belief. Merely having the representation stored somewhere in long-term memory, or being subpersonally influenced by it, does not count as consciousness in the sense at issue.

(d) Automatic or modular cognition. Cognitive processes that are fast, domain-specific, informationally encapsulated, and largely inaccessible to introspection. Classic examples include early visual processing, language parsing, and heuristic decision-making.

3. The Awareness Condition: Theoretical Motivations

Three families of arguments underpin the claim that conscious awareness is necessary for epistemic basing.

3.1 Normative Rationality and the Transparency Ideal

Wilfrid Sellars and later Donald Davidson argued that giving and asking for reasons is a space of commitments essentially governed by norms. Entering that space, on their view, requires that the subject can articulate—at least to herself—why she holds the belief. If she cannot, the belief is supposedly outside the scope of epistemic evaluation; it is a mere causal upshot of sub-personal mechanisms, on a par with a knee-jerk reflex.

This “transparency ideal” gains intuitive traction from the idea that justification is something for which we can be legitimately asked to account. If I could not, even in principle, answer the question “Why do you believe p?,” then it looks as though p is not my rational commitment.

3.2 The Phenomenology of Understanding

A second strand appeals to phenomenology. To feel that one’s belief is rational is (it is claimed) to be experientially aware of considerations that render the belief intelligible. When I solve a simple arithmetic problem, I enjoy a “grasp” of the premises and see the conclusion to follow. In contrast, when I consult an oracle who pronounces “121 is the square of 11,” my assent lacks the phenomenology of understanding and thus lacks epistemic standing, or so the argument goes.

3.3 Epistemic Agency

Finally, some epistemologists (notably, John Greco and Linda Zagzebski) ground justification in responsible agency: to be epistemically justified is, in part, to deserve credit for believing well. On one construal of agency, credit requires conscious control: I am not praiseworthy for bodily movements produced entirely by subconscious twitching; likewise, I am not praiseworthy for beliefs sub-personally caused without any awareness of the supporting reasons.

4. Empirical and Theoretical Challenges

4.1 Automatic Expertise

Chess masters can immediately suggest strong moves in complex positions. Eye-tracking studies show that they do not, and often cannot, articulate the thousands of micro-features they tacitly evaluate. Similar phenomena occur in radiology: expert radiologists can classify an X-ray as “abnormal” in 200 milliseconds, a duration too short for conscious deliberation. Yet it would be counter-intuitive to withhold epistemic justification from their judgments. These agents regularly outperform novices, respond systematically to defeaters (e.g., if told the X-ray image was mirror-flipped), and correct their beliefs when given stronger evidence. If justification tracks reliability, virtuous cognition, or epistemic responsibility, their beliefs appear eminently justified despite the absence of conscious access to the fine-grained reasons.

4.2 Perceptual Justification

Much perceptual processing is modular and unconscious. I am not aware of edge-detection or color-constancy algorithms executed by my visual cortex; nonetheless my perceptual beliefs—“There is a red apple on the table”—are paradigms of justification. To require consciousness of the reasons embodied in sensory evidence would threaten to undermine nearly all perceptual knowledge.

4.3 The Problem of Excessive Intellectualism

The awareness condition risks over-intellectualizing epistemic life. Infants, non-human animals, and human adults with limited cognitive resources routinely form beliefs that seem epistemically good (e.g., a dog who tracks its master’s scent). If conscious awareness were required for justification, these creatures would be irrational in toto, an implausible conclusion.

4.4 The Cognitive Science of ‘Unconscious Inference’

Helmholtz already spoke of perception as “unconscious inference.” Contemporary Bayesian models generalize the point: the brain constantly generates hypotheses that best predict sensory inputs. The ‘reasons’—probabilistic relations between hypotheses and data—are represented sub-personally. Denying that such processing can ground justified belief threatens a deep disconnect between epistemology and the science of cognition.

4.5 Swamping and the Value of True Belief

Ernest Sosa’s virtue epistemology claims that what matters is that a belief be formed through a competence aimed at truth. Whether the agent is aware of the competence’s grounds is irrelevant to epistemic value. Indeed, an agent duped by misleading conscious reasons but saved by a sub-personal competence (e.g., noticing an imperceptible tremor that signals an earthquake) ends up with a true belief for the right objective reason, even if she cannot articulate that reason.

5. Toward a Middle Path: Dispositional Awareness

While the above challenges are powerful, the awareness condition is motivated by genuine intuitions about agency and responsibility. I therefore propose a qualified view:

Dispositional Awareness Thesis: Occurrent conscious awareness of one’s reasons is not necessary for a belief to be epistemically based on them, but the agent must be suitably disposed to become aware of (some of) those reasons upon reflection, or to appreciate their rational force when they are brought to consciousness.

Key features:

(i) Basal Level Basing. Sub-personal processes can provide the immediate causal basing relation: the visual module delivers a representation; the expert’s pattern-recognition module fires. Justification is secured at that level.

(ii) Reflective Accessibility. If the subject reflects—by directing attention, asking herself “Why do I believe p?,” or entertaining epistemic challenges—she can often, though not invariably, retrieve an approximate rationale (“The X-ray looks hazy around the lungs,” or “The apple looks red and round”). The underlying micro-features remain opaque, but a coarse-grained summary is available.

(iii) Defeater-Responsiveness. Even when reasons are not conscious, the belief-forming competence must be sensitive to defeating evidence. A radiologist who keeps his initial snap-judgment despite learning that the image is from a corrupted scan forfeits justification; one who revises it displays epistemic responsibility.

The dispositional account reconciles the empirically grounded claim that many justified beliefs are automatically produced with the normative intuition that, as reflective agents, we are in principle answerable for what we believe.

6. Objection 1: Mere Disposition Is Too Weak

One might argue that being merely disposed to retrieve reasons does not suffice for rational responsibility. After all, most subjects lack the metacognitive capacity to articulate Bayesian priors or the etiological story of their visual cortex. How, then, can they be blameworthy or praiseworthy?

Reply: Responsibility comes in degrees. An ordinary perceiver cannot articulate edge-detection algorithms, but she can—in normal lighting—report that the apple looks red. That level of articulation suffices for first-order epistemic appraisal because it pinpoints the personal-level content that functions as her normative reason: the seeming that the apple is red. She need not decode sub-personal processes any more than she need to cite quarks to justify her belief that the table is hard. The control she exercises by being able to attend to the visual presentation, check for defeaters (e.g., colored lighting), or seek corroboration suffices for credit.

7. Objection 2: Animals and Infants Lack Even Dispositional Awareness

If awareness in any form is required, what about dogs or six-month-olds who cannot entertain propositions about their reasons? Do we deny them epistemic justification?

Reply: We may distinguish between epistemic justification proper and proto-epistemic statuses. My account grants that animals and infants enjoy a kind of functional rationality—they track environmental truths via reliable competences—but genuine epistemic justification, in the norm-governed sense implicating reasons, may indeed be restricted to agents capable of at least minimal reflective uptake. That is not a bug but a conceptual clarification: calling a wolf's tracking of prey 'justified belief' stretches epistemic language beyond recognition.

8. Objection 3: Unconscious Biases Would Then Be Justified

Suppose an HR manager has an implicit racial bias that operates unconsciously and issues in discriminatory hiring judgments. The bias is a “competence” of sorts—fast, automatic, and reliable relative to its (morally perverse) aim. Does my view entail that her biased belief that “candidate A is less promising” is justified?

Reply: No. Competence must be truth-directed and defeater-responsive. Implicit biases are neither. They systematically deviate from truth once the epistemic goal is fixed: they would not track the candidate’s actual qualifications in counterfactual scenarios where race varies. Hence they fail the reliability and sensitivity conditions built into the Dispositional Awareness framework.

9. Objection 4: Swamping Again

A reliabilist might push further: if objective reliability confers enough normative status, why saddle justification with even dispositional awareness? Why not say that if the process is objectively truth-conducive, the belief is justified, full stop?

Reply: Pure reliabilism faces infamous counterexamples: clairvoyant virtues, epistemic serendipity, and cases where we wish to distinguish epistemic luck from creditable cognition. Dispositional awareness restores an agency requirement that reliabilism lacks, without succumbing to the excessive intellectualism of the strong awareness condition. It occupies a principled middle ground between brute reliabilism and full-blown access internalism.

10. Advantages of the Dispositional Awareness View

(a) Comports with cognitive science: It honors the fact that sub-personal mechanisms do much epistemic work.

(b) Respects normative intuitions about answerability: Agents can in principle vindicate their beliefs when challenged.

(c) Graduated epistemic responsibility: It allows for varying levels of justification across novices, experts, animals, and malfunctioning agents.

(d) Explains the epistemic failings of biased or wishful thinkers: Such agents either lack a reliable competence or are not disposed to attend to relevant defeaters.

11. The Basing Relation Revisited

One might still worry that the view leaves the basing relation mysterious. If consciousness is not the arena in which reasons do their justificatory work, what ensures that the sub-personal causal path is the right sort of basing rather than deviant causation?

My suggestion, inspired by Ernest Sosa and Peter Railton, is that the relevant basing consists in the operation of a reliable epistemic faculty whose teleology is aimed at truth. Visual perception, memory, introspection, and expert pattern-recognition are paradigmatic faculties. Such faculties encode probabilistic relations between inputs and outputs; when they function properly in the environment for which they were designed (biologically or through learning), their outputs are epistemically grounded in the informational content they register, even if the agent lacks occurrent awareness.

12. Conclusion

Lack of conscious awareness does not, by itself, preclude a mental state from being epistemically based on reasons. Demanding occurrent awareness would jettison large swaths of everyday and expert knowledge, contradict cognitive science, and collapse into an untenable intellectualism. At the same time, abandoning awareness entirely threatens to detach epistemology from agency and normative evaluation.
