answer:
Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Is Simulation Necessary?

1. Introduction  

To an observer, seeing another person reach for a cup is usually effortless: we not only register a bodily movement but seem to apprehend, pre-reflectively, that the person is “trying to pick the cup up.” A family of simulation–based theories of social cognition—stemming from early mirror-neuron work and elaborated in cognitive science—contends that this intuitive capacity depends on motor resonance: the automatic mapping of the perceived movement onto the perceiver’s own motor system. If the neural circuitry that would produce the movement in me is covertly activated when I watch you act, the claim goes, that activation provides the very medium through which I perceive your action as goal-directed. The strong version of the thesis is modal: without motor resonance, perception of goal-directedness cannot occur.

In what follows I argue that the strong necessity claim is untenable. Motor resonance is one among several routes—perhaps a particularly efficient or developmentally primary one—through which goal-directedness can be made perceptually available, but it is neither logically nor empirically necessary. I begin (sect. 2) by clarifying the concepts of “motor resonance,” “perception,” and “goal-directedness.” Section 3 reconstructs the main arguments for the necessity thesis, drawing on philosophical simulationism and mirror-neuron research. Section 4 presents four lines of critique: conceptual, empirical, developmental, and evolutionary. Section 5 discusses alternative mechanisms—kinematic heuristics, contextual inference, and ecological affordances—that can ground perceptual access to others’ goals without motor resonance. Section 6 addresses the strongest remaining objections and explains why sufficiency, not necessity, is the right verdict. I conclude (sect. 7) by situating the debate in a broader pluralist framework about social perception.

2. Conceptual Clarifications  

2.1 Motor Resonance  
“Motor resonance” is the fast, involuntary activation of (part of) the observer’s motor system when she perceives another individual moving. In laboratory practice this is often indexed by TMS-evoked motor potentials, mu-rhythm suppression, or single-cell recordings of mirror neurons. Crucially, resonance is somatotopically specific: watching a hand grasp tends to excite hand-related motor areas, watching a kick excites leg areas, and so on.

2.2 Perceptual Availability  
To perceive a goal is not merely to form a reflective judgment—“I think she intends to grasp the cup”—but to experience the movement as imbued with teleological structure. Phenomenologically, the trajectory appears “on its way” to the cup. For present purposes, I will take perception of goal-directedness to involve (minimally) the on-line attribution of a distal aim that guides the observed kinematics.

2.3 Goal-Directedness  
An action counts as goal-directed if its unfolding is organized around the achievement of a distal outcome. Importantly, we often attribute goals across wide bodily and species boundaries: we can see a dog about to leap for a stick, a robot moving to plug itself in, or a pianist striking an octave—despite the fact that we do not share every motor routine with these agents. The breadth of application already hints that reliance on a one-to-one bodily simulation might be too restrictive.

3. The Case for Necessity  

3.1 Philosophical Simulationism  
Alvin Goldman and others argue that mind-reading emerges from a more general simulation heuristic: I understand your mental states by recreating, in a vicarious key, the inner processes I would undergo if I were acting as you do. Mirror mechanisms provide the neural implementation of such simulation. If seeing is underwritten by simulation, then lacking the relevant motor program would deprive me of perceptual access to your goal.

3.2 Evidence from Mirror-Neuron Studies  
Empirical work suggests that mirror areas respond more intensely to goal-directed than to non-goal-directed movements, they encode the aim of an action even when the distal goal is hidden from view, and lesions to premotor cortex can hinder action understanding. These findings are marshalled to argue that the mirror system does not just correlate with, but is constitutive of, perceiving goals.

3.3 Developmental Arguments  
At three to five months, human infants manifest motor resonance and appear able to parse goal-directed reaches. Given their limited cognitive resources, simulationists infer a causal link: the primitive capacity to covertly reproduce the movement grounds the very possibility of goal perception.

4. Four Lines of Critique  

4.1 Conceptual Counter-Examples  
Necessity is a strong modal claim: if motor resonance were necessary, then whenever it is absent goal perception should be impossible. But consider:

a. Observing novel tool actions. I can readily recognize that a skilled carpenter is aiming to dovetail two boards even though I lack any corresponding motor program; my motor system resonates minimally, yet I perceive the goal.  

b. Cross-species cases. I see a dolphin arc toward a fish. I have no motor routine for tail-propelled movement, but the goal is visually manifest.  

c. Intentional omissions. I can see that a goalkeeper is deliberately refraining from moving early to mislead the striker; here resonance would actually be suppressed relative to movement, yet the goal (to deceive) is perceived.

These examples show, at least prima facie, that motor simulation is not constitutive of perceiving goals.

4.2 Empirical Dissociations  
a. Akinetic but understanding: Parkinson’s disease patients with severe motor deficits, or individuals with spinal cord injuries, retain robust capacities for action understanding even when motor resonance signatures are drastically reduced.  

b. Double dissociation: Apraxic patients may have damaged motor programs and impaired action production yet can identify others’ goals; conversely, some individuals with intact resonance, such as certain autistic participants, report difficulties in grasping others’ intentions.  

c. TMS interference: Temporarily disrupting premotor areas diminishes resonance but, in many studies, does not significantly hinder performance on action-understanding tasks when compensatory visual and contextual cues are available.

4.3 Developmental Plasticity  
Infants born without limbs (amelia) cannot perform many common actions. Yet research by Meyer et al. shows they still perceive typical hand-based goals, relying more heavily on visual path information. The developing brain recruits alternative circuits—temporal and parietal—underscoring that resonance is not necessary, even if ordinarily recruited.

4.4 Evolutionary Scope  
Goal perception is crucial for predator–prey interactions and social coordination across the animal kingdom. But only primates and some songbirds exhibit recognizable mirror systems. Species such as reptiles or insects navigate goal-directed environments without anything resembling human-like resonance. The phylogenetic spread of goal perception thus outstrips the distribution of mirror mechanisms.

5. Alternative Routes to Goal Perception  

5.1 Kinematic Heuristics  
Humans are exquisitely sensitive to the law-like regularities that connect movement and goals. Trajectories that are efficient, smooth, and obey minimum-jerk principles are rapidly categorized as goal-directed. Computer-generated point-light displays trigger goal attributions despite impoverished bodily detail, suggesting that visual kinematics alone can ground teleological perception. Such heuristics depend on visual motion processing areas (MT/V5, STS) rather than premotor cortex.

5.2 Contextual Inference and Bayesian Predictive Coding  
Action unfolds in structured environments. Observers combine prior knowledge of situational affordances with on-line sensory data to infer likely goals. Predictive-coding models show that high-level expectations can drive goal ascription even when the specific motor gestures are ambiguous or unseen. These inferences, realized in temporo-parietal and medial-prefrontal networks, can occur with little or no resonance.

5.3 Ecological Affordance Perception  
Following Gibson and contemporary enactivists, perception of goal-directedness may piggyback on the direct perception of affordances. I need not covertly grasp the cup to see that the cup affords grasping: its handle, orientation, and distance situate it as the natural target of the hand I see moving toward it. The relational structure in the visual scene “invites” the goal attribution, bypassing simulation.

5.4 Linguistic and Symbolic Mediation  
In literate adults, linguistic labels and cultural scripts can make certain goals salient in advance of any motor imagery. Reading “Surgeon at work” under a video primes observers to detect operative goals that they could not personally enact, illustrating yet another cognitive—rather than motoric—pathway.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1 - Epiphenomenal Alternatives  
Perhaps non-resonant cues suffice in highly contrived laboratory tasks but in the ecological “wild” resonance invariably contributes; that still makes it practically necessary.  

Reply: Field studies on soccer, dance, or industrial assembly reveal that experts, who possess refined motor repertoires, do show heightened resonance, but novices accurately perceive core goals relying on visual and contextual strategies. Practical sufficiency lies with multiple interacting systems; no single route is obligatory.

Objection 2 - Parsimony  
Simulation offers the simplest neural mechanism; invoking extra heuristics adds explanatory clutter.  

Reply: Cognitive parsimony must trade off against explanatory adequacy. The plural mechanisms view is necessitated by empirical counter-evidence. Moreover, predictive–coding accounts unify kinematic and contextual routes under a single formalism—minimizing prediction error—without presupposing motor execution as the sole substrate.

Objection 3 - Developmental Primacy Entails Necessity  
Even if adults can compensate, infants rely on resonance; thus the mechanism is developmentally necessary.  

Reply: Neonatal studies reveal that infants track statistical regularities in movement (Woodward paradigm) even before robust voluntary grasping. Limb-deficient infants still succeed. Resonance may scaffold efficiency but is not a prerequisite. Development is opportunistic: multiple pathways mature in tandem and can substitute for one another.

Objection 4 - Lesion Cases Are Inconclusive  
premotor lesions that spare understanding might reflect residual resonance in untouched sub-units.  

Reply: Even granting residual activity, the necessity claim requires that resonance be present in principle. Callosal disconnection, cerebellar degeneration, and full paralysis cases show near-elimination of motor cortical recruitment yet preserved goal perception, undermining indispensability.

7. Conclusion: Toward a Pluralist Model  

Motor resonance is a fascinating discovery and a powerful facilitator of social perception. Its fast, embodied, and largely automatic nature confers evolutionary advantages, especially when speed and fine-grained motor prediction matter (e.g., joint action, imitation learning). Yet the philosophical leap from “often utilized” to “necessary” is unwarranted. Conceptual counter-examples, empirical dissociations, developmental plasticity, and cross-species considerations collectively demonstrate that perceiving goal-directed action can proceed through alternative channels—visual kinematic heuristics, contextual Bayesian inference, and direct affordance detection. A pluralist framework that treats motor resonance as one implementational option within a broader predictive architecture better respects the diversity and resilience of human social cognition.

Accordingly, the necessity thesis should be replaced by a sufficiency thesis: motor resonance is sufficient in many contexts to yield perception of goal-directedness, but it is not the sole or indispensable path. Recognizing its contingency opens fruitful avenues for studying how different mechanisms interact across development, pathology, expertise, and culture to secure our shared grasp of purposive action.

question: Some philosophers and cognitive scientists have argued that motor resonance—the mapping of another's action onto one's own motor repertoire—is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. On this view, one is able to perceive others' goal-directed actions only to the extent that one is able to simulate them with one's own motor system. Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions, or can goal-directed actions be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?
answer:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――  
                         Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action  
                         ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――  



1.  Introduction  

Watching an accomplished pianist, we seem almost to “feel’’ her hands glide across the keys; cheering at a football match, we instinctively jerk forward when our striker shoots.  These familiar experiences have encouraged the thought that perceiving what others are doing relies on the covert activation of our own motor system.  The discovery of mirror neurons in macaque area F5, neurons that fire both when the animal grasps an object and when it observes another doing so, lent empirical credibility to this intuition.  An influential family of motor simulation theories (Gallese, Rizzolatti, Jeannerod, Goldman, et al.) claims that such resonance is not merely helpful but necessary: without mapping the observed movement onto one’s own motor repertoire, one could not genuinely perceive its goal-directed character.  

The present essay questions that necessity claim.  I shall: (i) clarify what is meant by perceiving goal-directed action; (ii) present the principal arguments offered for the necessity of motor resonance; (iii) review empirical and conceptual considerations that undermine those arguments; and (iv) sketch an alternative, pluralist picture on which resonance is one among several routes to action perception.  My conclusion is conditional: motor resonance is neither sufficient nor necessary for perceiving goal-directed actions, though it frequently enriches, predicts, and scaffolds such perception.



2.  What is it to perceive a goal-directed action?  

Philosophers distinguish between seeing that a bodily movement is occurring and seeing what that movement is for.  The latter is goal-perception: recognising an action as directed toward an outcome or object.  Importantly, the issue is one of perceptual content, not of subsequent inference.  When you watch someone slice bread you do not first register a series of kinematic segments and then deduce “Aha, she intends to make sandwiches”; you ordinarily see the slicing-for-eating all at once.  This phenomenology motivates the claim that action perception is “smart’’ (Siegel 2017): its content is already richly structured.  The “necessity’’ debate concerns the sub-personal mechanisms that generate this smart content: does the visual system need help from the motor system, in the form of resonance, to present the goal as visually available?

Call Resonance–Necessity (RN): For any subject S and action A performed by another agent, S perceives A as goal-directed only if S’s motor system engages in a state that simulates performing A.  RN is stronger than the weaker facilitation claim (RF) that resonance merely improves accuracy or speed.  Our question is whether RN is true.



3.  The positive case for necessity  

3.1.  The mirror neuron argument  
The initial neurophysiological discovery seemed to show a direct coding of others’ actions in motor terms.  These neurons are said to be “goal-sensitive’’ because many fire selectively when the observed movement achieves a particular distal end (e.g., grasp-to-eat vs. grasp-to-place).  Hence, Appearances of goal-directedness map onto motor representations, not onto purely visual ones.  The natural inference: if such neurons are the only cells carrying that goal information, then without them the visual system would be blind to goals.

3.2.  The developmental prediction argument  
Newborns can imitate tongue protrusion and, by four months, match seen and executed grasps.  Advocates argue that shared motor representations bootstrap the infant’s nascent capacity to recognise others’ goals before language or theory-of-mind abilities emerge.

3.3.  The interference argument  
Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) disrupting premotor cortex allegedly impairs participants’ accuracy in judging whether an observed reach aims at a near or far object.  Because the manipulation targets motor cortices rather than visual ones, the drop in performance is taken as evidence for necessity.

3.4.  The evolutionary efficiency argument  
A single representational format—motoric—economises on neural resources.  If the brain already contains fine-grained encodings of grasp, pinch, or kick for controlling one’s own body, it is cost-effective to reutilise them for perception, rather than evolve a parallel visual code for others’ actions.  Necessity follows if this reuse is mandatory.



4.  Empirical and conceptual challenges to necessity  

If RN is correct, three empirical predictions follow.  (P1) Where resonance is absent or compromised, goal-perception should fail.  (P2) Whenever resonance occurs, goal-perception should co-occur.  (P3) There should be no cases of intact goal-perception dissociated from resonance, or vice-versa.  The literature now supplies numerous violations of each prediction.

4.1.  Neuropsychological dissociations  

a.  Ideomotor apraxia.  Patients with left-hemisphere damage often cannot execute purposeful actions (poor motor programs) yet can recognise videos of such actions and can state their goals.  Their resonance ought to be minimal—their own motor repertoire is impaired—yet perception of goal remains.  

b.  Superior temporal sulcus (STS) lesions.  Some patients have the opposite profile: they exhibit impaired action recognition but preserved imitation.  Here resonance (motor programming) appears intact; what is damaged is a higher-order visual area.

c.  Autism spectrum disorder.  Individuals with autism sometimes show reduced mu-suppression (an EEG index of mirror activity), yet many can accurately describe goals.  Recent meta-analyses find no robust correlation between mirror-network activity and behavioural measures of action understanding across ASD cohorts (Hamilton 2020).

4.2.  Behavioral evidence in atypical or non-resonant contexts  

a.  Cross-effector and tool use perception.  I can readily see what a violinist is doing despite being unable to simulate his bow grip; spectators unfamiliar with chopsticks still perceive “picking up sushi’’; we understand a dog pushing open a door even though we lack tails or snouts.  Human-dog cases are especially damning: our motor repertoire does not include tail-wagging, yet the wag’s communicative goal is plainly visible.

b.  Impossible-for-us actions.  Computer animations depicting biologically impossible joints (an arm bending backwards) can still present clear goals (e.g., “handing over a cup”).  Because we cannot simulate the trajectory, resonance should fail, yet perception succeeds.

c.  Point-light displays.  Johansson’s minimal dot patterns convey “kicking a ball’’ despite lacking shape detail helpful for motor simulation (no grasp aperture, muscle tension).  The reverse is also observed: MT area noise dots produce auto-kicking illusions even when TMS knocks out M1 excitability.

4.3.  Infants and non-human animals  

A wealth of infant work demonstrates goal-attribution to mechanical pincers (Woodward 1998) and animated geometric shapes (Gergely & Csibra 2003) long before the infant could possibly perform analogous movements.  Similarly, dogs discriminate intentional vs. accidental human actions, and macaques track the “what for’’ of robots that operate outside their motor capabilities.  Unless we postulate exotic cross-species motor resonance, these data show that action understanding overgenerates motor similarity.

4.4.  Direct neurophysiological evidence  

The original mirror-neuron interpretation has been tempered by findings that (i) many F5 neurons encode purely kinematic parameters rather than goals, and (ii) neurons in visual regions such as STS code goal-identity prior to premotor areas (Hafri, Wood & Scholl 2018).  This temporal precedence challenges the causal arrow from motor to perceptual coding.

4.5.  Conceptual objections  

Necessity conflates the metaphysical and the epistemic.  Even if motor simulation offers the quickest epistemic route for the observer, it does not follow that the property of being goal-directed metaphysically depends on the observability of motor equivalence.  An amputee with congenital limb absence grasps others’ goals via environmental regularities; thus motor equivalence cannot be a constitutive condition on the perceptibility of those goals.

Moreover, invoking necessity risks a regress.  For one to simulate an action as a grasp-to-drink, one must already possess a motor program that structures the command hierarchy of sub-goals (lift-cup, tilt-cup, swallow).  If perception of a higher-level goal depended on evoking an antecedent motor representation of that very goal, the model would be circular: you need to know what the action is in order to simulate it, but simulation is supposed to generate that very knowledge.

Taken together, these considerations rebut predictions P1-3 and undermine RN.



5.  What, then, does motor resonance contribute?  

Abandoning necessity does not relegate resonance to epiphenomenal status.  Several integrative roles survive the critique:

5.1.  Prediction.  Forward models in motor cortex generate expectations about how a chord progression will end or how a tennis swing will unfold.  Such anticipatory coding can speed perceptual processing, as evidenced by sharper detection thresholds when participants’ motor plans align with observed actions (Stadler et al. 2012).

5.2.  Disambiguation under uncertainty.  When visual input is noisy, motor hypotheses can “fill in’’ missing parameters (Kilner 2011).  Functional MRI shows premotor activity rising with increasing occlusion of the action trajectory, consistent with compensatory recruitment.

5.3.  Social coupling.  Resonance underlies contagious yawning, mimicry, and entrainment, phenomena that bolster cooperation and empathy.  These functions are orthogonal to the recognition of goal-directedness yet socially invaluable.

5.4.  Learning.  Action observation activates mirror circuits that drive synaptic plasticity, facilitating skill acquisition (observational learning).  Seeing the expert’s swing primes one’s own motor pathways for subsequent practice.

All four roles are compatible with resonance being modulatory rather than constitutive of goal-perception.



6.  A pluralist framework: multiple routes to action understanding  

The empirical landscape favours a dual-route model.  One route is “visual-conceptual’’: specialised visual areas (STS, LOTC) extract kinematic patterns, object affordances, and environmental context to classify actions and assign goals.  The other is “motor-predictive’’: premotor and parietal regions covertly reproduce observed movements, providing efference-copy-like predictions.  The routes interact but retain partial independence, explaining dissociations.

Gibsonian ecological theory lends philosophical articulation: actions are seen in terms of affordances, perceivable directly from optic flow specifying object-goal relations (cup-grasp-for-drinking).  Motor experience fine-tunes sensitivity to these invariants but is not constitutively required.  Conversely, enactivist views (Noë 2004) may stress the motor basis of perception, but even they typically endorse bodily skills as enabling rather than logically necessary conditions.  Thus the pluralist can subsume portions of ecological and enactivist insights without committing to RN.



7.  Answering objections  

Necessity theorists might press three residual worries.

7.1.  The redundancy objection: If a purely visual route exists, why does the brain waste energy on resonance?  Reply: prediction, social coupling, and learning supply non-redundant payoffs.

7.2.  The developmental objection: infants’ early goal-perception is best explained by motor mapping because other cognitive resources are immature.  Reply: newborns’ sensitivity to eye-gaze, causal motion, and statistical regularities furnish alternative resources.  Moreover, cross-effector evidence (pincer robots) appears at four months, before the infant possesses those motor templates.

7.3.  The phenomenological objection: “I feel myself in the other’s movement; surely that feeling is intrinsic to perceiving her goal.”  Reply: Introspective salience need not track necessity.  The “motor empathy’’ may be an attentional gloss added by resonance, much as colour saturation is a gloss on wavelength; but we can perceive shape in achromatic scenes regardless.



8.  Conclusion  

Mirror-based motor resonance is an elegant, influential mechanism, but the accumulated empirical record and conceptual analysis show it is not a sine qua non for perceiving goal-directed actions.  One can, and routinely does, grasp the goals of others whose movements are unperformable, whose effectors differ radically, or whose kinematics defy simulation.  Resonance nonetheless plays valuable predictive, pedagogical, and affiliative functions that complement a primarily visual-conceptual route.  The upshot is a pluralistic, non-reductionist understanding of social perception: to see another’s goal is to register a nexus of kinematic, contextual, and affordance-based cues; motor resonance enriches that registration but is dispensable.  Philosophically, this vindicates a modest direct-perception thesis while preserving the embodied spirit of enactivist insight.  Good science often unseats tempting necessities, replacing them with nuanced contingencies and collaborations—and so it is here.

question: Some philosophers and cognitive scientists have argued that motor resonance—the mapping of another's action onto one's own motor repertoire—is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. On this view, one is able to perceive others' goal-directed actions only to the extent that one is able to simulate them with one's own motor system. Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions, or can goal-directed actions be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?
answer:
Motor resonance and the perception of goal-directed action:
Is simulation required?

1. Orienting the problem  

Whenever we watch another person reach for a cup, perform a tennis serve, or tap a rhythm on a desk, two quite different explanatory projects tempt philosophers and cognitive scientists. One is behavioural: explain how we visually segment the bodily movement, pick out its teleological structure, and anticipate its likely outcome. The other is neural: explain, in terms of brain mechanisms, why the movement appears to us as “for” something rather than as a mere kinematic trajectory.  

The discovery of “mirror” or “action-matching” neurons in the premotor and parietal cortices of macaques and humans offered an elegant link between the two projects. If part of my motor system automatically fires in a way that mirrors your action, then perhaps that resonance constitutes my understanding of what you are doing. A strong reading of this suggestion—defended by Rizzolatti, Gallese, and many simulation theorists—states a necessity claim:

Necessity thesis (NT): Perceiving an episode as a goal-directed action requires mapping that episode onto one’s own motor repertoire; without such covert simulation, the event cannot be experienced as goal-directed.

The rival position rejects that tight link:

Independence thesis (IT): Goal-directedness can be perceived (or at least cognised) in the absence of motor resonance; resonance may enrich or speed perception, but it is not constitutively required.

The dialectic is not merely empirical. A purely empirical dispute could be settled by showing, for instance, that patients lacking resonance capacities nevertheless perceive goals. But NT is sometimes motivated by deeper, philosophical convictions: that we can recognise mindedness only by re-enacting it, that cognition is fundamentally embodied, or that perception is inextricably tied to the motoric possibilities of the perceiver. To evaluate NT, therefore, we must examine both the empirical evidence and the conceptual scaffolding that seems to support it.

My contention will be that NT overstates its case. Motor resonance contributes significantly to our sensitivity to goal-directed actions, but it is neither necessary in principle nor in fact. I shall argue for this conclusion in five steps:

2. Clarify the target phenomenon.  
3. Present the empirical and philosophical arguments in favour of NT.  
4. Expose conceptual and empirical counterexamples that undermine necessity.  
5. Sketch alternative mechanisms by which goal-directedness can be detected.  
6. Conclude with a pluralist account: resonance is one route among several, and its importance varies with context, task, and developmental stage.

2. What is it to perceive a goal-directed action?

Saying that an action is “goal-directed” is already an interpretive commitment: we ascribe to the agent an end or telos toward which the bodily motion is ordered. Philosophically, two distinctions matter.

a. Perceptual vs. inferential uptake. Some theorists reserve “perception” for informational pickup that is relatively automatic and non-discursive, contrasted with higher-level inference. Others allow that perception can be cognitively penetrated by belief and background knowledge. For NT to be interestingly true, resonance must be shown to be the constitutive basis even of direct, low-level perception, not merely one among many sources for higher-order judgments.

b. Personal-level vs. subpersonal-level explanation. Saying that “I perceive the action as goal-directed” is a personal-level claim. Saying that “my premotor cortex resonates” is subpersonal. NT is a bridging thesis: it asserts that the latter is (part of) the realizer of the former. But bridging need not be one-to-one; multiple realizability across individuals, species, and technologies is a live possibility.

3. The case for necessity  

3.1 Neural and behavioural correlations.  
Observing others’ actions reliably activates one’s own premotor and inferior parietal regions, largely overlapping those involved in execution. TMS applied to those regions slightly impairs performance on tasks such as predicting the end-point of a reach. Infants’ mu-rhythm suppression correlates with their ability to anticipate goal states in looking-time paradigms. These facts suggest—but do not alone establish—a causal role.

3.2 Lesion studies.  
Patients with lesions in inferior frontal or parietal areas sometimes show deficits in “action understanding” tests (for instance, matching a picture of a completed goal to a short video of an ongoing action). In such cases, the motor system seems to matter more than strictly visual areas, which bolsters NT’s claim that resonance is not merely epiphenomenal.

3.3 Developmental motor constraints.  
Between 6 and 9 months, infants who become able to reach and grasp objects also show upticks in their capacity to identify similar goals in others. Sommerville and Woodward famously found that letting 3-month-olds practice “sticky-mittens” grasping procedures accelerates their sensitivity to the goal structure of adult reaches. NT interprets these findings to show that motor competence is a prerequisite for goal perception.

3.4 Philosophical embodiment arguments.  
Gallese and Goldman deploy a broader philosophical narrative: traditional “Theory-Theory” approaches picture the observer as a detached cognitive scientist inferring hidden mental states from observable behaviour. Simulation Theory, by contrast, claims that we reuse our own cognitive architecture to model the other’s states. Mirror neurons supply the neural underpinning. If the mind is embodied, then recognising intentionality without motoric embedding would be like seeing colour without activating colour-sensitive photoreceptors.

Taken together, these lines of evidence and argument yield an attractive, unified picture. Yet necessity is a strong word. To defend NT we must show (i) that whenever goal-directedness is perceived, resonance is active; and (ii) that when resonance is absent or neutralised, goal perception is impossible. The next sections challenge both conjuncts.

4. Counterarguments: resonance is not necessary  

4.1 Conceptual counterexamples  

a. Observing actions beyond one’s motor repertoire  
Imagine I watch an octopus twist its tentacles through a narrow tube to retrieve a crab. Even adult humans have no motor routines anything like multi-arm, hydrostatic limb control. Yet I can effortlessly see that the octopus is reaching “for” something. Or consider perceiving the goal structure in a falcon’s stoop: rise, tuck wings, accelerate, strike prey. The kinematics are alien, but the telos is transparent to a modestly informed observer. If NT were literally true, humans should be blind to the purposiveness of such movements—which we are not.

b. Instrument-mediated actions  
Skilled violin playing involves micro-movements that non-violinists cannot imitate. Nevertheless, novices can tell whether the player is tuning, playing a melody, or merely warming up. Again, perception outstrips motor affordance.

c. Reverse cases: motor resonance without goal perception  
Robotic imitation setups can trigger human mirror systems even when the robot executes random, non-goal-directed movements such as waving an arm in a meaningless trajectory. Here resonance occurs, yet we do not perceive goal-directedness.

These cases collectively show dissociation: goal–perception can occur without resonance and resonance can occur without goal–perception. Dissociation blocks claims of necessity.

4.2 Empirical counterevidence  

a. Congenital motor impairments  
Children with congenital muscular or neural disorders that severely limit motor production (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy) nevertheless display typical development in recognising the goals of others’ reaches and gazes, as measured by looking-time preferences and anticipatory eye movements. Because their own motor repertoires are minimal, they provide a natural test of NT; yet they pass.

b. Amputees and limb differences  
Adults born without upper limbs show robust activation in visual and parietal areas when observing manual actions, but little or no activation in the canonical mirror network. Behaviourally, they score normally on tests of action understanding and goal attribution. A recent fMRI study (Vannuscorps & Caramazza 2016) found that these individuals recruited extra-striate body areas rather than premotor regions for action recognition, demonstrating neural plasticity: the brain finds non-motor routes.

c. Early infancy prior to motor maturation  
At 4 months, well before reliable reaching emerges, infants already treat a caregiver’s reach as goal-directed; they look longer when the agent, having consistently grasped object A, suddenly grasps object B instead of reaching to a new spatial location. Woodward’s classic paradigm shows that goal-attribution precedes, rather than follows, competence in the same action.

d. Cross-modal and abstract goal recognition  
Subjects can detect goals from minimal displays where the agent is a geometric shape (a triangle “chasing” a circle) with which neither motor resonance nor anatomical matching is plausible. These Heider-Simmel stimuli still elicit intentional attributions, complete with emotional tone (“the big triangle is bullying the little one”), showing that motor matching is not necessary.

4.3 Methodological concerns  

Lesion studies and TMS manipulations rarely create complete shutdown of the motor system; they modulate it. The observed deficits therefore warrant, at best, claims about sufficiency or facilitation, not necessity. Moreover, performance drops are typically modest and task-specific; action recognition does not vanish, it merely slows or loses subtlety.

Developmental correlations can run both ways. Gaining motor abilities may heighten attention to certain kinematic patterns, increasing learning opportunities; but the correlation does not show that motor representation is the underlying representational format. Infants who succeed earlier thanks to “sticky-mittens” training might simply have more practice associating specific visual cues with outcome states.

5. How can goal-directedness be perceived without resonance?

Critics of NT must supply alternative mechanisms. Several, not mutually exclusive, are available.

5.1 Kinematic cues and rational trajectory inference  
Even simple optic flow contains informative structure about efficiency, acceleration, and directionality. Computational models show that minimal assumptions—constant velocity, shortest path, smooth curvature—allow an observer to infer likely end-points. Csibra and Gergely’s “teleological stance” posits that infants expect agents to act efficiently toward goals given situational constraints. This teleology can be satisfied by pure visual analysis of trajectories without motor rehearsal.

5.2 Affordance perception in a Gibsonian key  
James Gibson argued that perception is direct pickup of affordances—possibilities for action in the environment—not internal simulation. On this enactive reading, an agent’s movement reveals what the environment affords her, and perceiving that structure suffices for recognising the action’s point. My ability to grasp the cup is not invoked; rather, the cup’s “graspability” for the observed agent is perceived in the relational dynamic.

5.3 Conceptual and narrative knowledge  
Humans possess vast background knowledge about typical behaviours, social practices, and object functions. Seeing a person raise a glass at a wedding may be taken as “a toast” because we possess the concept of toasting, not because we motorically represent glass-raising. This route can operate recursively: if the person’s arm trembles and the glass wobbles, I may infer nervousness or inebriation—states not obviously encoded in motor schemata.

5.4 Predictive coding and abstract generative models  
Contemporary neuroscience increasingly favours predictive processing frameworks in which the brain constructs hierarchical generative models to minimise prediction error. Nothing in that architecture mandates motoric formats at every level. A higher-level node might encode goals in a quasi-propositional code (“Agent wants to grasp apple”) while lower-level nodes encode expected kinematics. In people lacking a motor repertoire, the higher levels may connect directly to visual expectation layers without passing through motor cortex. Resonance is, on this view, a convenient but dispensable shortcut.

5.5 Social and linguistic mediation  
We often learn about goals by communication: “She’s looking for her keys.” Observers primed with such information can spot goal-directedness even in noisy or impoverished displays that do not elicit measurable mirror activity. Language thus opens a route orthogonal to resonance.

6. Philosophical reflection: what kind of necessity?

NT’s defenders sometimes exploit an ambiguity between causal, constitutive, and epistemic necessity.

• Causal necessity: given human neurobiology, resonance always in fact occurs when goal-perception occurs. Counterexamples from amputees and infancy falsify this claim.  

• Constitutive necessity: resonance is part of what it is to perceive an event as goal-directed; take it away and you no longer genuinely perceive the telos, even if you can verbally report it. This higher bar is vulnerable to the octopus case: I phenomenally experience the octopus as reaching, yet lack resonant mapping. One could respond that I merely “judge” but do not “perceive,” but that stipulation strips NT of empirical content.  

• Epistemic necessity: we can know another’s goal only by simulating it. The Heider-Simmel and linguistic cases refute this too: we gain knowledge of goals without bodily simulation.

Hence, under any plausible interpretation of necessity, the thesis fails.

7. A pluralist alternative

The empirical landscape points toward a multiple-routes model. We possess:

Route 1: Motor resonance—fast, automatic, delivering rich, kinesthetic predictions, crucial when the observed action closely matches one’s own motor repertoire and when fine-grained anticipation is needed (e.g., cooperative tasks).  

Route 2: Visual-kinematic heuristics—trajectory extrapolation and efficiency judgments, operating even for unfamiliar effectors.  

Route 3: Conceptual-semantic schemas—employing background knowledge, object affordances, and social scripts.  

Route 4: Communicative/language-based cues—utterances, gestures, and conventional signals that directly encode goals.

These routes interact: resonance can supply priors to visual analysis; conceptual knowledge can modulate resonance by refining goal hypotheses; and language can override misleading motor cues (a mime’s pretend drinking is recognised as pretend because contextual clues trump kinematics).

Such pluralism is compatible with the Bayesian predictive framework: different evidential channels update a common generative model. The motor system’s contribution is weighted by reliability and cost. For tasks requiring micro-timing—catching a ball thrown by a partner—motor resonance earns high weight. For tasks involving alien bodies—observing a snake strike—visual heuristic channels dominate.

8. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: Even when we observe birds or shapes, the mirror system may still operate abstractly; we just lack the tools to measure it.  

Reply: The burden of proof lies on NT. We have direct evidence of preserved goal recognition in the virtual absence of canonical mirror-circuit activation (e.g., congenital limb absence). Unless “motor resonance” is redefined so broadly that any cortical process counts, NT becomes unfalsifiable.

Objection 2: Cases of congenital impairment may recruit homologous motor circuitry in other effectors (e.g., foot or mouth).  

Reply: fMRI shows recruitment of occipito-temporal “body areas” rather than motor cortex, undermining the homologous substitution hypothesis.

Objection 3: Perhaps goal perception in octopus and bird cases is “inferential,” not genuine perception.  

Reply: The phenomenology is immediate and effortless; subjects can anticipate end-points without conscious deliberation, and reaction-time studies demonstrate rapid predictive eye movements. Setting aside terminological stipulations, the functional capacity is demonstrably intact.

9. Conclusion

Motor resonance is real, powerful, and philosophically intriguing. It supports embodied accounts of social cognition, enriches predictive precision in cooperative contexts, and grounds the distinctive phenomenology of “feeling” the other’s action. Nevertheless, the total body of evidence reveals that goal perception is robustly multi-modal and multiply realisable. Organisms, especially humans, can perceive purposiveness through motor simulation, through purely visual analysis, through conceptual frameworks, and through communicative signals. Motor resonance is therefore not a necessary condition, though it is often a sufficient and useful one.

Recognising this pluralism alleviates an unnecessary tension between embodiment enthusiasts and proponents of more traditional, representation-heavy theories of mind. The motor system is neither the entire story nor an incidental bystander. It is one protagonist in a distributed cast, recruited flexibly according to the demands of the narrative. A mature theory of social perception will map not a single road but a network of paths—all leading, sometimes converging, to our grasp of others as goal-directed, intentional agents.

question: Some philosophers and cognitive scientists have argued that motor resonance—the mapping of another's action onto one's own motor repertoire—is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. On this view, one is able to perceive others' goal-directed actions only to the extent that one is able to simulate them with one's own motor system. Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions, or can goal-directed actions be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?
answer:
Motor resonance—roughly, the recruitment of one’s own motor system when observing another individual act—has attracted enormous philosophical and empirical interest since the discovery of mirror neurons in macaques nearly three decades ago. A large and influential body of work claims that such resonance is not just a frequent accompaniment of social perception but a necessary condition for it: unless the observer is able, covertly, to map the perceived movement onto his or her own motor repertoire, the movement cannot be experienced as goal-directed. In what follows I argue that this necessity claim cannot be sustained. While motor resonance is an important, oft-recruited resource for interpreting others’ actions, multiple lines of conceptual analysis and empirical evidence show that goal-directed actions can be—and routinely are—perceived in its absence. The stronger thesis of necessity therefore gives way to a weaker, more ecumenical view on which resonance is one component in a pluralistic architecture of social perception.

1. Clarifying the Debate: What Is at Stake?

Before the arguments can be assessed, three distinctions must be kept firmly in view.

(1) Perception versus inference. To say that an action is “perceived” as goal-directed is stronger than saying that the perceiver can infer or believe it to be so. Perception suggests a phenomenologically immediate, non-inferential grasp of the action’s teleology, whereas inference allows for discursive or reflective mediation.

(2) Necessity versus facilitation. The motor simulation literature frequently slides from the claim that resonance facilitates goal attribution to the more ambitious claim that it is strictly required. The philosophical question here is one of modal force: Must resonance occur for goal perception to be possible at all, or is it merely one among several sufficient routes?

(3) Kinds of resonance. There is “strict” resonance (isomorphic muscle-specific activation) and “generic” resonance (activation anywhere in the motor system, possibly far removed from the effector perceived). The necessity thesis is only interesting if strict resonance is intended; otherwise it borders on triviality, because low-level premotor circuits light up in innumerable contexts and picking out which counts as “resonance” is arbitrary.

2. The Case for Necessity

Proponents of the necessity claim marshal three families of arguments.

(a) Mirror-neuron correlations. In both macaques and humans, brain areas active during action execution also activate while watching conspecifics perform the same action. This seems tailor-made for an “embodied simulation” of observed behavior. Moreover, intracranial recordings in epileptic patients show temporally precise resonant firing that precedes recognition of goal completion, suggesting that the motor code leads rather than follows higher-level interpretation.

(b) Developmental studies. Three-month-old infants who are not yet capable of grasping often fail to anticipate the goal of a grasping action; after a few weeks of motor training, they succeed, and this improvement correlates with signatures of corticospinal resonance (e.g., mu-rhythm desynchronization). The resonance theorist infers a causal link: newly acquired motor skills provide the representational vocabulary in which others’ goals can be read.

(c) Pathology and disruption. Adults with ideomotor apraxia or parietal lesions—conditions that compromise one’s own purposeful movement—sometimes show impairments in understanding others’ actions. Similarly, using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to disrupt premotor cortex can retard the recognition of action goals. Taken together, these results are offered as a demonstration that when the motor system is offline, goal perception collapses.

3. Conceptual Problems for the Necessity Claim

These considerations are impressive, yet they fall short of establishing necessity.

First, the familiar “correlation is not causation” warning bites especially hard. The fact that motor and perceptual activations are concurrent does not entail that the former is the causal basis of the latter; both may be effects of a common upstream process. The developmental data likewise underdetermine causality: motor practice may simply expose infants to richer proprioceptive and visual statistics that independently tune perceptual circuits.

Second, the necessity claim exaggerates what it means to “lack” a motor repertoire. Motor commands are extraordinarily plastic and hierarchically organized. Even when I cannot execute the precise kinematics of a gymnast’s triple-back handspring, I share higher-order motor primitives—flex-extend, accelerate-decelerate, maintain balance—sufficient to yield some generic resonance. If necessity is satisfied by such abstraction, the thesis becomes trivial; if it is not, the thesis is easily refuted by cases in which no high-fidelity mapping is possible but perception proceeds unimpaired (see section 4).

Third, the claim confuses phenomenology with implementation. Suppose the motor system indeed contributes causally to goal perception in neurotypical adults. That would show it is often used, not that its contribution is conceptually or metaphysically required. A mechanism’s ubiquity is no guarantee of its necessity; we blink when we perceive, yet blinking is not a pre-condition of perception.

4. Empirical Counter-Evidence

The empirical literature has increasingly turned up dissociations between motor resonance and goal perception.

(a) Congenital or acquired paralysis. Individuals with spinal cord injuries that eliminate voluntary movement below the neck nonetheless display intact recognition of lower-limb actions (e.g., jogging, kicking). Their primary sensorimotor cortex for the legs is functionally disconnected, and yet they perceive goals effortlessly. If strict resonance were necessary, such patients should be blind to leg-based teleology.

(b) Congenital limb absence. People born without arms reliably identify the goal of reaching-and-grasping movements, and their discrimination thresholds for subtle variations in grasp intent are comparable to controls. Neuroimaging often shows activation in parietal visual areas but muted or reorganized premotor activity, confirming that perceptual competence survives radical motor difference.

(c) Tool use and novel effectors. Observers instantly perceive the goal of someone turning a screw with an unfamiliar gyroscopic screwdriver, or of a violinist executing a novel bowing technique, despite lacking any capacity to replicate the action. Even in macaques, mirror neurons generalize only weakly to tool actions; yet humans display crisp goal perception here.

(d) Cross-species perception. Human adults can discern whether a dog is chasing prey or playing, and dogs can differentiate human reaching for an object from merely touching it accidentally. The motor repertoires do not overlap in a way that would support detailed resonance, but goal perception is nevertheless robust.

(e) Infants and abstract animations. In classic studies by Gergely and Csibra, 12-month-olds interpret geometric shapes as pursuing goals when the motion path is the most efficient relative to an obstacle. No opportunity for motor matching exists—the infants cannot simulate the movement of a triangle sliding across a 2-D plane—yet they detect goal-directedness and even look longer when efficiency is violated.

Together these bodies of evidence show that motor resonance, while common, is not indispensable.

5. Alternative Pathways to Goal Perception

If resonance is not obligatory, what does support our remarkable sensitivity to others’ goals? Four complementary accounts are prominent.

(1) Direct perception via kinematic cues (Gibsonian affordances). The spatiotemporal profile of a movement—its velocity, curvature, and biomechanics—carries information specifying the distal goal. Seeing a hand shape pre-adjust to object size makes the goal visually obvious; no motor emulation is needed, just sensitivity to invariant patterns.

(2) Teleological reasoning. Gergely and Csibra propose that observers adopt a “rationality principle”: agents act so as to minimize cost for achieving goals given situational constraints. Goal perception thus involves evaluating efficiency, not simulating muscular effort. Computational models formalize this as inverse planning in a Bayesian framework; simulation, when it occurs, is over abstract trajectories, not over one’s own motor commands.

(3) Predictive processing. On hierarchical predictive coding views, the brain continuously generates hypotheses about causes of sensory input at multiple levels. Motor areas may participate in this generative loop, but so do parietal and prefrontal areas coding statistical regularities, environmental affordances, and social norms. What matters for perception is the successful suppression of prediction error, which can proceed through weighted contributions from many sources. Lesion or TMS studies arguably show that dampening motor predictions slows error reduction, not that other routes are unavailable.

(4) Linguistic and cultural schemas. Many human actions—writing an email, ceremonial bowing—rely on shared conventions. Understanding them draws on semantic memory and socio-cultural lore, often exceeding anything that can be mirrored at the level of proximal kinematics.

6. A Pluralistic Picture

The evidence suggests a multilevel, multi-route architecture.

• Early, feed-forward kinematic analysis provides a rapid, probabilistic guess of likely goals.

• Motor resonance adds a second wave of constraint, honing predictions where an executable match is available.

• Higher-order pragmatic and contextual knowledge overlays still further constraints.

The contribution of any component is context-sensitive. Resonance is most helpful when observed actions fall within the observer’s sensorimotor repertoire, time is short, and contextual clues are sparse. When those conditions do not hold, other systems pick up the slack.

7. Replies to Remaining Objections

Objection 1: Disrupting motor cortex with TMS impairs goal recognition; therefore the motor system is necessary.

Reply: Impairment is not elimination. TMS induces transient noise, forcing the perceptual system to rely on less efficient cues. That performance dips under such noise is compatible with sufficiency, not necessity.

Objection 2: Infants’ anticipation of goals tracks their own motor development; hence motor competence begets perception.

Reply: The correlation is real but over-interpreted. Motor practice yields richer multisensory statistics, mature attention to object affordances, and parent-mediated social learning. Training confined to observation without execution can produce similar gains, indicating that execution is not crucial.

Objection 3: Phenomenology speaks for resonance—we feel ourselves “doing” what we watch.

Reply: Introspective warmth is unreliable. Phenomenology may reflect post-perceptual imagery or attention to already interpreted events. Moreover, many adults report no motor imagery when understanding abstract or culturally unfamiliar actions, yet comprehension is secure.

8. Conclusion

Motor resonance is a potent and fascinating ingredient of social cognition. Its discovery has catalyzed new experiments, therapies, and philosophical models. Nevertheless, the available evidence and conceptual clarity force us to reject the strong necessity thesis. Goal-directed actions can be, and often are, perceived by agents whose motor possibilities diverge drastically from the actions perceived, or whose motor pathways are temporarily or permanently disabled. Resonance enhances perception when available, but the mind is equipped with a battery of other resources—kinematic attunement, teleological inference, predictive coding, and socio-cultural knowledge—to secure robust goal understanding.

In short: motor resonance is a useful servant, not a sovereign master, of our capacity to see the purposiveness in other minds.

question: Some philosophers and cognitive scientists have argued that motor resonance—the mapping of another's action onto one's own motor repertoire—is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. On this view, one is able to perceive others' goal-directed actions only to the extent that one is able to simulate them with one's own motor system. Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions, or can goal-directed actions be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?
answer:
1. Introduction  

In contemporary philosophy of mind and cognitive science “motor resonance” designates a class of neural and bodily processes in which an observer’s motor system becomes active in a way that mirrors, simulates, or reenacts the action currently being witnessed. The paradigm case is the mirror-neuron system (MNS) discovered in macaque area F5 and its presumed homologues in human premotor and parietal cortex. With dazzling rapidity the initial finding was transformed into the more theoretical claim that resonance is not merely an interesting accompaniment of action perception but instead a pre-condition for seeing an event as an intentional, goal-directed action at all. If I watch you grasp a cup, what makes that observation intelligible as “grasping” (rather than a meaningless spasm) is said to be the fact that, underneath my skull, the very same motor pattern for grasping is covertly emulated.  

The claim is bold and has wide-ranging implications for social cognition, theory of mind, and even ethics. Yet it is far from uncontroversial. Must the perception of goal-directed actions be mediated by resonance or can such perception occur independently—perhaps on the basis of purely visual, kinematic, or ecological information? I shall argue for the latter. Motor resonance almost certainly facilitates action interpretation in many contexts, and its impairment can impose measurable costs. But resonance is neither necessary in the logical sense (there can be perception without it) nor in the empirical sense (huge swaths of normal action perception proceed in its absence). The case unfolds in six steps.  

2. Clarifying the Target Thesis  

The “necessity” thesis can be interpreted in two main ways.

A. Logical necessity: It is conceptually impossible (a contradiction in terms) to perceive an event as goal-directed unless one is covertly simulating it with one’s own motor apparatus.  

B. Empirical necessity: Given the actual make-up of the human perceptual system, resonance processes always occur, or must occur, whenever an observer succeeds in perceiving an action as goal-directed.  

Philosophers who speak loosely of “necessary conditions” sometimes slide between the two readings. Only the second is empirically testable; the first is purely conceptual. My strategy will be to (i) question the conceptual link and (ii) survey empirical findings that disconfirm the universal-occurrence claim.  

3. Why Resonance Was Thought Indispensable  

Proponents have offered three principal lines of motivation.

3.1. The poverty-of-the-visual-stimulus argument. A moving limb is an underdetermined pattern of pixels or retinal activations. Without supplementing that pattern with something “from within,” the story goes, the percept lacks the mark of intentional directedness. The motor system provides that supplement by “tagging” the observed movement with an executable motor plan.  

3.2. The common-coding principle. Wolfgang Prinz and others argue that perception and action share a common representational format; therefore, only by acting-or-potentially-acting can an organism perceive action.  

3.3. Developmental data. Infants begin to distinguish goal-directed reaches from mere flails at roughly the same age that they acquire those reaches in their own repertoire. On a resonance reading, the arrival of the neural circuitry subserving their own grasping confers the conceptual category “goal” on observed events.  

These motivations carry weight, but each is defeasible.  

4. The Conceptual Objection: Goal-Directedness Is Ecologically Specified  

The “logical” necessity claim inherits an intellectual debt to Cartesian internalism: properties such as goal-directedness must be projected by an inner mechanism because they do not reside in the “thin” geometry of the stimulus. Yet an alternative tradition, running from George Herbert Mead through J. J. Gibson to contemporary ecological and enactivist theorists, denies that action perception needs such supplementation. On a Gibsonian account, affordances—action-relevant possibilities—are specified directly in the dynamic structure of the optic array. A hand closing in on a cup along a grasp-appropriate trajectory just is grasping; no motor contagion is needed to endow it with purposiveness.  

The conceptual moral is not that resonance cannot figure in the perceptual process, but that its presence is not constitutive of perceiving an event as instrumental. One can coherently imagine a creature (e.g., an octopus) seeing a human grasp a cup and registering the event as a goal-directed “taking” while lacking the motor circuits for a five-fingered precision grip. Nothing contradictory is involved.  

5. Empirical Counter-Evidence  

5.1. Individuals without the relevant motor repertoire.  

a) Congenital limb-absence. A striking fMRI study by Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) showed that people born without upper limbs not only understand but visually anticipate the kinematics of grasping actions with intact speed and accuracy. Critically, multivoxel pattern analysis revealed no standard mirror-neuron activity in premotor cortex, yet their perceptual judgments were unimpaired.  

b) Locked-in patients. Behavioral work indicates that such patients, though unable to move, can track and predict others’ actions in real time. While some residual motor simulation may remain subcortically, the bulk of cortical motor execution circuitry is offline, undermining the universality claim.  

5.2. Cross-species perception. Cats perceive, stalk, and interpret the goal-directed trajectories of birds in flight, despite lacking the wing-flapping motor program. Similarly, humans easily attribute goals to snakes or drones, although we cannot simulate constricting coils or quad-rotor propulsion.  

5.3. Neurostimulation interference. If resonance were strictly necessary, disrupting the motor system ought to eliminate, not merely slow, goal recognition. TMS over premotor cortex typically yields a ∼50- to 100-ms delay in action understanding tasks but does not abolish the capacity (Avenanti, Cattaneo, et al. 2013). Partial deficit speaks to facilitation, not necessity.  

5.4. Developmental dissociations. At 3 months, infants with limited grasping skill already treat reaches as goal-directed when the hand literally cannot reach its target due to a barrier, showing “Woodward” preferences. Similarly, 10-month infants who have never walked attribute goals to upright walking agents. The developmental correlation between own-action competence and other-action understanding is real but rough-grained; it allows for many counter-instances.  

5.5. Artificial vision systems. Deep-learning architectures trained on large video corpora now classify goal-directed actions better than chance with no “motor” pathway at all, thereby serving as a proof of concept that purely perceptual architectures can extract goal structure. While one must not anthropomorphize networks, their performance falsifies the claim of a necessary computational architecture containing motor emulators.  

6. What Resonance Actually Contributes  

The negative result (not necessary) should not be mistaken for a deflationary verdict on motor resonance tout court. A growing consensus assigns it three supplementary roles:

6.1. Temporal prediction. The internal forward models embedded in motor circuitry excel at extrapolating near-future kinematics under uncertainty. This can tighten perceptual alignment and allow split-second social coordination.  

6.2. Affective attunement. Somatotopic resonance supports empathic feeling of effort, strain, or pain, enriching the qualitative texture of one’s perception. You may see the backhand volley not just as a goal but feel its muscular demand.  

6.3. Learning and calibration. During infancy and skill acquisition, motor resonance may scaffold the mapping from visible trajectories onto abstract action categories, especially where vision alone underdetermines functional possibilities.  

In short, motor resonance is like stereo sound: highly useful, sometimes immersive, but one can still hear the melody on a mono speaker.  

7. Replies to Remaining Objections  

Objection 1: “Even limb-deficient individuals show activation in premotor cortex when observing action; perhaps the simulation occurs in an ‘amputated’ format.”  
Reply: The debated papers carefully distinguish visual-motor coupling from canonical mirror coding. Moreover, the activation appears in multimodal association cortex, not primary motor maps somatotopically specific to missing effectors. Without homology, the core resonance thesis loses its bite.  

Objection 2: “The TMS delays demonstrate that when resonance is weakened, recognition slows; wouldn’t a more powerful disruption wipe it out?”  
Reply: Lesion studies (e.g., left inferior frontal damage) often leave intact spontaneous action recognition while compromising pantomime production. Evolution rarely builds single-points-of-failure into socially crucial capacities. Redundant visual and inferential pathways carry the load when the motor route falters.  

Objection 3: “Cross-species cases invoke different action systems with overlapping abstract structures; perhaps the organism simulates at a higher, goal-level rather than effector-level.”  
Reply: But that is to concede the point. The original thesis targeted motor resonance precisely as an effector-specific mapping. A shift to “abstract emulation” moves us into the terrain of cognitive inference, not motor mirroring, and abandons the distinct physiologic signature that gave the resonance claim its explanatory allure.  

8. A Positive Alternative: Teleological and Relational Perception  

If resonance is not obligatory, what grounds the perception of goals? Two complementary frameworks are promising.

8.1. The teleological stance (Gergely & Csibra). Perceivers tacitly assume agents take the most efficient means to reach desired ends, constrained by environmental affordances. Signatures of efficiency—shortest path, least force, energy minimization—are directly recoverable from spatiotemporal geometry. Such “rationality” cues allow observers to tag trajectories as purposeful without simulating the motor routine.  

8.2. Direct relationalism (Chemero, Witherington). Goal perception is neither in the head nor in the stimulus alone but in the relational unfolding of organism-environment dynamics. Seeing a hand move toward a cup against the background of thirst constitutes a cliff of information specifying the “for-the-sake-of” structure Gibson called the “ambient optic array.”  

Both accounts predict that perception of goal-directedness can be present in organisms with dissimilar or absent motor programs, provided they are attuned to the relevant ecological regularities.  

9. Philosophical Upshot  

What hangs on the debate extends beyond empirical psychology. If social cognition always piggybacks on first-person motor simulation, then interpersonal understanding is fundamentally egocentric; we grasp others only by importing them into the frame of our own embodiment. Rejecting necessity loosens this grip and rehabilitates the possibility of genuinely other-directed perception, a point dear to phenomenologists from Scheler to Merleau-Ponty. Moreover, ethical openness to forms of life very unlike our own (artificial agents, animals, drastically disabled persons) finds firmer footing when we grant that goal-directedness can be “read off” their trajectories without presupposing mirrorable sameness.  

10. Conclusion  

Motor resonance is a beautiful discovery and a versatile tool in the brain’s kit for social attunement. Nonetheless, the empirical literature, theoretical analysis, and cross-species considerations converge on a common verdict: resonance is facilitative, not foundational. One can, and frequently does, perceive goal-directed actions independently of simulating them with one’s own motor system. Like a helpful subtitle track, resonance can clarify the plot, especially under noisy conditions, but the movie plays perfectly intelligibly when the subtitles are turned off.

question: Some philosophers and cognitive scientists have argued that motor resonance—the mapping of another's action onto one's own motor repertoire—is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. On this view, one is able to perceive others' goal-directed actions only to the extent that one is able to simulate them with one's own motor system. Is motor resonance necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions, or can goal-directed actions be perceived independently of resonance mechanisms?
answer:
Motor resonance is one of the most celebrated discoveries of contemporary cognitive science. In macaques and humans alike, the observation of another individual’s reaching, grasping, or kicking is accompanied by covert activity in one’s own motor cortex—activity that, if it were not inhibited, would command one’s own hand or foot to move in just the observed fashion. From the mid-1990s onward this “mirror-neuron system” quickly became the cornerstone of a more general simulationist picture of social cognition. On that picture, action understanding, empathy, and even language comprehension are all functions of an internal emulator that re-enacts the observed behaviour in one’s own sensorimotor circuits. The strongest formulation of the view says more than that motor resonance is useful or typical; it says that resonance is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed action at all. If the motor emulator is shut down or if the action lies outside the observer’s motor repertoire, the observer, so the claim goes, cannot truly perceive it as goal-directed.

Is that bold claim defensible? I shall argue that it is not. While motor resonance is an important, and perhaps in some contexts indispensable, contributor to social perception, it is not constitutively necessary for the perception of goal-directed actions. My argument proceeds in five steps. (1) I clarify what the necessity claim amounts to. (2) I rehearse the empirical and conceptual considerations that motivate it. (3) I marshal counter-evidence drawn from atypical populations, cross-species perception, and the perception of technologically mediated or otherwise non-resonant actions. (4) I sketch alternative, non-motoric models of goal attribution that account for these data. (5) I diagnose the residual appeal of the necessity claim and suggest a more modest, integrative role for resonance in action perception.

1. What would it mean for resonance to be necessary?

Necessity, in this context, is a modal and explanatory notion. The thesis is not merely that motor activation happens to accompany successful action perception, nor that it improves accuracy or speed. Rather, it is that a subject S’s being able to perceive another’s behaviour B as goal-directed metaphysically depends on S’s being able to token a corresponding motor representation M of B. If no such mapping is available—if the relevant neurons are lesioned, paralysed, or developmentally absent—genuine perception of goal-directedness is supposed to be impossible, not merely impaired.

Notice two consequences. First, the thesis concerns perception, not merely belief or theoretical inference. The simulationist typically holds that what is at stake is an early, quasi-perceptual level at which the target’s arm-movement already appears as a reaching for the cup, rather than as a kinematic trajectory that is later interpreted. Second, the thesis is a biconditional in practice: it is not enough that resonance be sufficient, it must also be inescapable whenever perception of goal-directedness occurs.

2. Why think resonance is necessary?

The strongest empirical argument comes from interference studies. In human TMS experiments, applying magnetic pulses to premotor cortex while subjects observe grasping actions slows their ability to discriminate the goal object or to predict action kinematics. This suggests a causal contribution of the motor system to perceptual processing. Intracortical recordings in epilepsy patients show mirror-like neurons firing in lockstep with observed actions down to parametric details such as grip aperture. Developmentally, infants who are still motorically incapable of certain actions (e.g., raking a toy with a hook tool) appear not to anticipate the goal of those actions when others perform them, and their anticipation improves once they can perform the action themselves. Such findings support what we might call the “calibration” version of the resonance thesis: motor development tunes perceptual systems for social understanding.

There is also a conceptual argument, indebted to Gibsonian and enactivist themes. On this view, to see an action as reaching for a cup is to perceive it under a motor intentional description. The very content of action concepts is grounded in the agent’s own sensorimotor repertoire. Goal states, so construed, are nothing over and above patterns of possible bodily movements oriented toward distal objects. If one lacked a repertoire of reaching, there would be no representational resource with which to articulate the observed movement as reaching. In the slogan: no motor know-how, no action know-that.

3. Empirical counter-evidence

Despite their prima facie force, both empirical and conceptual arguments overstate their case. A wide range of findings show that goal-directedness can be perceived in the absence of any plausible motor correspondence.

3.1 Congenital and acquired motor deficiencies

Individuals born without upper limbs (amelia) cannot physically perform grasping, yet fMRI studies reveal typical activation of higher-level visual areas when they watch others grasp, and their behavioural performance in action recognition tasks is normal. More strikingly, these individuals often show little or no activation in classical motor resonance areas, yet they describe and anticipate others’ grasps as accurately as control subjects. Similarly, patients with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, who have lost nearly all voluntary motor control, continue to recognise and predict the goals of actions they can no longer perform.

3.2 Cross-species perception

Humans effortlessly perceive the goal-directedness of a dog chasing a ball, a squirrel leaping from branch to branch, or a hummingbird hovering to sip nectar. Few humans possess the proprioceptive patterns needed to emulate those actions. The same point can be turned around: dogs can track human pointing and fetch a thrown stick, yet their forelimbs cannot duplicate our manual actions. If goal perception required motor resonance, such cross-species understanding would be mysterious.

3.3 Novel or impossible actions

Parkour experts may run up walls and flip over railings in ways novices cannot imagine executing, yet spectators at a parkour competition have no difficulty seeing that the athlete is attempting to vault a gap or scale a wall. Audiences at a science-fiction movie instantly perceive the telekinetic “force pull” used by a Jedi character as directed toward levitating an object, even though no human can perform or has ever performed that action. The kinematics violate the constraints of our motor system, but the goal is perceptually clear.

3.4 Tool use and technological mediation

Humans manipulate joysticks, computer mice, and robotic surgical tools whose distal effects are not linearly mappable onto limb motion. Observers can nonetheless see the surgeon’s motions through a robotic interface as directed toward suturing tissue in a patient metres away. The visual system extracts an abstract, end-effector-centred representation rather than a literal body-centred one, bypassing the need for mirror-matching.

3.5 Neonatal and infant data revisited

New-borns a few days old react with longer looking times when a hand repeatedly reaches for object A and then unexpectedly reaches over the same trajectory to object B. Such dishabituation is taken to indicate goal attribution. Yet these neonates lack mature reaching skills and thus presumably lack the required motor “calibration”. More generally, motor development and goal perception proceed in tandem but not in lockstep: infants can attribute goals for some actions (e.g., an abstract block climbing a barrier to reach another block) before they possess the motor ability to reproduce any analogue of the action.

4. Alternative architectures for goal perception

If motor resonance is not strictly necessary, what mechanisms might suffice? At least three families of models answer that question.

4.1 Teleological reasoning with rationality constraints

On the so-called “teleological stance” (Gergely & Csibra) observers implicitly assume that agents act efficiently to realise desirable outcomes given environmental constraints. Perceiving a block detour around a barrier is enough to trigger an expectation that, once the barrier is removed, the block will take a straight path. This inference can be implemented with domain-general causal pattern detectors without invoking motor emulation.

4.2 Purely visual predictive coding

Predictive-processing models treat action perception as hierarchical Bayesian inference over visual dynamics. Generative models of optic flow and object mechanics forecast the unfolding trajectory, while prediction-error signals refine the model. A “visuodynamic emulator” can play the same computational role that a motor emulator would, yet its representational basis is visual, not motoric. Indeed, neuroimaging shows that superior temporal sulcus, posterior parietal cortex, and motion-sensitive area MT dynamically encode others’ action goals without obligatory recruitment of ventral premotor areas.

4.3 Affordance-based ecological perception

Gibson’s ecological psychology insists that what perceivers pick up are affordances—opportunities offered by the environment—in virtue of structured energy arrays.
