question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
A Sense of Time without Time as a Cause
                                                   --------------------------------------

1. Introduction  

A recurrent sceptical argument maintains that there can be no genuine “sense of time,” because the very idea of a sensory system presupposes causal impact from an external, detectable property upon the sensory organ, and—so the objection runs—time does not causally impinge on anything. Photons strike the retina, pressure waves jostle the cochlea, and volatile molecules meet olfactory receptors, but nothing analogous, the objector claims, occurs in the case of time. In consequence, whatever we call our temporal awareness—experienced duration, simultaneity judgements, timing of actions—cannot be sensory in the same manner as vision, audition, or touch.  

The objection packs considerable intuitive force. Yet many philosophers and cognitive scientists hold that organisms—including humans—do in fact possess specialised mechanisms for tracking temporal structure, mechanisms whose behavioural and perceptual outputs display characteristic signatures of an information-bearing sensory system. How can that be? How can a mechanism carry information about a variable that does not itself causally “push” on the mechanism?  

The aim of this essay is to offer a systematic response. I shall argue that the objection rests on a conflation of two distinct roles that an environmental feature may play vis-à-vis a sensory system: (i) acting as the *proximal stimulus* that triggers activity in the receptor, and (ii) determining an *information-theoretic correlation* between states of the system and states of the environment. When those roles come apart, the causal-impact requirement evaporates. A clock—even the organic “clocks” studied by cognitive science—carries information about time because its internal dynamics are law-governed functions of elapsed time, even though time itself exerts no causal force over and above the microphysical causes already present. In this respect, temporal sensing is no more metaphysically problematic than a thermometer’s sensing of temperature once we are clear about what does and does not do the causal work.  

Section 2 clarifies what the objection means by “causal impotence.” Section 3 distinguishes different conceptions of sensory systems and shows why only one version feeds the objection. Section 4 sketches an information-theoretic account of representation that dissolves the need for time as an additional cause. Section 5 describes two concrete families of temporal mechanisms—mechanical clocks and neural interval timers—to illustrate how the account plays out in practice. Section 6 replies to residual worries, including the “displacement problem” (a clock tracks only its own workings, not time “out there”) and the metaphysical question of whether time passes. A brief conclusion summarises the argument.

2. What Does It Mean to Say Time Is Causally Impotent?  

The claim that “time exerts no causal influence” can be unpacked in at least three ways.  

a) *No event may have time itself among its efficient causes.* When an apple falls, the story is told in terms of gravitational interactions, not “because ten seconds passed.”  

b) *Temporal relations are parameters, not forces.* The fundamental laws of physics use the variable t as an index ordering states of a system; they do not introduce a field that pushes matter simply by virtue of being temporal.  

c) *There is no temporal counterpart to photons or sound waves.* Nothing analogous travels from temporal property to receptor.  

All three ideas speak to the same intuition: whereas light or pressure literally acts on the sensory receptor, time does not. But remember: causes come packaged with laws. A charged particle in an electric field accelerates not because “space” pushes on it, but because the laws describing the field include space-indexed parameters. The temporal case is formally parallel. The state of a physical system S at time t is determined (in deterministic regimes) by its earlier states plus the laws; the laws contain an explicit time parameter. In this sense, time is written *into* the causal structure of the world even while never acting as a distinct *force­-like* agent. The question, then, is whether a sensory system might exploit that structural fact to carry information about t.  

3. Two Conceptions of a Sensory System  

Call the first conception *Impact Receptoralism*: a sensory system is fundamentally a receptor-effector chain that begins with an exogenous stimulus impinging on a receptor surface. Traditional textbook accounts of vision or audition adopt this model. If Impact Receptoralism is the only legitimate notion of sensing, the causal-impotence objection may appear decisive.  

But contemporary cognitive science has long moved beyond the receptor-driven picture. Many paradigmatic instances of biological sensing depend on internal processes that are not triggered by an incoming signature of the target variable. The canonical example is chemotaxis in *E. coli*: internal molecular networks oscillate, and the bacterium compares successive samples of the environment to compute a spatial gradient. Spatial location is not itself causing the oscillation; instead, the organism temporally integrates disparate signals to *infer* a spatial property. Similar stories apply to vestibular orientation, proprioception, and immune recognition. What unites these examples is not receptor impact but *informational covariance* between internal states and distal variables, a covariance explained by the physical laws governing both.  

Let us therefore adopt a second conception, *Informational Functionalism*: a system S counts as a sensory system for variable V if  

(1) There exists a physically grounded mapping f such that, over a specified operating range, f(t) = ⟨state of S at t⟩ ;  

(2) The mapping is reliably co-variant: different values of V lead, via the lawful evolution of the system, to distinct internal states;  

(3) The organism exploits that covariance to guide behaviour in a manner that enhances fitness (or, for artefacts, achieves a design function).  

Under Informational Functionalism, a receptor triggered by external impact is merely *one possible* mechanism for satisfying (1)–(3). Nothing in the definition demands that V itself be an efficient cause. What matters is that the state of S is a *deterministic (or probabilistic) function* of V according to natural laws.  

4. Information without Direct Causal Impact  

Information in the Shannon sense is a measure of *correlation*: S carries information about V to the extent that the probability distribution over V is narrowed when one conditions on S. Suppose that for an ideal pendulum clock with length L, the angle θ of the pendulum at physical time t is governed (neglecting friction) by θ(t) = θ₀ cos(√(g/L) t). Given knowledge of the clock’s initial phase θ₀, the current θ fixes t modulo the period 2π√(L/g). The clock state perfectly *encodes* t even though t exercises no additional causal influence beyond being the independent variable in the law of motion.  

The objector might reply: “But in vision, photons *cause* retinal excitation; in the clock, time does not cause θ.” The reply is that photons likewise do not cause visual information *by themselves*; photons cause only the photochemical reaction. The *informational* link between retinal excitation and distal object properties (say, an apple’s shape) is mediated by the laws of optics, the geometry of projection, and various ecological regularities. Nothing about shape pushes on the retina; only photons do. By parity of reasoning, nothing about “time itself” need push on the clock. Both cases rely on law-governed regularities to convert immediate causal inputs into informational access to distal variables. Since the distal variable in the temporal case is “elapsed time,” which is included as the parameter in the governing law, the informational tie is completely in place.  

We may thus articulate a general principle, *Lawful Encoding*: A system encodes variable V if the lawful dynamics of the system generate a mapping from V to internal states, whether or not V supplies a distinct causal input. The sense in which a thermometer “detects” temperature is exactly the same sense in which a pendulum clock “detects” time: the expansion of mercury is a deterministic monotonic function of ambient mean kinetic energy (temperature) according to the equation of state; the swing of a pendulum is a deterministic sinusoidal function of elapsed time according to Newtonian dynamics. That suffices for genuine detection in the informational functionalist sense.  

5. Two Varieties of Temporal Mechanisms  

5.1 Mechanical Clocks  

Consider a balance-wheel watch. Energy stored in a mainspring drives an escapement that releases the wheel to oscillate in near-isochronous cycles. The watchmaker adjusts moment of inertia and spring stiffness so that the period approximates one second. Because the governing equations stipulate that the phase variable φ evolves as dφ/dt = 2π/T, the state of the wheel (its angular position and velocity) at any moment specifies t (modulo an initial offset). A crucial point is that the causal influences *within* the watch are entirely local: forces among atoms, friction, elastic torques. Yet thanks to the temporal parameter in the equations, the internal state tracks t.  

Note what would be metaphysically odd is demanding that time additionally “kick” the balance wheel at every instant. That is no more required than demanding that space “push” on a metre stick so as to keep it one metre long. Laws suffice.  

5.2 Neural Interval Timers  

In biological organisms, interval timing—the ability to discriminate, say, two seconds from four seconds—is implemented by a range of mechanisms. One influential model is the *striatal beat-frequency* (SBF) hypothesis. Cortical neurons emit oscillatory activity at slightly different frequencies; striatal medium spiny neurons detect the pattern of coincident spikes, and learning tunes synaptic weights so that a distinctive coincidence pattern triggers at the criterion interval. The initial cue (a tone or flash) resets phases; thereafter, nothing enters the system from the environment. Nonetheless, because the joint phase vector evolves with differential angular velocities ω₁ … ωn, the pattern at physical time t encodes t.  

Here again: what causes the spike train is the cells’ intrinsic ionic dynamics, not time-as-agent. Yet the pattern corresponds one-to-one with elapsed time until noise degrades the signal. The SBF network satisfies conditions (1)–(3): lawful mapping, reliable covariance, and behavioural exploitation (rodents press a lever when two seconds have elapsed). The network is thus a bona fide temporal sensory system, notwithstanding the absence of external temporal impact.  

6. Replies to Residual Worries  

6.1 The Displacement Problem  

Perhaps the objector will urge a refined complaint: a clock only measures its *own* internal processes. If the clock malfunctions, its reading diverges from physical time; hence the reading is not really about time but about “how many oscillations this oscillator has produced.” By contrast, vision arguably remains about the distal scene even if the eye is slightly distorted.  

Two comments. First, no sensory system is infallible; retinal after-images, auditory hallucinations, and proprioceptive drift all show that sometimes the system’s state fails to match the distal variable. Fallibility does not defeat representational status. Second, both eyes and clocks track the distal variable only given a ceteris paribus clause that the relevant laws apply (Snell’s law for vision, the small-angle approximation or damping tolerances for clocks). If those laws break, misrepresentation follows. In this respect the clock is not at a special disadvantage.  

6.2 Does This Presuppose A-theory “Passage”?  

Another metaphysical qualm concerns whether the foregoing presupposes that time “flows,” as A-theorists contend. One might worry that if temporal passage is an illusion, then “sensing” passage is illusory too. But the account on offer is deliberately neutral between A- and B-theories. All that is required is an ordered parameter t enumerated in the laws. Whether ontologically that parameter “moves” or whether past, present, future are equally real is irrelevant to the lawful mapping. A B-theorist can cheerfully say: the clock’s state at world-line parameter τ conveys information about which hyperplane of the foliation one occupies, even though nothing literally passes.  

6.3 Isn’t This Merely Calibration, not Perception?  

One may still hesitate: perhaps we should reserve “sensing” for channels that rely on transduction of exogenous energy. Clocks, on this view, are *computational* or *inferential* devices, not sensory. This is a terminological preference, but it cuts across accepted usage in biology. Circadian systems are routinely called time-keeping or time-sensing mechanisms; bacterial chemotaxis senses gradients by internal comparison devoid of continuous exogenous input. Extending the label “sensory” to any lawful information-gathering interface is not merely semantic inflation; it underwrites fruitful empirical research programs (chronobiology, neurochronometry) and coheres with an evolutionary perspective: any heritable mechanism that improves fitness by informing the organism about a variable in its ecological niche counts as a sensory adaptation.  

7. Conclusion  

The causal-impotence objection rests on the idea that genuine sensing requires direct causal impact from the sensed property. A close examination of how information is carried in biological and artefactual systems shows that this requirement is misplaced. Sensory systems exploit lawful regularities to build an informational bridge from distal variable to internal state. In many familiar cases—vision, audition—one and the same energy transfer both provides the proximal stimulus and figures in the encoding law, making the role of law invisible. In temporal sensing, the two roles come apart: the relevant laws contain time as an explicit parameter, while the immediate causal dynamics involve only local physical interactions within the clock mechanism. Once we recognise lawful encoding as sufficient for sensory status, the possibility of a sense of time is secured. Mechanical clocks, circadian oscillators, and neural interval timers demonstrate in concrete detail how a system can carry information about time without time itself functioning as an extra causal force.  

Therefore, the claim that the causal impotence of time precludes a sensory system for time should be rejected. We do possess mechanisms that track time every bit as legitimately as eyes track light—by embedding physical laws that bind their internal dynamics to the temporal structure of the environment.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Among the elements that constitute the manifest image of the world, time appears both the most pervasive and the most elusive. We mark birthdays, beat rhythms, anticipate deadlines, and recoil at the thought of timeless oblivion. Yet a recurring objection insists that, whatever else we can sense, we cannot literally sense time. The argument is straightforwardly causal: every bona-fide sensory modality, from vision to olfaction, works because some environmental feature causally impinges on the receptor system—photons on the retina, odor molecules on the olfactory epithelium, and so on. “Time,” by contrast, is usually regarded as causally inert; it does not strike, bump, or push. Therefore, the argument goes, there can be no sensory system whose informational content is specifically temporal.  

The same worry is pressed with a familiar technological example. A barometer carries information about air pressure because pressure differences press against the diaphragm; a compass carries information about geomagnetic north because magnetic fields exert torque on the needle. But how can a clock carry information about “what time it is,” if time itself cannot exert force on any mechanism? If we are to respect the principle that sensing presupposes causal coupling, the objector concludes, clocks (and by parity, any biological “sense of time”) must be at best metaphorical: they piggyback on changes that merely correlate with time but do not constitute genuine temporal sensing.

My aim is to diffuse this objection without denying either premise that makes it attractive. I grant (a) that perceptual or measuring systems trade on causal interactions and (b) that time itself—understood as a dimension or manifold of ordered events—is not an ordinary causal agent. What must be shown is that a mechanism can lawfully and reliably carry temporal information in virtue of ordinary causal interactions with non-temporal properties, and that this suffices for legitimate temporal representation. The strategy exploits the simple but neglected point that information need not be transmitted by the very property represented; lawful correlation, rather than direct causal impact by the represented property, is enough. Once that point is appreciated, the “sense of time” slot becomes available, even in a broadly causal–informational framework.

2. Clarifying the Target  

Before offering the positive story, it helps to pinpoint exactly where the original objection presses. The opponent usually assumes something like the following principle:

Causal Contact Principle (CCP): A system S can represent an environmental magnitude M only if M itself enters into a causal interaction with S.

Variants of the principle abound in the philosophies of perception, mental representation, and scientific instrumentation. Yet CCP is considerably stronger than what is needed to preserve a causal account of information gathering. What causal informational theories typically require is not that M itself do the causal work, but that there be a nomologically grounded causal chain that establishes a reliable correlation between M and some state of S. Dretske’s “indicator semantics,” Fodor’s asymmetry condition, and Skyrms’s probabilistic information theories all build representation on reliable covariance, not on direct impact by the represented property per se.  

An example from exteroception makes the point vivid. When you see a cow behind a picket fence, very little of the light hitting your retina originates from the cow; most of it comes from the fence slats. Yet you do see the cow. Likewise, sonar sense in bats depends not on bats’ bodies being struck by insects, but on how the bats’ self-generated sound pulses are reflected. Perception is often displaced: what you detect is a causal proxy that lawfully tracks what you represent. Hence a first rejoinder to the time-skeptic is to deny CCP and replace it with the weaker, more plausible:

Information Covariance Principle (ICP): A system S can represent M if there exists a reliable, law-governed causal chain that produces state s of S iff (or with high conditional probability that) M takes value m.

Under ICP, the burden shifts from asking whether time causes the mechanism to whether the mechanism exploits some causal process that correlates with temporal facts in a sufficiently robust, non-accidental way.

3. How Clocks Work Without Time Doing Any Work  

Consider a paradigmatic clock: an escapement pendulum clock. Nothing “temporal” strikes the pendulum. Instead, gravitational force, tension in the escapement, and inertial mass conspire, under Newtonian laws, to sustain oscillations with a period approximately equal to 2π√(l/g). The number of swings can be registered by gear teeth which, in turn, advance clock hands. Because the period is (to a first approximation) constant and independent of swing amplitude, the cumulative count of oscillations is lawfully correlated with elapsed time. Provided the clock is initially calibrated, the reading after n oscillations will differ from the reading at n+1 oscillations by a constant temporal interval—say one second.  

Two observations emerge. (i) The causal work is performed by ordinary forces—gravity, springs, friction. (ii) Those forces interact in a way that instantiates a lawlike regularity that is expressible in purely temporal terms. Thus the physical state of the mechanism after n oscillations stands in a reliably mapping relation to the temporal interval nT since the last calibration, where T is the period. Time itself has done no work, but the reading nevertheless carries temporal information.  

Examples proliferate. Radioactive decay serves as a stochastic but statistically regular clock: the proportion of undecayed atoms after interval ∆t is e^-λ∆t. Heartbeats, circadian gene expression cycles, and cortical gamma oscillations in brains all operate as biological clocks. In none of them is “time” a causal reagent; everything is accomplished by chemical potentials, ionic diffusion, membrane electrodynamics, or genetic transcription factors. Yet each yields a variable whose evolving values are tightly governed by laws in which temporal parameters figure essentially. That fact suffices for temporal informativeness.

4. Information Versus Causation  

One might object that law-governed correlation is not yet representation; after all, innumerable properties covary with time—entropy increases, shadows lengthen, paint dries—but we do not treat every smudge of drying paint as a timepiece. The objection is fair but misses the target. Representation requires more than bare covariance; it requires a mechanism adapted (by evolution, learning, or design) to exploit the covariance for the purpose of tracking or controlling behavior with respect to the represented magnitude.  

Shannon information is a useful, if skeletal, formalization. Suppose X is a random variable specifying clock states (number of oscillations) and T is the elapsed time since calibration. Because of the physical law linking period T0 to oscillations, the mutual information I(X;T) can approach the entropy H(T) up to the resolution limited by noise. That is, observing X reduces uncertainty about T to near zero. By contrast, observing the wetness W of paint also reduces uncertainty about T (older paint tends to be dryer), but only feebly; the conditional probabilities p(T|W) will be broad and easily disrupted by humidity, pigments, or ventilation.  

Hence the difference lies not in the metaphysics of causation—both escapement and drying paint involve causal processes—but in the reliability, precision, and accessibility of the information channel. Clocks are engineered or selected specifically to maximize reliable time-coding capacities, whereas casual correlations remain unexploited except serendipitously.

5. Biological Senses of Time  

If the argument so far is sound, it should generalize to living organisms. Do animals possess genuine temporal senses? Consider the circadian system in mammals. The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) harbors a molecular feedback loop of transcription and translation whose period is roughly 24 hours. SCN output modulates hormone release, body temperature, and sleep–wake cycles. Light cues entrain the SCN via retinal photosensitive ganglion cells, but once entrained, the cycle free-runs in constant darkness. The causal influence on the molecular loop comes from gene expression kinetic parameters, photic input, and thermal noise; time itself exerts no causal push. Nevertheless, the chemical state of the SCN at phase φ functions as a biological “reading” of what portion of the day has elapsed, and many downstream systems treat φ as semantic for time of day.  

Likewise, the cerebellum and basal ganglia are rich in neural oscillators whose phase relations appear to underwrite millisecond-to-second range interval timing for tasks such as speech segmentation and coordinated motor action. Here again, ionic currents, synaptic potentiation, and inhibitory rebound do the causal work, but the organism behaves as though it directly registers durations: it begins to open the hand just in time to catch a ball, stops uttering a phoneme at the right millisecond, or starts foraging minutes before dawn. Empirical evidence thus corroborates the theoretical point: causal processes can be harnessed so that physiological variables function as temporal indicators.

6. Does This Satisfy the Intuition Behind CCP?  

The skeptic may still worry that the story only shows how mechanisms can measure change, not time itself. Perhaps clocks reveal motion, decay, oscillation—anything dynamic—but remain blind to the underlying temporal dimension. A persuasive answer requires distinguishing substantive metaphysical claims about what time is from epistemological claims about how it is known.  

If one thinks of time as a primitive ordering relation among events (as in so-called B-theory), then to know what time it is just is to place an event at the correct location in that order. But ordering relations manifest themselves solely through patterns of change. Trying to sense time “directly” apart from change is akin to trying to see space apart from spatially extended things. Our epistemic route to dimensional structure is always via how material processes are embedded within it.  

Conversely, if one endorses an A-theoretic “dynamic passage,” the passing is arguably manifest in the continual updating of changeable states. Clocks, by undergoing systematic change, embody that passage. Either way, the state-of-the-clock’s-mechanism stands in one-one mapping with the objective temporal parameter we care about. So the proposed account does not dodge the skeptical challenge; rather, it dissolves it by clarifying how any dimension can be epistemically accessed.

7. Measurement Theory and the Role of Calibration  

The sense-of-time defender can strengthen the response by appealing to general measurement theory. A thermometer measures temperature because (i) there exists a monotonic, law-governed relation between mercury column height h and thermal quantity θ and (ii) the device is calibrated so that intervals in h can be mapped to intervals in θ. Crucially, temperature does not shove mercury upward; molecular kinetic energy exchanges do. The role of calibration is to guarantee that the formal mapping endows the instrument’s readings with the appropriate semantics.  

Exactly parallel points apply to clocks. To convert 60 pendulum swings into “one minute,” we perform a calibration given gravitational field strength, pendulum length, and so forth. Once fixed, the mapping is upheld by the same causal law that keeps the period stable. The semantics of the reading (e.g., 14:07:33) resides in the system of counterfactuals: had 120 swings occurred, the reading would be 14:08:33, and so on. No special causal traffic from time to clock is missing; what matters is that the mapping is stable under relevant counterfactual manipulations.  

Measurement theory therefore supports ICP against CCP. A legitimate measurement need not rely on the measured quantity’s causal efficacy, provided a robust law connecting the measurement indicator to the quantity holds. Temporal measurement heads the list of quantities whose values are everywhere and always covariant with certain kinds of change processes. That is precisely why clocks are so easy to build and so versatile, ranging from sand trickling in hourglasses to caesium hyperfine transitions.

8. The Philosophical Payoff: Representational Pluralism  

At this stage the original objection appears to trade on a conflation. It confuses (i) the requirement that some causal chain carries information into the system with (ii) the mistaken requirement that the represented property itself be that causal carrier. The first is indispensable; the second is optional. Once disentangled, the road is clear for a pluralistic view of representation: a state can represent G if it is recruited within a system that, as a matter of explanatory practice, exploits a reliable correlation between that state and G’s values.  

An analogy may help. Scientists routinely speak of seismographs “recording tectonic stress” even though the stress does not directly act on the needle; what moves the needle are seismic waves mediated by mechanical couplings. The apparatus reads stress because seismologists calibrate the needle deflections against theoretical and empirical models linking stress, wave patterns, and needle positions. Clocks stand in the same relation to time.

9. Addressing Residual Concerns  

Two residual concerns deserve mention.

First, might the correlation between clock state and time be merely contingent? Suppose a freak cosmic event gradually alters the pendulum’s length. Then the clock would go out of sync, undermining the claim that its readings genuinely represent time. That is correct, but harmless. Representation is fallible and defeasible. A tachometer can be miscalibrated; a thermometer can stick. What matters is that the mechanism is designed or has evolved to be success-riding—a sustained mistake calls for repair, not for withdrawal of the claim that the gauge is a gauge.

Second, does the story trivialize temporal representation by making it ubiquitous? If any change reliably correlated with time can count, does every chemical reaction represent time? No. The difference, again, lies in functional role. For a state to be a representation, it must be poised to feed into systems of inference or control that treat it as about the represented property. The evolving concentration of a dye in table salt water may covary with time, but unless some user or downstream module exploits that fact—adjusting plans, making predictions, solving navigational tasks—what we have is a mere “standing in correlation,” not representation. Clocks and biological timers are embedded in broader control architectures that exploit their readings; uncontrolled covariances are not.

10. Conclusion  

The causal impotence of time, coupled with the causal nature of sensory and measurement processes, seems at first to license skepticism about any genuine sense of time. The objection rests on a too stringent Causal Contact Principle. Once we replace CCP with the more defensible Information Covariance Principle, the apparent puzzle dissolves. Clocks, whether mechanical or biological, harness ordinary causal forces arranged in law-governed structures to produce states that map systematically onto temporal parameters. Because these states are functionally exploited as indicators of duration, phase, or moment, they qualify as temporal representations, even though time does not itself knock on the door of the mechanism.  

In short, to sense time one need not be touched by time; it is enough to be touched by processes whose lawful unfolding is isomorphic to temporal structure, and to have the engineering or evolutionary wherewithal to treat those touches as a readout of the when. That is precisely what clocks—and arguably many neural systems—have accomplished for centuries, rendering the skeptic’s worry an instructive, but ultimately misguided, misunderstanding of how causal information flows can underwrite representation.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
A Clock without a Cause?
          Sensory Representation, Causal Influence, and the Perception of Time


1.  The Causal-Influence Requirement

Philosophers of mind and perception often begin with a simple picture of sensory systems: they gather information by being causally impinged upon by the very features they represent.  Light excites the retina, pressure deforms mechanoreceptors, odorant molecules bind to olfactory cilia.  If one takes this “causal-influence requirement” seriously, a natural objection arises against the idea that there could be a genuine sense of time.  Time, conceived as a dimension or parameter of change, does not itself strike, press, or bind.  Unlike photons or odorants, “the passage of five seconds” seems causally inefficacious.  Hence, the argument concludes, no mechanism could literally sense time; whatever appears to be time perception must reduce to the perception of other properties such as motion, change, or energy.

The objection packs considerable intuitive punch, yet its force depends on a particular (and arguably oversimplified) conception of how information is carried and represented.  In what follows I offer a multi-pronged response.  First, I show that the causal-influence requirement, interpreted strictly, is too demanding even for clear-cut sensory paradigms.  Second, I develop an alternative understanding of information bearing—nomic or law-governed covariation—on which a system can carry information about a property P even when P is not among the immediate causes of the system’s states.  Third, I apply this framework to the special case of time, explaining how a clock, biological or artificial, can encode elapsed duration without time “pushing” on anything.  Finally, I address familiar worries: Does this story collapse time perception into mere change detection?  And if not, how does it accommodate the familiar distortions and illusions of temporal experience?  Throughout, the guiding idea is that causal influence is only one way—indeed, often a derivative way—of grounding informational relations.  Systematic, lawlike dependence is enough.


2.  Why the Causal-Influence Requirement Is Too Strong

2.1  Sensing Without Source-bound Causes

Begin with an apparently uncontroversial case: color vision.  Photons do cause responses in the retina.  But what exactly are cones sensitive to?  A particular cone’s absorbance curve is determined by the opsin’s molecular structure; it is sensitive not to “being red” as a reflectance property but to an unstructured range of photon energies.  Moreover, seeing an extended surface as red depends on complicated neural inferences that compare outputs from millions of cones, discount illuminant spectra, and factor in contextual information.  The “causal influence” at the receptor is, strictly speaking, only the arrival of photons; the represented property—surface reflectance under standard illumination—is two explanatorily layers removed.

A thermometer pushes the point further.  When mercury rises, what immediately causes expansion is the kinetic agitation of mercury molecules, not the abstract statistical magnitude we call temperature.  Yet we happily say the thermometer “registers temperature.”  In both cases, the represented property is not itself a direct causal agent.  Rather, it stands in a stable nomic relation to the system’s microphysical causes.  This observation loosens the intuition that representation requires causal impact by the very feature represented.

2.2  The Many-to-One Problem

The scientist examines a seismograph trace and pronounces: “That spike records the Chilean quake.”  The stylus deflected because ground vibrations propagated through the Earth, not because “the quake” somehow reached into the laboratory and nudged the pen.  A single local cause (vibration of the support) is systematically linked, via well-understood laws, to a distal property (magnitude 7.9 quake at 10:38 UTC).  Sensing often works this way: the mechanism is causally affected by a proximal signal that, given background laws and calibration, carries information about a more abstract, distal, or relational property.  Once this more permissive epistemology is in place, the path is cleared for time representation.


3.  Information Without Causal Impact: The Nomic-Covariance Model

Fred Dretske coined the term “natural information” for states that stand in nomic (law-governed) conditional relations to worldly conditions: a flame indicates oxygen levels below 13% cannot obtain, owl ear asymmetry indicates prey azimuth, and so on.  What matters is not that oxygen, azimuth, or prey exerts a unique causal force on the indicator.  Rather, given the relevant laws, the presence of the indicator would not occur unless the indicated condition held.  For information-carrying, counterfactual dependence is enough: had the condition not held, the indicator would not be in its present state.

Time offers a special twist.  Physical laws are formulated with an explicit time parameter t.  Because these laws are temporally homogeneous (their form does not change over time) they generate regularities: if a radioactive isotope has half-life τ, then, ceteris paribus, the proportion of undecayed nuclei after an interval τ is ½ of the initial population.  The amount of undecayed mass, M(t), covaries with elapsed time per a simple exponential law.  The law is not a further cause; it is a counterfactual-supporting pattern that allows us to treat M(t) as a time stamp.  A Geiger counter monitoring the activity of a sample thus carries information about how long the sample has been decaying, even though “time” never crashes into the counter.  The mechanism plus the laws guarantee the covariance.

That, in miniature, is how clocks work.


4.  Clocks: Intrinsic Dynamics as Temporal Indicators

4.1  The Minimal Recipe

A clock, broadly construed, is a system whose internal state passes through a sequence S(t) such that for each interval Δt within a working range the mapping t ↦ S(t) is injective and approximately linear.  Translation: different durations correspond to discernibly different states, and equal durations produce equal state changes.  If the device is appropriately calibrated, the present state serves as a reliable indicator of how much time has elapsed since an agreed zero point.  Crucially, what drives the state transitions are the system’s own intrinsic dynamics: the escapement releasing a pendulum, the cesium atom’s hyperfine oscillations, the metabolic cycles in the suprachiasmatic nucleus.  No external “temporal force” is applied.

4.2  What the Physics Looks Like

Consider a classical pendulum clock.  For small amplitudes, the period T is approximately 2π√(L/g).  L and g cause the motion; time, as such, does nothing.  Nonetheless, because the equations of motion permit us to solve for t as a function of the number of swings n (t = nT), the count n encodes elapsed time.  The encoding relation is underwritten by the law that links n, g, L, and t.  Similarly, in an atomic clock, microwaves are tuned to the hyperfine transition frequency of cesium-133.  The relevant causal transaction is electromagnetic; yet by Métivier’s law the oscillation frequency is fixed at 9,192,631,770 cycles per SI second.  Counting cycles gives time.

In each case, physical law F maps cause-affect pairs onto a time-indexed trajectory; inverting F yields t as a function of the observable state.  No additional time-specific causal ingredient is needed.  Time has left its mark in the lawful structure of the motion.

4.3  Biological Clocks

Human and animal bodies contain multiple time-keeping subsystems.  Short durations in the range of milliseconds to seconds seem to be tracked by networks that accumulate neural pulses (the “pacemaker-accumulator” model) or by ensembles of decaying cellular processes with different time constants (“state-dependent networks”).  Circadian time is tracked by molecular feedback loops in the SCN in which gene expression cycles with a ~24-hour period.  Again, the immediate causes are transcription, translation, phosphorylation, ion currents.  Yet because these biochemical events instantiate stable dynamics whose unfolding rate is virtually invariant under normal physiological conditions, downstream systems can read elapsed duration from the present molecular state.  Disruptions—genetic knockouts, temperature shifts—alter the coding relation and predictably distort subjective time, just as changing g distorts a pendulum clock.

Thus, at multiple scales, organisms deploy internal “clock chemistry.”  The states of these chemistries carry temporal information by virtue of nomic dependence, not by virtue of time itself pressing upon tissues.


5.  Is This Merely Change Detection?  Distinguishing Time from Proxy Properties

A critic may insist: “Your story only shows that organisms are sensitive to change rates of internal processes.  That is not sensing time; it is sensing motion, decay, oscillation.”  The challenge is to articulate why such sensitivity nevertheless counts as temporal representation.

5.1  Many Proxies, One Abstract Variable

Temperature, as we saw, is sensed via kinetic energy; color via photon energy; spatial location via retinal displacement.  In each case the proximal cause (molecular agitation, photons, retinal pattern) is not identical to the represented property, yet we do not hesitate to say organisms sense temperature, color, position.  What makes the representation one of temperature rather than of molecular velocity is not the proximal cause but the system’s broader functional role: how the signal is used, what downstream inferences it licenses, under which conditions it is calibrated, what error-correcting feedback sustains it.  By the same token, an internal decay constant, beat count, or oscillatory phase may function as an elapsed-time parameter because:

   a) It is calibrated in operative contexts by correlating internal state with external temporal markers (sunrise, heartbeat, metronome).
   
   b) Downstream systems treat alternative values as specifying how long ago some event occurred or how long remains until another event.
   
   c) Deviations are assessed epistemically as temporal errors (“my watch is slow”), not as errors about decay or oscillation per se.

When an archer counts “one-and-two-and-three” to time a breath, the relevant variable is not the number of syllables uttered but the duration thereby marked.  Likewise, when the brain uses the phase of a theta oscillation to predict the next auditory beat, what matters functionally is elapsed time.  Change detection becomes time detection when its functional role is temporal.

5.2  Counterfactual Scenarios

Suppose a malicious neuroscientist intervenes and doubles the period of every SCN oscillation while leaving all other neural circuits untouched.  If the organism subsequently eats, sleeps, and anticipates daylight on a 48-hour cycle, we say its sense of time is distorted.  We do not say it now perfectly represents a slower molecular oscillation.  Our explanatory practice singles out the temporal variable as the content of the signal.  This suggests that content attribution flows from the system’s causal-semantic embedding, not from the identity of the proximal cause.


6.  Objections and Replies

6.1  The Metaphysical “No Time, No Cause” Objection

The motivating objection insists that because time lacks causal powers, no state of affairs could nomically depend on it.  Yet modern physics does not treat time as a sparse, force-like entity alongside electromagnetism and gravity.  Rather, time is a parameter encoding ordered relations among events.  On relational or structuralist views (Leibniz, Barbour, Rovelli), causal interactions proceed among events; time supervenes on the network of relations.  If so, we should not expect “the flow of time” to be a separate causal arrow.  The causal differentiation objection therefore misfires: it mistakes a representational parameter (t) for a force vector.

6.2  The Underdetermination Objection

Could two clocks in different physical media (sand, quartz, cesium) produce identical states while differing in how much time has passed, thereby breaking the information link?  Strictly speaking, the states “one pound of sand in the bottom bulb” and “digit readout: 12:00” can coincide under different histories.  But this is a general problem for representation: any indicator can misfire.  What secures reliability is not logical necessity but causal-nomic regularity within an appropriately delimited context.  In normal conditions, given how the sandglass is built and calibrated, one pound in the lower bulb means one hour has elapsed.  If someone flips the glass mid-run, misrepresentation occurs.  Similarly, your retina can misrepresent surface color under weird lighting.  The possibility of error is a hallmark of representation, not a defeat of it.

6.3  Phenomenological Objection: The Subjective Flow

Some authors insist that the distinctive phenomenal feel of temporal passage—the “specious present”—cannot be captured by a mechanistic clock picture.  Here one must distinguish: the target of the original objection was the *existence* of a sensory system for time, not the metaphysics of temporal qualia.  A plausible story of information flow is logically compatible with further debate about qualia.  Indeed, by showing how biological clocks feed predictive coding networks that stitch events into short retentional envelopes (~100–300 ms), the mechanistic account illuminates where the flow-phenomenology might arise.


7.  Taking Stock: The Analogy Extended

Vision:

   • Proximal cause: photon impacts.
   • Represented property: environmental layout, color.
   • Lawlike link: optics + neural inference.

Thermoception:

   • Proximal cause: kinetic agitation → receptor ion channel opening.
   • Represented property: temperature.
   • Lawlike link: statistical mechanics.

Time perception:

   • Proximal cause: intrinsic periodic or monotonic processes (oscillation, decay, accumulation).
   • Represented property: elapsed duration.
   • Lawlike link: dynamical equations specifying the rate.

In no case is the represented property itself a standalone causal agent acting on the receptor.  Instead, lawlike covariance plus appropriate functional embedding suffices.


8.  Toward a Positive Theory of Temporal Representation

Building on the above, one can outline a positive account:

1.  Base Dynamics.  The organism contains one or more subsystems whose temporal evolution D(t) approximates a known function f(t) over the range R.

2.  Calibration.  Through evolutionary selection, developmental plasticity, or active learning, the organism establishes a mapping between distinct states of D (call them σ₁ … σₙ) and conventional temporal magnitudes (e.g., circadian phases, milliseconds).

3.  Exploitation.  Downstream systems consume states σₖ in ways that would promote success only if σₖ tracked elapsed time (e.g., predicting prey trajectory, regulating sleep).

4.  Error Monitoring.  Mismatches between expected and experienced temporal outcomes drive plastic changes, keeping the mapping accurate—recalibration.

Under this framework, time representation is an emergent, functional achievement grounded in but not reducible to direct temporal causation.


9.  Conclusion

The objection that time cannot be sensed because it exerts no causal force trades on an overly narrow conception of information acquisition.  Clocks—whether pendula, atoms, or cortical oscillators—show how a system can reliably encode duration by harnessing internally stable dynamics whose unfolding is law-governed.  Time, on this view, is not a ghostly cause; it is the order relation we abstract from lawful change.  A mechanism that instantiates change with a stable, parameterizable rate carries time information in exactly the same sense that a thermometer carries temperature information.  Once we appreciate that representation hinges on nomic covariance, calibration, and functional use, the supposed explanatory gap between “sensing temperature” and “sensing time” shrinks to insignificance.  The clock’s tick, the neuron’s oscillation, and the Geiger counter’s clicks are temporal indicators not because time pushes on them but because, through the lawful structure of the universe and the organism’s ingenious exploitation of that structure, their states and the amount of elapsed time stand and fall together.

Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
I. Introduction  

That there could be something properly called a “sense of time” strikes many philosophers as suspect. Sensing, as we ordinarily understand it, involves an encounter with a worldly item that causally impinges on a receptor: light on retinas, air-borne chemicals on olfactory cilia, pressure waves on cochleae. Time, the objection runs, is not the sort of entity that can “bump into” anything. If time is merely a dimension, a parameter, or (for the relationist) nothing over and above the changing of events, then it is causally inert. Hence there can be no dedicated receptor or channel by which an organism, or even a simple device like a clock, could obtain information about it.  

Yet clocks are astonishingly good at telling time, and animals—including humans—routinely time intervals with surprising precision. How can a mechanism, biological or artefactual, come to carry information about the passing of time if time never reaches out to influence it? In what follows I argue that the objection rests on a mistaken picture of representation, information and causation. A clock does not need to be pushed or pulled by time in order to represent temporal facts. Rather, it need only instantiate physical regularities that covary, lawfully and robustly, with temporal magnitudes. Once that more modest requirement is acknowledged, the path is clear for defending both the intelligibility of mechanical time-keeping and, more cautiously, the possibility of a genuine sensory system for time in biological creatures.  

II. Three clarifications  

Before addressing the objection directly, it helps to draw three distinctions that are frequently elided.  

1. Causal influence vs. causal mediation. Photons causally influence retinal photoreceptors, but what makes the retinal state one that carries information about, say, surface colour is not that being red causally did something to the eye; rather, the photons’ particular wavelengths mediate a causal interaction. In other words, the property represented (surface colour) is not itself a cause; the causal work is done by electromagnetic radiation correlated with that property.  

2. Representation vs. detection. The retina is not a “colour detector” in the sense of responding to colour qua property of surfaces; it responds to light of various wavelengths. The representational link between retinal output and worldly colour is secured by systematic, evolutionarily entrenched correlations. Representation is thus typically indirect.  

3. Constitutive vs. etiological explanations. Asking how something currently represents temporal intervals is different from asking how that representational capacity arose in evolutionary or cultural history. Even if time never exerts a causal push, an organismal trait can evolve because organisms that “kept good time” reaped fitness benefits.  

With these clarifications in place, the objection begins to look less forceful. If colour can be represented indirectly, so can time. Indeed, in many canonical cases of perception the represented property never touches the receptor; what touches the receptor is a signal that is reliably correlated with the property in question.  

III. What time does and does not do  

The objection’s core premise is that time is “causally impotent.” How should that be understood? In contemporary metaphysics, two broad families of views dominate. The substantivalist takes time (or space-time) to be a sui generis entity that underlies and structures events. The relationist, by contrast, treats time as nothing above and beyond relations of precedence and duration among events. Both camps agree that time is not a force on a par with electromagnetism, nor a substance that pushes matter around. But neither conclusion entails that no mechanism can be sensitive to temporal facts.  

All dynamical physical laws are explicitly time-indexed. If you want to predict where a pendulum bob will be, you treat its position as a function of t. A pendulum does not need to be “acted on” by time; instead, its behaviour unfolds in lawlike ways that increasingly diverge from its earlier state as t increases. To build a clock, one harnesses exactly such lawlike regularity. What matters is not an external temporal shove but an internally stable dynamical evolution that tracks the temporal metric.  

IV. Clocks, covariance and information  

Claude Shannon famously defined information in terms of reduction of uncertainty in a receiver about the state of a source. Crucially, the mathematical framework is silent on the ontological status of what the message is “about.” A mercury barometer carries information about atmospheric pressure by dint of reliable covariance between pressure outside and mercury height inside. Pressure does causally impinge on the column, yet “atmospheric pressure” at a distance does not. Likewise, a smoke alarm’s LED status light carries information about the presence of combustion gases by means of circuitry that only ever “sees” voltage differentials. In both cases, representation depends on dependable correlation, not on direct causal traffic from the represented property.  

A clock’s moving hand, oscillating quartz crystal, or pulsing cesium transition is correlated, by underlying physical law, with elapsed temporal intervals. The mechanism’s states partition time into discriminable equivalence classes—seconds, minutes, hours. When I consult a clock, I exploit those correlations: the pointer’s angular position covaries with true time of day (within a tolerance), so by perceiving the pointer I gain information about the time. Importantly, “true time” does not need to enter the mechanism as a cause; the mechanism’s own periodicity suffices, provided that its period is stable.  

V. Why stability, not external causation, is the crux  

What qualifies a physical process to serve as a clock is (i) its periodicity and (ii) the robustness of that periodicity under environmental perturbation. A balance wheel oscillates roughly twice per second because of its mass and spring stiffness. Those parameters, together with laws of classical mechanics, fix a natural period. The same holds for quartz resonators and atomic hyperfine transitions. No extra causal influence from “time itself” is required; the system’s micro-structure guarantees reliable repetition.  

Notice how this differs from paradigmatic sensing of exogenous features like light or sound. A photoreceptor must continuously receive photons in order to keep representing the colour or luminance of a scene. A quartz crystal, by contrast, would continue to oscillate at 32,768 Hz even in a dark, sealed box. Its representational power stems from intrinsic regularity, not continual stimulation. Nevertheless, that intrinsic regularity becomes informative about time precisely because the underlying physics guarantees that the nth oscillation will occur after n/f seconds.  

VI. From artefacts to biology: endogenous time-keeping  

If the objection concedes that artefactual clocks can legitimately track time without being causally nudged by time, one might still resist extending the lesson to biology. Isn’t perception supposed to yield continuously updated, action-guiding information? And don’t animals obtain interval estimates by monitoring external changes, like motion or countable events, rather than via an internal sense organ?  

Empirical work on circadian and interval timing undermines this scepticism. Nearly all multicellular organisms possess molecular feedback loops (e.g., the PER-TIM mechanism in fruit flies, the CLK-BMAL loop in mammals) that oscillate with a period near 24 hours, entrain to zeitgebers such as light and temperature, and regulate a host of physiological processes. These loops keep running in constant darkness. They function, in effect, as biochemical clocks: temporally structured internal signals that the organism consults to anticipate dawn, schedule feeding, or switch metabolic pathways.  

Shorter-scale timing in the seconds-to-minutes range appears to rely on ramping neural activity, coincidence detection across cortical oscillations, or population clocks—distributed patterns of firing that reliably unfold over time. None of these mechanisms requires external temporal stimuli. Instead, they exploit lawful neural dynamics whose trajectory can be calibrated to an interval of interest. And animals use those internal states to control behaviour: bees revisit flowers at the time of day when nectar replenishes; rats press levers approximately 12 seconds after a cue.  

If physiological devices can represent time by virtue of endogenous regularity, then a “sensory system” for time is not a conceptual impossibility. What makes a system sensory is that its outputs are treated, by downstream cognition, as information about the environment—here, environmental temporal structure. The retina is evolution’s solution to wavelength-specific covariance; the suprachiasmatic nucleus is its solution to daily periodicity. Both are ways of bringing world-relevant information under the organism’s control.  

VII. Direct vs. indirect realism about temporal perception  

One might reply that, even granting the foregoing, all that the organism or clock really “senses” is change—chemical reactions ticking along, spikes propagating through axons, cogs turning—not time itself. The representation of time is therefore derivative, reconstructed from primary sensory modalities. But this conclusion once again overextends a legitimate observation (representation is indirect) into a skeptical thesis (there is no representation of time).  

Consider an analogy: temperature. No sensor responds to “temperature as such.” Thermistors and warm receptors respond to molecular kinetic energy, which under standard conditions covaries with what we call temperature. Yet we are happy to say that a thermostat senses temperature. The step from causal interaction with kinetic energy to representation of temperature is mediated by a lawlike bridge principle: in gases at constant volume, mean kinetic energy is proportional to temperature. Similarly, in a harmonic oscillator, the number of completed cycles is proportional to elapsed time. The bridge principle, not an occult causal influence, licenses the representational claim.  

Hence direct causal contact with a property is not the price of representing that property. What is required is nomic mediation: stable laws that link the internal state tokened in the sensor to the external magnitude represented. For time, those laws are the laws of motion themselves. Because all physical processes evolve in time, any suitably regular process can, in virtue of that evolution, serve as a representational vehicle for temporal facts.  

VIII. Objections and replies  

1. The ‘multiple clock’ objection: Different processes run at different rates under varying conditions. How, then, can any internal mechanism count as veridically representing time, rather than merely instantiating its own idiosyncratic dynamics?  

Reply: Clocks, biological or mechanical, are constantly calibrated—by sunlight, by social coordination signals, by temperature cues—precisely to correct rate drift. In artefacts, we adjust wristwatches; in organisms, entrainment mechanisms shift oscillatory phase in response to zeitgebers. Representation does not require absolute accuracy, only sufficient accuracy for the organism’s practical purposes. Vision is no less a genuine sense because it is fooled by optical illusions; likewise, temporal perception can be distorted (e.g., under psychoactive drugs) yet count as perception.  

2. The ‘redundancy’ objection: Why posit a sense of time if all timing can in principle be derived from other senses plus memory of change?  

Reply: In principle derivability is cheap. In principle, three-dimensional shape can be derived from two-dimensional retinal images plus assumptions about lighting. That does not show that stereopsis and shape-specific cortical processing are explanatorily redundant. Having a dedicated system confers efficiency, precision and robustness. Empirically, organisms deprived of robust circadian entrainment exhibit metabolic and cognitive dysfunction—evidence that dedicated timing circuits afford adaptive benefits beyond what opportunistic use of exogenous change would permit.  

IX. Consequences for the philosophy of perception  

Recognising time-keeping as a kind of sensing has two attractive philosophical pay-offs.  

First, it dissolves the sharp dichotomy between so-called exteroception (of the outer world) and interoception (of bodily states). Temporal information straddles the boundary: the signal is produced inside, but what it represents—when dawn will break, how long until a predator re-emerges—is unambiguously worldly.  

Second, it prompts a reassessment of the causal theory of perception. If representation can ride on law-grounded covariance absent direct causal impact from the represented property, then causal contact, though important, is not the whole story. The richer story foregrounds structural or inferential relations—what philosophers of science call “structural realism” or “representation as structural similarity.” A clock is structurally isomorphic, in one dimension, to the ordering of temporal instants. That structural match, secured by laws, is enough for representation.  

X. Putting it all together  

We can now articulate a direct response to the original objection.  

Premise 1: For a sense modality to exist, there must be a mechanism whose states are caused by, and hence carry information about, the environmental property sensed.  

Premise 2: Time does not causally influence mechanisms.  

Conclusion: Therefore, no sense modality for time exists.  

The argument is unsound, because Premise 1 mischaracterises what is required for information-bearing. The mechanism’s states must covary with the property in virtue of lawful relations; the causation can be mediated by, or located entirely within, the mechanism itself. Photoreception is the paradigm, not the only model. Once we reformulate Premise 1:  

Premise 1*: For a sense modality to exist, there must be a mechanism whose states lawfully covary with, and can be exploited to learn about, the environmental property sensed.  

The argument collapses. A clock, whether worn on the wrist or embedded in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, satisfies 1* even though time applies no forces. The lawful dynamics of oscillatory processes secure covariance, and organisms (or observers) exploit those dynamics to reduce uncertainty about temporal magnitudes.  

XI. Conclusion  

Clocks, both artefactual and biological, teach a lesson of philosophical significance: representation hinges on reliable structure-preserving relations, not on a spooky causal handshake with the represented property. Time is woven so deeply into the dynamical fabric of physical law that any suitably regular process ipso facto tracks it. By leveraging that fact—by harnessing pendulum swings, quartz vibrations or molecular feedback loops—systems come to carry information about time without time ever “touching” them.  

Accordingly, the existence of a genuine sensory system for time is not blocked by time’s causal impotence. The sense in which a creature “feels” a looming deadline or “hears” a silent second hand is, of course, distinct from the way it sees colour. But difference of mechanism is no bar to legitimacy. Temporal perception, like colour perception, is an evolutionary solution to a coordination problem: how to align an organism’s internal states with the structure of its world. It need not await a metaphysical revolution in our understanding of time; it operates, law-obedient and causally unremarkable, in every tick that guides a bee to a blooming flower or a human commuter to the morning train.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
A SENSE OF TIME WITHOUT THE CAUSAL HAND OF TIME:
HOW CLOCK-LIKE MECHANISMS CAN CARRY TEMPORAL INFORMATION

1. The Objection Restated

A venerable line of thought holds that perceptual systems earn the honorific “sensory modality” only if they are causally impinged on by the environmental magnitudes they detect. Vision counts because photons strike photoreceptors; audition counts because pressure waves buffet the cochlea; olfaction counts because volatile molecules bind to receptors. Time, by contrast, is said to be causally inert. It does not push, pull, strike, or bind. If causal influence is the price of epistemic admission, time can never be sensed. A fortiori, a human being can possess at most an inferential or reflective awareness that time has passed, never a genuine temporal sense.

The challenge divides into two parts:

A. Information requirement: To qualify as a sense of X, a system must take in information about X.

B. Causal requirement: Information about X is taken in only when X itself causally affects the system.

Granted both, a sensory modality for time looks impossible. The task is therefore to show that (B) is false, or at least not universally required. We must explain how a mechanism can “carry information about” elapsed time despite lacking a causal coupling to time as such.

2. Information Without Direct Causal Origin

Begin with the concept of carrying information. Fred Dretske famously characterized a signal as carrying the information that p when the probability of p, given the signal, is (near) unity. That is an essentially statistical or nomological relation; it need not be a direct causal relation. Archbishop Ussher’s worn Bible might raise the probability that its owner believed the world began in 4004 BCE, even though the Bible did not cause Ussher’s beliefs.

A classic non-temporal illustration is the barometer. The mercury column rises and falls owing to local atmospheric pressure. Yet sailors treat the reading as evidence of an approaching storm. The storm is not the cause of the mercury level; rather, both the storm and the barometer’s reading are downstream effects of the same pressure pattern. Covariation, not direct causal contact, suffices for information. In Shannon-style information theory, what matters is reliable correlation under an appropriate channel model.

Thus premise (B) already over-reaches: an organism can exploit a signal that correlates with a worldly magnitude even when that magnitude does not itself work the causal levers of the organism. Time might be another such case.

3. The Clock Paradigm

Consider a simple pendulum clock. What makes a pendulum a timekeeper is not that Time with a capital “T” reaches into the apparatus and nudges the bob. Rather, Newtonian mechanics supplies a law: the period T of a small-amplitude pendulum is approximately 2π√(ℓ/g). Given a fixed length ℓ and local gravitational field g, each full oscillation will take extremely close to that period. The succession of oscillations is a lawful, practically invariant process. Anyone who can detect which oscillation number the pendulum now occupies can infer (to within tolerance) how many seconds have elapsed since an agreed “phase zero”.

A similar story can be told for hourglasses, quartz oscillators, caesium atomic clocks, circadian gene expression loops, or the pupil’s damped jitter after a flash. What each shares is an endogenous, regular, and law-governed change of physical state that can be:

a) Calibrated against a standard temporal metric.
b) Sensed by the organism’s nervous system (proprioceptively, interoceptively, or exteroceptively).

No extra causal arrow from time is added. The world provides lawful processes whose own dynamics mirror, by necessity, the temporal parameter in our theories. Detecting the state of such a process just is detecting elapsed time.

4. Nomological Versus Causal Ties

Perhaps the objection will shift: “Fine, but the pendulum’s present angle is caused by its earlier angle and gravitational forces, not by time. So the sensory system is really sensitive to the pendulum’s physical state, not to time.” The defender of temporal sensation can concede that the immediate causal input is some physical variable (pendulum angle, sand level, oscillation phase), yet insist that what those variables lawfully track is elapsed time. The crucial philosophical point is that carrying information about a magnitude does not require causal dependence on that magnitude; it requires being tethered by lawlike correlation.

Wilfrid Sellars urged that vocabulary for theoretical entities is introduced by “lawful correlation” with observation terms. We have no causal interaction with electrons as electrons; we have interaction with clouds in chambers, tracks on photographic plates, scintillations on screens. The electron is posited because the pattern of those effects is law-governed. Mutatis mutandis, temporal properties are posited because the pattern of the pendulum’s swings is law-governed by a temporal variable t. If the brain is wired so that every n oscillations it generates a neural pulse, those pulses lawfully correlate with roughly n × T seconds having elapsed. The neural pulse therefore carries temporal information.

5. Calibration and Design Histories

Teleosemantic theories (Millikan, Papineau, Neander) add a historical dimension. A trait’s representational content is fixed by the function for which natural selection, learning, or engineering designed it. Suppose early mammals with neural machinery that tracked diurnal light patterns used the resulting signal to schedule foraging. The selection process favored individuals whose internal oscillators matched the approximately 24-hour environmental cycle. The function of the oscillator is then to indicate environmental time of day, not to indicate photon flux per se. That function is inherited even when the animal is temporarily in total darkness inside a burrow. Under a teleosemantic account, the content “roughly 06:00 hours” is assigned because that is what the system has historically been used to indicate. Again, no direct causation by time is needed.

6. Temperature, Length, and Other Non-Causal Magnitudes

The smell test for a philosophical thesis is often parity of reasoning. Temperature does not literally cause mercury to expand; rather, molecular kinetic energy (itself a statistical property) causes increased collisions that cause expansion. Yet we happily say that a thermometer senses temperature. Weight does not cause a spring scale to stretch; gravitational force combined with mass does. Height does not cause the shadow on a sundial; geometry plus solar incidence does. If we insisted on direct causation by the very magnitude named, much of measurement theory would collapse. Better to say: a measuring device is one whose states stand in a reliable, exploitable, and law-governed relation to the magnitude. Clocks meet that criterion as well as thermometers or rulers.

7. Neuroscientific Respectability

Empirically, humans exhibit multiple timing mechanisms.

a) Millisecond timing: Purkinje cell firing patterns in cerebellum, critical for speech and fine motor control.

b) Seconds-to-minutes timing: Striatal beat-frequency models, in which cortical oscillators converge on basal ganglia coincidence detectors.

c) Circadian timing: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in the hypothalamus, whose gene-protein feedback loops run close to 24 h even in vitro.

In every case, the system is an internal oscillator or integrator whose successive states can be read as ‘how long since reset.’ Experimental disruption (pharmacological dampening, optogenetic phase shifts, lesions) degrades temporal judgments. Subjects unable to hear auditory clicks can still estimate durations; blind individuals maintain rough circadian phase; peripheral clocks keep ticking after the central pacemaker is ablated. The biological data confirm that bodies contain mechanisms that track time without needing “time rays” impinging on receptors.

8. Is Time Special?

Still, one might insist there is an ontological gap. Temperature, pressure, and weight are macroscopic manifestations of microphysical causal networks; time is a dimension of all events. But the difference is not relevant to the epistemology of measurement. What matters is whether there are processes whose evolution with respect to the temporal parameter is predictable, monotonic, and regular enough for a consumer system to use as a proxy. The laws of physics guarantee a superabundance of such processes. Indeed, every causal process unfolds in time, so every continuously changing magnitude is, by suitable calibration, a potential clock.

The same thought can be recast in structural realist terms: what measurement devices latch onto are structural relations, not intrinsic properties. A pendulum’s phase structure mirrors the affine structure of the real line of time. If the structure is preserved, information about one instantiates information about the other. There is no need for an extra metaphysical ingredient called “temporal causation.”

9. Objection: Mere Correlation Is Insufficient

A worried critic may protest: the lawlike relation between pendular phase and elapsed time is a correlation we, the theorists, notice. The brain, however, must treat the signal as indicating time. Otherwise the oscillations could mean anything—we risk indeterminacy of reference. Here the teleosemantic point returns. Through evolution, learning, or engineering, the system is conditioned so that its downstream consumers behave as though the signal heralds a temporal fact. When the SCN phase is π radians, melatonin is secreted; when the basal ganglia detect coincident oscillations, a timed movement is initiated. Misrepresentation (phase slips, jet lag) impairs performance in ways selection disfavors. The usage establishes semantic anchoring: the system “means” the time, because that is what consequences hinge on.

10. Objection: Internal Versus External Senses

Some philosophers distinguish exteroception (world-directed) from interoception (body-directed). If the clock-like signals arise inside the organism, perhaps they deliver only bodily information (“what my neurons are doing”) not worldly information (“how much time has passed outside”). Again we can borrow the barometer analogy. The mercury height is inside the cabin yet informs the sailor about outside atmospheric pressure. Information flows outward epistemically even when causal processes flow inward physically. Internal oscillators can be entrained to the light-dark cycle; once calibrated, they continue to represent outside time when cues vanish—much like a sailor consulting the barometer below deck. The relevant notion of “external” is representational, not anatomical.

11. Toward a Positive Account of Temporal Sensation

Putting the pieces together, we can sketch a general recipe:

Step 1 (Regular Dynamics): Identify a physical process P whose mathematical description includes a monotonic dependence on the temporal parameter t.

Step 2 (Calibrated Mapping): Establish a mapping f from the state-space of P to temporal magnitudes (seconds elapsed, phase of day, interval lengths).

Step 3 (Detection Mechanism): Provide receptors sensitive to the relevant state-space coordinates of P.

Step 4 (Utilization): Link the receptor outputs to downstream systems (motor planners, attentional controllers, hormonal secretors) that benefit when the temporal mapping f holds. Evolutionary or engineering feedback ensures the link is maintained.

When Steps 1–4 are satisfied, the organism possesses a sensory subsystem that delivers usable information about time, even though time never directly “makes contact” with receptors.

12. Philosophical Payoff

The response to the original objection is thus two-pronged.

i) Methodological: The causal criterion for sensing is too strict. Lawful, exploitable covariation suffices for information pick-up.

ii) Metaphysical: Time’s alleged causal impotence is irrelevant, because what clocks detect are states of processes whose lawful unfolding serves as a surrogate for time. Those states do causally influence the detector, satisfying the more modest requirement that perception involve causal interaction—just not with time itself.

By parity, we ought to admit a sense of time into our taxonomy, on a par with the sense of temperature, acceleration, or magnetism.

13. Conclusion

A clock mechanism carries information about time not by being bumped or prodded by a sui generis temporal force, but by exploiting the lawful evolution of internal or environmental processes whose states covary in a principled, measurable way with elapsed duration. Organisms, including humans, possess neural machinery attuned to such processes. Through calibration, learning, and selective pressure, those signals function to guide behaviour as representations of temporal facts. Causal impact from the process is present; causal impact from time per se is not required, any more than causal impact from “height” is required for a ruler to measure length.

Therefore, the objection that the absence of direct temporal causation precludes temporal sensation fails. A genuine sense of time is not only metaphysically coherent but empirically well supported.

answer:
