What follows is a sustained answer of roughly two thousand words (≈ 2 070) that develops one coherent way of defusing the “causal-impotence” objection and showing how both biological and artefactual clocks can legitimately be said to carry information about time even though time itself is not one more causal agent in the chain.

1. Framing the Objection

A familiar—indeed, almost textbook—story about sensing is that it always involves causal traffic from the worldly feature sensed to the sensing apparatus. Photons strike the retina, pressure waves set the basilar membrane in motion, volatile molecules bind to olfactory receptors, and so on. If sensing is essentially the end-point of such causal chains, and if time does not itself impinge on anything—there is no “temporal particle” that ricochets off rods and cones—then it looks as though there can be no genuine perception of time. At most, the organism may register temporal characteristics indirectly by detecting other, causally efficacious properties—motion, frequency, rhythm, etc.—but there is no dedicated sense of time itself.

The force of this objection rests on two assumptions:

a) A sensory system “for X” must have X itself as the proximal cause of its information-bearing states.

b) Time, considered as the “passage” or “flow” of events, does nothing; it merely parameterises the causal goings-on described by physics.

I shall argue that both assumptions are contestable. Once they are relinquished, the door opens to a principled account of how clocks—both biological and mechanical—encode temporal information without being acted on by some mysterious “time force”.

2. Two Kinds of Causal Relevance

Begin with a distinction, emphasised by philosophers of science such as Wesley Salmon and James Woodward, between productive causal influence and correlational or counterfactual dependence. Productive causation is a matter of actual energy-momentum transfer: the photon imparts energy to the retinal molecule. Counterfactual dependence, by contrast, concerns systematic co-variation: if the atmospheric pressure had been different, the mercury column in the thermometer would have risen to a different height. Both relations can underwrite information-carrying links.

Notice that in the barometer case, what directly pushes the needle is not “pressure” in the abstract but the concrete motion of gears and springs modulated by air pressing on an aneroid capsule. Nevertheless we are content to say that the barometer registers pressure because there is a reliable, law-governed mapping from atmospheric pressure values to pointer positions. Reliability, not ontological contact with a sui generis “pressure stuff”, is the decisive factor. The same moral will apply, mutatis mutandis, to temporal representation: what matters is a well-behaved mapping from elapsed time to internal states, not the existence of a dedicated time-specific causal channel.

3. Temperature and Other Non-Forces

The objection under scrutiny, if pressed hard, threatens to over-reach. Consider temperature. It is not a fundamental force but a statistical measure of molecular agitation. Yet thermoreceptors in the skin, the pit organs of vipers, and digital thermometers all count as sensory or measurement devices for temperature. What they exploit are causal interactions—infra-red radiation, heat conduction, molecular collisions—whose statistical features covary with temperature. That is enough to ground talk of temperature perception.

Time is more abstract still; it is the parameter with respect to which change is defined. But the moral remains: a system can carry information about a nominally “causally impotent” quantity if it hosts processes whose states correlate in law-governed ways with that quantity.

4. Clocks as Dynamical Regularisers

How, then, does a clock manage systematically to covary with elapsed time? The core idea is simple: harness a physical process whose dynamical evolution is (i) well understood, (ii) sufficiently stable, and (iii) readily coupled to a read-out mechanism. Here are three canonical recipes:

i) Decay Processes. Caesium-133 emits radiation at a frequency defined by 9 192 631 770 transitions per second. The oscillation period is fixed by quantum mechanics; counting cycles yields an excellent time base.

ii) Harmonic Oscillators. A pendulum’s period approximates 2π√(L/g). Variations in length and local gravity are manageable; within tolerances the period is invariant. The escapement counts swings; gear ratios convert counts into minutes and hours.

iii) Wave Propagation. In a quartz wristwatch, an electric field makes the crystal flex; the piezoelectric effect converts mechanical oscillation back into voltage. The resonant frequency (≈ 32 kHz) is strikingly temperature-stable. Divide-down circuits deliver one-second pulses.

What these mechanisms have in common is not influence by “time itself” but an internal, self-propagating evolution that a) would proceed even in isolation and b) obeys equations in which physical constants fix the rate when measured in SI seconds. Small disturbances affect amplitude, not phase; the oscillation therefore tracks objective time more or less faithfully. In short, one gets temporal information “for free” once a sufficiently regular dynamical process is enlisted.

5. Information Without Direct Causation

Claude Shannon’s classical measure of information turns on statistical dependence, not direct causal coupling. A variable S carries log 2(P) bits of information about another variable T when their joint probability distribution differs from the product of their marginals. The pointer of a clock at noon is perfectly correlated with the fact that twelve hours have elapsed since midnight; conditional entropy H(T|S) is near zero. That mutual information suffices for representational content, provided the correlation is non-accidental—i.e., sustained by underlying laws. So even if time is not a productive cause, it can be the “semantic” source of the content borne by the clock state.

6. Biological Case-Study: Circadian Entrainment

Turning to biology, circadian clocks illustrate the same strategy in an evolutionary key. A cyanobacterial cell contains a KaiABC protein complex that undergoes a phosphorylation cycle of ≈ 24 h. Absent external cues (“zeitgebers”), the cycle free-runs. Crucially, sunlight and metabolic signals modulate the rate, entraining it to the astronomical day. The system thus integrates causal input (light) with an intrinsic pacemaker. Selection favours mutants whose phase relationship to dawn optimises photosynthetic yield. The result is a molecular mechanism whose state predicts local solar time with biologically actionable precision, again without any “influx” of time itself.

Comparable stories apply in mammals: suprachiasmatic-nucleus neurons express clock genes whose feedback loops produce circadian oscillations; retinal ganglion cells carrying melanopsin entrain the phase to the light–dark cycle; downstream hormonal outputs (cortisol, melatonin) regulate sleep, metabolism, and so on. The general shape of the explanation never calls for a special temporal sense organ. Rather, the organism cultivates regular self-oscillations that are reliably indexed to objective temporal regularities in its environment.

7. Objection: But Isn’t the Correlation Trivial?

A critic might reply that any physical process unfolds over time, so every state trivially correlates with some temporal interval. What confers distinctively temporal content on a clock’s state, as opposed to a teacup’s cooling curve? One answer appeals to functional role. A state represents t o’clock when the system is embedded in a network of use that treats that state as informing time-sensitive decisions: opening the floodgates, triggering school bells, or initiating melatonin synthesis. The cooled-teacup state ordinarily plays no such causal-informational role; hence it does not count as a time representation. Representation is not in the bare covariation itself, but in the exploitation of that covariation by downstream consumers. (An analogy: tree rings carry information about age, but only become a representation of age when an archaeologist, dendrochronologist, or indeed the tree’s own growth program makes systematic use of the rings as temporal markers.)

8. The Semantics of Temporal Representation

Philosophers of mind often require three ingredients for representation: covariance, functional use, and historical etiology. Clocks satisfy all. The covariance is designed, engineered, or selected precisely to track elapsed time; the system is used by agents who rely on that tracking for scheduling behaviour; and there is a historical process that explains why those covariance relations exist (technological design or natural selection). Given these jointly sufficient conditions, talk of a “sense of time” is perfectly warranted even if time does nothing causal over and above structuring the equations of motion.

9. Replying to Strong Causal Demands

Still, the original worry may persist in a stronger guise: perhaps representation requires that the represented feature make an explanatory difference inside the mechanism, not merely outside. Even here one can respond. Although time itself is not a substance, the rate parameters in the system’s differential equations are dimensionally t-dependent. For a pendulum, d²θ/dt² = −(g/L) sin θ; for nuclear oscillations, dφ/dt = 2πν. Without the parameter t, those equations are meaningless; hence the system’s very dynamics “embed” time. In that minimal sense, time is woven into the causal description of the device. The demand that time be an extra force thus mistakes “being an indispensable variable in the causal story” for “being another interacting entity alongside masses and charges”.

10. Relational Theories of Time

A relationalist about time (Leibniz, Mach, Barbour) might go further, claiming that time just is the ordering relation among events. On that view, any device that maintains a quantitative relation to ordered events ipso facto tracks time. The supposed gap between temporal order and causal influence evaporates, because to stand in the right order-relations is already to instantiate temporal structure. The measurement of time is thus an exercise in mapping one ordering (pendulum swings) onto another (sunrise, heartbeat, work-shift). No “flowing medium” need press upon the clock; sensing time is sensing ordered change.

11. Phenomenology and Neural Clocks

What about human temporal experience—our sense of duration, simultaneity, and rhythm? Current neuroscience points to multiple overlapping timing mechanisms. The cerebellum seems crucial for millisecond-level motor timing, the basal ganglia for interval timing in the hundreds of milliseconds to seconds range, and prefrontal–parietal networks for prospective timing of intervals up to minutes. Again, the guiding principle is internal dynamical activity—ramping neural firing rates, population oscillations, and network state-space trajectories—that can be “read out” by other circuits as duration indicators. Pharmacological intervention (e.g., dopamine agonists) predictably speeds up or slows down perceived time, just as filing the tip of a pendulum shortens its period. Temporal phenomenology is thus grounded in brain processes that tick in a regulated way, not in a mysterious temporal input channel.

12. Objection from Accuracy

Another worry: if the environment never “pushes back” with a corrective temporal signal, why don’t internal clocks drift uncontrollably? The reply is that real clocks are seldom entirely open-loop. Photoperiod, temperature cycles, feeding schedules, and social cues entrain the circadian system; NTP servers and radio-timecodes discipline quartz oscillators; pulsars anchor the long-term stability of atomic clocks. So while the basic pacemaker supplies a free-running mapping from state count to elapsed time, calibration signals tune the mapping and curb drift. These external cues do exert ordinary causal influence; what they influence, however, is the phase and frequency of a process whose existence and basic regularity are intrinsic. Temporal accuracy is therefore secured without time acting as a force.

13. Summing Up the Rejoinder

In light of the foregoing, the causal-impotence objection rests on a mis-specification of what sensory information requires. A system need not be buffeted by the represented property; it need only instantiate states that map, with appropriate regularity and under suitable control, onto values of that property. Time representation is achieved by:

a) Employing processes whose dynamics are describable by time-indexed laws;  
b) Ensuring that those processes are sufficiently stable to licence a deterministic (or probabilistically tight) mapping from process state to elapsed time;  
c) Embedding the process within an agent or device that exploits the mapping for action, decision, or further computation.

Neither mechanical clocks nor biological chronometers invoke any occult temporal force. They simply couple internal change to objective temporal parameters in ways that preserve order and metric structure. Consequently, the absence of a “time particle” is no barrier to temporal representation, just as the absence of a “temperature fluid” is no barrier to thermal sensation.

14. Wider Implications

The lesson generalises. Many scientifically respectable measurement practices rely on lawful correlations rather than direct “contact”. DNA microarrays measure gene expression by fluorescence intensity; seismographs detect earthquakes via pen deflections; gravitational-wave detectors infer ripples in space-time from laser-interferometer fringes. In each instance, the measured quantity is represented by its imprint on some intermediary, not by an elemental confrontation between property and sensor. Clocks stand in illustrious company.

15. Conclusion

The notion that perception demands causal impact from the very property perceived conflates productive causation with information-bearing correlation. Time, in mainstream physics, is not an exotic substance capable of strikes and pressures; it is the formal parameter of dynamical law. Yet because many physical processes evolve with dependable temporal profiles, a suitably engineered or evolved system can treat those profiles as a yardstick. Pendulums, quartz crystals, atomic oscillations, and biochemical feedback loops all instantiate such profiles. Clocks, both artefactual and biological, ride on those intrinsic regularities, calibrate them when possible, and thereby generate reliable indicators of elapsed time. Thus there can indeed be a “sense” of time—one rooted not in a direct temporal force but in the elegant strategy of correlating internal dynamics with the temporal order of the world. The causal-impotence objection, once the subtle relationship between causation and information is appreciated, loses its bite.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
Time Without Temporal Causation:
                  How Clocks, Creatures and Cognitive Systems Can Sense Time

1. Introduction  

Among the perennial puzzles in philosophy of perception is whether creatures like us possess anything deserving the title “sense of time.”  A widely-cited objection rests on a causal premise: genuine sensory systems obtain information from the world only if a relevant environmental magnitude stands in a causal relation to the receptor mechanism.  Photons impinge on retinas, chemical volatiles bind to olfactory receptors, sound waves vibrate the cochlea.  But, the critic continues, time itself exerts no causal force.  Since nothing is pushed, pulled or otherwise modified by the mere passage of time, no receptor could be stimulated by time, and therefore there can be no temporal sense.  

The objection appears forceful.  Yet it sits uncomfortably beside two mundane facts: (i) organisms and artefacts routinely keep track of temporal intervals with impressive accuracy, and (ii) our ordinary psychological life is suffused with temporal phenomenology—duration, order, simultaneity, rhythm.  If the causal impotence thesis disqualifies every mechanism that tracks time, something has gone wrong in the underlying picture of information-gathering.  My aim is to diagnose the fault and to show how a mechanism—biological or artifactual—can legitimately “sense” time even though the passage of time is not a causal stimulus.

The strategy has four steps.  First, I will argue that the causal-influence criterion for sensory systems is too stringent once properly interpreted.  Second, I will distinguish several kinds of covariance that can underwrite information without requiring direct causal influence by the very property represented.  Third, I explain how ordinary clocks exploit lawful covariation between their internal physical processes and time; they thereby carry information about temporal intervals without time being a separate causal factor.  Finally, I draw out implications for biological time-keeping and human temporal perception, dissolving the original objection.

2. Re-examining the Causal Influence Criterion  

Why believe that sensory representation requires direct causal influence?  The core intuition comes from a naturalistically respectable thought: perception evolved and operates because environmental magnitudes make a causal difference to an organism’s activity.  In paradigmatic cases, there is event-to-event causation: the photon striking retinal photopigment alters its configuration, causing a neural cascade that eventually contributes to a behavioural response.  If the environmental magnitude did not causally trigger the receptor, the objection continues, the system could not reliably track that magnitude.  So the causal link is treated as a necessary condition on perception.

But attractiveness is not entailment.  To see the overreach, consider three familiar counter-examples:

a) Colour vision.  Objects do not emit “colour forces.”  What causes the retinal response are photons with particular frequency distributions; colour is a higher-level relational property of an object’s surface relative to an illuminant and observer.  The receptors are causally affected by light, not by colour per se, yet we credit colour vision as genuine perception.

b) Thermometry.  A mercury thermometer “registers” temperature even though temperature, as a mean kinetic energy, is not a causal agent.  What directly expands the mercury are collisions of molecules.  Nonetheless, we are satisfied that the column represents temperature.

c) Barometers.  Atmospheric pressure is not a discrete causal impact on the aneroid capsule; rather a disjunction of micro-level molecular collisions maintains the pressure difference.  Still, we treat the instrument as carrying information about pressure.

The pattern is that a sensor can represent a macro-level or abstract property even when what causally impinges on it is a micro-level realizer.  Colour, temperature and pressure differ from time in some respects, but they share the key feature: the represented property is not identical with the immediate causal interaction.  Therefore the causal-influence criterion must be formulated more carefully.  A realistic constraint is that a sensory system must stand in a reliable counter-factual dependency with the environmental property, normally mediated by physical processes governed by laws.  Direct causal impingement by the represented property itself is optional.

3. Information Without Direct Causation  

What does it take for one variable, X, to carry information about another, Y?  On a standard Shannon-based approach, X carries information about Y if values of X are probabilistically dependent on values of Y, relative to some background channel.  Causal connection is one route to dependence, but lawful covariation is enough.  This perspective has been elaborated in epistemology (Dretske), philosophy of science (Woodward) and evolutionary biology (Skyrms).  A mechanism can legitimately rely on informational covariances produced by common causes, by deterministic constraints, or by symmetries of the world.

Time embodies perhaps the most universal constraint: every physical process unfolds according to dynamical laws expressed with an explicit temporal parameter.  Consequently, the state of a lawful dynamical system at t2 is a deterministic (or probabilistic) function of its state at t1 and the elapsed time.  From the vantage point of information theory, a process evolving at a rate specified by such laws is an internal correlate of elapsed time.  To utilise that correlation, a clock must:

(i) Contain a component process whose evolution is monotonic and stable relative to some calibration.

(ii) Have an interface converting the internal state into a readable signal.

(iii) Be initiated (or periodically corrected) so that internal state S corresponds to an origin-point on the temporal scale.

Nothing in this set-up requires time itself to do causal work beyond furnishing the independent variable in the dynamical equations.  Let us examine two examples.

4. How Mechanical Clocks Track Time  

4.1 The Pendulum Clock  
A pendulum of length L, displaced by small angle θ, undergoes oscillations with period T ≈ 2π√(L/g).  Gravitational acceleration g and length L determine period, but “time” is not an extra force; rather, the oscillatory dynamics constitute a physical process whose regularity is described with temporal parameters.  If one counts the swings, one counts equal temporal intervals because each swing is law-governed to occupy approximately the same duration.  The escapement mechanism translates this periodic motion into discrete tooth-by-tooth advances of the gear-train and hence rotation of the hands.  Correlation with external time arises from the lawful constancy of the oscillation; no additional causal input from time is needed.

4.2 The Caesium-Beam Atomic Clock  
At the quantum scale, caesium-133 atoms undergo a hyperfine transition with frequency 9,192,631,770 Hz.  Interaction with an RF field and subsequent detection of state populations allows the device to steer an oscillator so that each cycle matches the atomic transition.  The result is a clock accurate to 10-15 seconds per day.  Again, time does not act upon the atoms; rather, the transition frequency, set by internal energy levels and fundamental constants, serves as an intrinsic, reproducible process.  Tallying 9,192,631,770 transitions defines one second by convention.  The clock’s output state is reliably conditional on elapsed time because a fixed number of cycles corresponds to a fixed interval.

4.3 What Does the Clock Represent?  
Both artefacts convert a predictable dynamical compulsion into an external read-out.  Because the mapping from internal state to elapsed time is stable under calibration, observers (or connected machines) can treat the display as a sign of how much time has passed.  The clock thus carries semantic information: the content of the clock-reading is about a temporal interval.  Importantly, the truth-conditions of that content depend on the relation between the internal process and external events, not on time’s causal action.

5. The Metaphysics of Temporal Representation  

The foregoing dissolves the objection by noting that temporal representation hinges on law-governed covariance, not causal influence from a sui generis temporal entity.  Let us articulate the metaphysical moral.

(a) Time as Parameter, Not Cause  
In canonical physics, time is a coordinate or parameter, not a field exerting forces (except in certain relativistic contexts where space-time curvature influences motion, but this still does not involve “time forcing clocks”).  Just as a spatial location does not push objects to inhabit it, the temporal location does not cause events to occur.  Yet spatial perception is unproblematic: retinal stimulation by photons lawfully depends on the observer’s relative spatial position to objects.  Analogously, temporal tracking exploits lawful dependence of a system’s internal state on its position along the world-line, determined by the system’s equations of motion.

(b) Content Ascription Through Calibration  
Representational content often flows from pragmatic calibration, not intrinsic causal structure.  A mercury thermometer only became a temperature indicator when we discovered, via calibration, the relationship between column height and temperature.  Likewise, a pendulum becomes a clock when its swings are counted against Earth’s rotation.  The constitutive rule “s correspond to one second” is a piece of social-technical normativity, not metaphysical causation.  Nevertheless, once the rule is fixed, the physical covariance makes the device a reliable carrier of truth-valued temporal information.

(c) Teleosemantics and Biological Time-Keeping  
Clark and Dretske style teleosemantic theories reinforce the point.  An organism’s internal circadian oscillator, driven by transcription-translation feedback loops, has the evolutionary function of indicating time-of-day to schedule behaviour (sleep, foraging, mating).  What gives the oscillator the content that, say, “it is morning” is that natural selection favored systems in which that internal state correlated with dawn and led to advantageous actions.  The moon does not causally push the gene network, but photic entrainment ensures reliable covariance.  The content is fixed by historical success, not by time’s causal potency.

6. Is There a Genuine “Sense” of Time?  

Armed with a more sophisticated conception of sensing, we can re-evaluate whether humans enjoy a temporal sense.

6.1 Endogenous Versus Exogenous Sensing  
Typical sensory modalities are exteroceptive: vision, audition, olfaction detect external objects or properties via external energy.  Time perception resembles interoception: it depends on monitoring endogenous processes (heartbeats, neural oscillations, cortical drift-diffusion).  But interoceptive senses like proprioception and nociception are bona fide senses though they monitor internal states.  So being endogenous is no barrier.

6.2 Multiple Timing Mechanisms  
Empirical neuroscience reveals a multiplex architecture: sub-second interval timing relies on cerebellar and basal ganglia circuits; circadian timing relies on the suprachiasmatic nucleus; long-range prospective timing involves hippocampal event segmentation.  Each subsystem relies on biochemical or electrophysiological processes that evolve in law-governed ways (decay of calcium traces, oscillations of neural populations).  Covariance with elapsed time allows the brain to use those signals as metronomes.  The brain, like the pendulum, piggybacks on physical regularities.  The sensory objection thus misfires; we possess mechanisms that behave functionally as temporal receptors, even if the “stimulus” is internal dynamics.

6.3 Phenomenology and Representation  
Temporal phenomenology—felt duration, temporal order—likely arises when the outputs of the internal timing mechanisms are integrated into higher-level representational models.  The global workspace uses these signals to tag perceptual representations with temporal metadata, yielding experience of succession.  That conscious temporality supervenes on internal covariance, not on external causal bombardment by time.  Again, causal impotence of time does no damage.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Correlation is cheap; anything that changes covaries with time.  So why not say every physical process represents time?  

Reply: Representation requires more than covariance; it needs (i) systematic exploitable mapping, (ii) decoupling capacity—i.e., it can misrepresent, and (iii) assignment of consumer-relevant content.  A lump of melting wax covaries with both ambient temperature and time, but nothing interprets that state as temporal information.  In a clock or organism, downstream consumers (user, behavioural controller) actively exploit the state to regulate action.  Teleosemantics or functional role distinguishes mere covariation from bona fide representation.

Objection 2: If temporal representation hinges on calibration to other time processes (e.g., Earth’s rotation), the system only measures time relative to those processes, not time itself.  

Reply: All measurement is relational.  Thermometers measure temperature relative to a chosen scale defined by fixed points (triple point of water).  Spatial position is measured relative to chosen coordinate frames.  That does not nullify representation; it is inherent to empirical quantities.  Temporal scales anchored to astronomical or atomic processes are as objective as any other physical measure.

Objection 3: General relativity treats time as locally varying; so a single oscillator cannot track “time” in curved space-time.  

Reply: Clocks track proper time along their world-lines.  Two clocks following different paths can disagree, but each accurately represents the invariant interval defined by the metric integral along its trajectory.  The absence of universal simultaneity does not negate the representational role; indeed, GPS satellites adjust for such relativistic drift precisely because their on-board clocks reliably represent local proper time.

8. Lessons for Philosophy of Mind  

The debate illuminates broader themes.

First, representation via internal lawful dynamics extends the palette of sensing beyond direct stimulation.  This matters for models of self-representation, interoception and predictive processing, where the brain uses endogenous generative dynamics as evidence.

Second, causal theories of perception must separate two questions: “What causes the sensory state?” and “What does the sensory state represent?”  The cause can be an underlying microphysical process; the content may be an abstract relational property supervening on that process because of systematic mappings and functional use.

Third, the case of temporal sense undermines the idea that phenomenology is necessarily tied to external causal inputs.  One can be locked in a dark, soundless chamber yet vividly experience the passage of minutes.  Conscious temporality is sustained by self-generated signals.

9. Conclusion  

The objection that no sense of time can exist because time is causally impotent misconstrues how information and representation operate in physical systems.  Clocks, from pendulums to caesium fountains, demonstrate that a mechanism can reliably register temporal intervals by exploiting intrinsic lawful processes whose evolution covaries with elapsed time.  The passage of time need not act as a force; the stability of the laws already embeds time into the very fabric of process.  Biological and cognitive timing mechanisms mirror this strategy, making the sense of time as genuine—though distinctive—as vision or hearing.  What matters is not direct causal bombardment by a temporal entity, but the existence of calibrated, law-governed covariations pragmatically appropriated for control and representation.  Once this is appreciated, the alleged causal impotence of time ceases to threaten the possibility of temporal perception.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
How do living creatures and artefacts such as clocks come to possess information about the passage of time when time itself—unlike light, sound-waves, or chemical molecules—exerts no causal pressure on them?  In what follows I offer a response in four stages.  First, I sharpen the objection by distinguishing two different senses in which something may be called “causally impotent” and show why only one of those senses is relevant.  Second, I introduce a general picture of how a physical state can carry information about something even when that very property is not among the efficient causes of the state.  Third, I apply that picture to mechanical, electronic and biological clocks, explaining how they come to track elapsed time.  Finally, I draw out the broader moral: a “sense of time” is interoceptive rather than exteroceptive.  It exploits endogenous dynamics that lawfully covary with elapsed time and can be calibrated to the external world without requiring a distinct “time particle” to impinge on the sensory surface.

1. Disentangling Two Notions of Causal Impotence

The complaint that “time is causally impotent” is ambiguous:

a) Parameter-Impotence:  In standard physical theories, time appears as a parameter indexing the evolution of more fundamental magnitudes.  On this view time is not itself an additional force or field, so there is nothing for a sense organ to latch onto.

b) Inefficacy-Impotence:  If a property makes no causal difference to anything—if whether that property obtains or not leaves the causal nexus untouched—then mechanisms cannot be sensitive to it.

The second notion would, if true of time, doom any representational relation, for informative states must be causally dependent on something.  But time fails to be a causal difference-maker only in the first, parameter sense.  The dynamical equations that govern every causal process contain an explicit t-variable, and without that variable the processes would not unfold.  An oscillator’s next position, the radioactive decay of Cs-133, or the gradual conformational change of a cyanobacterial protein all differ depending on the lapse of time.  So while time supplies no extra force, the amount of time that has passed conditions the causal evolution of every ordinary force.

The objection therefore needs refinement:  because there is no “time stimulus” distinct from the ordinary causal goings-on—no temporons striking a receptor—the brain (or a clock) cannot acquire information about elapsed time in the same way that rods and cones acquire information about wavelength.  That takes us to the second stage.

2. Information Without Direct Causal Impact of the Represented Property

Philosophers since Dretske have distinguished two relations:

• Information-carrying:  A state S carries the information that P when, given suitable background laws, the probability of P is 1 (or is significantly raised) conditional on S.

• Information-producing:  P is among the proximate causes of S.

The crucial point is that information-carrying does not require P to cause S.  What it requires is a nomic (law-governed) regularity between P and S.  That regularity may arise because P covaries with some intervening magnitude Q which does cause S, or because S forms part of the same lawful process as P.  Three familiar measuring devices illustrate the distinction.

Thermometer:  The length of a mercury column covaries with temperature, not because the abstract attribute “temperature” pushes the mercury upward, but because molecular kinetic energy affects the volume of mercury according to the ideal-gas law approximations.

Barometer:  The height of a mercury column covaries with atmospheric pressure; again, pressure is not a stuff but a composite parameter describing force per area.  The causal route runs through collisions of air molecules on a reservoir, not through “pressureness”.

Speedometer:  Needle position covaries with vehicle speed, even though “speed” is an abstract relational property.  What pushes the needle is magnetic flux from the rotating driveshaft.  But law-like connections ensure that so many rotations per minute mean so many kilometres per hour.

Let us draw two philosophical morals.

Moral 1 – Redundant Representation:  A representational system need not be impinged upon by the property it represents; it suffices that there be a reliable, counterfactual-supporting correlation produced by something.

Moral 2 – Calibration Principle:  The correlation must be stable enough that the user of the representation—driver, meteorologist or organism—can rely on it for practical or epistemic purposes.  Calibration achieves this by setting initial conditions (zeroing the gauge, synchronising the clock) and checking for drift.

With these morals in hand we can answer the time objection by showing how clocks implement precisely this structure, the only unusual feature being that the law underwriting the correlation is the general temporal unfolding of a system’s own dynamics.

3. How Clocks Track Time

3.1  Clocks Exploit Predictably Evolving Physical Processes

All clocks, biological or artefactual, rely on “reference processes” whose evolution is highly predictable: pendular swings, the decay of radionuclides, electronic oscillations of quartz crystals, hyperfine transitions of caesium atoms, or chemical feedback loops in a circadian pacemaker.  If the reference process has a known period T and if we can count n complete cycles, we can infer that nT seconds have elapsed.

In causal terms:

Initial State S0 at physical time t0 → (laws of dynamics L) → State Sn at physical time t0 + nT.

The mechanism that registers Sn (a set of gear teeth, a flip-flop register, a phosphorylation threshold) does not need an external shove from “time”.  It is enough that Sn would not have obtained had a different amount of time passed (counterfactual sensitivity).

Thus the representing state (e.g., gear position, neuronal firing rate) is causally produced by earlier states of the very same mechanism plus ordinary forces.  Because the evolution is law-dictated, the representing state lawfully covaries with elapsed time.  The system is, in Dretske’s sense, an information channel whose source variable is the duration since a calibration point.

3.2  Synchronisation:  Closing the Loop With the World

Unlike self-contained thought experiments, actual clocks must be periodically synchronised to an external event so that their count of cycles corresponds to what we call “objective” time.  The calibration may be human (setting your wristwatch), astronomical (calibrating an atomic clock to Earth’s rotation), or ecological (dusk resets a fruit-fly’s circadian oscillator).  The resetting input is a genuinely exogenous causal signal—sunlight, electrical command pulse, etc.—but crucially that signal need not directly convey “how much time has elapsed”; it merely re-aligns the phase of the reference process with a conventionally chosen marker (solar noon, lights-on, start-gun).

The existence of calibration inputs does two jobs.  First, it brings the endogenous oscillator into phase with events that matter for action and coordination.  Second, it provides an empirical test of whether the lawlike regularity still holds.  If the oscillator drifts, the mismatch will be detected at the next calibration, prompting compensation (advance or delay).  Hence the representational link is not blind faith: it is constantly corroborated and corrected through causal feedback, ensuring high mutual information.

3.3  Biological Pacemakers

If one worries that artefactual clocks win their informational status only because human engineers already understand physical time, biological pacemakers show that evolution can accomplish the same feat without foresight.  The molecular gears of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus form a feedback loop of phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of three proteins KaiA, KaiB and KaiC.  The kinetics of the loop robustly yields a ∼24 h period across a range of temperatures.  Natural selection can reward mutations that shorten or lengthen the period to match a planet’s day because an organism whose endogenous dawn prediction matches sunrise will turn on photosynthesis at the right moment.  No flagellum is shoved by “day-ness”; rather the temporal regularity of the loop is exploited as a proxy signal.

Neurophysiological interval timing in mammals provides a psychologically closer example.  Scalar Expectancy Theory (SET) models rats and pigeons as running an internal “pacemaker-accumulator”: dopaminergic neurons emit pulses, a switch closes at the onset of the to-be-timed event, a counter integrates pulses until the event ends.  The accumulation rate can be pharmacologically modulated (amphetamine speeds the pacemaker, haloperidol slows it), producing predictable distortions of time estimates.  Again, the information about interval duration is present because of lawful, counterfactually robust dependence of pulse counts on real elapsed time, not because a temporal entity buffets receptors.

3.4  Clocks and the Metaphysics of Time

One might object that, by appealing to the laws that govern the oscillator’s change, we smuggle time back in through the laws themselves and thus fail to answer the original challenge.  The worry mistakes an explanatory level.  The clock explanation is not metaphysically prior to the concept of time; it is epistemically prior for the creature that wields the clock.  To know what time it is an agent needs a state that covaries with the temporal parameter, not a theory of what time fundamentally is.  As Bas van Fraassen puts it, representation is pragmatic fidelity to patterns, not metaphysical duplication.

4. The Sense of Time as Interoception

The original objection tacitly assumes that a genuine sensory modality must be exteroceptive, driven by external stimulants impinging on a peripheral transducer.  But the bodily senses already include paradigmatic interoceptive channels: proprioception (muscle spindle stretch), vestibular balance (fluid inertia), hunger, thirst, dyspnoea, and nociception.  They turn inward, exploiting internal bodily signals to construct representations of posture, energy deficit, tissue damage, and toxin presence.  Temporal perception falls squarely within this family.

4.1  Markers of Key Time Scales

• Milliseconds:  The auditory system uses phase locking of cochlear neurons up to ~4 kHz to discriminate pitch, allowing localisation by inter-aural time difference as fine as 10 μs.  Those neurons are not hit by “micro-time” beams; their volley code simply is the regular unfolding of their refractory periods.

• Seconds:  Gap detection, temporal order judgements, and rhythm production rely on cortico-striatal loops whose oscillatory activity (beta and gamma bursts) forms cyclical reference patterns.  Disruption of the basal ganglia in Parkinson’s disease yields characteristic impairments in tapping to a beat precisely because dopamine modifies the rate of the internal pacemaker.

• Hours to Days:  The suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus houses a ∼24 h biochemical oscillator affected but not driven by light.  Even in constant darkness the cycle persists, “free-running” at 24.2 h and entraining when dawn resets it.

Different scales recruit different mechanistic clocks, but all share the basic information-link:  state-of-oscillator-as-of-now ↔ elapsed duration-since-reference-point.

4.2  Phenomenology Without Exogenous Stimulation

Human introspection paints time as always present, unlike the ephemeral presence of smells or colours.  On the presented view this constancy is exactly what one would expect: because the pacemakers are endogenous, they produce representational signals whether or not the outside world is changing.  Hence in total darkness or sensory deprivation tanks subjects still experience something like the flow of time, albeit often distorted when usual calibration cues vanish.  The phenomenology is the consciousness-level correlate of an interoceptive signal.

5. Addressing Four Residual Objections

Objection 1:  “Correlation isn’t enough; genuine representation demands that the represented property explain the correlation.”

Reply:  For clocks, the explanation of the correlation does invoke the represented property, but in the form “if ∆t had been different, pendulum phase would have been different.”  That is a counterfactual dependency sufficient for explanatory relevance.  No extra causal arrow from “time” to pendulum is needed, just the law’s time-indexed form.

Objection 2:  “Endogenous clocks are like rulers—they measure length but do not sense it.”

Reply:  A ruler provides information only when an agent deliberately aligns it with an object; nothing in its internal states signals length spontaneously.  An oscillator, by contrast, continuously produces updateable markers (ticks).  The organism does not need a distinct act to obtain a temporal estimate; pulses accumulate automatically and can be read out by downstream neural circuits that initiate action at threshold.  That is enough like spontaneous firing of photoreceptors to count as a sensory channel.

Objection 3:  “Your story generalises to any law-governed variable: blood glucose covaries with time since breakfast, so why not call glucose a clock?”

Reply:  Information utility and calibration frequency impose constraints.  A variable is a clock only if (i) its dynamics are sufficiently monotonic and predictable over the time scale of interest, and (ii) the system exploiting it has access to mechanisms for mapping that variable to action-relevant intervals.  Blood glucose fails on (i) because its evolution depends on contingent metabolic events; by contrast, pendulum length and gravity yield a period independent of amplitude (to first order).  So the account avoids trivialising representation.

Objection 4:  “Even if a creature can track duration, it still lacks a sense of temporal order or direction (past vs future).”

Reply:  Order can be coded by tagging events with the accumulated pulse count at time of encoding and storing those tags in memory; retrieval then delivers correct temporal precedence.  Direction is built into the irreversible dissipation of the pacemaker’s microstates (thermodynamic arrow).  Thus relative order and directionality piggyback on duration representation plus one-way causal storage.

6. Conclusion

The charge that the absence of a distinct causal “time stimulus” rules out a sense of time conflates two ideas: that representing demands impingement, and that causal efficacy must come only from the represented property.  Measure-instruments and living systems refute both.  They gain information whenever there exists (1) a lawful, counterfactually robust dependence between their internal states and some external condition, and (2) a calibration mechanism that keeps that dependence accurate enough for use.  Clocks satisfy these criteria through internal reference processes whose progression is itself causally sensitive to the amount of time elapsed—sensitive not because time is a force but because the laws governing any physical process are time-indexed.  Biological temporal perception is therefore an interoceptive capacity that exploits regular endogenous dynamics and need not postulate a sui generis “chronoreceptor”.  In short, one can have perception of time without time knocking on the door, because every physical process is already keeping step to time’s silent beat.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
1. Introduction: the “causal-impotence” objection  
A familiar story in philosophy of perception begins with a simple maxim: to be sensed, a property must act on the sense organ. Light excites photoreceptors, airborne chemicals stimulate olfactory neurons, variations in air pressure jog mechanoreceptors. Because “time itself” seemingly exerts no direct push or pull on a transducer, some conclude that there can be no strictly sensory system for time. The conclusion looks bolstered by a picture of clocks: a bell-tower clock keeps track of the hours, yet nothing like a “temporal particle” ever strikes its gears. How, then, could either an artefactual clock or a biological nervous system bear information about elapsed time?  

Below I argue that the objection relies on an overly restrictive conception of sensory information and a mistaken picture of what is required for a mechanism to represent or measure a dimension. After clarifying what it means to say that a system carries information, I show how a clock can lawfully covary with temporal intervals without requiring “causal influence from time.” The key ideas are (i) correlation rather than direct stimulation, (ii) calibration and error-detectability, and (iii) internal generative dynamics that are themselves temporally regimented. Once those ideas are in place, nothing bars us from speaking of genuine chronoreception in biological systems.  

2. Reassessing the “contact” requirement  
A first quick reply notes that many paradigmatic measuring devices do not maintain contact with a distinctive substance corresponding to the measured magnitude. Thermometers, for instance, measure temperature, yet there is no “temperature fluid” that flows into the bulb. What matters is that the mercury column’s length L is nomically related to mean molecular kinetic energy ⟨E⟩: given the relevant boundary conditions, L = k · ⟨E⟩. Likewise, a barometer tracks atmospheric pressure, but pressure never bombards the barometer by itself; instead, the weight of air molecules transmits a force to the column of mercury. What the measuring device exploits is a reliable law-bound relation, not a unique causal vector labelled ‘pressure’ or ‘temperature’.  

Time is similar. Time is a dimension along which every physical process unfolds, and temporal intervals can be encoded in other, more directly causal processes—oscillations, decays, rotations, phase changes. The causal stage is already crowded with ordinary physical events; we need not treat ‘time’ as another entity that must somehow join the causal chorus.  

3. Information without external stimulation  
To make that point rigorous, it helps to separate two questions:  

   a. What is the causal path that produces the representational state inside the system?  
   b. What property of the environment does that state carry information about?  

According to mainstream causal-informational theories (Dretske 1981; Fodor 1990) and to Shannon’s quantification of information, a state S carries information that P just in case there is a reliable, law-grounded correlation between S and P in the relevant circumstances. Crucially, the proposition P need not itself describe the feature that causally generated S; it only has to be nomically linked to that generating feature. Dretske’s favorite example is a gauge on a tanker truck. The needle’s movement is brought about by changes in electrical resistance, but what the needle tells the driver is how much gasoline is left, because in the calibrated context resistance covaries with volume.  

In exactly this sense, a clock’s internal state carries information about elapsed time because the phase of its oscillator covaries with the temporal metric according to a known law: t = n · τ where τ is the oscillator’s period and n the number of completed cycles. There is still causation—friction, elasticity, inertial forces—but the causation links material features of the oscillator at distinct moments. Time is the parameter that structures the lawful relation; it need not be an additional causal agent.  

4. The pendulum clock as a case study  
Consider Huygens’ pendulum clock. Given local gravity g and rod length l, small-angle oscillations obey T ≈ 2π√(l/g). Once the pendulum is set swinging, nothing external need interact with it for the next several hours. Yet each swing marks another T seconds. An observer watching the escapement wheel can, by counting swings, recover the elapsed time since the pendulum was released. The source of the representation is an internal causal process (gravity acting on the bob, inertia returning it), but what is represented is the temporal interval.  

The analogy is clearer when we recall that a mercury thermometer can be read without contact once put into an insulated container: after reaching equilibrium, the mercury level remains fixed and tells us the temperature that obtained at the equilibration moment. We do not complain that ‘temperature did nothing’ to shift the column after that moment. By parity of reasoning, we should not demand that ‘time do something’ at each tick of a clock.  

5. Clocks, covariance, and nomic dependence  
Why should covariance be sufficient for representation? One answer invokes the notion of nomic dependence: state S represents property P when (i) S is produced by a process lawfully sensitive to P, and (ii) the consumer of S is adapted (by design or by evolution) to exploit the correlation so as to perform some function—guiding behavior, updating beliefs, coordinating action. A reading lamp’s switch does not “represent” anything because there is no consumer that treats the switch position as a source of information; a marine chronometer, by contrast, is designed so that the pointer registers degrees of longitude when read by a navigator, and every stage of its manufacture is constrained by the demand for accurate timekeeping.  

Notice: the crucial link tying the internal state to the environmental magnitude is the lawlike mapping, not a direct, continuous causal bombardment by the magnitude. In technical terms, the internal variable is an index of a parameter in the system’s own equation of motion; time is that parameter.  

6. Biological chronoreception  
The brain appears to use the very same strategy. Neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) cycle with an approximately 24-hour rhythm owing to transcription-translation feedback loops. Again, what drives the intracellular concentrations of Bmal1 or Per proteins are chemical reactions influenced by the current state of the cell, not a mysterious causal influx of ‘circadian time’. Still, the phase of the oscillation carries information about the time of day, and downstream areas exploit that information to modulate hormone secretion, body temperature, and sleep–wake cycles.  

At shorter timescales, cerebellar Purkinje cells, striatal medium spiny neurons, and cortical ramping neurons exhibit dynamics that correlate with intervals from tens of milliseconds to several seconds. Psychophysical data show that humans can detect deviations in regularly spaced auditory clicks as small as 10 ms, and functional imaging links that capacity to oscillatory subcortical circuits. No exotic temporal force is needed; neurodynamics themselves unfold at particular rates, and the brain has learned to treat those rates as temporal counters.  

7. Objection: mere correlation is not sensation  
One may object that correlation tout court is too cheap; after all, my beard length covaries with the number of days since I last shaved, yet my beard is not a sensory organ. Two additional conditions fend off the charge of cheapness.  

First, the correlation must be highly reliable and exploitable. A quartz clock’s resonance frequency at 32,768 Hz is extraordinarily stable across contexts; that stability explains why downstream logic gates can interpret each 215th oscillation as exactly one second. Beards, by contrast, grow at different rates depending on temperature, hormones, and age, and we have no evolved or designed system that “reads” follicle length to plan temporally sensitive action.  

Second, calibration and error-detectability must be possible. Clocks drift; living systems adapt; both must be correctable. A pendulum clock includes a length-adjustment screw, a watch includes a regulator lever, and the SCN includes light-sensitive retinal inputs permitting phase reset. Where there is a norm of correctness, there is representation: the system can mis-represent when uncalibrated. Beards provide no such standard.  

8. Does the account trivialize causation?  
Another worry is that the reply re-describes every ordinary causal process in temporal terms, making time tracking trivial. But note: not every causal process is usable as a clock. An ideal chronometric process must satisfy at least three constraints: (i) monotonicity—state changes must order time without reversals; (ii) homogeneity—units must be of equal duration; and (iii) decouplability—rate must be insensitive to most environmental perturbations. Radioactive decay, for instance, is monotonic but not well-suited for a wristwatch because the variance in decay intervals is large at short timescales. Boiling water bubbles appear periodic but are wildly affected by contaminants and pressure. Only special processes such as harmonic oscillations in crystalline lattices meet all three constraints in a broad range of contexts. So the present proposal in no way collapses the distinction between generic causation and chronometric utility.  

9. Time, structure, and the metaphysics of influence  
The causal-impotence worry may also stem from a metaphysical view on which time is an empty container, a Newtonian receptacle in which events are placed. If that were correct, one might think a genuine sense of time would require awareness of the container as such. But many philosophers now endorse a relational or structural conception: temporal facts supervene on patterns of events and the laws connecting them. On a relational picture, to track time is precisely to track those patterns. A mechanism does so by being one such pattern whose internal evolution mirrors the metric relations among events. The “absence of temporal influence” is therefore not a defect; it is a mark that time is not an entity alongside causal processes but rather a structural aspect of their unfolding.  

10. “Internal” versus “external” senses  
Even granting the dialectical point, one might, for taxonomic reasons, resist calling the relevant mechanisms “sensory.” Yet there are familiar proprioceptive senses—vestibular balance, kinesthetic feedback, hunger, nociception—that do not rely on environmental impingement from outside the skin. They are nonetheless bona fide senses because (i) they employ specialized receptors, (ii) their signals travel dedicated neural pathways, and (iii) they subserve perception-like functions such as guiding action and informing belief. Temporal estimation circuitry satisfies the same tripartite test.  

11. Putting the pieces together: a functional definition of a time sense  
We can therefore sketch a functional account of chronoreception:  

   A system S implements a sense of time relative to a temporal range R just in case  
   1. S contains an internal process P whose state space is homomorphic to R (e.g., phase angles of an oscillator to seconds within a minute).  
   2. The evolution of P is governed by laws that make the mapping between state and elapsed time sufficiently stable under background conditions.  
   3. Downstream consumer systems C use the state of P, under a norm of accuracy, to guide behavior or inference about timing.  
   4. There exists a calibration procedure whereby mismatches between P’s predicted and actual relations to external events can be detected and corrected.  

This functional profile captures artefacts (clocks and chronometers) and biological systems (circadian pacemakers, cerebellar timing circuits). The profile does not require “time to cause P”; it only requires ordinary causal chains within P and between P and C, plus the nomic regularity that makes those chains clock-like.  

12. Conclusion  
The objection that a sense of time is impossible because time cannot causally influence a receptor trades on two conflations: (a) that representation requires direct stimulation by the represented property, and (b) that time, if not a causal substance, cannot ground reliable correlations. Both conflations are false. Information theory, the practice of instrumentation science, and the empirical study of biological timing all show how a magnitude can be represented whenever there is (i) an internal variable evolving in accord with a law in which the magnitude figures as a parameter, and (ii) a user that exploits the variable under a norm of correctness.  

Clocks—from quartz wristwatches to the brain’s suprachiasmatic nucleus—carry temporal information precisely because the lawful evolution of their internal states mirrors the metric structure of temporal intervals. The causal story is entirely ordinary: elastic restoring forces, electric fields, biochemical reactions. Time does not sit outside these processes pushing them along; rather, it is the structural dimension they jointly instantiate. Recognizing this dissolves the causal-impotence worry and opens theoretical space to treat chronoreception as a genuine sensory modality—one whose receptors are oscillators, whose transduction is phase progress, and whose perceptual deliverance is our experience of duration, succession, and rhythm.

question: A common objection to the existence of a genuine sensory system for time holds that sensory systems gather information about the world through causal influence from the relevant environmental features on those systems (e.g., photons impacting the retina for vision). Since time is often considered causally impotent—it cannot exert causal force on any mechanism—there cannot be a sense of time. How might one respond to this objection and explain how a clock mechanism could carry information about time without time itself causally influencing the mechanism?
answer:
1. Introduction  

Humans and many other organisms manifest an impressive ability to keep track of time.  We can tap a rhythm, anticipate the moment a traffic light will turn green, or organise multi-year projects whose stages must be sequenced with temporal precision.  Neuroscientists have identified circuits—basal ganglia oscillators, cerebellar timing micro-complexes, cortical ramping neurons—that seem dedicated to these competences, and psychologists measure timing acuity with the same experimental care they lavish on vision or audition.  Yet a long-standing philosophical objection maintains that there cannot literally be a “sense” of time.  Sensory systems, the objection says, work by being causally affected by the very features they detect: light perturbs photoreceptor cells, pressure deforms mechanoreceptors, airborne molecules bind to olfactory cilia.  Time, however, is causally inert.  If time is a dimension along which change occurs, rather than a force or field, it cannot strike, push, or in any other way causally impinge on a receptor.  So, although we talk loosely about a time sense, strictly speaking no such sense is possible.

That argument looks powerful, but it rests on a too-narrow picture of how biological and artefactual information-gathering devices work.  In what follows I develop a reply in four stages.  First, I diagnose the hidden assumption that the detected property must itself be the proximate physical cause of the receptor’s state.  Second, I show—using familiar scientific instruments as examples—that many genuine measuring devices violate that assumption.  Third, I explain how clocks, biological or mechanical, can lawfully acquire information about time without time exerting any distinctive causal influence.  Finally, I address residual worries about representation and evolutionary justification, closing with a broader moral about the nature of sensory systems and the metaphysics of time.



2. The Objection Laid Bare  

Let us begin by disaggregating the objection.  It has three premises:

1. Sensory systems (and measuring instruments generally) require a causal chain that runs from the distal property P to the state of the receptor R.

2. Time is not the kind of entity that can stand in causal relations; it is not a force, field, particle stream, or energetic flux.

3. Therefore no receptor can stand in an information-carrying causal nexus with time.  Hence no genuine temporal sense.

The inferential move from (1) and (2) to (3) depends on equating “property P” with “that which exerts the causally operative influence.”  The thermometer receives information about temperature because temperature, construed as mean kinetic energy of molecules, causes the mercury column to expand; vision works because photons cause conformational change in retinal opsins, and so on.  If every sensory modality exhibits that template, then failure of time to play the causal role would indeed preclude a time sense.

But is that template universal?  We can expose its limitations by distinguishing two causal roles: (i) the cause of a signal S’s being in some state s, and (ii) the property about which S carries information.  These roles sometimes coincide, but often they do not.  Once we pry them apart, premise (1) is revealed as an over-generalisation.



3. Causation, Correlation, and Representation  

Consider three devices whose credentials as genuine measuring instruments are uncontroversial.

a) The Mercury Thermometer.  Strictly speaking, what directly pushes the mercury up the glass tube is not the abstract property temperature but the mechanical collisions of faster-moving air molecules against the bulb.  If those collisions embodied some different micro-physical correlate—say, pressure generated by a pump—while preserving the same functional relation between column height and the distal variable, the thermometer would still carry accurate temperature information.  The proximate cause of the reading is distinct from the property reported.

b) The Bar Code Scanner.  A laser beam reflects off alternating black and white bars; a photodiode picks up the reflected intensity profile.  The scanner represents product identity, yet what causally affects the sensor is merely the reflectance contrast within a tiny patch of surface—a correlate of the integer that is the Universal Product Code.  Here, too, representation outstrips immediate causal impact.

c) The Gyroscope.  Spinning rotors maintain orientation in virtue of angular momentum conservation, not because “absolute space” presses against the instrument.  If we adopt a relational view à la Mach or Einstein, there is nothing ontologically robust called space that does causal work; nevertheless gyroscopes reliably indicate orientation because their internal dynamics instantiate lawful correlations with that orientation.

From these examples we can extract a moral: what makes a physical state a representation of some property P is not that P itself is the direct cause of that state, but that, across the range of circumstances in which the system is designed or has evolved to operate, the state is a dependable correlate of P, exploitable by downstream consumers (other circuits, engineers, organisms).  In information-theoretic vocabulary, mutual information suffices; direct causal contact with P is optional.



4. Clocks as Temporal Transducers  

Let us now turn to clock mechanisms, the paradigmatic time-keeping devices.  A clock has two components:

i) A dynamical process that repeats, oscillates, or accumulates change at a stable rate.

ii) A counter, dial, or comparator that maps the current phase or accumulated change of that process onto a time reading or a motor command.

In a pendulum clock, gravity and length fix the oscillation period via the equation T = 2π√(L/g).  In a quartz watch, the lattice structure of the crystal and the piezoelectric effect generate a 32,768 Hz resonance.  In an atomic clock, the hyperfine transition frequency of caesium-133—exactly 9,192,631,770 Hz by definition—provides the standard.  None of these devices is driven by “flows” of time.  Rather, each exploits a lawful regularity: given certain boundary conditions, the physical system evolves through its state-space at a rate that is (nearly) invariant when expressed in conventional time units.  The clock extracts temporal information by counting iterations of that regular cycle.

Because the regularity is lawful, a reliable correlation holds between the number of cycles completed and the objective temporal duration elapsed, whether or not time does any causal work.  The device’s capacity to represent time thus piggybacks on second-order facts about laws, not first-order causal pushes from time.  The same point scales down to the nervous system.  Pacemaker-accumulator models, cortical oscillatory interference models, and cerebellar state-dependent networks all posit some quasi-regular neural dynamics.  When the organism calibrates those dynamics—through development, learning, or evolutionary design—so that n cycles ≈ one second, the resulting internal variable can be read by other neural subsystems as “current duration.”  Time information is carried internally, without a dedicated external stimulus.

This account matches empirical findings.  Short-term timing (millisecond to seconds range) persists in darkness, in silence, under immobilisation, even under pharmacological blockade of exteroceptive input.  What disrupts timing most dramatically are manipulations that disturb the intrinsic pacemakers—dopaminergic drugs, cerebellar lesions, hypothermia.  That profile looks exactly like what our lawful-regularity model predicts.



5. Does Information without Causal Action Suffice?  

A sceptic might grant that clocks exhibit correlations with elapsed time, yet still worry that such correlations are “accidental” or ungrounded if time itself is not in the causal story.  But the correlations are far from accidental.  They follow from the dynamical laws of the systems in question.  For a simple harmonic oscillator, the period’s independence from amplitude (for small angles) mathematically entails a linear mapping between cycle count and Newtonian time parameter t.  In the quartz crystal, the dispersion relation for acoustic phonons depends on lattice constants that are exceedingly stable under ordinary environmental variations.  The lawful regularity provides precisely the modal robustness we expect genuine information to exhibit: had slightly different micro-states arisen, the mapping would still have held; under various counterfactual perturbations, unless those perturbations break the law-grounding conditions, the reading would remain faithful.

Philosophers of science sometimes call this phenomenon indirect measurement.  We measure λ (wavelength) of light in a Michelson interferometer, not because λ “hits” the detector, but because stationary fringe patterns arise lawfully from path-length differences.  Similarly, a clock measures time indirectly via the lawful evolution of its internal variable.

Admittedly, the metaphysical status of laws is itself contested.  But even on the Humean mosaic, regularities are patterns in the temporal ordering of local events, and the clock simply embeds a micro-pattern that mirrors a macro-pattern.  No breach in causal empiricism appears.



6. What about Sense Organs?  

Still, one might insist, thermometers and clocks are instruments, not sense organs.  Organisms evolved eyes and ears because they needed information about uninternalisable external magnitudes; clocks are detachable artefacts.  Yet the line between organ and instrument is blurry.  Owls possess magnetite crystals that respond to Earth’s magnetic field; sharks have ampullae of Lorenzini sensitive to electric fields.  These receptors piggyback on their own regularities: a magnetic field is not a force that targets a biological signal transduction pathway, yet magnetoreception remains bona fide.  The brain’s pacemaker networks, vestibular hair cells, and proprioceptive spindles are all endogenously active, requiring only generic nutrients and thermodynamic conditions to cycle.  Their outputs are integrated with exteroceptive input and commandeered for prediction, motor coordination, and learning.  The theoretical roles they play—information provision, error correction, action guidance—are indistinguishable from the roles of vision and audition.

Moreover, the very evolutionary utility of timing undermines the causal objection.  Selection cannot reward a trait unless reliable correlations exist between the trait’s output and fitness-relevant states of the world.  If internal oscillators lacked such correlations, timing behaviours would not improve survival.  Their persistence in diverse lineages is therefore powerful indirect evidence that the correlations are lawful and robust enough to fuel adaptation.



7. Are We Still “Tracking” Time Itself?  

A deeper objection appeals to the metaphysics of what is tracked.  Perhaps clocks and brains merely track the motion of their own parts—oscillations, decay processes—and we read temporal content into those motions.  The representational status is then a projection, not an objective transactional fact.  To answer this we need a theory of representation generous enough to allow that a state can represent some distal magnitude M even if M is not registered through direct force transmission, provided that (i) the system was produced or sustained because its states covary with M, and (ii) the system exploits that covariation for control or inference.

Such teleosemantic or use-based accounts are already standard in the philosophy of perception.  A frog’s “bug detector” retinal circuit is sensitive to small moving dark dots; it will indiscriminately snap at a simulating dot on a screen.  The circuit qualifies as representing bugs because ancestral frogs that used the correlation between dot-motion and edible insects had higher fitness.  Likewise, timing circuits have been selected (or, in the human case, culturally tuned) because their outputs covary with objective duration in ways that facilitate navigation, foraging, communication, and social coordination.  The representational link is indirect but no less real.

One might press still harder: what fixes the metric of time that clocks are supposed to match?  After all, the second is defined by a particular atomic transition.  Does that not render clock correlations tautological?  Here the response is pluralist.  Any monotonically increasing physical process could, in principle, serve as a surrogate time parameter.  What matters is relational consistency: whichever process we pick, the internal states of clocks and organisms remain systematically aligned with the order and duration structure that defines physical laws (e.g., Newtonian or relativistic dynamics).  If our planet’s inhabitants calibrated everything to a different oscillator, dynamical equations would adjust accordingly; experiential and behavioural coordination would survive.  So the clock’s information is about objective temporal structure in the same sense that a ruler’s markings are about spatial length, despite length being definable via the speed of light times a temporal interval.



8. Lessons from Relativity  

Special relativity might seem to complicate the picture: observers in different inertial frames disagree about simultaneity and duration.  Does that undermine the idea of a single temporal magnitude clocks represent?  Not really.  Each clock embodies proper time along its worldline, an invariant in relativistic physics.  The causal inertness objection, if sound, would preclude any clock from measuring proper time, yet relativistic experiments routinely verify that atomic clocks on high-speed aircraft or in gravitational wells display time dilation exactly as predicted.  The fact that no mysterious “time force” acts differently on fast-moving versus slow-moving clocks strengthens our thesis: lawful internal dynamics suffice.



9. Objection from Illusion and Distortion  

Psychophysical data reveal systematic timing illusions.  A burst of adrenaline shortens perceived intervals; saccadic eye movements compress temporal sequence; attention modulates the apparent order of tones.  Do these distortions imply that the internal variable is merely an heuristic fiction?  No.  Visual illusions coexist with a robust sense of space, and auditory illusions with a robust sense of pitch.  Distortion shows only that the internal variable is modifiable by context and resource constraints.  In fact, illusion patterns teach us something important: timing mechanisms are integrated with other sensory modalities and decision systems, not encapsulated.  If timing were just a memory of oscillations with no external significance, such cross-modal interactions would be puzzling.  Their ubiquity confirms that temporal information really is being used to interpret and predict the environment.



10. Putting the Pieces Together  

We can now articulate a general schema for how a system S can sense a property P even if P is not itself causally operative.

1. There exists some physical process X internal to S whose state variable x(t) evolves according to a law L.

2. Across normal operating conditions, L guarantees a stable, monotonic mapping f such that x(t) = f(t) (perhaps up to minimal noise).

3. S contains further mechanisms that sample x and, via learned or evolved decoding rules, deploy its current value to regulate behaviour Y.

4. Because of evolutionary contingency or deliberate design, success of Y depends on accurate alignment of x with t; misalignment is penalised.

The combination of (2) and (4) makes x an indicator of t: perturbations in t would, via L, covary with x, and downstream consumers exploit that covariation.  No additional causal arrow from t to S is required.

Applied to photoreception, the schema collapses into the familiar causal story because light’s impact is the most efficient way to obtain a law-grounded mapping from luminance to receptor potential.  Applied to timing, the schema manifests as internal oscillators and counters.  The phenomenological sense of duration that accompanies their operation is a high-level readout of this circuitry, just as colour qualia are a readout of photoreceptor balance.



11. Objections Revisited  

• “Correlation without causation is coincidence.”  Reply: lawful reliability is the opposite of coincidence; it supports counterfactuals and practical exploitation.

• “Information must flow from outside in.”  Reply: vestibular, proprioceptive, and interoceptive senses already undermine that dictum; they chiefly monitor organism-generated dynamics.

• “If time does not cause anything, the representation is empty.”  Reply: emptiness would follow only if causal action were the sole ground of representational content; but use-based, teleosemantic, and structuralist accounts furnish alternative grounds.



12. Conclusion
